Problem is, your teeth have almost been knocked out, so the manliness of the jaw is somewhat lackluster… Being a fatalist is way more fun when you've got several options available, wouldn't you agree?
I agree.
I'm fed up with you. Get lost.
Where do I get them?

You can mug the passers-by or barter with them. Children will gladly trade most valuable things in exchange for what others consider junk. Moreover, our drunkards usually have bandages on them; when you're a drunk, it makes sense to always be prepared for a fight. When they're hungover, however, they'd sell their own sister for a bottle of water. Water is scarce here.
I'm an outlaw?
Where do I get water?
There's often some left in the water-barrels; enough to fill an empty bottle if you have one.
Okay. Go on.
What's hurt my reputation so much?
An unfortuante misunderstanding. I wouldn't be so rash as to call it slander... but it looks very much like it.
Tell me about it.
My friend will do it better, that's his part. My job is explaining to you how to keep your body in a working condition.
All right, go on.
I know basic anatomy all right. Spare me your advice.
I was happy at first that it wasn't bubonic plague... Now I realize I would have rather preferred it!
You're right, there is little to be happy about.
So you've begun studying the disease, I gather?

I have. And you—actually, you can help me with that. Tell me, is it true there are special people in the local community—the only ones who have the, er, moral right to pierce others—even the dead—with tools?
Will this sample do?
Would you like me to get you some?
Damn! Are you sure this tissue belongs to a person who died of the Sand Plague?
I am.
I've got something for you, oynon. You were looking for dead tissue, if I recall correctly?
Yes! I need it so bloody much!
I hope this will be of use to you.
Could you do me a favour, oynon? Bad Grief wants to see you.
Who the hell is that?
Thank you, oynon.
Has it been hard on you lately?
Why the sad look?
I'm okay. Some people have it harder.
I have been feeling dizzy again, I've had a "pit". I felt that Notkin was in danger. Have the two of you met yet? He lives at the Warehouses. Their Castle is there.
Sure, I'll check.
I don't think so. Perhaps if I have time to spare.
I'll go and see what's up with your friend.
Thank you! Help him please... What if it's something dangerous? And the Bachelor has forbidden us to leave our homes. He said we were quarantined.
I'll come back with the news.
I'm not exactly sure what happened. Your dear Notkin was attacked by some bandits.
Ah! And…?
I can't refuse a gift from you.
Your friend is out of danger.
What was threatening him?
I don't care, I could use anything.
So? Why the hell is your nose pokin' around here?
Dunno… perhaps to teach you some manners, fattie?
Oi, here comes the leather bag! Bad Grief's dropped a note tha' you're one of us now, is that right?
Grief's orders: Leave the boys alone. Get lost.
My lot are all astir... The pricks are repining against me. Gotta see us split any day now.
Was the order to gut the boys yours?
That's fine. It's not like you're splitting in half yourself, right?

Okay. I've got a lil' favour to ask of you then. That Bachelor outsider is way too proud to come by, and it doesn't seem like he's plannin' to. You tell him to come. I only need to talk. It'll be beneficial for him.
Ok. I'll bring him over.
The Bachelor will come. He gave me his word.

Ok, I'll send a peon over to my lot so they don't fiddle aroud too much. Or better yet, you could go yourself, I'm low on free hands and feet. If they start bein' pig-headed, just say, "Agathay onay ethay ogothpay."
Deal.
What have you got under the counter, Grief? Show me the good stuff.
Actually, I wonder… how did you manage to sneak in? Freeze! Parley?
Thank you.
Oh the times we live in. An epidemic! I hope my scouts are back soon...
Scheming, are you?
Don't hang around in the streets for no good reason, okay?
Do you need any more infusions?
Always! And it's not me—we all need them. Don't you see what's going on? We're forced to protect ourselves.
Wait for me then. I'll bring you some.
Here are the infusions I've promised you. Made by a Burakh according to an ancient rite.
That costs a fortune! The map will be waiting for you from tomorrow on.
I'll be sure to come over.
Mugger

DEAD TISSUE. This is blood and tissue of a person who died of the Sand Plague. Procuring this sample took a lot of work. Illegal dissection of dead bodies may result in an accusation of sacrilege, leading to exile at best and more commonly to lynching.
The yesterday's endeavour turned out to be a complete disaster. I couldn't extract the microbial culture from the dead cells. Not to worry though. There's still hope!
Okay, I'll speak to Lara.
How do we catch this detestable pest... Who could have thought I'd have to encounter such a nasty specimen of the diverse microbial world!
All right, I'll look for Stakh Rubin. Have you changed your mind by any chance?
No. Call me superstituous if you will, master Burakh, but this is a promise I am not going to break. Ask someone who knows Rubin's movements better. I've only been here for three days, after all.
I won't.
Here is a sample of the tissue Rubin works with.

I'll take a look at it when I have the time. As for now, just examine it under the microscope. But I doubt you'll find what you're looking for there. In any case, I'm still wondering whose tissue we're working with... Thankfully, I can still tell human blood from its… erm… substitutes.
I will.
I've managed to sneak into Rubin's workplace. He's not there.
Damn it! I wonder if they got to him after all... And?
People are counting on your educated intelligence, oynon.
What do you want, murderer?
I'm not a murderer.
Can I help you?
I'm looking for Stakh Rubin. Where can he be?

There was a fight at the abandoned warehouses by the Works. The townsfolk discovered Barley's lair. Barley is the bandit whose men were the first to go about cutting... God have mercy... cutting people! Rubin has secretly infiltrated the area. He was called to help the wounded. Look for him there.
Thank you, Lara.
No, you can't.
I owe you an apology, Artemy.
Forgiven and forgotten, Stakh. I know you loved my father.
I've been told you've taken over his duty. You're making a panacea. You're putting your life at stake and your well-being at risk every hour. You are being hunted, just as I am.
I wish you luck.
Be careful.
Don't worry.
And what do you want, eh? Got yourself a death wish?
Let's go.
Hoo-boy... Here we are! Weird, it's locked. Either no one's come yet, or they must have gone away to get a lockpick. Got a lockpick?
No.
Now that's just dirty! The Soul-and-a-Halves, those pricks, say I lick Khan's boots! Call me a traitor… Now they won't take me with them to mug the barbers. Those stinkers…
Well, whattya waiting for? Go ahead, break it! Oooh, you're tough as nails, uncle man…
If you make any more noise, I'll throw you out the window.
What barbers?
Don't make that sour face, Burakh... It'll be fine.
Okay, you have a deal. Where is the place?
...If we live to see the day.
"The Weapons Stash"
By the cemetery, one of the homeless children will meet anyone brave enough to enter the house where weapons are hidden.
*** The stash was discovered. The children wouldn't dare challenge the outlaws anymore. Because of this, a few more lives will be saved.

Go to the Cemetery. You'll find a buddy of mine there, name's Stump. Tell him we're in cahoots and all that. He'll take you to the place. "Rubberneck" is the word. You gotta share though! If you don't share with me, there will be payback!
"Rubberneck" it is then. Deal.

Good morning, sunshine! They've probably done all the harvesting by now... Well, you could give it a go, I suppose… Like maybe a miracle would help you or something. Go to the Cemetery. If Stump's still hanging around, then you've still got some time.
Okay. I'll say hi to Stump from you.
I've found the chest. Thank you, pal. Did you know that the house was infected, by the way?
Holy... You're kidding, right?
That's no laughing matter. Just ask your friends.
CHEST BADGE. An emblem of a bull's head; such badges are worn by the local police forces. Taken from a dead patrolman.
The mistress of this house, Lara Ravel, keeps in touch with Rubin. Was she captain Ravel's wife or daughter? I can't recall…
The Bachelor is dead set on arranging for me to meet Stakh Rubin. But I know well enough that he has dealings with him. He could have asked about anything himself… What does he want?
Rubin has left his shelter and is hiding here. Apparently, Stakh's an outlaw himself. Some vigilante! He's been keeping busy, hasn't he…
"The Mysterious Blood"

My childhood friend, Stakh Rubin, who is going out of his way to accuse me, decided to supply the Bachelor with a mysterious broth of blood. It's hard to say what kind of blood it is, since it barely resembles human. What could it be? Stakh did always have a tendency to go against the tide... I wonder what kind of specimens could be found on his workbench.
Rubin left his hideout right after the carnage at Barley's lair. He must be doing rounds now, somewhere at the derelict warehouses by the Works.

*** So this was how the Suprahuman Simon died... To give him credit where credit is due, he did prove that a man can beat the Sand Pest. His blood is proof of this. I wonder if a cure could have been made of this sacred ichor.

The Bachelor is a man of principles. Apparently, he doesn't want to take responsibility for whatever consequences may arise from my meeting with Rubin. Because of this he has advised me to ask Lara Ravel about Rubin's whereabouts. And Lara is likewise a principled person. I am not even sure she will agree to talk to a Ripper like me.
WILLOW'S HEART. The heart of a Steppe girl, a sick dancer called Willow. It beat in her chest mere minutes ago. Was she really sick? This can be confirmed under the Bachelor's microscope.
BRIDE'S HEART. The heart of a Steppe girl, a Herb Bride. Cut open to appease the butchers hoping to end the epidemic. Was she really sick? This can be confirmed under the Bachelor's microscope.
BUTCHER'S HEART. The butcher was probably infected. They were hiding from Olgimsky's wrath in infected houses, correctly assuming that the guards wouldn't try too hard to look for them there.
Herb Bride
So you have luckily escaped custody. I wonder if that's for long.
I see your point. Butchers, dancers, and odonghe... I wonder why.
No. I'm not opening Boddho's children up for your experiments.
I was wrong to underestimate the Steppe medical knowledge…
Okay, I'll help you. Will it really be of use to us both?

There must be some kind of pattern here. It's a shame those people are all locked up inside the Termitary right now. I wonder if that locked-up horde could still be alive and kicking? I'd love to find out... and so I will. But that's my job, not yours.
Okay. I'll find someone.
I will. Wait here.
There's nothing medical in their knowledge.
The Kin is ready to follow your lines, oh eldest of the Burakhs.
Is that so, sister?

There are no more runaways in the town. The last ones were led out secretly this morning. They are planning to perform a rite and make a sacrifice of their own though—and so they went to the gatherers. Those moronic animals! Do they really believe they can guess the lines required for such a feat? Unthinkable...
Thank you, Aspity.
My time is yet to come.
Would you me to do anything special for you, young Burakh? As a daughter of Boddho, I have to obey you. The locals call me Willow.
Yes. I would like you to tell me how many of you dancers have died of the plague since it began.
I see.
Not now. Later.
I've found a dancer. Her name is Willow. Do you know of her?

Yes, I've heard of her. She looks like a Steppe person, but is actually an outsider. Anna Angel knows the details of her story. Don't hurt her, please. She will be of no use… and I have a personal agenda in that regard.
But it is a fortunate opportunity.
I've brought you Willow's heart, Bachelor. I had no choice.

That was a horrible mistake, master Burakh. Its consequences promise to be ten times worse than I could ever expect. Her father, the hunchbacked usurer, has lost his mind to hatred. He wants to take revenge.
So do I.
Here. I've brought you a daughter of Boddho. A Herb Bride. It's the same thing as a dancer.
Good. Are you sure she was sick?
The Steppe will take her. Don't worry.
I've brought you what you wanted. It's a butcher.
Good. Are you sure he was infected?
They won't try to reach civilization anyway. They'll stay in their nomad camps.
You're so unkempt... What's that on your sleeve? Is that blood?
Do you know Willow the pub dancer?
Oooh... I do! What about her? Is she dying? I sure hope so.
Wow... What did she do to you to make you so angry?
This Willow girl—she's gone.
Sweet, oh how sweet... That's just so sweet! Damn, that feels good! So, what reward did we agree on?
...And don't you try being cheap, you abominable freak. I'm not your plaything.
Possibly.
Are you the only son of oynon Burakh, the elder of your kin, and heir to the leadership in the Kin?
They want to feed the Steppe with my blood to stop the plague. But I'm not strong enough for the Earth to accept this sacrifice as sufficient. Please, make them go away!
You have the boon of fertility, don't you?
I will abide by your will, Burakh.
Brace yourself.
You are your father's son, You Who Know the Lines. You know how to liberate flesh. Open this woman up for us.
Okay. I will open this girl up for you.
I'll open you up first, you brutal beasts!
Why are you here?
No. No one is going to help you now.
How are you feeling, Willow?
What for?
Her juices nourish the Steppe. She is full of Mother Boddho's warmth. We want to quench the Earth's thirst for blood with hers to stop the death.
Whose death?

Sons and daughters of the Vein of Boddho are dying in the Termitary. The Mother Superior is still young. Her warmth is not enough to keep the plague at bay. The dead Mistresses' daughters haven't come into their power yet. We need a sacrifice. Opening a herb bride will help.
Why should I smear my hands with innocent blood?
That's not true.
You haven't heard of it, oynon, because the Termitary has been locked up. It is guarded. Behind the guard, inside, is the disease—and no salvation.
How come none of you can cut her?
You will be rewarded. You will do a good deed. You will be loved and respected. Our children will grant you meat and even bread.
So I'll have a better reputation if I kill this girl?
Yes. You will have the best reputation possible. Bring Mother Boddho's warmth back to her, and the Vein will reward you.
This girl's death will do you no good. It won't stop the disease.

You've been brought up away from home, oynon, and you have forgotten the laws that your wise father has always abided by. If you open her up by the Rite, as you can, it will do good. It will help. And we will respect you as we respected your father.
So I'll have a better reputation if I kill this girl?
Will you accept me as my father's heir after the sacrifice?
...If the sacrifice helps.
Is that so?
We respect your knowledge, oynon. We know the simple lines of bull flesh, but the secret lines of human flesh are concealed from us.
Will the Kin accept me if I perform the rite?
I don't need your children's meat, and I am not going to not kill the girl.
Then our children will die.
Nonsense. You're biased.
I won't.
Then you are no son of a Burakh! Whose blood flows in your veins?
Keep your temper! I'll open the bride up for you.
These words will cost you your life. Eat this, swine!
Well, then you're not entitled to having opinions concerning the things you have no idea about.
Will you open the herb bride up for us or not?
Yes, I will.
No, I won't.
RAT. A living grey rat. Not very large, but nimble.
Rat Prophet
RAZORS. No crime is greater in this community than violating the integrity of a body with a sharp piece of metal.
COMBUSTIBLE FLUID. A bottle of combustible fluid. Clear evidence of the demise of one of the terrible firestarting zealots, dubbed Exterminators by the people.
BULL'S BLOOD. The blood of an infected sacrificial bull, cut open by impudent Worms at Ragi Barrow for some unknown purpose.
Why are you so happy about it?
I don't need anything.

I don't like lewd wenches. Especially this one. I've been watching her for a while. She's grown to become something very different from what I had expected. She was destined to become a wonderful performer... But went to serve an ugly freak that had murdered her parents instead. She has no reason to live.
Oh my, aren't you zealously virtuous!
All in all, I'm happy that she's dead. You've done well, Burakh. I want to show you my appreciation.
You liar.
Why would you say that? I haven't told you the whole truth, of course, but you wouldn't understand the whole truth anyway... We used to have a delicate relationship.
You haven't told me anything whatsoever.
We'll settle this in time.
Three thousand is enough. That's a good price for human life.

It's not about anger, and it's a long story anyway. She's a truly special girl... a bad girl, too. You know what I mean? It's a shame they didn't catch her four days ago! I'd spare no expence just make sure the lewd wench is dead!
I'll remember these words.
Was she the person who had brought plague to the town?
It's entirely possible… She's not from around here, you know.
Oh, please do, honey… Everything happens, you know? So if it ever just so happens that you get a chance to assist with the tender bird's death, do keep in mind that I'd pay very generously for that.
I don't trade in other people's death.
I'll keep that in mind.
Do I look like an idiot to you?
Okay. If she finds herself in a life-threatening situation, I won't interfere.

Do you, darling? Not at all... Or would you like to know why I hate her so much? Here you go then: she had ruined someone very dear to me. Does my story make more sense now? If you're looking for the most vicious creature in town, it's her!
The conclusion being…?
The conclusion being that there's no need for her to live. Perhaps the plague is our punishment for her sins? So keep my words in mind, will you? And do keep in mind that I'm a wealthy person now.
I will.
If you want her dead, go and do the killing yourself. It's not that hard.
How come you know about the state of my affairs?

Rumour has it that native Steppe people are actually unlikely to die from the disease—I'm not sure there have been any lethal cases at all. Dancers, butchers... those bull people of yours, what's the word...? That doesn't mean the infection passes them by—but for some reason the disease doesn't seem to reproduce within their bodies. Perhaps it has something to do with their blood.
Who on earth was so eager to get to me?
It feels like the style of the governor. Alexander respects me, so I'll do my best to protect you from any further persecution, but I can't guarantee anything.
That's fine. I can do without guarantees.
I've been looking for you.
Why?
I think I know why…

We need a sample of infected tissue with a high concentration of the bacteria. A heart would work best. A living one, in fact. No more than half an hour can pass after you extract it, and the donor has to have an early—non-critical—stage of the disease.
Thank you. That's helpful.
You are a funny man, oynon. Do you think I walk around cutting people open for my own pleasure?
Quite the contrary. I need a heart to make a protective vaccine. I think it would serve our common interests.
Who is "we"?
Doctor Rubin and I. You are well aware that we're working on a vaccine that will provide Sand Plague immunity. I need the microbial culture for that.
Why can't you just take any infected blood?

The bacteria die or become unreasonably weakened as soon as they're extracted from their nutrient medium; we need to find a way to capture the disease at an active stage. Doctor Rubin's experiments with... a subject... have shown that the heart is the medium where the bacteria reproduce most actively.
Why a heart? Why not something else?
What does that mean?
I'll do it if you pay for the heart.
I'm trying to make a panacea. A serum. A very different thing.

I need the disease itself. You need the useful antibodies produced by a living being. I think both can be found within the same medium—the blood of a person infected, but not yet devoured by the plague. The antibodies suppressing the bacteria's development are precisely the reason for that person to not having been devoured yet.
How much do you want?
Fifteen thousand.
Ten thousand is the sweet spot.
I don't have that kind of money. In all honesty, it never occurred to me that you may want to set up an exotic meat shop…
Farewell then.
How much can you pay?
How much would you offer?
I'll give you everything I have except for the little I can't do without.
Fine.
So what kind of heart do you need?
Do you really think, oynon, that people can fight the Sand Plague?
Sounds vague.
Don't worry, I won't try to swindle you. I always keep my word. You'll be pleased.
So what kind of heart do you need?
All right. Will any heart do? Or do you have preferences?
No deal.
But you can profit personally from this. You haven't forgotten your obligations, I hope?
I haven't. What's your point?
I can fulfil my obligations on my own. Goodbye.
You won't find any butchers in the town. Everyone who had escaped the Termitary has fled.

Not every single one; as far as I know, someone is still being harboured by certain sharp-tongued lady. Her name is Aspity. You can also find dancers in the pub, but the pub is Andrey Stamatin's domain—hell if he allows you to open any of them up in front of him… The dancers may go out for a walk from time to time though, right?
Find yourself another aide, oynon. I'm not helping you.
The first statement is true. As for the rest...
Yes, I am Burakh.
Have you come to open my flesh up along the Ragi line?
No.
What do you mean?
Your time has not come yet.
The Steppe loves me and grants me herbs. I can call white whip with my songs, and brown twyre is lured by the warmth of my breath. Black twyre is abundant if I give my juices to the earth in winter.
No problem. I will feed the Steppe with their blood.
Then please make those butchers go away! They've already made the decision to kill me. But none of them knows the Ragi line. They just want to cut me to get a bucketful of blood.
To get your blood? Why would they do that?
Don't worry. No one will lay a finger on you.
Will twyre become rarer if you die?

Of course it will. Now and forever. I wanted to give birth to a daughter in nine years so that she'd take my warmth and become a Bride in my stead. I am the only one to call herbs out of Suok's gut until then. Don't kill me, please... I will be of more use to you alive...
I'm not so sure about that. Let them take their blood, and I will take something else. You are about to come back to the earth; prepare yourself.
You will live. Calm down.
Not so good lately. My lips are always dry, my tongue rough. I have to drink a lot. Why do you ask? Can you help me?
Yes, I can release you from suffering.
Wait! Someone is going to come here soon, he's a doctor, perhaps he can help me...
You mean the Bachelor?
Yes, the Bachelor! He needs me. Don't you lay a finger on me or you'll make him very upset…
I'm afraid you're sick, Willow.
Okay, you two sort things out yourselves then.
And so he will be upset. Prepare to die.

Do you think I'm a carrier? No, that's not true... I've been in a crowded place all the time, people saw me! You know how quickly the Sand Plague spreads, the pub would have become a mass tomb in no time.
Have you been... with anyone recently?
Why do you ask? Well, yes... Of course.
Are they in good health?

I don't know. I haven't seen any of them since then... None of them have come back to the den. That doesn't mean they are dead though, does it? There are plenty of reasons to avoid public places these days…
I doubt that. Prepare to die.
Fine. Live ahead. Let this one remain on the Bachelor's conscience.
I never waste breath saying things I don't mean.
My lines have brought me to a bloody path…
Oh... You are looking for your Sacrifice, aren't you? I know. How can I help you?
I need a butcher.

That's a weird thing for you to say. Do you really think that your father had such a worthless creature in mind? You're looking in the wrong place. A butcher is but a man. Why concern yourself with men?
I need him for other purposes.
Will you tell me?
You know that I'm making a panacea... I need the tissue of one of the Boddho's children.
No. You are to follow blindly. Your curiosity is unnecessary.

What a ridiculous idea! It's not my place to judge what the elder families do, but you are a different case. You didn't grow up here, you only came back recently. I fear you've fallen under the Bachelor's influence—the prickly prick that'll bury us all! There's no way in hell I'm going to help him... or his minions.
Yet you are going to help me.

No, Burakh. I'm no fool. I can see the Bachelor standing behind your back. It is he who needs the panacea, not you. He wants to offer it to the Powers That Be along with someone's head—that is the price of his victory. You should find your own path.
Don't you judge my actions, woman. I follow the lines of my father's will.
Pity.
All right. What do you want to know?
I want to know where to find a butcher.
You can't. You are too worthless a creature.
Whoa... I never expected to hear something like that from you. You are throwing me away too early... Even a mouse managed to help a panther once. But the choice is, of course, yours.
That was rude of me. I apologize.
Yes. The choice is mine, and I will make it.
You might as well open one of the Worms or a Bride dancer, that would be of more use... And have you tried getting into the Termitary?
I have. It's impossible—and I'm very short on time.
I see... It is indeed not my place to judge. Do you want me to show you where the butchers are hiding?
I don't even want to try. Dying would be too simple an out for me right now.
Yes.
Which gatherer did they go to?

That I do not know. But I think they're not interested in the gatherers themselves—they rather have business with the Herb Bride that lives with them. I do not know or care which one she's living with these days.
Okay, I'll look for them.
Obey me? Why?
I am a dancer, you see. It's a very special trade, an ancient trade. The Rite is obligatory for us—even more so than for butchers.
What does your trade have to do with religion?

Are you joking, Burakh? A dancer knows the lines. Only a dancer can bend and extend them—it's a sacred art. These days we're not dancing because of the mourning... But when happier days come, you will see how far we can extend the lines of body.
I hope happier days come very soon.
Only one. The one that was ripped apart and burnt at the Bone Stake four days ago. Why do you ask? And what's that look you're giving me...
Why did the crowd kill that girl?

She emerged from an infected house—the one that was later visited by torchmen, you know the one. They say your father, old Isidor, used to work there. So they asked her what business she had there. She said she had brought your father a word and a deed. Everyone expected her to die very quickly, but she didn't.
I'm asking because I'm very much surprised that you do not get sick.

Oh, but we do! You can't imagine how many of us died during the First Outbreak! And butchers too... That was a few years ago. It's just that we have more options. The disease leaves us quickly if we're not seriously infected. If we are, however, then we die...
Shouldn't they have been happy…?
Why do you think it works like that?

...Then the townsfolk decided she was to blame for everything. Called her a carrier. And then the rumour spread of a shabnack-adyr coming from below the ground, and so they broke her lines and burnt her at the Bone Stake. But it was a wrong thing to do. Even if she was sick, she couldn't infect anyone else.
How come?
Do you know what Brides are? The Brides who are engaged to the Earth; the Brides who summon twyre.
No.
Yes, I do.

They are no Mistresses, of course... Compared to a Mistress, even a young one, they're merely candles next to a bonfire. They do have powers, however, and impressive powers at that. Brides say that their—that our juices flow in such a fashion that we can do no harm. Our bodies are clean.
What do you mean by that?

If there's not too much Sand Dirt in our bodies, it leaves them quickly. And we can't infect anyone at all, that much is certain. If the Dirt is abundant, however, then it devours us just like any other person, and there's nothing to be done about that.
I see. Would you like to come with me?
I'd like to…! But I can't. I have to stay here until the evening—and I do have plans for that time. A handsome guest in a snakeskin coat has arranged to meet me in the Blind Backyard.
Is that so... I think I know who the happy man is.
Seems like you are blessed with a great metabolism—who could have thought metabolism is a thing that can depend on the social status. See you later.
Too bad.
Don't worry about him. We really are harmless. As a Burakh, you ought to feel it.
I do feel it, relax.
The Blind Backyard, eh…? When exactly?
Nine o'clock. I'll probably come earlier though, I want to have some me time first.
It will. I am positive that there are antibodies to be found in the bodies of Steppe people. Unless they have natural immunity, that is—which sounds unlikely.
Okay. Double-checking time: please tell me what you need precisely.

Sure. As far as I understand, almost every townsperson here has a trace of Steppe blood in them, but there's also an ethnic layer that's been completely untouched by civilization. I'm talking about that Kin of yours. I'm not sure who exacltly belongs to it—I only know that dancers and butchers do. Try one of them.
Isn't that the usurer's daughter?
I don't know.
Perhaps. She'll be waiting for someone in the evening. In the Blind Backyard.
Don't touch Willow, Burakh! You will ruin my plans. Take anyone else.
What, does the whole town know this? Is she telling everyone about her plans?
She's not the quiet type, that's for sure.
What if she's the only option?
All right then...
...Then do it. The vaccine is more important than a single life. But I'm seriously asking you to try every other option before you go through with this.
Deal.
So a profitable deal of yours have fallen through, I gather?
That's not the point. The town has lost a usurer and acquired a disruptive gang leader—Grief and Barley pale in comparison to this. I wonder where all his madmen came from... Must be his debtors.
I don't understand.
They want to burn the town down. We'll have to deal with a firestarter gang from now on. I have a really bad feeling about this…
Right. So do you need the heart or what? The clock's ticking.
Yes, of course I do. I hope it wasn't for nothing.
Take revenge? How?
No, I'm not.
Well. Peace be with her.
I'm not, but I didn't have much of a choice.

Yes, I know that already. Bloody Aspity did her best to sneak each and every one of them out into the Steppe. Haven't seen a creature more repulsive in my entire life! Every quarantine measure we've taken will prove useless if any of them reaches civilization.
They are not contagious, oynon.
Oh really? How do you know? If the bacteria live within their bodies undeveloped, they are very much contagious! They are walking carriers!
The patrolmen aren't running out of legs, are they…
They get their job done.
Are you the boss here?
You could say so, Ripper.
I don't like being called that. You better keep it in mind.
You're the one who needs me, not the other way round. And so you will speak my tongue. I'm not the one who needs you.
I need one of these women.
You've got strong muscles and a good reaction. You must be an excellent fighter. But I will kill you if we ever fight. Get it?
Well, I can do without you as well.
You got it, I see. You can call me Haruspex.
They're not for sale. Neither are they take-away—especially now. They are very dear to me. I'm getting more and more sentimental by the day.
The words you're using are way too big for someone like me.
I need to talk to them.
Fine by me. Talk ahead.
Thanks.
To hell with you kids. Getting into your business was a bad idea…
I do.
Damn! Should have taken one from Sticky. I thought it would be standing all ajar... I wonder why it isn't. Have the Soul-and-a-Halves locked it or something?
Okay, I'll take care of it. Thanks for bringing me here.
What about my tip, uncle man?
Get outta here...
You'll get your reward if I come back alive.
Keep quiet.
Right… You know what? Go ahead and keep all the weapons to yourself—I'll find myself some more.
I am.
It's sharing time then. Fifty-fifty, remember? I want a revolver! The rest is yours—I don’t mind.
No, pal. I'm not giving you any weapons—you'll only get yourself in trouble with them. But I'll find a way to thank you later.
You may take it all if you like. I can manage well enough with my bare hands.
I knew it! C'mon, be a good man, give it to me…
No. I won't.
All right. But only when I'm absolutely sure that the barbers are all dead.
A wise choice.
Are they correct?

Cor-wrecked! C'mon. Notkin's just angry because I refused to join him when he wanted me to. Khan has no special liking of me eigher... I've done them both favours. I've even climbed a chimney for them! And all those pricks do is boss about… Well, let them just wait and see!
And they're planning to mug the muggers, right?

Hello there! Living under a rock or what? The angry guys that split off from Grief's gang to cut people on the streets. "We ain't listenin' to ya no more," they said, "the Kin's gone, the old life's blasted, so we ain't got nothin' to lose!" Big words, huh? And so they went slashing and robbing everyone. Those sons of bitches...
And so your friends are planning to attack them?
They ain't no friends of mine! Arrogant bastards, stinky turncoats... Ooh, I hate them... What did I do to them?
That's not an answer.
Big deal… Don't be silly, just take care of yourself. It'll be all right.

Well yeah, they are. As if they'd have a shot at it. They planned on arming up—got them weapons stored at a certain place... Well, I'm gonna ruin their party! How about we snatch their weapons away? And we'll save the dumbheads from the barbers' knives as well...
Why not. Where is the place?
I don't have time for this.
Are you Stump? "Busybody" is the word. I'll be the one to escort you instead of Sticky.

Ah! Well done, Sticky. 'Cause, y'know… people say it's dangerous out there. These jerks have gone absolutely mental, they're running rampant! I'd put a knife or two into them if I could, too. Come on, follow me.
I will accept it if you tell me the truth.
I wonder why.
You are being hunted? I didn't know that.

I'm forced into hiding, as you can see. The only reason I've come here is because the barbers have wounded a person that I owe a debt. I'm an outlaw on the run now. And I deserve it way more than you…
What have you done?
Most likely—considering your recent attitude.
That's no laughing matter. I have wronged you.

There was no doubt in my mind that it was you who had killed the Master, until recently. He was obviously killed for the inheritance. It was connected to the Kin admitting the spiritual leadership rights of the Burakhs for the second time. And there is other evidence that... fit together to support the assumption.
What evidence?

Firstly, the wound. The thing they're calling a shabnak's claw had inflicted too precise a wound. A wound following every rule of the "secret line", as though the criminal had an intimate knowledge of the inner ways. No butcher could make a blow like that. Secondly, the news of your arrival...
It's all gotten so confusing. I've been told a strange story not so long ago. I think you are being hunted for something that I had done. For Simon Kain.
Who told you I was to come shortly?
Katerina Saburova. Alexander is the governor now. Beware of him.
What did Katerina Saburova say about me?
Am I being hunted on his order?
No. The order is Georgiy Kain's. And he is even more dangerous than Alexander.
What have I done to upset him?
The reason being…?
She said you were coming. Said you would spend your first days here in secrecy. That you are to make a bloody sacrifice.
Not much then. Did you believe her?
Of course I did. How could I not? She even said that you will "drown the town in blood", "quench the earth's thirst for blood", or "start a bloodshed". That is literally what she said.
That could have been said as a metaphor.
Yes... Those guys that have been working around this place have shed more blood in one day than one could imagine!
Well, I'll speak to her.
I don't understand.
Yes, I've heard that Simon has beed killed.

You've been attacked, remember? At the Station. They were there on their own accord, I've learned. Tried to ambush Simon's murderer. Thought he would try to escape by hiding in a carriage when a scheduled train arrives.
What does that have to do with us? I thought oynon Dankovsky had established the truth. Simon's killer is still among us. And we can't punish them yet.

And so we are hunted by fanatics for desecrating Simon's remains. Well, unlike you, I deserve it. When I realized the nature of his superhuman blood, I had a desperate decision to make. And I've decided to make Sand Plague medicine from Simon's remains.
Why didn't you explain yourself? Your choice would've been accepted.

Like hell it would! Explaining myself to the Kains is pointless. They've fetishized Simon! They'd rather place their bets on his sacred power, or the power of his name, or hell knows what else. They are a family of high-handed esoterics who only believe in dark arts!
Have you looked for antibodies in his blood?
"Fetishized"? What does that mean?
Where have you been all these years? I thought you were studying.
I'm kidding. Just didn't expect a word like this to escape your lips. Go on.

That was the first thing I did. There was nothing of the sort. I am a sceptic, you know. Yet each time I come across the Kains' mysticism, I am filled with fear. It's like the disease began to wither away within him, all on its own... but it didn't die.
So what are you planning to do to him?

I'm not planning. The deed's been already done. The sacrilege is complete. I've cut his body open by every line, and squeezed everything I could from it. I pulled the bacteria from it and have made a few protective vaccine samples already. Old Simon has fed mankind with himself once again.
Can I count on you?
That depends on what you're planning to do.
"All on its own"? What do you mean?

His blood is of a completely different nature to anything I've seen before. It isn't quite human. More than human, I'd say... In any case, the blood is gone. I used every drop to make the vaccines. I don't regret it though; it wouldn't have helped you anyway, I think.
Okay. Thank you for the news.
I'm sorry I can't be of more use. And don't harbour ill feelings against me, please.
I don't like blind hatred, Stakh.
Are you telling the truth? Look me in the eye.
I did kill... But I had my own reasons to. I'm a killer, not a murderer.
I haven't killed a single person, I promise.
...Not only are you a murderer, but also a liar! The former is horrible, but the latter is despicable. I don't want to speak to you, go away.
You idiot.
Can't we be friends at all?
Well... We all do bad things, so we must right our wrongs with the good deeds. The worse the original deed, the more good we must do.
Tell me where can I find this man that I'm looking for.
I won't tell you anything. Go away.
Aren't you going to listen to me at all?
What do I have to do to restore my good name in your eyes?
You hurt people. Now, save a few diseased ones from the pain.
Okay, I'll do as you ask.
Painkillers aren't that easy to find. I have better uses for them.
So you've softened your heart, haven't you?
I shouldn't have thought so badly of you. If only you knew how horrible the rumours surrounding you are, you wouldn't be so harsh on me…
What rumours?
I'm not being harsh on you at all.
They say you cut human bodies to express yourself.
Many people do just that. Those who can't muster up the courage to cut others resort to cutting themselves. That's barbaric.
They say a body is like a tight knot for you—a knot you're longing to untie. That you see knots instead of people around you when walking along the street!
That's not true.
What's the point of untying them without need? Knots are only untied when you need loose rope to connect the disjointed.
They say you make human sacrifices, but refuse to believe in heathen gods.
The inexplicable is always frightening. I'm surprised you're not scared by the people that kill out of greed or anger.
That doesn't mean every single knot is supposed to be untied.
I wish I'd catch the person spreading the rumours. They'll make a perfect sacrifice for some worthless deity. I'd do it by the rite, too!
It is your good luck that I know where he is. But what do you need him for? You want to take vengeance on him?
What for?
He threatened to punish you. He believes that it was you who killed Isidor. He's… he's wrong though, isn't he?
Of course he is.
So why do you need him?
And what do you think?
Oh, I don't know what to believe!
Whatever the case, Rubin is a man that can stand up for himself. So where is he?
I'm making a panacea—and so does he. I want to know if he's had any luck.
I want to talk to him. About my father's death, for one.
Your face is terrifying… No, I can't tell you. I don't think you're up to any good.
Whatever, I'll find him without your help.
Fine, Lara. I'm making a remedy that helps with the Sand Plague. I need his advice.
Can you promise me that you'll never reveal his hideout to anyone? Can you swear on your father's memory?
I can.
No. I won't swear on my father's memory.
Your fear speaks for itself. I won't reveal to you where he is.
As you wish.
I do. I'm tired of his moronic spite.
There was a curious sample by his microscope. I've taken a look, but I'm not sure what I saw.
So who can this be?

Rubin is the only person who can answer that question, I'm afraid. We should hurry and find him before his persecutors do. I would even be willing to break my word for that. But you said he's not in his prosectorium, right?
No, he is not.
Perhaps he is back by now.
I think Yulia and Lara keep in touch with him... or rather he keeps in touch with them. Perhaps they know something. Try to get to Lara while I'm analyzing this sample.
You are one stubborn oynon.
Don't forget to get a sample from him.
Do you have a plan?

Master Rubin, who doesn't trust me and is concealing something important, has an unusual source of infected tissue. He's using it to conduct his first experiments. It is not a vaccine, of course, but it's something. I think it might be of interest to you as well.
You have my attention.

Seems like Rubin is working with a mysterious carrier of the disease that has weakened microbial culture in their blood. I doubt we could make a vaccine from it—your reagents seem to deal with it all too mercilessly. I wonder what had weakened the infection though…
Disaster is a big word.

An appropriate one. I couldn't extract living bacteria, and this little... muck that it leaves behind in dead bodies is of no use... Not to mention that there are no antibodies. But I'm not losing hope.
Why not?
What's your vaccine-making process?

Oh, this out-of-the-way hole—pardon me once again for saying so—knows only one process. The microbial culture is treated with natural agents so that it adapts... Well, Rubin treats it, I test the results. You know all this though, don't you?
Why is obtaining living bacteria so important?

Because the purpose of a vaccine is to give the organism a chance to develop immunity. To teach it how to fight the infection. It's obvious! I wonder how a strong and healthy organism would react to these... bacterial experiments?
Yeah, it won't fight. It'll probably just reject the sample.
I know how vaccines work, I'm not an idiot. I just wanted to double-check if you're positive there are no antibodies in dead tissue.
I know all this better than you do. See you later.
You and Rubin are working on a vaccine. What does it have to do with me? I'm not trying to extract the bacteria.
Most certainly. But we ought to look further.
Where?
You need the antibodies though, don't you? Just listen to me before you refuse my advice.
I'm listening.
Who is the carrier?
Beats me. Rubin is keeping tantalizingly mum about the whole business. You're closer to him than I am, though; perhaps he'd be willing to share with you the information that he is concealing from me.
Rubin hates me.
He absolutely doesn't. Last time we talked, I described your feats in detail and proved that his suspicions were completely baseless. You're his hero now, and he's deeply ashamed of his tantrum.
Where do I find him?
That is something I cannot tell you. I gave my word.
What? This makes no sense.
This shadowy scheming and double-dealing is absurd. I have no need for cardboard excuses. Have a nice day.
Telling me would be in your best interests though, wouldn't it?

Sating your curiosity is not in my best interests, no. Rubin shares his findings with me—and for me that's enough. Even if the microbes turn out to have come from his own saliva, I don't care. You are the one who does.

Rubin's trust is very precious to me—and it's so very fragile. If he finds out that it was I who told you where his lair is—a lair that's being actively sought after by numerous armed robbers, I must add—I will lose a very important ally. No way. You're free to look for Rubin yourself.
I won't ever abuse this knowledge. I can give you my word.
Okay. How did you manage to find him?
And where do I start?

I was introduced to him by a lovely lady called Lara Ravel. She is a very kind, gentle creature. I suppose it would be very hard to be accepted as her guest without a stellar reputation, but you'll probably fight your way in somehow.
I see where you're going with this. It's this thing people call a "joke", right?
Sounds like too much fuss. I'll handle it myself.
What are you doing, my good people?
Stay out of it, you nutjob! Or you'll taste my knife all right…
You shouldn't have said that. Here it comes!
All right, calm down now, all right! I'm going...

We ain't no good people, and we sure as hell ain't yours. Gotta pick them dirty punks' noses with our knives! They're showin' off a lil' bit too much, y'see, them jackanapeses. Did Bad Grief send you?
Maybe he did, maybe he didn't…
Were you?
Y'know what, get lost then before we peel your face off your skull!
Oh my... That was colourful. Eat this!
All right, calm down now, all right! I'm going...
Unmount your ambush, you unshaven scum.
What the hell're you babblin' about here, tailcove?
"Agathay onay ethay ogothpay". Got it, tailcove? Now ready, set, go. I want to see your heels flashing.
Eat this, you asshole! Who do you think you're calling a "tailcove"....
We'll meet again, cheeky face…
Hope so.
How about we sort it out right here, assface?
Parley, parley…

Take this weapon. It's handmade. Granddad said it used to be a fowling piece... Well, the hammer's different and the barrel has been somewhat modified. It can use rifle ammo or shot cartridges. Know where to get those?
Calm down. I will do you no harm.
And where are the crooks? How did they let you through?
It's all right. They are no more.
They're dead. All of them.
Cool! Did you do that all by yourself…?
All by myself.
Would you look at him! Listen, this means we ought to thank you somehow…
It would help.
Who do you children think you're dealing with? Have you lost your marbles?

Watch your tongue! We ain't no children. We are Soul-and-a-Halves! And there's more than enough of us back home. Multiply that by two too 'cause our pets fight alongside us. We are a force to be reckoned with.
Well, the guys by the door weren't exactly trembling with fear.
Whaddya want? What? We won't give up our dogs! We'll fight back!
What dogs?
Well, don't give them up then. Your choice.
So you aren't a thief?
No. I'm not a thief and you know it.
I'm joking. Aren't you a bit young for knife fights?
What pets?
Our Halves. The thieves hate them. They hate them all: dogs, cats, crows, owls, rats. Especially dogs!
Is that why they were waiting for you by the entrance?
No thank you. Farewell. And don't go about looking for trouble anymore.
Help me out here.

Ammo is rare. It can be found here and there... Always in small quantities. We've ordered our girls to go out looking for it. You could ask them! They will probably trade ammo and cartriges for their girly treasures...
I'll figure it out, thank you.
Great Mother! Does it shoot at all?
It does, but you have to find suitable ammo.
And what ammo is suitable?
Obviously.
I think it will do better in my hands than in yours.
Maybe I am. Want to help out?
That depends on what you're up to.

I'm up to a good thing. My Soul-and-a-Halves are sneaking about everywhere—watching out for enemy Dogheads, catching Halves, and just generally messing around. So I want to use them for the greater good. Even Sticky will turn green with envy.
What kind of greater good?
Who is Sticky?

Just a bloke. Thinks he's the sharpest. Likes to stick his nose everywhere, won't miss anything fun for the life of him. The more dangerous, the better. Quite above himself too... Wouldn't join our gang... Eh, why are we even talking about him!
What do you want to talk about then?
We will scout out which houses have been infected. We'll make a map of them every day. Imagine that! If it goes well, the Bachelor himself will happily trade his right arm for such a map!
Interesting. Will you show me?
We can even make a copy for you if you want. Can you do us a favour in return?
How many?
Give us ten protective mixtures, and the map is yours. And don't you think I'm being greedy—I just need the infusions to equip the scouts with.
I agree. We have a deal.
No. It's a hard task that would take too much time.
Hardly. Unless someone lends you a hand…
What kind of favour?
Your father knew some awesome rare recipes for twyrine infusions. He wrote down the ones that protected from the Sand Plague after the First Outbreak. Can you make them?
He landed himself in a soup with some bandits.
Is that because of the Halves? I must have heard about it! Grief demanded they get rid of their wardogs! Were they defending their cubs?
Yes, most likely.
Well done, Notkin! Don't you think he would pick a quarrel over nothing…
How did he manage to settle so close to a bandits' den anyway?

He had a quarrel... with another boy. Khan. Khan is a brave boy as well, and very high-handed, too. They used to be best friends. Now Khan lives in the Polyhedron and the proud Notkin struggles among bandits in a small hut at the Warehouses... It's a long story. How can I thank you?
I don't need anything. Helping you makes me happy already.
Calm down. He's fine.
Thank you... What did you do to the bandits?
I killed them. I had to.
.......But you have helped Notkin. Would you please allow me to thank you?
No. I don't need anything.
Castle?

It's by the southern Warehouses. That is where the Soul-and-a-Halves—that's what they're calling themselves—live. He is not an urchin, he is just... independent and parentless. And he is getting out of hand. Maybe you could go and check on him? What if he is indeed in danger?
A "pit"? What's that?

Well... That is what Maria and I call our visions. She calls hers a "flight", I call mine a "pit". That's peculiar because mine are usually joyful, while hers are grim. Or maybe it's just me. So will you check on Notkin?
How do I find them?
Sorry, I'm too busy.
Will he keep it?
I've seen his eyes. He's the type that always keeps their word.
I don't know.
Well, you dunno, I dunno, nothin' to talk about then. Ain't nothin' to look at here, Burakh.
Damn....
What does it mean?
What it means is our thieves' talk, and you ain't got nothin' to do with it. So stop bein' smart and go. They'll do what you tell 'em to.
Hope so.

Whaddya think I am, some kind of kid-killin' monster? Even though the lil' punks re nasty, so so nasty... No. I only ordered for the rabid dogs to be taken away from 'em. They're getting' out of hand.
Maybe you aren't a monster, but the people you've sent came with their knives sharpened.
…To scare 'em a tiny lil' bit, perhaps?
Or perhaps not, Grief? How about ordering your thieves to leave? The times are tough, you know, it's no child's play... Rats are more dangerous than dogs these days.
Yes, I must have got it wrong. I'll be going then.
He'll ask me what the matter is.
The most profitable ever, you answer. Nobody will ever lay a finger on him here, we ain't no enemies to ourselves. You believe me?
I do. I'll bring him over.
No. I don't believe you.

Most honoured master Burakh! Or rather oynon Burakh. You will be called that soon... for you are the keeper of knowledge. A warden, a menkhu... a surgeon, so to say. And even more than that. So, have you looked into the matter of your inheritance?
I have. Nothing is more important for me right now.

My daughter told me about these... doomed children that the deceased used to... take care of. I see no point in hiding the truth from you. The brand this... mysterious subject is marked with belongs to the secret steppe code. Can you read Longmark? The so-called "circles or copious brands"?
No.

You've been away for a while... Pray forgive me... Yes, you were but a child when you left... Longmark is a kind of alphabet. The signs that the bulls were branded with. Each of them has many meanings. Each sign is a song. A magical story told in lines. A spell.
Yes, I see what you mean.

I don't know this secret code. The Kin does. Maybe some of the odongh Worms or the butchers... And I have to admit, it is me who stands between you and these secrets. I've locked up all inhabitants of the Termitary.
Why?
Pray forgive me…! The're an epidemic. A quarantine. I cannot violate it. There are about eight thousands inside. What if the disease finds a way in?
What if it already has?

Most respected Bachelor Dankovskiy... has already harassed me with these pointless questions. If the disease is already inside, then there's all the more reason to keep the doors shut. But enough about that. I want to help you. You want to know the meaning of the brand, don't you?
I do.

A few butchers managed to escape the Termitary before it was blocked off. I propose a deal. I've explained to you how you may find them helpful, so you will be looking for them anyway. After you find them, tell me where they are. If you promise to do so, I'll tell you where to start.
I agree.
I am no snitch.

I'm not going to kill them. I must keep an eye on them, however. Don't you realize? Can't you see what's going on? Any possible carrier of the disease has to be isolated! Moreover, mind your obligation...
Fine. You've convinced me.
No.

There is a shack... I've tried sending people over there already, they were greeted coldly. A certain lady lives in it... She is always in the loop; she knows the butchers' ways and what they're after. They say she was begotten by an odongh and a twyre bride... Start off there. She will treat you with respect.
How come?

Well... You're Isidor Burakh's son. The eldest Burakh now. It means a lot to them that you are from a menkhu family. Menkhu aren't just surgeons or butchers; they are healers. An almost sacred role... a spiritual one, so to say. All in all, the lady will honor your request and tell you about the runaways.
Well... if that is enough, I'm going. Show me the place.
A bride?

The gatherers... They've got these virgins, these so-called "twyre brides". They claim to chase the herbs from below the ground and onto the surface. You're supposed to know this, aren't you? In any case, they do know you. They acted as midwives when you were born…
Is that so?
I can deal with my inheritance myself.
An ill-judged reply. Or maybe you do know the meaning of the brand you've found inside the stash?
So it's a brand! How come you know about it?
You mean the hieroglyphic alphabet?
A cruel decision.
So, what was it that you wanted to tell me?
I'm glad you are still alive.
I want to speak to Foreman Oyun. Can you arrange that?
I had to work hard to stay that way.
Wha-at? What Oyun? Why... with the Foreman? What Foreman? The current one?
Yes. The current one, Oyun.
Why so anxious all of a sudden?
Have the Mistresses told you about him? Yeah, I've lost one friend called Burakh already, and Foreman Oyun knows why... yes. He will pay for it... Anyway, I don't want to lose another.
He knows who killed my father?

Does he... He knows all right. Allow me to say I'm pretty sure he's not unhappy about your father's death... Oyun, that is. He wouldn't be unhappy if you were to die either. No, there's no reason for you to meet him right now.
What do the Mistresses have to do with it? It's just rumours.
It's just rubbish, Artemy Burakh. You needn't meet him, not right now anyway.
I cannot agree with you.
Fine.
I want to see him.
What does he know?
I haven't spoken to him yet. We'll have some extreme interrogation when he's back.
He went off to the Steppe. He's not in town at the moment. I think he's supposed to come back in a day or two.
Where is he now?
When did he leave?
Three days ago. Or maybe four. Exactly on the eve of your arrival, master Burakh.
So will you arrange for us to meet?
I see.

The're a plot being woven against me. The Bachelor is nosing about the Termitary and the Abattoir... If I meet the Foreman, I'll give him another reason to suspect me... It'll all be fine, it will all settle... in time. But I wouldn't be so keen on meeting him if I were you.
That is for me to decide.
Thank you for the advice.
"Let us camp near the mountain, a suitable place… Let us camp next to the river, a suitable place…"
What a strange coincidence... Do you know why I came here?
"...for our herders to pitch up their bark-tents; for our shepherds to fill up their gullets."

I can imagine. You're looking for the runaway. Oh, it's such a shame that Fat Vlad managed to weasel his way into your circle of friends! That friendship will do you no good, oh no... But you're too late anyway. An outsider fop, a bachelor in a snakeskin coat, came by poking his nose everywhere. I've lead the runaway butchers into the Steppe. Otherwise he'd have shot them all dead.
Are they all gone?
Does he have firearms?
I think so—else he wouldn't be so confident as to attack butchers. He isn't you, he couldn't beat them with his bare hands.

Some are still hiding throughout the town. I'm planning to collect them one by one—I've found one already, and it won't take me too long to find the rest. The children of Suok have no reason to expire in this torture chamber. You can count on me, oynon. I won't let your people die.
Do you know where I can find the butchers?
Where is this one hiding?
You wouldn't turn him in to Fat Vlad, would you? Promise?
I promise.
This butcher's life is mine to command. I shall decide his fate—for my father.
Then I want his fate to be desided by you, not by Fat Vlad. I am counting on your decency. You are your father's son, aren’t you?
I am.

Ok, I'll tell you. His hideout is the place that anyone with two legs runs away from today. Look for him there. But be careful. He is being hunted. Don't let the hunters catch you two—because they won't waste their time trying to get to know you.
Do you know what the longmark brands mean?
How could I? Women aren't allowed to know that.
Pity.
Don't worry.
Why did you come, child of Boddho?
What are you doing here?
We were hired by the outsider oynon. He gave us a task, we had to open the dead up for him. He was looking for the disease inside them. There were four of us.
How did it go?

Patrolmen came. Killed two of my brothers. Now they're after the third one. I've hidden here. The body that I opened up was taken away to be buried. I opened it up poorly, brother... I'm ashamed of that. I did manage to cut the small lines and prepare the thin tissues for the oynon though.
Okay. That's not why I'm looking for you.
I want to ask you about Longmark.
I have no knowledge of the circles of Longmark. I'm neither an oynon, nor a menkhu, nor a shaman.
What do you want?
Tell me what this brand means. Look, I've drawn the sign for you.
Tell me what this brand means.

You are an oynon of a menkhu kin, are you not? I've seen this brand before. I don't know its lines. I've seen it in a terrible place. There is a corridor in the depths of the Abattoir, the route that Supremes take when they come from the Steppe to be celebrated. Oyun, the Foreman of the Abattoir, can explain the meaning to you.
Supremes?
You don't know who Supremes are? You're joking.
Tell me.
You are joking. They cannot be called by name, for they are not to be talked about. What next? Are you going to tell me you don't know of the one that is called Bos Turokh?
Are you talking about bulls?
Are you talking about gods?
Yes. Among other things. Don't play jokes on me, oynon. Don't make fun of me just because I'm a simple man.
What else can you tell me about this sign?

If something is marked with this sign, then it is neither a man, nor a child of Boddho, nor of Suok. It's a Supreme. What you need is not a man, oynon. Your father had something to do with Those Who Walk the Corridor. It scares me. The brand is drawn there for a reason. They are not men. This is all I know.
Well, thanks anyway.
Be careful.
Are you aware that Olgimsky is after you?
Boös Vlad? Yes, I know.
Get away from here as quickly as possible. I promised to lead him to your hideout if I ever find you.
As you wish. You've made a wise and honest choice.
Will you help me?
All right. In any case, I need your help.
The local thief kingpin.
Oh, that lowlife... What does he want of me?
He only said that your meeting would be mutually beneficial.
I'm not going to meet those pickpockets. They'll have to make do with Rubin.
I want to be completely honest with you, oynon. They will leave the boys be if you promise to come by.
Are the boys' lives in danger?
They are.
All right. I'll go.
No, they're just picking on them.
I think he's simply mocking us.
The matter will settle itself then.
As you wish.
He sells weapons at a bargain price.
I've got a revolver already. Haven't shot once with it; hopefully I won't ever have to. I've been warned that it's prone to misfiring and will most likely just explode after ten or so shots.
Then do it for the kids. There are urchins living next to the thieves.
All right. As you wish.

I hope I manage to make what I want out of it. Meanwhile, how can I return your kindness? I have no money, but I can offer you something better—the drugs that are not available to the general public yet. I can't give them all right away though, so you'll have to choose what you want: immunogens, antibiotics, or painkillers?
Immunogens.
Antibiotics.
Painkillers.
I'd rather have bandage packages.
A little bird told me.
Was this little bird Rubin?
Rubin doesn't speak to me, oynon. Seems like he still believes that I'm guilty of patricide.
I can remedy that.
I would be very grateful. Good luck with the tissue.
Yes. You're talking about menkhu—they're butchers and wardens. That is their right. But it's not about morals.

Exactly. I need tissues of a person who died of the Sand Plague. I need them today, right now! I've tried to get them at the cemetery, but failed miserably. The patrolmen are vigilantly watching over the dead.
I'd reward you generously for that.
Deal. I'll do what I can, even though I still don't have the right to.
Why? Aren't you one of the—what do you call them…? Well, your father was a surgeon.
Nobody knows me here yet. But I've said my word. I'll do the best I can—if I can.

Please allow me to return the favour. Here are the medical supplies that are not available to the general public yet. I can't give them all to you, so choose what you want the most: immunogens, antibiotics, or painkillers?
Immunogens.
Painkillers.
Antibiotics.
I'd rather have some bandage packages.
I want to ask you something, oynon. Something very important. It's about a panacea.
What are you talking about? The serum?
Yes. Tell me how to extract antibodies from tissue.

First of all, they have to be there. If you're sure they are, then there are several general ways to go from there. A serum, after all, is just a blood component. As far as I understand, you can mix a sample of it with those… natural agents. We'll need to get a sample first though. Then go ahead. Experiment.
Right. An experiment like this has been successful once before.
So I've heard. Your father was a natural. So what did you want to ask of me?
When you get down to studying a tissue sample, please see if there are antibodies in it.

I have no intention to hide my results from you, obviously. But, regrettably, I have serious doubts that they are going to make you happy; it doesn't look like human organisms can resist the disease at all. At least that's what I've been seeing so far, sadly…
Yet my father's endeavours were a success.
That's all I'm hoping for. Don't worry, I'll tell you of my findings. The first results will become available as soon as tomorrow.
Thank you.

I know you are a killer. One of the worst killers anyone in this town has ever seen, in fact. You are charged with premediated murder of at least four people. The death of Simon Kain and your father are being looked into.
You have no proof.

But I will, damn it! If it weren't for Simon's death... And the sudden threat of an epidemic... If only they let me off the leash! Perhaps tonight I will finally get rid of it though. Your patron, Olgimsky, won't be able to veto my decisions then!
I'm starting to like him.
Is there somewhere I can stay in this town?
You've got estate here, I believe. Your late father had a house and a secret laboratory even.
My father's house is unclean.
Can't help you with that. It is your house.
Not any more.
Go to hell!
Who is investigating my father's murder?
No one at the moment.
Why?
Because there's no time for that. There are matters of greater importance.
I'm not really sure what's keeping me from breaking your nose.
Who will take care of it and when?

I will deal with your father's murder personally when I'm not distracted all the time and the order is restored. And something tells me that you won't be too happy with the results. I won't let you off the hook.
Undoubtedly.
That's better than nothing.

It is only out of respect for the Bachelor—he is for some reason absolutely sure of your innocence, that's understandable, he's an outsider after all—but it is only out of respect for him that I will hand you the inheritance. I will be watching every step you make, however. Don't even think about absconding.
Be my guest.

You may take possession of your inheritance. The affairs of the deceased were conducted by one Aspity. She lives nearby, her den is in the Crude Sprawl. You'll have to make do without a guide and find the way to her house on your own. And don't you dare leave the town! Your culpability is all but proven. It's almost over.
We'll see.
Watch your tongue!
A shame I'm bound by my word! Or you'd be dealt with right here!
I've come to take possession of my father's inheritance.
What I "will do"? That's interesting.

Don't play innocent, Burakh. You were born here. You were raised here. Sometimes it even seems to me that I remember you. You must have seen the "long strife" of the two Mistresses, Victoria and Nina. You know how Mistresses can see the future!
So what do the late Mistresses say I will do?
A living Mistress does. Katerina Saburova, my wife. She knows you will bring us much sorrow in the coming days. You'd be in jail already if not for Olgimsky's protection!
Since when are a clairvoyant's words grounds for imprisonment?
I'd put you in jail at my own risk, willingly. This isn't the Capital, your civil rights mean nothing here. Here, the scope of your rights is determined by the will of the rulers.
Got that already.
I never intended to.
I'll have to make use of what little time I have left then.

You kill a single living soul, and you're a dead man! Dead on the spot! You hear me? I will even distribute weapons to the townsfolk so that they can shoot you! I'll make you an outlaw so that anyone can put you down like a rabid dog!
I see a rabid dog right before me.
I'll make you regret this conversation yet.
Why are you so self-assured, architect?
Because I have the will to kill. It is easy for me to take the life of a living being. Living beings can feel that, and fear paralyzes them before I even strike.
Will is not enough. You have to have skill as well.
Where there's a will, there's a way. And I know how ways are supposed to work, be it archways or ways of taking lives. I've got a knack for it, it's an artist thing.
Is that so? It's hard to find a way in the Steppe.
It depends. And if I can't find a way, I can always make one. Perhaps they won't die, but they'll serve me just fine.
Why are you telling me all this?
I'm telling you this, Steppe man, so that you know what to expect from me. Perhaps one day you'll need it.
My name is Artemy Burakh.
How do you know?
I can see it in your eyes. How much?
It isn't only twyre. Swevery, for one, is rare this season.
Well, let's trade.
I'll remember that.
So I've been told.
No use trying that on me.
One day you may encounter someone who knows their ways better than you.
You don't know anything about the Steppe.
We'll see.
Are a twyre buyer?
No. But I'm its fervent admirer. And constant consumer, too.
Do you drink twyrine?
I do.
How long have you been drinking it?
What, are a you a doctor too? Have you all conspired to ask me the same questions? Or am I having a deja vu? Eh, no, I get it. All of you are the same person, right?
"All of us" who?
The touchy-feely girl and the guest-star scientist. All that's missing is my pulse measured and a kiss on the forehead. Yes, I am healthy, thank you very much.
Don't worry. I'm not going to kiss you on the forehead.
That much is obvious.
Does it help?
It helps with inspiration, wish I could say the same about the heart rate. It is also a great way to deprive yourself of memory, which is often a very useful quality.
Actually, temporary amnesia comes with bad brain vessels.
Why is it that you hate me so much?
You smell of blood.
Oh! You've got a keen nose.
I've got a keen heart.
I'm coming to see the Bachelor.
You'll have to bear with the smell of blood for as long as I have business to discuss with your tenant.
Blood smells like smoke. It smells of memory, knowledge, and ancient religion.
Heart? My favorite part.
Stop it... I want you to stop coming to my house!
And empty eyes.
What are you burning in here? Is it harl or something?
Heh! We're arming ourselves. Testing the improvised grenades. Smoke grens, they need care too. And we're also burning the fur.
Fur? What fur?
Our animals' fur. We're combing them! But we've known each of them since the first day of their lives. It's nothing to worry about.
Sounds quite suspicious, what with the news about the outbreak.
And what kind of animals are they?
Dogs. Cats. Rats. A wolf cub. Crows. Owls. Grass-snakes.
Bet the grass-snakes shed the most fur…
I see.
What have I done to earn your respect?
Your father was respected by us lot, so you will be too. If we get a connection, that is.
Did you know my father closely?
Heh... He never went refusin' us lot help, and that was 'nough for me. Thou shalt respect kindness more than anything else.
So you had business with him?

No way... I couldn't even get near him. He was a wise, well-respected man, your father was. Us children of dirt had no business rubbin' shoulders with a guy like this... It just feels good to have a spiritual beacon walk among us people—keepin' both himself and us in austerity.
Who could have killed him?

Nobody's got nothin' to gain from that, I think. There was a tale goin' about though… that your honourable father was plannin' to finally take the proper place—the one that belonged to the guy by the rite and the right… of birth, that is.
What place?

The place that ain't pointed at by no charters. But every single whelp in the Kin can see that invisible throne. Foreman Oyun sits it now, all comfy there like a slug on a fruit. Sittin' tight all right, but it looks mighty ugly…
I see.
Planning? What do you mean?

I mean what I say, mate. He has stated his willingness to do just that. Aye, you think nothin' of it. 'Twas not about ambition, 'twas only unavoidable fate. He must've foreseen hard trials comin'. And here they are! The Kin is all locked up, and the Sand Dirt's leakin' from every crevice.
Is that so…
Well, keep yourself in good health, will you!
Same to you.
We'll see.
That is true.
Those were unexpected words from you.
Do you?

I have already heard that Saburov hates you. Katerina has scared him witless with her prophecies. It seems that he believes you to be more terrible a creature than shabnak-adyr herself. If he gets absolute authority, we will have to hide you. He will demand we turn you in.
How can he get absolute authority?
Isn't his authority absolute already?

Of course not. The town is governed by three families, just like before. The Saburov's position has grown stronger since mom died, however, since Katerina is the only Mistress left. Oh, I wonder how much longer I have to wait…
What does Saburov want?

Katerina is a weak Mistress. She can see the future, but I doubt she can change anything. Nor can she grant others strength like mom did... Saburov wants to make up for her weakness with his power. He wants to rule alone and with an iron fist.
How can he do that?
He will do so on the pretext of curbing the epidemic. Have you heard what the Bachelor has announced?
When is this likely to happen?
It depends... If the Bachelor's suspicions are correct, it could even happen tomorrow. Hopefully it never does.
Hopefully.
A Bride. A true Bride now. I was but a girl yesterday. Now I dance with the Earth, sing to the herbs, and lure swevery out in the open with my very whisper.
Do you gather herbs?

No. Gatherers gather herbs. I merely live. I caress the Earth, I kiss the Earth, I nourish it with my warmth. Every night I run through the herbs naked and sing lullabies to them. Every night demands a different lullaby. Every herb demands a different lullaby. I know them all. I know how to make herbs lush.
So you summon herbs from below the ground?
Not all of them. Some of them.
Your husband is a lucky man.

He will be rich, but for that—he is never to touch me. That makes him miserable. Can you see how much I love him? Could it be that this generous summer has been conceived by my love? Herbs are everywhere; the world is a-herb; the odour makes my head spin! Herbs lull the world to sleep; my chosen one is sleeping. But I do not miss him.
Why?

My father sold me to another man, he sold me to his odongh, the one that has made camp on the other side of the river. He could have become rich; I could have become well-respected. Perhaps there will be less herbs now. Perhaps none at all.
That's too bad.

You may come into your inheritance. No one will dare get in your way. There's no proof of your wrongdoing... You may take the keys from Alexander Saburov. I can't imagine how they got into his hands... but never mind. That's the good news.
Who is this Alexander?

Pray see... I'm not the only one to bear the burden of authority in this town. The power is divided among three families: the Olgimskys, the Kains, and the Saburovs. The Saburovs are mostly in charge of… shall I say… the executive power. The enforcement machine, so to speak.
And the bad news?

The bad news. I've spoken to Saburov about your... case. And he is, to say the least, furious. It seems that he's set on destroying you by any means possible—disregarding my protection and my personal warranty of good faith.
What have I done to make him so angry?

It's not him, I think, but rather his wife. Katerina is a Mistress, a woman of a mystical gift... Her opinion is well-respected... no matter what kind of person she is. And she has had a vision of you bringing some horrific bloodshed to pass. That is the price of your ascension to glory, according to her.
Is that so? I had no plans for mass bloodshed.
Everyone has their ups and downs.

I believe you, I do... But can it really be helped? Alexander trusts his wife more than he'd ever trust me. The Saburovs' duty is to maintain order, and such a discovery about your... mission couldn't make them happy. It seems that Alexander has taken it upon himself to stop you from fulfilling this... ahem... prophecy.
Is your name enough to hold him back?

Yes—for a while... But the news of Simon Kain's death, the rumours of some epidemic... they're stirring our small town. The people are scared. Alexander is demanding emergency powers. And if he gets what he's asking for, I won't be able to help you like I do now. The Lump will not protect you then.
So what do we do?

We hope for the best. I have arranged for a hideout to be prepared—just in case... You will be able to lay low and continue your work there even if Saburov does get the power... and orders me to turn you in. The place isn't exactly comfortable, but it's reliable. It will become your home.
Thank you, boös Vlad.

Not at all... I've done so little for you... The times we live in—the mad and cruel times! But you will come into your father's inheritance. Talk to Alexander... and his wife even. Use the short break and the immunity that you have while you have them...
I'll come by later.
What of the bad news?
I will.
Are you trying to drive me away from here then?
Are you human?
Raawrrr! No hummin am I! Ha ha ha! What, does it look like I've really got a dog's head?
It does look like it from far away... Come to think of it, it's eerily realistic at close range, too. Makes me shudder a bit.
Yes! Yes! That's right! We're not called Dogheads for nothin'! Ya see, ya hobo man? No way ya can tell if it's real or not!
I came here for you, little doggy.
Oh really! You're in cahoots with them then too? No way... So, who sent ya?
Someone who's very unhappy with you. They want your blood.

Are they nuts? Why are they bullyin' me? So I did some snoopin' here and there, so what... So I did do some double agentin'... Ugh, I'm done! Don't wanna rat out the Soul-and-a-Halves to the thieves, don't wanna rat out the thieves to the Soul-and-a-Halves! I'm the only sensible person around here!
Jokes aside, kid, I've got bad news.
There is a reliable method. I can simply take that head off you along with your neck and check it out.
They say spirits used to grant heads like these to traitors in ancient times.
Why do they want you dead? This is your last chance. I don't like traitors.
Because you're going to run out of people to rat out, eh?
Have mercy on me, good man. He who saves a life will be rewarded! I just can't tell ya what they want me dead for... It would make me feel real bad. But I won't do it anymore.
Oh no, I'm done with that for reals. Done! So what do ya want?
I've come to kill you.
Shove off! You make me sick...
Who is this?

Don't finish him off, please! This is the man that tried to kill you. One of those who assaulted you at the Station. He says it was you who crippled him. He will die soon enough anyway, he's got so little blood left… Will you let him be?
How can you possibly transfuse blood to him?
