The three ruling families are completely bankrupt, however, so the so-called "Mistress" will attend the council in their stead. She will vouch for our intentions before the townsfolk.
Do you have any binding obligations towards the families in power? If so, this may become an issue tomorrow. It would be a shame if you weren't allowed to attend the proceedings. Alas, the law is the law and I won't be able to do anything about it.
Aglaya Lilich, Inq.
The Evening Letter from the Inquisitor. Day Eleven

Inhuman creatures often play human roles in our lives, wouldn't you agree? Oh, but you've failed to find one. A hybrid of man and bull… creatures of this kind inhabit myths rather than natural environments. They're not real.
I've got bull's blood for you.
Let's see.
Time is of the essence.
What do you say?

Well, it's obvious now why bulls don't get infected. Their antibodies do nothing to destroy the bacteria, but rather block them, suppressing their reproduction. They possibly die after a while—and even if they don't, the disease is still no longer lethal. Perhaps it becomes assimilated...
And the conclusion is…?
Ideally, you need some hybrid of bull and man. Human antibodies kill the bacteria, whereas bull antibodies prevent them from reproducing.
But a creature like that doesn't exist.
Yeah, I know… So you're out of luck. As am I.
Could we maybe synthesize it artificially? By combining human and bull tissues?
We could try. Unfortunately, Rubin is nowhere to be found... We'll do the test if he comes back. I'll let you know.
I'll be waiting.
That's a shame.
The stuff's rare, we sure know that. So, thirty clips'd be enough.
I need him.
You're too late, chief. We're gonna torture him now.
What for?
We have our reasons. He promised to bring us rifles 'n ammo, but brought dummies. So we're gonna ask him where he's keepin' the real stuff…
Let him go. I'll get you the ammo. How much do you need?
Go ahead. Good riddance.
Are you nuts? I'll get as many as I can, but how about having reasonable expectations?
I don't think so, chief. The deal was thirty. Ya'll have your Bachelor when we have our part of the deal.
Okay. Have it your way.
Those are real service rounds, eh?
You can check.
Burakh's word.
Do you think I can see who you are behind that mask?
You let me go a week ago. The day the Old Man died.
Let me take a closer look... Buster?
I hope they treat you better here.
Well, it ain't bad... They value what I do, sort 'o thing. Ya need help?
Let the Bachelor go.
Ah! Sure, ya can have him. Tit for tat. Lemme talk to the guys...
That's inconvenient.
You remember me, chief?
Thank you.
You're a brave guy, as I see...
What are you worrying about?
The soldiers... Do you know what they're doing?
They're not doing anything. Don't be afraid. There are posts on every corner.
They kill, burn, and rape.
No. By the children.
That isn't as funny as you might think. If those were Kaspar's Dogheads, then it's all the same—they are nothing more than little soldiers. What do they want from him?
He gave them blank cartridges instead of the service ones.
I think they want him dead.
Could you find out more and get him out of there?

I see. He did indeed collect some ammo—but he didn't want to supply the children with service cartridges. He feared they'd start shooting… Thought the Dogheads may provoke the soldiers into destroying the Tower…
They want the ammo.
Take it! He left everything he had collected here.
They want weapons.
No, I don't want to.
The First Circle?
Well, here, to the Polyhedron! We wanted to make it our fortress... Too bad it's so fragile... Nothing you can do about glass. We're afraid it might fail. Hoping for the Kains. Eh…
Is the oynon here?
What do the Kains have to do with this?
They protect us! What do you care? What are you, a spy?
I'm no spy. I need Dankovsky.

No! We took him out. He gave Khan blank cartridges instead of real ones. And swindling Khan isn't a smart thing to do—his temper is short. He let the Bachelor live for now out of respect. Perhaps the man changes his mind and spills the beans…
So, where is he now?
They took him to the Works. He'll be subject to extreme interrogation techniques there. Just tell everyone he's not here if you're asked. Especially since that's true.
Where did you take him?
Yep.
Willing to share?
What do you want?
Bring us four crowbars, and you'll have it free of charge. Four crowbars mean four dead marauders.
They shouldn't have killed Button. I told them we'd take out four of them for any one of ours.
All right then.
No, that doesn't sit well with me.
Yes, it is.
I find it puzzling that the Bachelor disregards this fact so easily. He's not as spirited as you are. Is there a way to make as much of this serum of yours as possible?
No, it isn't.
Then go to hell! Your loss.
You could be the one on your way there....
Why the hell are making a fool of me then? You've cured someone though, haven't you?
Accidentally.
Farewell, general.
Never happened.
Does the cure exist or does it not?
The source material is too rare. I've run out of ingridients.
It does not.
What is it made from?
I used aurochs blood. An aurochs is a rare creature. You can say they're extinct.
Manners, general. I'm not one of your soldiers.
I have neither time nor mood to be mannered with you. Answer the question.
It's made from the blood of a beast on the brink of extinction.
I won't.
Where did you get this blood?
At the Abattoir.
I'm not telling you.
You are if you are put to torture.
I know nothing of it.
Good. That is very good! You deserve a commendation.
Why?
Because now, thanks to you, the Inquisitor has no reason to be here. She can end her short leave and march back to the scaffold. She won't be getting in my way, and that'll make things easier for us.
To the scaffold?
What are you planning to do, general?
How much do you need?
How much? Hundreds of litres. Enough to cure everyone infected here and send an emergency batch to the Capital.
That's impossible.
Ancient blood? What is this rubbish even supposed to mean? Blood can only be living, that you don't have to explain to me. And why is the chance elusive?
I know the breed. Facing death and enduring pain come easy to them. They won't reveal the secret.
Why?
The source material is too rare.
Naturally.
I've heard that you are a Steppe man yourself. Can you gain this subterranean Foreman's trust and find out how to get the abominable blood?
That's the most curious part. Why is it still living and where is it stored?
And how are you planning to handle it once we have it?
Divine then. Whatever. It doesn't matter. What matters is that it would allow me to neither bombard a homeland town nor kill civilians.
I'll do my best.
Yes, you do your best. I am waiting to hear from you. Dismissed.
Don't take that tone with me, general.
Yessir.

I? You'll be the one to do the handling. I will simply report to the Capital—mission successful, conscience clear. Obviously, I'll do it over the head of that scheming fox that wants to outsmart us all and profit from it too. She'd have us dance to her tune and make us think we're doing out duty—while playing directly into her hands.
Don't speak bad of Aglaya.
I need results. Everything else is secondary. Do you copy?
Copy.
Fine. And leave Aglaya alone.

She's sentenced to death. Her leave here was the final chance for her to rehabilitate herself. She will be cleared of all charges if she finds a solution and wins; otherwise the verdict continues to apply. But she deserves it fully, so don't worry.
Deserves it how?
I'll keep that in mind.
That's not what we're talking about at the moment. We're talking about your cure.
I never concieved it as a tool of someone else's execution!
Isn't the possibility of creating a serum enough?
Do not forget that I—and that means you—have no more than three days for ad-libbing.
I know that.
Soon.
To kill the Inquisitor, yes. But it's not enough to save the population and localize the epidemic.
Panacea isn't poison. How are you planning to kill Aglaya with it?
It will happen automatically. If she returns to the Capital with her mission failed, she loses her head in an hour. Merry runs the bloody river and all that.
The invention of a panacea is not a failure, it's a success.

...But not her success. It wasn't she that invented the panacea, was it? Her mission, by the way, is saving the town from destruction. But if there's not enough panacea, I won't have the moral right to pull back my guns.
Do you really want to destroy the town?
No. Not at all.
Yet you want Aglaya to die.

My personal feelings are irrelevant. Only my duty is. I do indeed hate Aglaya. I can foresee her tricking me and turning my weapons against me. She will get what she wants, no matter what I do. I want her off the board—but no one's asking me what I want.
Good.
Whew.
...I have. Why?
How deep did you go?

I haven't gone far. They seized me almost immediately. I would have died a grim death if not for the Commander. The military came in the nick of time—I'm inclined to think of their intervention as of a miracle.
Was the Commander inside too?
He was. We are best friends now. Why do you ask?
Has he taken anything from the Abattoir?
Did you take... the blood from there?
I didn't. It wasn't the reason why I went there in the first place—I wanted to take a soil sample and talk to the Foreman… He didn't seem the talkative type though.
Have you taken something? Anything?
Who has?
Butchers... and those hide-clad thugs.
Where did they go?
I took no notice of it. It was dark. Also I ran inside immediately.
You are no coward, oynon.
What kind of ammo?
Military. 7'62, I think... Common military rifle ammo. I hope they shoot each other with them.
They are impossible to get!
Take the ones I left at Eva's—the Stillwater, first floor. They probably won't be enough, but at least we won't have to fight the riflemen. Go get them somehow.
Have you been to the Abattoir?
Later. I can't talk in the presence of these little… just get me out of here!
Oh well...
I'll try. Hang in there, oynon.
Aren't you bothered by its inhabitants?
You see, I have a theory about it... I'm surprised I haven't considered it before.
Tell me.
Later. I'll tell you if it proves true.
Be careful.
Why would I not, Elder One?
You are not brave. You are thick. I can kill you with my breath. I can kill you with my touch. I can burn you with my gaze.
Go ahed then!
I have come to ask you, Elder One.
Ask once. There is no second question.
Who killed my father?
Why?

A question heard! You will have an answer. Becaurse you want knowledge. A suckling craving meat. A spineless creature begging for a heavy burden. You will not withstand big knowledge. I know what you want to ask.
Why won't I withstand big knowledge?
You have asked once already. Get out.
Test me.
Really? And what do I want to ask you?
I made a mistake.
I see. I hear.

Your father was killed by the horn of Bos Nuhdr, a bull massive, red-skinned, his lines fomed by Suok's song. Mother Boddho's warmth, the blood in her earthen womb, or any of the Mistresses will speak to the truth of my words, for they cannot lie.
Your answer clarifies nothing.
Because you do not know how to ask. You are thick.
I wish I was sharp like you.
Who is my sacrifice, Elder One?
You will learn that in time. How can you know you are worthy of your father's inheritance otherwise?
Okay then.
I have accepted his inheritance already.
Have you? Are you content with pickings and scraps from your family's feast? If you are, then yes, you have. Ha ha ha…
Erm…
Show me what you took from the Abattoir.
Why? We need it.
You'll have to give it back.
I want to know where exactly you got it.
You can't get udurgh blood from below the ground. But you would be able to get enough from the wound if you cut the growth that's been bothering him for some time now.
Will you leave us alone if we tell you?
Deal.
No. I've come to end you.
Prepare to die now.
You may do whatever you want now. You are dead to the Kin all the same.
That's way too complicated for me, oynon. Could you please use shorter words?

Stop making fun of me. My words are way shorter than the chants of your people's backwards beliefs anyway. Anyway... Have you considered that your father may have actually had something... very complex in mind, and not simply a huge beast? Something so recondite that the only way to describe it is with that... term of yours?
What else am I supposed to think?
How do you know so much?
Leave my father alone! I don't want to hear you babble about the things you don't have the slightest idea of!
Come now, Artemy... I'm sorry if I came across as condescending. I only want to help. Remember how you helped me when I was running circles in the dark?
And you think that you can lead me out of the dark with your educated mind?

I kind of do. You shouldn't underestimate my wit. A lot of water has flowed under the bridge since I came here. I'm not so sceptical towards your Kin as I used to be. I have confirmed that your chimeras do indeed exist. I just see them... in a different light. In a plainer one.
I hope your plainness helps you—because it definitely won't help me.
But my musings can give a nudge to your train of thought. Aren't you interested in what I've found out?
Fine. Speak.
I'm not.
I've... spoken to a Mistress.
Which one? There's not a single Mistress in the town that I would trust.
Even Capella?
What do you know of such things, oynon! Do you really share my beliefs?
Then your father's will should be interpreted as a metaphor rather than a literal description…
No, it should be interpreted literally, oynon. If you don't want to see it that way, then stay out of this.
So?
Well, seems like I've accidentally found the thing that you've been looking for all this time. I'm standing on the verge of an extraordinary discovery.
Well? Don't leave me hanging.

I'm going to play a little unfair now. I suspect there is an ancient… archeological bed, so to speak, under this town. The place where the herdsmen of old used to live before the factories were founded—when the Abattoir was twice as tall as it is now.
And?
...Why did you have to impose your conditions on me? I would've done it in good faith—for our friendship. You have offended me, oynon.

I want you to ask the Foreman about the precise location of this place and point it on the map. I only need him to tell me under which district this... bed lays. Not much, is it? Then, I'll tell you my interpretation of your father's will. I think it'll clear up your confusion.
I have my own issues with the Foreman. I can barely pry the information I need myself from him.

I'm in a tough spot myself, Artemy. Don't get me wrong. I've tried everything I could. I don't have another way of finding out what I need. What I can tell you though is I need this information to neutralize the Commander. Or would you rather have him raze the town?
No. Of course not.
You are very unlikely to help me with this, oynon.
Wrong. Block trusts me—and for a good reason, I must say. And I have good reasons to trust you. I count on your integrity.
Then help me out, Artemy, and I'll help you back. Try to make the Foreman talk, and if he doesn't... then the Commander won't have a choice but to turn this place into a pile of ashes.
Hmm… And on the Foreman's integrity as well?
Little Victoria told me that he cannot lie—just like she and the rest of those… in charge cannot.
That is most likely true.
I don't think it'll actually work out.
Tell me what you want to know. You can ask me one question. Choose wisely.
Who did my father have in mind? What is this udurgh creature marked by this brand?

That creature is all that you see around you. The Earth and the settlement nurtured by it—from the Abattoir, the house of Bos Turokh and the Vein of Boddho, to the Gorkhon river. They cannot be separated. The town cannot live without the Earth feeding it. The Earth cannot live without the parasite feeding it. A question answered.
What sacrifice am I meant to make?
You will learn that tomorrow if you pass the next trial, Kindred One. Don't get ahead of yourself.
Any body contains a world.
Yours doesn't. Mine doesn't. The world in your head is not a world, it is mould.
He did.
I have another interpretation of the term.
Do you?
I think that the mysterious sigil in Isidor's will stands for Simon Kain. Your father's friend. A suprahuman. The creator of this town, an architect of inhabited worlds.
Is that so?

I'd like to know what the Olgimsky girl thinks about my interpretation. Capella. I would also like to have the opinion of a person whom I'm not allowed to visit under any circumstances, Katerina Saburova. I want to study this hypothesis at length. Maria may be biased. Ask these women, Artemy. If you're the one doing the asking, they'll talk.
What exactly should I ask them about?

Ask if Simon can be the udurgh. Let it be a general question, a simple yes or no in response will suffice. They're... tricky ladies. They seem to know everything about us in advance... yet their knowledge is vague and devoid of specifics. They see very far and very little... But they'll know what you're talking about.
Can the Foreman lie?
...I don't know. I don't think he can. If he doesn't want to tell the truth, he'll just gloss over the issue.
Is he dangerous?

Very much so! Talking to him is a constant risk. I think he is only waiting for an opportunity to get rid of you. But he doesn't have the heart to just go through with it. So he's waiting for permission...
I'll keep that in mind.

I wouldn't call Simon himself that. He was born a man after all; man and udurgh are different... Had Simon been reborn though, had he transferred his spirit to a new vessel—a body huge, perfect, and able to let others in… then he could have been called that.
Is that possible at all?

I doubt that. But in theory… You're talking about the local ideas and myths, are you not? An "udurgh" is not the same thing to us these days that it used to be to the Steppe people before. An udurgh is an idea now.
Do you think the longmark symbol my father used referred to an idea?
Ah, so that's what you are talking about... Of course it didn't! Your father most likely meant exactly what the Steppe myths do. But creatures like this no longer exist… I don't think they ever have.
What you're saying is…
If they have never existed, perhaps one day they will? Who knows.
I don't think so.
Speak to the Mother Superior about that. She knows more about udurghs. Perhaps she even knows what exactly your father meant.
Are you sure?
An udurgh is a living creature. A deity of sorts. It has have a glimmer of life in it. It has to be able to be born and die. A man can probably be an udurgh for worms and germs, but ewww... so gross!
Does the word have different meanings?
An idea?

A cult, for example. Or a big family. But it's all misguided. The most important aspect of the udugrh concept is that it is a body, a corpus. Does it make sense? If Simon were to turn into a great ship carrying his people away into a better life—and he would carry them on while remaining alive—then he would become an udurgh.
Creatures like these have never existed.
I can't leave my smoke and mirrors be.
Why not?
Because I cannot lie when it comes to details... My lips literally cannot enunciate something that is untrue. Riddles and vagueness leave me a degree of freedom.
Then tell me what you can.
I know for sure that you are to destroy a woman, a beautiful woman... a woman that loves you already... Isn't that enough for you?
It isn't. That can be anybody.

A commonplace fairy-tale bit… The one whose existence you so eagerly endeavour to preserve and the sacrifice that has to be made for that are alike. They are reflections. See? I can do the mirror without the smoke... You'll know what needs to be saved when you know what needs to be sacrificed.
Tell me about my sacrifice.
What can you tell me?
Well, thankfully the last requirement excludes me at least. I hope your knives will pass me by. Look for the udurgh among the people, not the chimeras.
Can a person be an udurgh?
Some men are larger than men... Now leave me. Your presence makes me terrified. You stink of blood.
The one stinking of blood here is you, you cruel ruler!
I know what an "udurgh" is all right. Can't be so sure about the others. You can't just ask everyone around, got it? They'll tell you all sorts of stuff…
Do you know who my father had had in mind when he used that brand?
Nope... You never know! Perhaps he had nothing in mind. And nothing on his mind, too. At all!
Can it be that the udurgh is a man, Simon Kain?

Simon Kain? How is he a man? I mean yeah, of course he can—he can be anything! I don’t know for sure if he's the udurgh or not, but he had to do with it. He had grown a tumour on udurgh's body! That's what Daddy used to say. "The old man's grown a tumour on the udurgh's body." Got it?
Not really. What does that mean?

Well, I mean, he didn't do it all by himself, he had help. Mostly Dark Nina's... Oooh, I know! Maybe one udurgh smothered the other? That would make a lot of sense. Two heads can't live on one neck, as Notkin likes to say.
You are talking in riddles. Can you be a bit more straightforward?
That would make me lie! Do you want me to lie?
No, I don't.
And why not? Go ahead!
The udurgh is you!
Very funny.
How do you know that I've been asking around?
A little calf told me, uncle Burakh! My guards tell me everything.
Tell me, is it posible that Simon Kain is an udurgh rather than a man?
And how did your daddy know that?
Daddy? He knew everything, duh! He even knew how to read and write.
So, Simon had grown a tumour on his body?
That I didn't say! And neither did Daddy.
What did he do then?
What do you want?
Bring us four crowbars, and you'll have it free of charge. Four crowbars mean four dead marauders.
What are they dying for?
It's "who", not "what". For Jemmy. That sin is wholly my responsibility.
All right. I don't like that lot myself.
No, that doesn't sit well with me.
As usual.
I'd like to take a look.
A body that contains the world—what else could it mean? This is what we call the flesh of the gods that inhabit the earth, holding its bones and its blood and its sky and its living brood.
Can a spirit be called an udurgh?
Why are you asking me? It is I who should be crawling before you, beggind for answers…
Yet I am asking you.

You are testing me, heir. I understand. Obviously a spirit cannot be an udurgh—it's rather the opposite of the word. The "udurgh" brand literally means "flesh" or "a vessel"—something that the spirit lies within. Something that's essential for the spirit to be able to walk this earth.
Why indeed. I have nothing more to ask.
What do you think of those who consider an udurgh to be nothing more that an idea, a symbol? Who claim that it's applicable to any creature whose mind has come to know the size of the Universe?

I'd call that person a nursling that is yet very far from becoming a Mistress! I know who's whispering this nonsense in your ear. Don't you listen to the Olgimsky girl! ...Or perhaps I'd call this person a heretic that laughs at our fathers' beliefs. Then this person deserves death.
Enough. I get the point.
I don't want to kill children of Boddho.
Then I'll send Worms after them. When they return, I will answer their questions.
They won't ask for knowledge.
That will be of no difference to you. Knowledge should be paid for in blood. Pay, and you will get it—along with a gulp of Bos Primigenius's blood.
I will be back later.
All of them?
Yes.
Could you be more specific?

The settlement is dying, fool. Your father knew that the town would be attacked by the plague. He thought not of the people, the tiny parasites on the skin of Bos Turokh, but of the udurgh, a creature so huge that moon catches its sight and changes its shape into a crescent to greet its counterpart, with its flesh proudly spread upon the Earth!
Are you telling the truth?

You are not only thick, but impudent as well. Your question is so preposterous that it is not a question at all. How am I to lie, Halfblood One? Neither he who wants to imagine a tall tale, nor he who wants to conceal the truth can tell a lie. Our nature is the warden of our conscience.
Are you saying that men are incapable of telling lies?

He who has abandoned his roots is living a lie with every minute of his existence. But a child of Boddho cannot lie. Why, Burakh? What is he who is nurtured by the Vein of Boddho to fear? What is he who has grown into Bos Turokh's flesh to be ashamed of?
I have heard the answer to my question, Elder One.
What exactly have they betrayed?

He who takes this blood from the depths of the House of Boddho is ripping at Mother Suok's flesh! They have bared a sharp knife, cutting themselves off from Bos Turokh's body. They are not longer Kin to us. They can die.
Why did they steal the blood?
You ask too much, son of Burakh. I thought you wanted to ask me one question today—the one which is worth a thousand others. Do not waste your breath on idle words.
The spirits will talk to me?

I will give you a drink now. You will feel hunger at once. You will feel pain. You will go to the Ragi Stone and fall asleep against your hunger pangs. You will sleep until a spirit tells you what their trail smells like. Then you will find them. You will kill them. You will return.
Do I absolutely have to kill them?
No, I won't do that.
How can I find them?
How am I to find them?

A hungry man has a better sense of smell. You must be hungry to kill them. Hunger cleanses. Food desecrates you. Bringing back the sacrificial blood isn't worth it with a stomach full of food. The blood will return dirty and won't do us any good.
Will I be allowed to eat when I kill them?
When you bring back the blood and get it back. Not before that.
Where are they?
What will become of this blood when I bring it back?
When it is cleansed, I will give it to you.
Where are the butchers?
What is that drink?
It will cleanse your guts. To bring back the blood, you must be clean. Don't you dare take any food. If you take as little as a bite, blame yourself.
I won't drink your poison.
I'm sorry.
Rest in peace.
What's going on? Are they shooting again?
No. You must be hearing things.
Come in, good sir. They are waiting for you.
Whoa… You are uncannily polite.
What are you waiting for, good sir? Come in! Even we have no power over the passing of the local time.
I will come in when I feel like it.

Ripper!
We thought we should write, because you don't seem to be listening to what we tell you! You've gotten completely out of hand!
As of late you keep doing whatever you please. This is unacceptable. You are spoiling the game.
If this letter reaches you in good time, do come to the Polyhedron. They will let you inside. Keep your eyes tightly closed, descend to the bottom, and say: "Three, four, five." Open your eyes.
We'd like to have a little chat with you.
The People Who Own You
A Letter from the Powers That Be

Please do come by to meet us at the Theatre if you have a spare minute.
We'd like to have a rather inconsequential but mature talk with you.
We apologize in advance for the inconvenience.
The People Who Executed the Whole Thing
A Letter from the Makers

Our fate will be decided today.
There are so many things I want to tell you, but would never dare to utter... I'd rather not write you at all than influence your decision. The one thing I am fully convinced of is that your father's inheritance, denoted by the sign of the Udurgh, is the town itself; the settlement made of three parts: Earth, the Knots, and the Stone Yard.
Everything else I would expect you to know already.
We won't see each other before the Council. This is how it has to be.
Whatever you choose—I will understand it.
A.
Aglaya's Letter

Artemy Burakh!
If what I am told is right, you must be the only physician of some moral integrity in the town. You are the only one to have avoided any dealings with the wretched Inquisitor, a fact all the more confirmed by her trying to give me the opposite impression.
I am somewhat confused, so I believe the best I can do is to go with your decision whatever it is. The proceedings are to begin at seven in the Cathedral. Before six-thirty you may find me at the Town Hall.
Alexander Block, Fourth Army Commander
Block's Letter

I know you are interested in pairs, oppositions, and other meaningful similarities, so let me remind you of something.
The first pair should be read as follows: if the udurgh your father spoke of is the town, then the Polyhedron is your sacrifice. There is no other way, since the two are correspondent to each other. Crush the Polyhedron—and rivers of blood will flow, the underground ichor emerging from within the hollow rod on which the Tower stood.
The second pair means: if Aglaya is your sacrifice, then Simon is your udurgh. In this case you have no other choice but to protect the Polyhedron.
I am staying in the left wing of the Termitary, come and see me if you please. My plan is the only one that is feasible.
Nothing will have to die.
Clara's Letter

This is to remind you of how the Inquisitor has deceived you in regard to the udurgh, which is none other than Simon Kain, the last patient your father ever had.
I am well-prepared to explain the situation to Block, although as of now I have had no such possibility because of the mutiny. The logic behind the whole affair is quite straightforward: if we destroy the town, the Inquisitor dies. If the Inquisitor dies, the Polyhedron will be saved.
Every fibre of this woman's being is dedicated to one purpose: eliminating the Polyhedron. She would not hesitate to die if this would lead to the destruction of the Tower. No one can vouch for its safety while she is alive.
If the Polyhedron remains intact, Simon's existence would likewise be protected, and the supreme creature your father spoke of will be formed. You will fulfil your father's dying request and in doing so resolve the whole situation.
I hope you may see that my logic makes sense, even if my presentation is muddled.
D. D.
P. S. Please find an opportunity to see me if you require further proof of my correctness.
The Bachelor's Letter

I was. If I'm captured and taken off the board, then the Commander will be free to make his move. If you choose Capella's path, then I'll live. If you choose Clara's or Bachelor's path, then you'll lead me to the scaffold and fulfill your purpose.
I'm confused. What should I do?
Were you really lying to me?
It's not my place to advise you. Any word I say will be considered an action. I want you to be free. You are the only one here who is stronger than me.
I never told you the whole truth. Is that a lie?
Yes.
No.
I'll follow my heart.
These powers than barred us from seeing each other in the morning—what were they?
Have you been to the Polyhedron? The Theatre? You haven't, have you?
No.
How does Capella's path save you?
What about the Commander?
He is my equal. And I become stronger before him, but before you I weaken...
Right...
Die, Inquisitor. Here and now I shall fulfill my destiny and inherit my father's burden. You are my sacrifice.
Speak to her yourself. But she is the only one who can help you keep this town alive. And this is essential for saving me.
What's the price of this solution?

You know the answer. The Polyhedron—the cause of the Plague—will be destroyed. That is what Alexander Block demanded. He has to spend some ammo for his report. The town will survive... that is my pardon warrant. This is how you fulfill your destiny.
I kept from you my desire to crush the evil Tower. But you could say I had no obligation to reveal that…
As you wish.
What, you surrender just like that? Or are you keeping some hidden ploy as a last resort?
I won't fight you… They chose just the right weapon. Anyone else I would have led into a trap—but before you I stand meek and silent. Do what you have to do.
Go to the Capital. Your well-earned punishment awaits you there.
Wait. Let me collect my thoughts…
So the butchers are expecting your murder. And then what, they let me reach the sacrificial blood?
...And make you their ruler. Foreman of the Cult and head of the Kin. You will restore the Kin and bring the town back to life—after you take the place that should have been your father's.
Do I really have a choice then?
You do, and you know it. I'm so happy you didn't have to learn it from me!
I know nothing.
Fine. I'll think it through.
Nothing? Then I will stay silent. Let Capella speak.
What does she really want?
What is the Bachelor's choice?
Talk to him. There is still time.
And yet?

The Bachelor intends to exact his revenge on me for... using him. He wants to do it all the other way round—demolish the city, keep the Polyhedron. If you lead him to victory, you may consider your sacrifice made. You return to the exultant butchers, triumphant.
I'll ask him myself.
No. This won't happen.
But... the sacrifice?
My head is splitting. Two possible variants of my life have now crossed.

I feel for you. It's one of these moments when no one but you can decide what was your destiny. Choose a future, choose a past. You are free. You are the only free man I see here. It's how I fell in love with you.
The town is my udurgh. Then my sacrifice must be the Polyhedron. You are my sacrifice. Then my udurgh must be Simon, preserved insidethe Polyhedral shell.

The destruction of the Polyhedron is quite an adequate sacrifice. The butchers may bar you from reaching the blood, but you'll be able to take it on your own... Although I should refrain from offering you any advice. My advice is dangerous.
I must think now.
Wait here. I'll go and speak to the others.
What is Clara's choice?

Speak to her yourself. She offers a miracle… for a high price. A bloody price. Their will is now enslaved by the mirror trap. They know not what they do, these... madmen. The Tower turned them into benevolent murderers. For this is the true purpose of it—to bring death and sorrow.
I'll talk to her.
Yes, that's true.
You didn't tell me you were the sacrifice the Kin expected.

See? You found out everything all by yourself. I never resisted you. Trust me, all I had to do to keep you in the dark was endeavour to do so. Imagine—you make your sacrifice, and at first you don't even notice that the butchers never accepted your offering to the Earth. And then, one day, you do… But I'm far away by then.
I believe you.
No. I still don't believe you.
And that means what? We are all toys?
But the udurgh is no man. The thing you save and the thing you sacrifice must be proportionate to each other.
Simon was almost human. And me—I'm not quite human. Haven't you already had a chance to convince yourself of that?
How?
Tell me, did the heavens open up? Did the Focus of this town show? Did these… hands… reveal themselves?
I don't understand.
Oh, that... And how are you different from the rest?
Because I am a doll that is smarter than its children. I'm a bit closer to them than… to you. You might call me half divine.
I can't and I won't agree with that.
And so all the pieces fall into place.
So you're a product of imagination. A made-up illusory creature. You don't exist. You have a fate, but not a future.
Yes. Exactly. Not a pleasant surprise?
I thought I was a person.
I didn't know myself at first either. My only advantage was that their mother took me to bed with her when she was young. I know many things they don't.
So you are older than me?

Never thought about it. It's not like we have age. New ones are better than the old, that much I know for certain. But they restuffed me not long ago and made me a new dress—see? That probably makes you a bit older than me.
What did we ever do to them?

Me? They hate me. And I loved them so dearly all my life… when they were still little babies, I dreamt about how they will grow up one day and finally start playing with me… Instead they loathed me from the very start. Was it because their mother wanted them to like me?
And the Plague—is it a game they play?

No. The town is a toy, but the Plague is real. Go outside, walk the streets… you'll see. Their make-believe has nothing to do with it. They are scared to death themselves. They just came home from a funeral… I don't even know who died yet. Maybe that's the real cause of all this?
I refuse to believe that!
Who said that? I can hear the voice… but I don't believe it is the voice of my beloved.
It's me, the player. Wanna chat?
No. I don't. I want to be with Burakh. Go away.
You misheard. Doesn't matter. Keep looking at the Haruspex. It's a nice model.
Did you fall in love with him because he was free? But that wasn't him; it was me. When I leave, he'll turn into a stuffed dummy—same as everyone else around you…
Fine. I'm leaving.
...Really?
No, no. Just tempting you.
Yes.
Get out of here! Scram! I won't talk to you any more. I need my Haruspex.
As you wish.
Hey, gorgeous? Hey…?
Which means damn you to hell!
Can I fix this still?

There's very little time left. Only fifteen portions of the concoction could have been produced. If you've collected them all, then good for you! You're welcome to make the rounds. Offer the medicine to the vulture-faced corpsebringers standing watch by the doors, waiting to hear the owners' last breath... All is not lost yet.
Wait for me.
We are not going to wait for too long though. Time is in short supply. You have until ten o'clock.
Go to hell!
That is precisely what I mean! You are incredibly sagacious, Artemy Burakh.
What? At least one? You gotta be kidding me…
We have every right to do this, too. It's our Theatre, not yours, isn't it?
Okay. I'll bring your actors back to you.
Don't try to bribe them into leaving their posts. Don't stoop to begging. Guarding your dying is a pleasure to them, not a burden.
They are not mine.
That much is obvious…
Oh yes they are…
Up yours...!
I'll find another way.
Fine, I'll find another way.
You pricks!
Not from this distance. That is out of the question.
Then wait for me at the Cathedral.
What happens if I don't come to the Cathedral?
The Inquisitor and I will have a conflict.
Take my advice. Beware of the Inquisitor.
Why?

No matter how hard you struggle, an Inquisitor will always find a way to trick you, and there's nothing to be done about it. An Inquisitor can always use you in their interests so that you won't even notice it. And that's exactly what is going to happen to us all today.
Why is the Inquisitor so dangerous to you, general?
Officially I don't have the right to fire unless she or even that Bachelor provide me with a detailed report on the hazard situation.
So?

I suspect that the young fox has concealed her major arguments, waiting to reveal them at the last minute. She will most likely do it in such a fashion that I'll have no out and won't be able to open fire. I'm not barbarous. I have no intention to kill civilians unless there are no other options.
You seem to have enough artillery not to fear a single woman.
I'll keep that in mind.
I've heard that one before—and I've already given an answer. I will do as my conscience tells me to. If this aligns with someone else's schemes, so be it.
That is good to hear.
I will come to the Cathedral.
As a matter of fact, I'm fine right here.
Do you support the Bachelor?
Yes, he seems to have reasonable suggestions.
Like what?
Speak to him yourself, surgeon. He is back at his place, I think.
I wanted to talk to you.
The Bachelor can speak for himself. As for me, there's nothing to speak about.
Fine.

So, Burakh the healer. Your father used to be the leader of the local cast community, which is important to me—it was neither greed nor plotting nor circumstance that has informed your choice, but your conscience alone. I've been given orders to level everything here. But if that's not necessary, I am willing to trust your judgement, risking my life and honour, for I am merciful. Where shall I point the weapon?

True. That's what I've been told... Victoria Olgimskaya, styled the White Mistress despite her young age, confirms that you are capable of accomplishing this goal. The people you have saved support your claim. Act then. The cannons will rumble at ten to twelve. Evacuate the children from there by ten.
It will be taken care of. Aglaya will give orders. This is my choice.
Speak, Clara. Artemy Burakh! Are you sure you have nothing else to tell me?
I'm sure, commander. I've made my choice.
You only have to destroy the Polyhedron to put an end to the disease spreading. There's no point in razing the whole town.
There's no need to destroy anything. We can do altogether without gunfire and preserve this world as it is.
Look, look! Haruspex is here! He's so big! How did you find us? Oooh, so lifelike… and sooo angry!
I want you to tell me everything.
No problem. What do you wanna know?
What diabolical game are you playing?

Look! It's a magic sandbox! See how it reflects in the mirrors? It's because everything's for real there! Here's a town, we've made it out of sand. And there's this awful thing going on there—an EPIDEMIC! So it's all crumbling… the town is falling apart… But we've sent heroes there to fix it.
To fix it?

It's rotting, see...? Eww. We hoped they'd think of something. Mure it in sand, at least… They're magical to, you know, the heroes are! Take you, for example—look how it all worked out! You used to be a doll and now you're alive. Perhaps the rest also work like this?
Did you know that your dolls were alive?

Everything is alive around here! It's this structure, it brings things to life. it's not like we're twisting anyone's arm... It just happens. All on its own. We only built the town—and then it became miraculous all on its own! And the dolls… We just stuck the throwaway ones in, they were lame anyway. Oops, sorry...
Don't you touch anything else around here. And don't stick anything there anymore!
Just—just don't you dare crush anything here. I'll try to fix it.
And what are you going to do now?

Heal the town, please! Just look, it's so wonderful... It's alive and it's our favourite one... We won't be able to make another one like this. If it can't be helped, then it will disappear forever. You know how much we love it?
I didn't think you could love at all.
Indeed. I agree with you on this.
So how did you go about sending the heroes?
Show me your sandbox.
You little pricks! Tell me everything you know before I beat the living hell out of you!
Hey, hey, you keep your hands to yourself... Little doll! A litle doll smarting around!
Who are you?
We didn't touch anyone! We're playing town here! It's so fun, you know. You are there too! Well, we thought you were there, but you turned out to be real...
So you thought I was a plaything?
No! You aren't our plaything anymore.
Now that I've found out about you, you are my playthings.
We'll do as you say.
Go home and try to start things over tomorrow.
The sand is wiser than you.
Show me your sandbox.
Yeah. I know how fun it is.
A doll? Me?
Yeah... Well, you personally have grown a bit big…
I'll rip your heads off.
Don't be upset. Being a toy is also nice.
But why did you play it like this?
Well, we did need to find some use for you. We never liked you all that much anyway… You've always been the scary doll. Playing with you was no fun.
So you stuck the throwaways into the thick of it.
The ones that could fix things! You can't always have a Smart Doctor Man at hand. That's just how the game goes. Will you help us heal the town?
I will.
Get the Commander out of there.
That's impossible now! We can't. Mirrors make it all very complicated. You can't take your move back once you've made it—these are the rules of a real live game.
I'd rather it was an unreal dead game.
Then just don't touch anything.
Get the Inquisitor out of there.
I'm afraid you will never know if that's true.
I hope I can still switch places with you some day.
Everything happens.
Then you will know what it's like being a toy in the hands of a monster.
Only I will be more humane.
The hero is a doll, but so are the children. The real game is what's happening between you and us.
I cannot leave Haruspex's body. You are imposing your limits upon me.
Haruspex has lost his battle for freedom since the very day he was born. What about you?
I wanted to stop the epidemic.
But did you understand what the epidemic really was?
A toy danger that has ravaged a toy town.

Was the disease the true evil though? The disease is only a method. The evil's weapon—just like a scalpel is yours. The disease will go, devouring itself. Then there'll be war, famine, heresy. Was it really worth the effort? Look around.
All this—for a single wretched town?
No. It was the town that had been built for you, not the other way round. We apologize if it's been a disappointment.
I still don't get it.

It had been built so that you could make your final choice now. We are observing you. Everyone who makes it to midnight will have made a choice—one way or another. We want to see what yours looks like. You stll have a chance to change your mind.
I've made it already.
Good—if it really was you. The only enemy, the only evil in this story, you see, is called Inevitability...
I will be the one to say the final word.
I don't care about that.
So you're curious as to what fate I will choose for the town?
We have to make sure that it truly is you who is making the decision. Are you absolutely positive that your choice is not predetermined by anyone or anything?
I am.
Could it have been otherwise?
Oh, absolutely. When every step you take has been predicted, you are still free to either take it or not. When it has been foreseen, however, you remain a mere puppet in someone else's hands.
Being my puppeteer is way to good a position for you.
I don't care. I will do as I see fit.
That is precisely what we are waiting for.
I will be the one to say the final word, not anyone else.
I know now that it was all a children's game in a glass sandbox. But what for?
Haruspex is my hands and nothing more. I wanted to see if I can make it.
That's what we're interested in as well! Can you make it or can you not? Can you make—what, exactly? Could you not have made it?
I've made it. I managed to destroy your poisonous evil that has spread thin across the world.
You see how sad our fortune is. We put all our hopes in you! We poor actors were hoping you'd become the director of a new show—the old one has been beaten to death. But you turned out to be a doll…
But I am not a doll.
Did I hear you right? Who is it speaking?
It's me, the player.

Oh! Then I apologise profusely... You are definitely not a doll, but that seems to be unhelpful for our hero now. He is humiliated, crushed, but most importantly he is deprived of the power that we have all hoped for. By the way, are you still willing to take responsibility for him?
Yes. He is my responsibility. I will stay with him to the very end. His words shall be my words. His deeds shall be my deeds.

Oh... Then I apologise once again. Perhaps not all is lost yet. Let's wait for the finale and see if the day brings any surprises. We still have a chance to play in a drama with an unpredictable story.
Watch me act.
Yes. And highlight Haruspex better. It's my solo now.
No. I don't need a humiliated, crushed, and powerless hero. I'm fed up with it all, actually.
As you wish. Then with all due respect we will treat him accordingly. If you wish to leave him, then he will not be able to accomplish anything we could worship him for.
Yes. That is what I wish.
No. Do as you wish.
It's me, the Haruspex.
That was a blow for me too. I thought I was a human being…

It's high time we make choices. As for me, before the artillery starts firing, I'm packing my belongings and leaving this town, having grabbed some people I want to save. I could have found my own solution, but I don't have the time…
Who are you planning to grab?
A few people. They will assist in building a new town.
What would your solution be?

I could make them destroy the Settlement along with the Bull Project—yet the Polyhedron would remain. Block assured me he'd fire a strike so precise that the other shore of the Gorkhon wouldn't be scathed. "The river will swallow the plate," he said.
The people will die if we destroy the town.
So that's what the true price of your choice was! Do you have any idea as to what happens now?

What happens now? Now the efforts of thousands of people, the energy of a wonderful family, and the talent of genuis creators will collaborate to construct a real-life miracle; a miracle capable of pushing humanity towards a new breakthrough and granting us the capability to produce things of genuine beauty.
So, a new Utopia is going to be built here?

Yes. I find it remarkably fascinating, damn it! You know, daring endeavours of this kind seem almost extinct in the modern times… small wonder we're losing the war. People are evolving to become boring and shallow. History passes us by, paying little notice. The world strives to move forward, but we're not pushing it! A shame.
If the Polyhedron alone caused so many deaths, how much evil will a whole city of incarnated miracles beget?
But the price!
Everything has a price. Kaina's triumph promises to be ruthless but fruitful. This place is remote; but when a phantasmagoric garden blooms here, it'll give birth to a new Renaissance.
Rather a lot. Let's be realistic here. Does this mean, however, that we—all of us, the humanity, I mean—should abandon our attempts, efforts, and search? You'll never convince me of it.
The truth is older than we are. There's no point in trying to invent it. Just repeat after the days of old…
Are you aware that we turned out to be toys?
Really? You're kidding... Though figuratively speaking… That is true—after a fashion. We are all mere toys in the hands of Providence.
No, oynon, I mean literally. You are a toy. I am a toy. We are mere dolls made of rags, sawdust, whalebone, and hell knows what else.
Have you gone mad?
No. My eyes were opened. You have owners. They are children. The game they're playing with us is almost over.
I hope my side wins!
No. You lose. They don't love us, by the way. They're fed up with us. That's why we're stuck here… they've stuck us here.

Very witty, Burakh. Forget it; my laboratory is beckoning to me from the Capital! I can't for too long entertain the thought of it also being a dollhouse. I'm an adult man that has responsibility to bear, you see. I invent medicine that helps with old age and death.
...Out of nuts, syrup, and sleeping pills stolen from the adults. Don't make me laugh.
Enough. This isn't funny any more.
You've failed to grasp anything at all…
Oh, look around. There's no one left alive except for the two of us. The infected ones don't count; they have less than twenty-four hours to live in any case.
I could at least help them.
A new town? What's going to happen to the old one?

Really? Then could you please make it so that I could show up at the Council and present the Commander with arguments in favour of the following arrangement: the corrupt town disappears from the face of the earth, and the Polyhedron stays. It's aseptic and... damn it, it's simply worthy of preserving!
I like your decision, oynon. Let Simon be the udurgh.
What do you need to do so?
No. Not happening.
Wait for me.
I'm not ready to make a choice yet.
That is wise. You will have neither a second chance nor a replay option. I advise caution.
I'll keep it in mind.

She lied to me. Fooled by her, I was acting on her prompts the past few days—and I even encouraged others to do the same. My discovery has been reinterpreted and presented in a fashion that has turned truth into lies. I've been violated.
I will make my own choices.
Then why did you bring me here at all? I don't get it. I'm giving you solid advice and you are not listening.
Worry not, oynon.
So what?

Think you're in a better position? She has simply chosen a different tactic for each of us. She has abused my hate and anger. She has abused your love and sense of commitment. I wonder what she did to get to Clara—if she found the Changeling worthy of her schemes at all...
...because you're smarter than me, oynon. Is that what you wanted to say?
Let's put it this way: because I am more predisposed to logical thinking.
...And what do you suggest?
If you are still fooled by her, how come you speak so confidently? What if it's also a part of her plan?
And what do you suggest?
I suggest you use the chance she is giving you... Or—or do the unexpected. Although… What if she sees through that too? It's scary to think how far her acuity goes…
Really?
Perhaps I tend to demonize her—but I am furious about what happened to me…
...And you want to keep the Polyhedron intact just to spite her.

Yes and no. The Polyhedron and the Inquisitor are mutually exclusive. The Polyhedron will stand if she's gone—and vice versa. I suggest you end her. That's how we can keep one of history's greatest monuments for the humankind. It's a sprout of our future.
I see your point.
It was lucky enough to reveal her plots—I think that's because I'm…
Okay, I get it.
How do you suggest we destroy her?
Destroy the town. That will be her death sentence. She is responsible for it before the Powers That Be.
I understand.
I think we should finish her. Block is a tool in our hands, but we are still her tools.
I've heard all this before. I am not a tool, oynon. I can tell you that with utmost certainty.
The world isn't as simple as you think, Burakh. I know how to arrange it so that both the town lives and the Polyhedron stands. It will all be just like it used to be!
And how will you arrange that?
It's a secret. Something has to be sacrificed anyway… a lot, really… but these are things that actively want to disappear off the face of the earth. Nothing to regret about.
Curious. What are these things?

What do you care? They are but fuel that would allow to preserve the old state of being. Oh, the Powers That Be will be delighted. They really shouldn't have persecuted me! I could have offered them a wonderful gift.
What do the Powers That Be have to do with this?

Whatever the Powers That Be claim, they don't really care about the disease. The town, the town, the town—in the precise state it's existing in now—that's their primary concern. The town whose juices flow to feed the blooming and active Polyhedron!
And you think you could arrange that?
...A chimera! A greedy, insatiable chimera. I'm so happy it's not you who is to make a choice, Changeling.
What's the cost?
Yet another secret! Curiosity killed a cat. My word is enough. I will keep it. I am a mystical creature. I am a Mistress!
Are you now?

I could arrange it so that everything stays the way it used to if I could get into the Cathedral and look the Inquisitor in the eye. But I can't. I have to care for my… confidants. They have put their faith in me already, you see. I cannot abandon them now.
Wait for me. I'll take care of your outcasts.
Turns out that you're a toy, Clara. And I'm a human being.
Of course I am! Were you not?
I wasn't… and you're so calm about it!
How long were you aware of that?
I'm aware of something else, too. I am. Almost everyone we've come across in the past few days are toys—honest to God toys. But some creatures here are more intricate…
Who?

You and me, for example. You surely understand quite a lot about yourself—you feel a powerful will standing behind you... And I'm going to surprise you quite a lot, tee hee… What would you have done if you knew beforehand?
I would have acted more confidently.
I would have shot myself.
Lil' puppets we are, true… but it's not the puppet that matters, but whose hands control it! Have you seen them?
I have.
They probably think themselves so big? Think they're real human creatures, lil' baby kids, don't they?
…Aren't they?

I wouldn't be so sure! I have a gut feeling about it! That's my knack, what can you do. And the Bachelor is probably still thinking he's a bachelor, doesn't he? Hahaha… He would have got on very well with those kids!
I doubt that.
Tell what you know!
I have already told you everything. I don't know anything—but I sense a lot. See you, Ripper!
See you…
Are you sure?
I am.
No, not really.
Why? Look at your hands. Are they really yours? No, not these ones... Now count them. Are there exactly two and not four? Hahaha…
That's not funny.
Do not pretend to be alive.
I'm not pretending. But you shouldn't have called me a toy… I'll make you regret that… Tell me, who am I really? What do you think?
A doll.
...The Plague.
A miracle-maker.
No. That is my doppelganger. My twin sister.
So I was mistaken.
Whatever I choose, you will immediately change your essence. Is that what you're hinting at?
I'm in your head now! This is what I'm hinting at. I am you!
Whatever! I'm in no mood to argue…
Fine. Score one for you.
So I'm not human. That gives me a huge advantage over you.
Why?
Because you think I'm a toy. I know who you are, but you don't actually know who I am. So I have an advantage.
How so?
Who were you fighting all this time? Oh you human…
The plague.
The inevitability.
Was I fighting you...?
Do you realize now that you have lost? And there's nothing to be done. It's too late.
All right. Let's go to the Cathedral.
I'm tired of you! Your lies are so crafty it's too easy to mistake them for the truth. Even the Inquisitor is less skilled than you…
Just wait a bit more.
I would still like to know how you're going to keep the town intact.

Burakh, Burakh...! What are you saying? I told you it's my secret. I will only reveal that to the Queens. General Alexander will never compromise, you know that full well. And if I can't persuade Aglaya that mine is the way to purge this world of plague, then nothing happens at all. What is to happen, will happen.
Seems like you have a strong influence on Block.

Even if I mesmerize him, he won't forget his procedure. Don't worry. I'll tell the Queens everything—separately, of course... But not to you. I don't want to see my secret become gossip all too quickly.
Aren't you afraid of telling the Queens?
My choice demands they destroy one another, Burakh! It's all taken care of. Don't you worry.
Now that's some news.
My choice is full of surprises, Burakh. Or did you really think this little dilemma of yours was unavoidable? An "either-or" thing?
Look at you talking... It's like you're a different person.
Perhaps it's not the same me you knew before. There is more than one me… a lot, perhaps. We've got the same pretty face—but who knows whose will is behind it right now?
Enough.
No, I won't let you choose.
What happens to Aglaya?
Aglaya will die.
Can you make it so that she lives?
No. I have no power over that. This is a mandatory part of my plan.
Then step aside and do not meddle.
Who else will die?
Look, there is no need for prying... You'll make it, don't worry.
You impudent girl! You are naïve to speak as if you've won already.
Whatever.
Why do you think that my victory's impossible without them?

You wanted to protect the town, didn't you? But the udurgh is a living being. It's a body that contains the world. And do you really think that the world can exist without activity inside? Who is going to govern it? Who will paint it different colours, tints, and shades? I will distribute these roles among the children when they come of age.
Tell me what the children I've saved are going to do until then.
The Mother Superior will start managing the Kin right away—you don't really understand their day-to-day life, do you? You can rule and guide knowledge. If will be the power of malachite and black.
Go on.

Notkin will be a scout, exploring the Steppe for now. He will also keep an eye on the Warehouses and the Station—we will have to start communicating with the big world soon. Red gold will be his colour.
Who else?
Murky will look after street improvements. The town must look pretty. I will also assign her to be in charge of the water supply and the sewage. She will become the Lilac Mistress.
Very nice.

Sticky will be in charge of commerce. He'll be the chief merchant, controlling all shops in the town and making sure everyone has everything they need. He will become a ruler later… just like all the other boys you have saved. His power will be of amber color.
Right.

Grace will keep doing her job—she'll bury the dead. They have a whole realm of their own, you know, and they need a caring hand too. She will be a Beige Mistress. The most valuable aspect of this colour is the subtle shade of dawn. A little nuance of pink and lemon...
And who'll be the head of all this?

We will enter into a marriage with Khan. This will put an end to the enmity and the disagreements of our families. We will restore the harmony of ruling. I will become a Mistress and will do what my mother used to. Khan with his army of Dogheads will rule the town. I'll make him white—as I am.
Actually, I had other plans for the future.
I am not going to force you. But I thought you'd become the new Foreman. Since you made him no more, you are the one to take his place. It is not a reward, it is your duty.
I'm leaving this place, Capella. Today. You guys rule the town without me.
What of the other kids?
A good choice.
You cannot even imagine how good it is.
But how will he deal with the thieves?
Do you really think that I, Victoria Olgimskaya, the White Mistress, will not be able to restore order? You are mistaken.
Sorry. I had no doubts about that.
So that's what the town is going to be like now...
Well, nothing to be done then.
I'm so sorry I can't break your neck.
No question escapes my lips. I am not asking anything of you.
We'll leave this place. You and me, together.
Do you have any regrets about what you have done?
No.
It's impossible to change the choice you've made now, is it not?
Yes, it isn't.
I'm looking forward to midnight!
I meant well.
Don't.
Wait and see the consequences of your choice. It will all be over by twelve.
Farewell, General Ashes.
Regret is the most honest of feelings. Who said that?
I don't think I'll be there to see it.
Why did you come?
The Bachelor is putting his hopes in you, isn’t he?
Hopes? I have no idea. What does it have to do with the Bachelor anyway? He's played his part—and is now heading off the stage. I will be in charge now.
Where is your uncle, Georgiy Kain?

My uncle will die tomorrow, after he carries Simon's soul into the Focus of the Polyhedron. He's leaving the stage too. He has already made all the choices he was supposed to make. I admire his choice.
Where is your father, Victor Kain?
My father will die today, after he carries my mother's soul into the Focus of The Crucible. He has also departed the world—I'm the head of the House of the Kains now, as you can see.
How are you going to live with this?

I have no husband to hold me back like my father did to my mother. No one can stop me from building what I intend to build—there, on the other side of the Gorkhon! The life that will be begotten here today is none of your concern. You do not know what life is—at all! And so obstain from judgement.
The door was unlocked.
Do not despair, Maria. Do not regret a thing. But you will not become the Scarlet Mistress.
Curse you!
Spare me the curses.
I am the only person here who knows what life is. At all.
Can't argue with that…
Please do not feel yourself obliged to do anything…
Who are you talking to?
I don't.
You don't have to do any of this.
Who are you talking to?
I know.
BULL'S BLOOD.

PROSECTORIUM BLOOD. The blood that Stakh Rubin had been working on for the past four days. It has an unnaturally vivid crimson colour and seems to glow with some inner light. Could such blood really flow inside a human body?

KIDNEY. Human kidney. Extracting organs from a human body is seen as a horrible blasphemy in the local tribal community. Only the menkhu are allowed to do this because they have an ancestral right to cut living bodies. However, some gatherers and also the Hunchback from the Atrium district would be willing to trade for something this rare...

INFECTED KIDNEY. Menkhu know how to prepare healing potions by treating organs with twyrine infusions. In this kidney, harmful microorganisms are probably winning a fight against antibodies. The composition is constantly changing. A lot depends on the stage of infection.

LIVER. Human liver. Extracting organs from a human body is seen as a horrible blasphemy in the local tribal community. Only the menkhu are allowed to do this because they have an ancestral right to cut living bodies. However, some gatherers and also the Hunchback from the Atrium district would be willing to trade for something this rare...

INFECTED LIVER. Menkhu know how to prepare healing potions by treating organs with twyrine infusions. In this liver, harmful microorganisms are probably winning a fight against antibodies. The composition is constantly changing. A lot depends on the stage of infection.

INFECTED HEART. Menkhu know how to prepare healing potions by treating organs with twyrine infusions. In this heart, harmful microorganisms are probably winning a fight against antibodies. The composition is constantly changing. A lot depends on the stage of infection.
They're expecting a sacrifice.
What kind of sacrifice?
A proportional one. I don't know what can be proportionate to the town.
Inadvertently.
The Kin is frozen with anxious anticipation. You are their hope. Perhaps they'll give you the blood now. Long live the new king—after having slaughtered the old one... What else can they do...
Maybe there are other ways to get the blood?
Perhaps you can think of one?
I have a bold idea. The brand denotes the Town—so perhaps the sacrifice should be an anti-Town? The Polyhedron? Hmm…?
How is that? Isn't it a part of the town?
No. It's a useless, pointless, poisonous abomination. If the Kin believes the Town to be the body of the Cosmic Bull, then the Polyhedron is a knife in that body.
A knife?
If only you knew what the Bachelor's found out for me... I shouldn't get carried away with the thought though. It's all conjecture. Mindgames.
I have no idea.
Have you heard the legend of blood puddles that appear by the Polyhedron base from time to time? Children stop playing and become gloomy when that happens. They think it's a bad omen.
That's none of your business, Inquisitor.
What kind of sacrifice do they expect from me?
Why do you keep asking?

Because I want the town to live. It's my duty. The Powers That Be only need the recipe, the formula to success—and the town itself can go down in fire. All they need to do is to wait for a new wave of settlers—and those will be provided with your serum from the get go, don't you doubt that. Why would they want to hear the reproaches of those who went through this hell?
I don't want to talk about this… barbarity, this savagery, this superstition. Is it possible to get the blood without making a sacrifice?
Why do you care so much?
I want to stop the plague. I want to use your panacea to save the infected. And that means we need a lot of panacea, wouldn't you agree?
I see.
A legend? How real is this one? Who can tell me more?
I don't think so. They're waiting for the sacrifice.
So how do I get to this blood without sacrificing anyone? ...Or anything? What do they want from me?!
Don't worry. The hour is nigh. Soon I will kill who they want me to kill.
A stupid idea.
Never mind. It's just a curious interpretation. The Polyhedron is like a whole town in and of itself. And children do think it's alive…
Alive? And how on earth does it deserve that title?

The Bachelor has recently become the expert on the matter... Basically, it speaks to them somehow. Reads their minds and grants them dreams. It's a machine, really, but children think it's a living machine. And they also say that it can bleed…
What?!
Stop licking my boots.
Do you remember the tale of an Orphan? A butterfly pupa helped him, and he helped her in return...
So this is your plan…
I don't know this tale.

Well there are loads of tales like that, believe me. One in three Steppe tales is about an Orphan. A robust tradition, as you can see… an Orphan is a blessed figure. You are following in well-established footsteps.
Perhaps.

That was a gesture of respect. I'm surprised you don't know. Don't you know only an orphan can take in the Earth's knowledge and thus succeed the authority over the Kin? Everyone will bow down to you.
I don't need that.
Call me another name.

The Foreman will offer you the final trial today. He'll promise to reveal everything if you pass it. He'll tell all about the sacrifice you're required to make, and you will only have to kill it. See? And then they'll give you the blood. But it's all lies.
You're on your way to see the Foreman now, aren't you?
Well, yeah.
Why?
How do you know?

The Foreman's trial will be designed so that you wouldn't stand a chance. He'll tell you to descend into the Depths or go through the throat—or something. And to get back from there. And that's where you'll die because there's no coming back from that place. But I know how to outsmart him.
How?
Don't ask, I won't tell you. It's not my choice.
What do you want for it?
Perhaps I'll ask a favour of you tomorrow morning. Deal?
Deal.
No. I find your offer suspicious.
All right. I agree.
Then do as he says and fear nothing.
What should I fear?
I will catch you so that you don't fall to your death. I will open the door for you so that you come back from where few do.
I trust you.
I have nothing to lose anyway.
Well, I'm not an entirely common person. I have a way of knowing. Trust me.
So what can you offer me?
Why would you help me?
I help everyone. I bring the dead back to life. This is why I came to this world; this is what I've been doing my whole time here. Healing and reviving. There's nothing for me to gain from it.
Toot your own horn… right?
So do you agree?
I've heard different.
I do.
No. I don't want your help.
Are they souls?
Where did these... women come from?
These are not women. These are their tekhe.
Their what?

These are tekhe. A tekhe is the clot between the warm and the cold. It's like a soul, only smaller and able to talk. It escapes the sick and the sleeping, hanging between the warm earth and the cold sky so that the spirits could whisper in its ear demanding to hear the story of the person's life.
Wait a minute. And then what?
She will stay here instead of you.
Where are we?
I don't know, but I think this is what the dead tell Grace about. This is a Kaiur—the passage that connects two worlds. When people die, they usually fly through it in an instant without noticing.
Why are they here?
I made them stay here for a while.
What a dirty trick! Someone else will have to die in my stead?
Okay.
How did that happen?
No need for sorrow, they are all dead anyway. Don't waste your words in vain. Save your breath.
Fine. I will remember this!
No, it will not do. I'm staying here.
Then everybody dies. The town will be destroyed, and Plague will devour the Earth. You won't fulfil you destiny. Your father will remain unavenged.
Let it be so.
No. It's your return fee.
What happens to them?
How do I get out of here?
Okay. I'm going.
When you have chosen a soul, ask her what you want to know. She will tell you the truth. Use the opportunity. Then walk through the black opening. It will let you through.
I will.
Okay.
And who is… beyond the wall?

I don't know. I can only feel them. They are obscure. They are the ones in charge of everything here. They're big but narrow-souled, trying to hide their wretchedness from us. It was all their doing. They haven't revealed themselves yet.
Will they?

Their time hasn't come yet. They are waiting in the wings. They will probably break into the world when it ends. Tomorrow they will show themselves… As for now, it is better not to disturb them. Just go along the tunnel.
Are they gods?
No, they are something different. The masked demons are their minions and envoys. Don't talk to them! Just walk along the tunnel.
What's going to happen to me?
What's going to happen to me?
Who are these women?
Who are these women?
I see.
But these ones—are they alive?
I'm scared.....
I'd like to...
Don't talk! Or do you want her to die in vain? Move, you won't have a second chance! Be quiet and clench your teeth.
Are you telling the truth?
Who killed my father, Isidor Burakh?
Who is the sacrifice the Kin is expecting from me?
So, you must be Artemy Burakh?
Yes. Answer the question.
...That's unclear. I see the line breaking into two here. They are parallel though. Like a circle turned inside out. I can't look at it anymore. I'll lose my mind.
You didn't answer my question. Who is the person I am meant to sacrifice?
I want to ask you a question.
Go ahead. Just be quick. It's hard for me to stay here for so long.
There was no person.
Damn... I still don't understand.
Am I dead? I don't think so... The host is merely asleep.

...Anna has been slandered. They think she was a kidnapper, a leech, a Caravan murderer. The host was too proud to offer excuses. Now that she's ill, no one will be there to help her. Her death will bring joy to many.
Are you telling the truth?
I cannot lie.
How will you die?
I believe you.
It will have something to do with the girl that came to the town a few days ago. She'll have a hand in the death of the host.
Are you telling the truth?
I'm not dead yet.
Talk some more, sweet soul. Look, some nails are already in.
Are you drawing my last breath from me?
No way in hell!
Indeed, sweet soul. It's leaving you with every word you mutter. Look at the nails—there's only one left. Make your final step.
I won't.
Go devour someone else.
I want to ask you a question.
Ask me anything you want, just make it brief.
Who is the sacrifice that the Kin is expecting from me?

Foreman Oyun has fallen out of favour with the Kin. When they learned that Suok rejected Oyun's offering of aurochs they were infuriated. The Foreman failed to read the lines of the Great Bull appropriately. Were it not for the plague, he'd have been killed already. The Kin, then, will accept any offering you make as long as you put an end to the order that precluded your arrival.
You did not answer my question. Who is the sacrifice?
Who says the offering is necessarily a "who"? All you need to do is to stop looking for it. Having done that you will have fulfilled your destiny before you know it.
I want to understand what I'm doing.
That's quite enough. Tell me now, what I myself shall do? Is it safe to go back?
I'll tell you later.
Who killed my father, Isidor Burakh?
You are Burakh's son?
Yes. Answer me.
Foreman Oyun is the one who killed your father.
He will pay for that!
Are you telling the truth?
I cannot lie.
I believe you.
How did you die?
I didn't die yet. My body has entered a kind of lethargic stasis.
How will you die?
It all has to do with the girl who came to town a few days ago. She will play a decisive role in how the host dies.
Are you telling the truth?
Is that so? I have commited suicide, perhaps. The changeling girl has obliged me by exposing the crushing vacuity of my existence.
Are you telling the truth?
I'm sorry.
Well, let's see what's infected and what's boarded off.
All right… We need money, as usual. A donation to the Scout Care Fund. A thousand and a half—that's a bargain!
Did they kill one of yours?
Not just someone. They killed Riddle.
It's all tied up, wish someone would untie it... You're free to take your business elsewhere if you're not interested. I'll find another client.
All right. Have it your way.
Whatever.
Will you answer a question for me?
I will. Go ahead.
Who is the sacrifice that the Kin is expecting from me?
I don't know! This future turns inside out when I turn towards it. I'm losing my mind. But there's definitely a false bottom to it! Be careful.
You didn't answer my question. Who is the person I am meant to sacrifice?
It's a trap. I shouldn't tell you. Don't ask me about the sacrifice. Just follow your heart.
Fine.
Should I follow the clanking of the beaks?
No, wait for now.
Who killed my father, Isidor Burakh?
Foreman Oyun. He did it on Big Vlad's orders.
I knew it!
Are you telling the truth?
I cannot lie.
I believe you.
I need time to process this.
How did you die?
I'm not dead yet. My body is asleep.
How will you die?
I will be executed—executed by a firing squad for an attempt on the life of Alexander Block, the commander.
Are you telling the truth?
I got sick when I went outside.
Are you telling the truth?
I'm going.
Sleep well.
Is this a parable or something? Why?

Clara has shown me that the disgrace that befell our family was but a terrible mistake by the military. I've always though so… and now I know for sure. It's all Block's fault. He'd been the commanding officer then already.
Why did you?
…Clara convinced me that it had to be done. It's not her fault though. Don't scold her when you get back.
A disgrace? What was it about?
That I will not tell. And I'm getting weaker. Don't ask anything else. I'm short of breath…
Who?
Foreman Oyun.
The Foreman said it was a bull.
Perhaps he said it was a "bull's horn"? You must have thought he was just being poetic... but he simply was unable to tell a lie. And yet he didn't say it was him… He weaseled himself out.
I want to know why you ordered my father killed… you shit!
Was the Foreman acting on your orders?

Oh... I knew that's what you would be told. It is… somewhat reasonable. I wanted him to die. But I never had him… killed. They didn't really need me to… I've arranged the whole thing so that the oynons of the Kin would settle it themselves… I gave no orders. It happened on its own.
Explain yourself.

The plan was direct and simple. He went off to the Steppe back then, you know… My daughter told me he'd come back with a demon piggybacking him. Then she pondered about it for a while and came to the conclusion it was a nightmare rather than a prophetic dream. So I went to Katerina… to ask her if Isidor would come back.
Go on.

Pray believe me... Only in the areas that had to do with the works. He maintained… cast-iron discipline. The Kin was timid under his ledership. They're like a single being, as you probably know… Well, under Oyun this being was dormant. Obedient, sluggish, and dull. But they did work... they worked well.
How did he control them?

Just like every Foreman ever has... from generation to generation. They worshipped the traditions; they looked for bulls in the Steppe according to the Rite. Brought them to the Abattoir, invited them in, begged them to come... all along the lines of the rite. Then they killed the bulls and cut them open... Every Foreman ever. It's been like this for hundreds of years.
Was he a man of noticeable influence?

I don't know. I didn't really care, to be honest. Why would I—as long as meat was plenty? My son, on the other hand... he was interested... too much, really... It went against his best interests... the poor boy.

Katerina... It was frightening. She foretold everything that has happened here during the last few days. She knew that Isidor was to become Simon's demise… and that Simon's death would lead to thousands more. I concluded there was going to be a riot… that he'd come back and incite an uprising among the Kin… He was planning on changing many things, you know... Who would consider a plague back then?
I am going to kill you, Olgimsky. How would you prefer to die?
...Are you sure about it?
I am.
Why are you surprised?
Fine. Then please do me one last favour. Let me do it myself. It will be over in three hours, I promise.
I will come to the Lump in three hours. If you're still alive by then, I will help you die. It will take me way less time.
Your spirit is still strong and unwavering. That is good. Fine. I will leave this matter to you. If your conscience lets you live, then live.
Let it be as you will... Foreman Burakh.
Everything will be as I will from now on.
Yes. Let it be so.
