He used to be a cynical leech, and now he is a hero. So why wouldn't I follow his example? Give away what little I have left? Count me in!
Commendable, Anna. But how are you going to do that?

Well, I have procured what Lara asked for. Voila! A small weapon of self-defense. Oh no, no need to thank me, I got it practically for free... you know, from the previous owner. But there's more! If you deliver this present to Lara anonymously, I will gladly give away the most valuable thing I own—my panacea!
Why?

Lara needs it for self-defense, she's afraid of the soldiers. You must give it to her in secret, no questions asked and… no names mentioned. When you deliver the pistol to Lara, come back for your reward. I don't mind parting with it anymore.
An uneasy conscience betrays itself, Anna. This is another folk saying.
I know all about your scheming. Explain yourself now. And no trying to weasel your way out of it!

...There's no other way to stop our precious little Lara. Have you spoken with her? There you go! You see, she is slightly out of it. If I don't give her this toy, she's just going to get a real one… and fire it. Better she be arrested by our noble General Ashes than shot by the guards.
Who are you talking to, Lara?
I know everything, madam! What's with the insane fantasies?
Ah, thwarted again! Please, at least don't report me…
But why?

He is a war criminal! All his fame is nothing but lies! Hearsay would have him as some kind of faultless knight, but in reality he's a bloodthirsty butcher! And we'll all find that out soon enough… but by then it will be too late…

I've asked everybody, even the Changeling! You know that tiny pistol she carries around? That looks very handy. It's just what I need… But she wouldn't give it to me. She said she has plans for me, that she requires my life.
And why do you need a pistol?

I can't tell you… I just want a weapon! Yes, I'm scared of the soldiers. But it really has to be small, like Clara's—I won't be able to handle a big one, so I'll miss... I'll reward you, I'll give you whatever it may cost. Here, I saved up…
Lara, I don't like this at all.
Yes… it depends. Some can take the life out of you with a few dried peas.
So your life is what you're going to risk, isn't it?

Oh, it's not like you're my husband or older brother, are you now? If you won't bring it to me, I'll just ask the Haruspex, he's less squeamish. And I can give you a very rare and valuable thing in exchange. That thing from yesterday… remember?
Fine. I'll get you a pistol.
I've had a very exhausting day—and I'm not the only one here who has, I suspect… We would all be better off if we had some rest. Let us talk business in the morning.
All right.
I have other plans for the night.
Don't be so fast to judge.
Indeed. Walking the streets of your town at night has been an entirely unpleasant experience since my first day here.
So you were expecting something? A calamity?
There were dreams… devoid of images. But tonight I saw a fragment of one of the days to come.
…All these years I've been dreading war more than anything.
I heard you were offering a reward for exterminating the barbers?
And what does it entail?

A lot. In truth, I have never made such a promise before. My mother has… just twice, I think… and kept it both times. And because she was a Mistress, it meant that the wish could be anything. A Mistress would find a way to fulfill it.
Your mother did this twice? Why?

…This is not really something we talk about. I will tell you, but l'll do so later. For now, I'm not allowed to… and neither can I give such a promise. I just couldn't help myself; it was a lapse of the tongue.
So what exactly happened back then?
Spoken words are like flown birds, Maria. Neither can be recalled.
I don't need your reward. I'll fight the robbers because my principles dictate so.
That sounds mighty suspicious.
That would be redundant in your case. Your—how did you put it?—virtues are already a sight to see.
...Anna, are you really that stupid, or is this just you acting?
Fair enough... Not only are you a hypocrite, you are an idiot too...
Pardon me? You've thrown me off a bit…
What are you up to?
So you say your pistol is only a toy? Dubious, all of this…
Why inform on her then?

Oh, the wisest of bachelors, you really have no idea… There's one more actor on this stage. And what an actor she is—a prima donna! I could never outdo her. It's Yulia. She was the first to find out, and wanted to fix it so that everything would seem to be my fault. So I had to tell the truth. She would have had me otherwise.
Then why the secrecy? I was told the letters were sent anonymously.
So I'll talk to Yulia. And then I'll get back to you. Maybe. Depending on the result.
Take it. I just happen to have one.
Are you saying you have no need of that thing anymore? And why would that be? No, Lara. I need you alive. Don't even think about getting a firearm.
Yes, that's exactly the kind I needed. Thank you.
Good luck, Lara Ravel.
Someone already has, Lara. You won't accomplish anything.
But who did it? And more importantly, why? He is an evil demon, he deserved this…
It's the Changeling and her hidden plots. You shouldn't have trusted her.
Anna Angel. Your choice of friends is imprudent.
Your plot has been exposed. Praise the heavens that your name remains a secret for now.
You still don't realize who the real demon is…
So you decided to make an attempt on him? Very well. Go ahead and try. But you may come to regret it.
A panacea? I won't take it. Farewell, Lara.
Unfortunately I cannot boast the same.
Glad to hear that. I'm counting on you.
Would you like to inspect the Cathedral?
So there really is a spring with drinking water inside?
Is it true that you've ordered to arrange… a morgue in the town Theatre?
A hospital, kind sir. A hospital.
The Theatre is closed for the public. We await further orders from you.
They're simple. Bring the infected here before their disease enters critical stage. Take care of them according to my instructions.
Will do. Anything else?
Obviously, you also need to arrange for the dead bodies to be transported to the cemetery and buried.
Act as the situation demands.
The Cathedral is closed. We await your orders.
My orders are simple. Any person who, for whatever reason, has entered an infected district, is to come here. Keep track of them. If there are no signs of infection after four hours, let them go.
And if there are?
Take them outside immediately and have them wait for the sanitary party. Apply antiseptics and give an antibiotic to anyone who was near the infected.
Act as the situation demands.
I've already seen everything I need.

Yes, two even. I think it's going to be very crowded here soon… Do you know there's been some strange sabotage? Someone ruined the town's water supply, and drinking from the river doesn't feel safe nowadays…
Above all, you must prevent any contact between the quarantined and other people. Even their families.
Will do, sir. Anything else?
Can the Cathedral be locked from the outside?
No.
Yes.
Then keep it locked. And reinforce the guard. The quarantined must not leave the building before the designated time. Expect rioting.
You can let people inside until we start getting the first potentially infected. I forbid entry after that.
You're right. It's best to avoid drinking from the river for now.
I disagree. It's safe to drink water from the river, it just needs to be boiled.
Please be so kind as to take my orders seriously!
Please do come in! The facility is ready to be examined.
Is the supply of spring water constant?
Thank you.
You're welcome to check it yourself, honourable Bachelor… You're welcome.
Fine. Carry on with your duties.
Clean up the facility. And order the delivery of anything that the hospital attendants might require.
No, that's all.
Will do. What should we do if the disease finally gets to the… well… critical stage?
Hand out pain relievers. Suppress panic and aggression. Act as the situation demands.
Find a place for them apart from the rest of the patients. Say… second balcony.
It's still too early to give up.
It's remarkable how this… microorganism seems to penetrate walls and permeate the air. It's not supposed to. This microbe doesn't survive long outside a nutrient-rich environment.

A new phenomenon manifested itself today. It might be of interest to you, as it admittedly is to me. We may have stumbled upon a mystery whose solution may have far-reaching consequences. This concerns the Skinners district.
With it we'll quickly learn the duration of this mysterious fever's latent phase.
"The Blockaded District"

Victor said that my word would suffice. Still, I think he would appreciate if I provided some evidence of how thorough the inspection was. I believe that a dead looter's belongings will serve this purpose just fine.

*** The district is hazardous still, but for reasons other than the disease. Fortunately, the looters are much easier to get rid of. This district will be repopulated soon, as will many other ones. What Victor did is a laudable accomplishment, no less.

I was informed that our major concern today is to prepare the town to defend itself in the face of the calamity that has befallen us. Although it is the Olgimsky family who are in charge of these issues, we would like to contribute as much as we can. Besides, something tells me you are not going to be all that happy with the yieldings of Vlad's undertakings.
Please find a moment to discuss a certain idea with me.
Victor Kain
Victor Kain's Invitation
*** This isn't quite my line of work, I'm afraid. I heard some of the volunteers were eager to support Rubin's initiative. They will be fine.
*** This is madness! I cannot work like this! To hell with it all!
*** Let him search for his wanton daughter himself! I've got more important matters to take care of!
God will provide.
Go, sweetie, this is no place for you to be.
Yeah, keep listening to your Notkin, you little brat!
Blood. I'm talking about blood. We obviously have to find her now. How is that hard to grasp?
More maneater-hunting?
Hold your horses. Leave this to me.
I can see that myself.
And what were you doing, I wonder? Huh? I'll have you all court-martialled!

Simon is alive! I just saw him suddenly appear at the Crucible! I sense him, you know, I can't ignore it… I woke up, but the feeling refused to let go of me… He's there, he is still there! It was all a lie, an illusion! Rubin will back up my words.
I don't understand. Why Rubin?

Rubin must tell the truth… he never lies if you make him swear on his Master's name… He will tell you then that he never dissected the body. Simon is at the Crucible! It was all an illusion, a deception!
Why would somebody arrange such a deception?

Illusions… The Kains engineered the epidemic… then hid it behind a false murder… Simon is at the Crucible, I know he is—and I will have proof. If you won't do it, I'll stoop to asking the Changeling… And even the Haruspex if she refuses too! Aglaya will heed their words... more willingly than she would heed mine... And she needs to know.
Simon is, to a certain extent, a concept… That much I have concluded by now. Which means your words can be taken very much as an allegory.
You've made a wise choice, Bachelor. But we've encountered certain complications…
What is it?
There are already half a thousand people who have agreed to leave the infected districts for the Cathedral. It's you who they owe their lives to, Bachelor.
You've mentioned complications.
There are food issues. We still have enough water, but the people are starving. The crowd is beginning to get cranky. They demand to be allowed to go search for food in the clean districts.
And I demand they don't. Don't let anyone out. Direct orders from me.
I'll speak to Olgimsky. You will be getting food supplies.
If you let anyone out, the whole idea of an isolation ward goes down the drain. Tell them we're almost done with the vaccine. They only need to wait a little longer—two days at most.
I. I'm almost done with the vaccine.
Yes, we. I refer to myself in plural because I bloody well deserve it! Too bad you don't seem to share this opinion.
Spare me the pathos! What do you need?
We first encountered them several days ago, in case you didn't notice.

Bachelor Dankovsky! I'm not sure what your instructions were and what Big Vlad's opinion on this is, but we've only received a tiny fraction of the food supply required. People demand that we let couriers in.
I know the town is starving. They know it as well. The goods train is going to arrive very soon. They'll have to be patient.
If you say so. Perhaps you would like to know there are more than seven hundred people inside. Even the upper galleries are crowded already.
Let them brace themselves. It won't take long now.
When the Cathedral gets overcrowded, we'll find another place. For what it's worth, we can use the structure on the other side of the river—even though it's usually off-limits.
No can do. We'd rather die out here than go there.
Bah, it's useless to argue with you people…
You not only can, but will do whatever I order you to do.

Here, that's all the food I've got on me right now. Distribute it among the children. I'll fetch some more by the morning. But no aimless wandering back and forth! Make sure this door only gets unlocked according to the regulations.
Let no one in or out.
The Abattoir's central entrance is open. I must hurry!

I have examined the data that the Watchers have collected and compared it to your own conclusions and suggestions.
Once again I was pleasantly surprised by your insight. Did you ever consider becoming an Inquisitor yourself?
We have to conclude the conversation we held yesterday and to decide who our real enemy is, and what the target of our next strike should be. The goals are consistent, I think. It rots from within.
Waiting for you at the Cathedral, Aglaya Lilich
It Rots from Within

Please do come to the Shelter. I know how preoccupied you are, how exhausted, but the matter is of great importance. I hope this will be the last thing I ask of you.
Your Lara
Lara's Note

Bachelor,
I sincerely urge you to see me at the Willows as soon as you can. We have serious business that needs taking care of. Pay no heed to those slandering me—everything is different now! The fact of the matter is, we have an opportunity to save the life of one of your closest associates.
A. A. A.
Anna's Note

Allow me to invite you to the Trammel, Bachelor. For your own benefit, of course, since the matter I'd like to discuss has a bearing on yesterday's happenings. Make haste, Bachelor, time is of the essence. Three more parties are playing this particular game and we may easily find ourselves outpaced.
Lyuricheva
Yulia's Note
The fortress is off limits. Khan's orders. You carry Sand Dirt on your snakeskin coat.
I brought you important news.
Tell us. We will tell the others.
I want to see the Agate Pit.

I am in urgent need of your help, Bachelor. The circle of suspects is getting smaller.
I urge you to put off all secondary matters that are dividing your attention. There is no time to spare. My hands are tied by General Ashes.
Remember, we must hurry if we are to cease the outbreak and avoid unnecessary casualties. The muzzles of their artillery are still obedient to the voice of reason.
Looking forward to meeting you at the Cathedral as soon as possible, Aglaya Lilich
Aglaya Lilich's Letter
…Again your words make no sense. Just like when we met for the first time.
My God, you're doing it again… That's it, I have had enough!
You say you can feel his presence, but if Simon is alive, why weren't you feeling it all this time? Surely he couldn't have risen from the dead?
One would certainly think so… Katerina, you're on the verge of real madness. The whole town is. And I, a champion of reason, fear madness over anything else! Farewell.

I do not know myself… I would never mislead you… why would I? We the Saburovs are done for… We were the first to suffer Clara's punishing hand… whoever wins, we shall never again rise from the ashes… and still I say to you—he is there! This is for you…

No! No! That's exactly why the Kains are so abhorrent… Any fantasy that only has the right to exist in the realm of dreams, they give substance. It's as if they're just bringing all those illusions, all the vastness available to the human imagination, into this world!
What's so abhorrent about that? They deserve praise… worship even… if this is actually true.
Simon is, to a certain extent, a concept… That much I have concluded by now. Which means your words can be taken very much as an allegory.

Oh yes! Look around and see the fruits of that worship! No, they have no place on this earth! I speak as the protector of the weak! I speak on their behalf! When those such as them begin to create, the weak are always the first to suffer. Everything the Kains do is a challenge, and challenges are for the strong! How are the rest of us supposed to live?
You speak on behalf of puppets. Let the weak become strong then.
There's no compassion in you… so ruthless… how can you be so? Even Burakh, that dreadful ripper destined to drown us all in blood… even he has more compassion for people than you.
What do you want from me, Katerina?
Fine. But why are you so upset?
Yeah, his compassion is evident. The crow bewails the sheep, and then eats it.
Indeed. Whenever an exceptional feat is achieved, the dregs are forced to compare their whole lives with its greatness… not a simple challenge.
Wait, there are several dead in there now?
Why, blasphemy, of course… Or do you still not realize the fate that befell Simon?
Tell me the truth, Rubin. Is Simon alive?
What do you mean? Simon is dead. Certainly dead, now. Although he was alive… for all the while he was thought to be dead.
Then your transgression is not so great, colleague.
Farewell, Rubin.
How are you certain that the man whose body you took was Simon Kain?

You think I don't know what Simon looked like? You think his greatness, his noble visage, is comparable to his brother or anyone else? After all, if it wasn't his superhuman blood, who else's could fight the disease for so long and almost beat it, even if at the cost of lethargy? Whose? Can you tell me?
Understand that in all my time here I have never—not even once—seen Simon; the only man I hoped to meet here! I never saw him alive, never saw him dead! What do you expect me to believe?
Fine. Ask at the Crucible! Since they let me go, they clearly don't think of me as either a murderer, or as a blasphemer! Let them explain where Simon is! I've said all I can!
By the name of your Master, Rubin, answer me... did you tell the truth?
I don't. I feel like I'm still missing something.
Katerina Saburova came back from another soujourn with the spirits and declared that Simon has arisen in The Crucible. Just now. She's hysterical.

Hm… well, Katerina is… That Clara did something to her… took her power and her crown as a Mistress. Are you certain that she said that? It's impossible. I broke Simon down into tiny particles with my own hands, and turned him into the white vaccine.

Dear colleague, I stole the body from the Kains—the body that was sacred to them. With my own hands I took Simon Kain's life… if that state could be called life, that is. Finally, the body itself, in which Georgiy had some… uh… scientific interest… I evaporated it.
What do you mean—evaporated? I've just received positive information that he's alive.

I turned him into the vaccine. I literally saturated the town with him. Maybe that is what's being implied by your…. source, whose identity I could guess? He lives on in the hearts of those for whom he gave his life. Didn't I explain it to your back then, four days ago? Do you still not understand?
Katerina says that Simon is alive.
Thank you. Your word is sufficient.
No. You are a truly beautiful woman, Maria.
Katerina is preparing an attack on you. She will use the imaginary murder of Simon to claim... that your family is who stands behind the plague.
...I am, en-Daniil. You are a man of honour.
Maria, tell me... Maria, have you always been frank with me?

You are the only person I've always been frank with, en-Daniil. This is probably because out meeting was so strange... and we have spent too little time together... You are the only one I've always been honest with... and I will keep being honest with you, en-Daniil. I don't want to lie to you.
Maria, tell me... Is it true that Simon is alive?

...Not quite. It's complicated… But you're not going to believe me anyway… It's a pity that you've come to know our family at this horrible time. None of us is in tune with their true nature these days… Hopefully you haven't yet talked to… haven't been to the right wing. The wing where my father used to live.
What's going on with you all, Maria?
You sound like a somnambulist—and remind me of Katerina.
All right. Talk to my dear... to my father. Just don't be surprised by anything. And do not ask unnecessary questions. He's a bit out of it… But they can… he can offer good advice.
Fine, I'll do just that.
I need to see Georgiy. Why is his door locked?
I need explanations now. The accusations you family is facing are too grave.
We are innocent before our town. Nobody has ever done so much for the people as we have. Just wait some more until I awaken—and I shall explain it to you.
I trust you... But would those who want to see you fall do likewise?

Our family is staring it in the face. The plague is an attack on us. It was us—not anyone else—who have become its main victims… You will see. Katerina already has… which is why she's running rampant… she's already lost her power. She has transferred it to someone else... and I don't mean Clara...
…Katerina is also planning to seek the Inquisitor's support—and a trial for you…
I see it would be better not to disturb you now.
Is it true that Simon Kain is alive?
But what do you call life?
Strange… Throughout my career, I've answered that question numerous times… but now I don't know what to tell you.
Do you believe in the soul's immortality?
Yes, I do.

So you want to know the truth about Simon? So be it. You will. The truth is that Georgiy Kain, who so ardently desired eternal life for his brother, has committed himself in entirety to Simon's Memory. He is imbued completely with memories of him. That is what Katerina saw... but she is very sloppy with her visions.
Victor, I—
Ha ha ha… forgive me this inappropriate laughter. I'm too unused to this. And I don't want to get used to it because this state will not continue for long. So you—
I have heard that Simon Kain is alive. Is that true?
What state?
Do you know of that which we call Memory?
Yes, I think I have the basic idea.
No. I don't believe in it.
Why, then, did you ask me that question about Simon?
Katerina was in a frenzy. She is convinced that Simon is at The Crucible.

Ah, so that's why! Tell me, did Katerina only talk about Simon? Only him? And you say she was in a frenzy? Did she not notice the presence of another person at The Crucible, the very thought of whom should make the girl tremble?
Life is any state of a human being that is different from death.
I'm not sure.

Memory is the very fine particles of a person that exist between that which is the person and all that isn't. Some have the ability to collect those particles. For as long as people are able to retain the particles inside themselves, the person is not dead. They remain here, but their soul is not imprisoned. It flies off to where it's supposed to be.
I understand now.
No. She spoke only of Simon
I want to know where Simon Kain is now.
...Who are you?

You cannot know the answer to this question. Had my daughter not fallen in love with you, you wouldn't have been allowed to ask even the questions you've asked so far. Why have you come here, Bachelor Dankovsky?
I want to know the truth about Simon.
I think I'm beginning to understand…

If Katerina starts spreading rumours of Simon's return, tell them Georgiy has gone mad. That he imagines himself to be Simon and Katerina is sensing those waves… Talk to Georgiy; let him confirm his consent to being presented as a madman.
Will he talk to me?
...You really have no idea how much has changed. The cost of shutting up mouths is now several times greater.

Yes, you are exactly as I imagined. My boy, when Isidor described you to me… I knew that this is the way I would like my heir to be. Alas, I have never begotten one. I am not the first Kain to lack a son, and, regrettably, not the last.
Why?

I think this is the price we pay for leaving too much life in our wake. Life that is lush, blooming, unpredictable and unrestrained. The soul that could have belonged to our children is dissolved in our man-made legacy.
You are a mystic.
Are you not seeing what you expected to see?
I want to know the truth about Simon Kain.
I'm not a boy, Judge. You shouldn't attach so much significance to age differences.
Beyound a shadow of doubt, this is a man, not a boy standing before me. So why is this man here?
Judge! There is rumour in the town that Simon is alive and his supposed death was a ruse set by the Kains to disguise their involvement in this plague outbreak.
Judge! There is rumour in the town that Simon is alive and his supposed death was a ruse set by the Kains to disguise their involvement in this plague outbreak.
To speak to you. Forgive my temper.
What have you done to yourself, Judge?
You know what I did; you will see if you look well enough. But that's not really the question, is it? What you really want to know is why.
Yes.
No. I know why.
I do not know. For some reason it seems to me that this Changeling, Clara, can be of help here.
I have extremely valuable information. Where do you imagine Simon Kain currently is?
Partly in heaven and partly in the ground, I suppose. Why? You have reason to believe otherwise?
You should know that Georgiy Kain has gone insane. He believes himself to be Simon. He will possibly die soon. Victor too.
It seems to me that Simon is alive.
I don't believe that. Out of the question. I don't even want to hear about it. Don't make me disappointed, I beg of you.
I have told you what I intended to. Draw your own conclusions.

Is that so… Well, that changes everything. I will of course draw my own conclusions; in fact, I am doing so right now. The information is indeed extremely valuable. I will even allow myself to appraise their precise price tag. However, it wouldn't be very nice for two crafty people like us to outwit each other. Wouldn't you agree?
The impression is all over the place, to be blunt.

I wholeheartedly agree. It's turning into a bedlam, wouldn't you agree? I can feel it here all too well—still can't get used to the piquancy of the whole ordeal… See for yourself—I've been thinking about leaving this place of the dead for a while now, but I get the feeling that this is exactly the place for me to fulfill my part...
Why did you want to see me?

To confirm your sharpest observation, actually… I've got competition now, as you can see. The lowest kind of it, I suppose. I am no tragedian myself—I'm rather a comedian—but this is a most grotesque and insane parody…
And who is the competition?

Some mob is trying to act out a… I'm not sure what to call it, it's not really a performance… well, they're trying to act out a living image of something by the Bone Stake. Although I'm not sure "living" is the best word—the centerpiece is a dying creature, after all.
How is that competition?

Everybody started to talk about it, interpreting and reinterpreting the… act. Just like they do with our very own Mask Act here. The prophetic excitement is growing by the hour… hand in hand with the anger.
Anger? What are they angry about?

I don't know. I only have the Executors' sardonic reports at the moment. I wouldn't have bothered you with this if not for the nasty smell coming from the detestable farce… Because, honestly, who would really believe that it was my epigones' doing? The mob thinks it's a heavenly portent, no less.
Do you believe that I have gone mad?
No. But you have changed—and I'm surprised.
I'm starting to think that I've been in a madhouse all this time.
You're asking as though you owned the situation… I find it disturbing.

Ah, I apologize... A nasty stage habit. Of course, I wouldn't in my wildest dreams dare… I wouldn't ever think about producing such a cheapjack and, if I may, tasteless play. So I had nothing to do with it. And let us forget the jests on the subject.
Why did you want to see me?
Are they planning to lynch someone there once again?
Did you see it? Was it impressive?
What is it? What am I supposed to make of it? You just wanted me to see it, didn't you?

Hmmm... First of all, I have to confess that this is not my handiwork; on the contrary, it's a direct attack on my interests. It never even occurred to me that this could make an impression on you—let alone a positive one—but I wanted you to see how impressed the mob is.
I'm afraid you're right.
No. The set is too poor. Although the beast is real—I've checked.
There are several people there—each of them so noisy you could take them for a dozen.
I think the Kains are.

Actually, I don't care in the slightest. But you should. You are now at a timepoint when you cannot afford to not care—you've only got a day and a half left… I want that thing to end because I don't like their style. What about you?
I do indeed care. It's dangerous.
But how can they be removed from there?
I'd rather like to know who had arranged it.

Why are you asking me? I wonder! Which irredeemable blockhead has gotten it into their blocky head to arrange such a performance? I don't know! I only know it resembles a bulldog throwing a recently-strangled cat on a festive table! The owners' beloved cat, I might add...
You?

Oh please... Do you still view me in my former quality? No, I am no longer a mime show interpreter. That's too good for me. I voluntarily—you hear that? Voluntarily!—renounce the laurels of a destiny-maker. Except maybe a bit—for fun… eh?
Who do you think fits the description best?
Well, I don't. I've been embroiled into a stupid melodrama already—and now you want to embroil me into a farce? No way in hell.
I don't know... I think it will resolve by itself somehow. And I have more pressing concerns.
Who is the target then?
Of course it's not.
Let's hear what the smart man has to say.
You are probably right.

I sincerely hope you can. I have to admit—I'm furious. The directive I received from the top brass gave me very broad authority and the right to make strategic decisions. It made no mention of an inquisitor! And now this…
What?

That is still unresolved. For many years now it has been an unspoken rule for military command to obey the decisions of an inquisitor. The justification was that an inquisitor would find a way to make a soldier obey their will anyway—whether the latter knows it or not.
To be fair, until very recently, military commanders also left remarkably little room for illusions concerning themselves…

But it's all different now! I am willing to cooperate, but she refuses to even meet with me. She has gathered information, not without your assistance I imagine, and now she's busy setting the gears in motion, waving me away until my gear is up for turning!
What are you responsible for, commander?
I hasten to report an issue of an utmost importance. There is a riot brewing in the poor districts.

Let the Inquisitor deal with that. Riots are right up her alley. I wish no part in it. She won't share information with me, so I won't step onto her turf. I'm not being vindictive. I'd hate to disturb her arrangements.
Certain special circumstances are in play, ones directly related to you responsibilities.
No… something tells me that the Inquisitor will not deal with it.
What is the scope of your duties?
I am responsible for ensuring that the epidemic never spreads from here further. I am also responsible for the lives of my men. That is what I know for a fact.
Your flamethrower corps are burning out everything infected, whether it moves or not. Is that within the scope of their jurisdiction?
There is a giant decaying animal carcass in the middle of the poorer districts. Do you realize the consequences?
I do.
Absolutely.
It's in the Bone Stake Lot—I see it marked on your map.
Many interesting things for them to see on the Bone Stake Lot. I'd lead them in that particular direction if I were you.
I understand you completely, commander. This is exactly what I wanted. Everyone performing their duty.
No. The vigilante is a much more significant woman.
I fear only one woman in this town. And if she chooses to try for my life, so long me. But I don't think she would use such extravagant means to achieve that end.
Her name is Yulia Lyuricheva. She suffers from a neurotic condition.
Fine. I'll send riflemen there immediately. Let her be under house arrest until I have time to make a closer acquaintance.
Yes. She is a singer, very eccentric. She often fails to realise where she is and mostly lives inside her own fantasy world.
This woman has the intellect and willpower of a man. The owner of the Trammel manor, on the bluff in the Chine district.
One more thing. The... gentler half of the town community is already... abuzz with the news. So should any overexcited lady come here...
I understand. She will be treated with utmost respect. I will talk to her and do my best to set her right. But if she turns violent, she will be locked up.
We have—but it's all very sudden. Somehow I can't shake the feeling you knew beforehand…
I'm not. It's all very clear.
It's all clear as day.
In the Bone Stake Lot?
In the Bone Stake Lot.
No. I know nothing about it.

She is a witch. The Dark Mistress. Have you already heard about Nina and Victoria? Ask around. Then you'll see who Maria strives to be. She will turn into a warlock queen and make the town bend before her tyranny. Like Nina before her, only even more frightening. It can be proven.
Tell me about Nina.

Nina was the embodiment of absolute evil. The charming, intoxicating, beautiful evil, the evil that can drive you mad. The graceful and elegant evil that is fast to capture anyone in its web—even those who stand up to evil till the very last.
"Pray forgive me," as one of our common friends likes to say. Quite a lot of outrageous events happened yesterday…
Yes. Someone tried to incite a riot.

The military have exterminated an unarmed mob. A perfectly healthy mob. This is the event I'm talking about. And I know for sure who was behind it—because I know who turned out to be guilty of this horrible crime… me! I was the one they framed!
So who was behind it?

The Kains, most likely. They have arranged this provocation and tied every loose end to me—as though it was I who's done it. They've done a splendid job. I couldn't have done better. That's because such things can only be done by a very special woman... it's about genetics as much as it is about skill...
Maria?
I think we understand each other full well, Inquisitor. Everyone was doing their job. Everyone only knew what they were supposed to know. Supposed by you.
You are mistaken. It was me.

You? No. You only provided the military with the information… that's not what I'm talking about. I'm talking about those who have orchestrated this… mysteria. Undoubtedly, it was Maria. And this Mark, the impresario of the local Theatre, has given her a cue as to how.
This is beyond Maria's capabilities.
Yesterday she was unconscious all day long.
Are you trying to say you're painting Maria's portrait? Considering they're supposedly alike?
Who is it?

Olgimsky's son. The second is Maria's younger brother, little Kaspar, who also knows Maria's immediate plans better than anyone else. He is so terrified of them that he's ready to run to the ends of the earth…
This is interesting...

By the way, if you want to talk to this Kaspar boy, please hand this panacea over to him. This vial was brought to me by Burakh yesterday, it's reliable. The boy will understand. Actually, after talking to him so will you…
Damn... Me dealing with Olgimsky turned out to be so untimely…
Who are you talking about, boy?
You should know that better than me. I am not going to help you with this.
You hold a grudge against your sister? Why?
Sister forces us out from here.
Why?
You ask her!
Who was it built for then?
Not for you, that much is certain. At least I'd like to think so.
Tell me, is your sister involved into what happened yesterday in the Stake Lot?

No. But she's involved into many other things. For example, it was she who got rid of Eva. How's that for news, huh? She wanted to have you all for herself. I could tell you a lot about my sister… but I don't want to flaunt the dirty linen.
Take the panacea. This is for you.
Aglaya Lilich asked me to give you this.
I do not want to have anything to do with with Aglaya Lilich.
It's a panacea.
It was she who put down the bull in the Bone Stake Lot yesterday, wasn't it?
So no Kain has anything to do with what happened in the Lot?
If you tell me what she is up to, perhaps I'll be able to help you.

Simon. It is for his sake that father and uncle are throwing away their lives. Well, I don't believe in all that metempsychosis! And this is the only place where we can play for real. This is our childhood. We are not giving it away to anyone!
And that's all? Pfft. No one would remove you from here until the disease is over.
And when it is? Then what?
Take the panacea. It's for you. Let us not meet ever again.
How do you know about Eva?
Ask my sister. She knows how to do these things. She won't lie to you. She'll tell the truth.
Eva has committed suicide and left a note.
I'll tell the Inquisitor that you by any stretch of imagination cannot acknowledge the complicity of your relatives to the Lot situation—against your personal preferences. Is that correct?
It is. Now no one will claim that I'm only saying that to protect my family.
Yes, I have already realized what your position is.
He is alive and well.
Yes, of course. It was ugly. Burakh is beside himself.
Do the Kains have anything to do with it?

Wait a minute... No, this can't be. The Kains were within a hair's breadth of destruction. The bull situation was arranged to smear their name and set the people against them. Who gave you this… unique idea? Because I can't believe that you've come to this conclusion on your own via logical inference.
Aglaya thinks Maria did it.
This is your love for her speaking.

No. The nature of my love for her allows me to justify any installation of hers in any lot. Let her build everything she deems necessary! Because sooner or later Maria will construct the space for magic to return to. There's nothing more beautiful than the expectation of a miracle.
Doesn't sound very Olgimsky, to be honest.
My father never loved me—so I have no desire to pursue his lifework. I will revere him as I did before, but the family business… is no more. Little sister is right. The powers switch places.
I promised to give this to you. It's a panacea.
Well. Does this mean Maria had nothing to do with the yesterday's accident?
She hadn't. But even if she had—what of it? Would it have changed anything?
I'll relay your words to the Inquisitor.
Why are you telling me this?

My daughter had two final wishes. To talk to her mother, and to visit the other two chrysales. She can do neither now. I don't think she will ever talk to her mother again. But she must see the future Mistresses.They must acknowledge her.
Is there anything I can do to help?

Someone needs to take the symbols of succession from these "chrysales". They know what this is about because they can also feel this awakening. It is very much possible that Capella knows who has inherited the title of Katerina, the usurping Mistress of the Earth. She was, after all, the leader of one of the powers while we were dead.
But why are you asking me?
Maria did. She specifically pointed out that she didn't want a stranger's hand to touch the rings that will forever adorn her body.

Oh how ferocious Mother Nature is! For 'tis her wrath that has to be withstood… Oh friend, if only I could wet my whistle… I'd gladly give you anything on earth in exchange for a gulp of chilly spring water!
How about we barter? You'll have your water and I'll have bandages.
Do you need a drink, you poor soul? How about some water?
You want to barter? We are a poor lot, but we'd fork out something for a good man, a kind man, a big-hearted man… like a fork! Yeah! A fork!
Here you go then.
Do you have bandages—or something else that one can dress wounds with? Give them to me. They're of no use to you anyway.
I'll give all my water to you! And you… can you give me something to stop the bleeding? I'm injured, you see…
Now we barter, drifter man. I brought you some water.
Why don't you drink from the river then?

Only lowly animals, dirty of image, drink from the river. Us proud men deserve to drink spring water... 'Tis brought here in barrels, but they're often empty. I'd get it from there, but I'm out of bottles; I'd drink straight out of a fountain, but I'm gonna faint... the air here's too spicy. I'm barely walking as it is.
So the local herbs are in bloom this time of year?

They're not blooming, professor, they're withering… Withering and thence producing general langour. People fall dead without sleep like leaves from a branch… All because of the surplus of juices. Or maybe not—I'm not really a science guy…
So you're a student?
Oh no, I'm but a woeful wretch, professor… A wretch that had suffered all too much.
My condolences.
Why don't you shut up then?
So you've got an Abattoir in the town? What is it?

It is with great trepidation that I set about to answer your question, professor. The Abattoir has been here since nothing else was. And mark my word—here it will remain when nothing else does. For 'tis all vanity of vanities, and all is vanity.
Do switch your silver tongue for a tongue more common, kind sir.

Hundreds of bulls are being slaughtered there—what else is there to know? It is our humble town that provides the whole Northeastern Region with beef! Or even the whole country, mayhap. How many poor bull souls does it take to stuff the belly of a country that has millions upon millions of citizens? Eh?
Your humble river obviously also supplies the whole country with water…
A lot.
Why trepidate?

My trepidation comes from uncertainty and confusion, professor. The Abattoir instills fear, for what is it if not a temple of death? An operational one, mind you, unlike the town Cathedral on Bridge Square…
Operational?
You are a lowly animal. Dirty of image, too. Drink from the river.
You are a suspicious crowd… Your mugs scream of penal labour! Each of you is a murderer-to-be! What, am I wrong?
So what? Did you find out whose guise the shabnak assumed yesterday?
What? Who are you calling a shabnak?

It's not a "who". It's a "what". A living myth. The Steppe people believe that a shabnak is not human at all, but rather a wandering soul; a state of evil—and 'tis among us that it walks. Bottoms up, buddy! Have a drink! That'll clear your head up.
I am absolutely amazed that you people can believe in things like this while simultaneously having the capability to use a railroad.
'N what is wrong with that, eh? Life is a complicated matter, it can't be catalogued. You think we're all savages here, making a fuss about a fairytale?
Hardly.

We're breathing Steppe here. Oh, the vapours that evaporate from it! The Steppe is wiser—no railroad can conceal it. Eh, the necromancers shouldn't have pinned their hopes on you. It requires a knack rather than intelligence… You don't believe in the shabnak—and it has just passed you by.
I'll find my way around it somehow.
Yes, the air here is unhealthy. My eyes are about to burst from the fragrance.
This is exactly what I think, yes.
Thank you, but I'll pass.
I didn't. Tell me, what do they store in the local warehouses?

The mortal remains of the late animals are in the southern part, as well as hide and ground bones. Jerked meat, cured meat, smoked meat, canned meat—all storaged and ready to go. The southern part of the Warehouses is a giant bull mortuary. So it is!
And what about the northern part?

The nothern part is house to consumable junk. The regular train comes regularly, as is evident by the name, bringing fancy goods to our neck of the woods. Pants and snaps, chemicals and perfume, all them thingamajigs… 'Tis essentially another mortuary, for everyday life is the killer of spirit...
Aren't you a philosopher!
A woesome rag I am; I'm walking ashes; a freak devoid of grace. As are we all… Do not take yourself too seriously, and you will learn the truth. Bottoms up, brother! The grass is wiser than we are!
As for you, do try to just take yourself for granted, kind sir. Stop being so hard on yourself.
Yes, the picture you've painted is spot-on.
Thank you.
Someone mentally unsound. Or a soaker like you.
Well? What's the news around the town?

Vanity of vanities! All is vanity! Take the Polyhedron, that's become a children's game now... 'Tis lovely children that reside there now; they've weaved a nest among the deadly tines of the machine—like charming singing birds… But not for them the Tower's been conceived, but for the glory of the benefactors. The family of them philantropists!
What family are you talking about?

The Kains, stricken down with bitter grief these days… who else? For 'twas another purpose that their project was intended for… The purpose without notice having lost, it stands abandoned now. And so it will until the end of days.
What was it intended for?

Damned if I know… not for the mortal life, that's filled with honest sweat, with mundane pain, and transient jealousy. There was a lofty purpose that is unknown to me. A purpose unfulfilled. A dream! Yessir!
Pah! Words, words, words… you're just saying words—while having absolutely no idea what you're talking about.
Okay. Tell me, is any of your mates sick with a strange disease?
Our souls are sick... Mine, and those of my friends. A sickness both contagious and lethal… the sickness unto death.
Thank you. That would be enough.
Isn't time endless? Why do you even think there is an end to days?
Isn't there? If not today or tomorrow, it surely will come… someday. I'm planning to drag my miserable existence for at least forty more years here.
Let's hope that you will.
People like you are a pointless burden to the world anyway.
Tell me about the Spleen district.

'Tis in the Knots, which would be the middle part of the Town of Men. The Spleen flanks the Station from northwest, stretching along the tributary; and the tributary's called the Guzzle. All them spleens and guzzling are quite intricate, ain't they? Heh heh…
That's fine. I'm good at anatomy. I'm a trained specialist, after all.
Which is exactly what we're hoping for...! So what's up with Simon? They say he's… not entirely dead? That would be logical: we're alive, so our father must also be…
I haven't examined him yet.
Simon is dead.
Indeed. Never in my life have I seen a trickier topography.
Top-o'-what? Well, anyway... You've asked, I've answered. No one's at the top o' anything. We're equals.
Thank you.
I think I'm very much at the top!
A common occurrence.
What are you reeking of, my good man? Is this some kind of sap?
Aye, twyrine sap it is… And let me tell you, the twyre gathered at the Flabby Mud last year had extraordinary properties, truly extraordinary!
Really? What were they?

Here's what I think. A herb is like a person—each blade has its own character. The bouquet has to be collected carefully, like a family, bloom to bloom—and the proportion, mind the proportion!—but water is also important. You can't just take any water.
Yes! Tell me about the water, my good man. What kind of water do you have here?

We all live off Steppe juices. Twyre the herb draws its juices from the Steppe; sun draws its juices from twyre; so does a bull, who gives and takes away—so does a man, a sinful worm, who sucks the earth out for his needs. The juices of a body are a gift—and the key to understanding everything!
Where do you draw water from?
The Steppe grants us water. Each spring has a different kind: one of them is filling, another's joyful, and the third one may be evil…
Evil? How?

'Tis no good drinking the Sugagh water, professor. Whenever anyone offers you a glass of water, take the lovely dove shritfront and inquire as to whether the water's been taken from Sugagh. And if they confess that it has, stuff that water down their throat, for 'tis a sin to blight an honest man with it. Evil comes from that water. Not the pest, just... evil.
What kind of water does Gorkhon produce?
The common kind... Dirty.
I see.
What kind of evil?

Bad fortune, here's what kind. Whoever drinks that water, dies not their own death. That's a reliable omen, I'm telling you. Beware of that water, doctor. You never know—what if you drink it? And next thing you know, your demise is waiting just around the corner.
Superstition, nothing more.
Do you know who's destroyed the town waterpipe?
No... Shady business. Everyone's been asked and no one knows. Who would destroy it but the one that craves our demise? It must have been Shabnak the bloodsucker.
I see. One theory less then.
Empty talk…
Tell me about the Flank district, good man.
'Tis adjoined to the middle of the Knots from northwest. In simpler words 'tis the western edge of the middle cape. The Shelter, the Ravels' mansion, is there. Why d'ya ask?
Who are the Ravels?

A shady family. There used to be a captain Ravel here—the only military man in the entire town, but he was worth a battalion, if you ask me. He snapped a bull with his bare hands once. Used to hit nine bottles out of eight from fifty steps away. A tough man he was...
Did he die?

Killed in the war, or so they say… In the war, but not in the field. There are rumours aplenty. And now his daughter Lara, a xenial and cordial orphan, lives in The Shelter. An angelic lady, pure and worthy of most sincere compassion!
Thank you.
Why did you call the Ravels shady then?

For I am rotten! 'Tis all my foul tongue striving to tittle and tattle. But your reproach is just, professor, and so I will be keeping mum from now on. Not a single vicious word shall escape my lips. And as for the departed, 'tis all nonsense!
What departed?

What departed? I never said a word about departed people! No one departs anything. 'Tis all baby talk and superstition. And now I have to take my leave, professor. Here's your hat, so to speak, and what's your hurry? Goodbye and good riddance.
You tattler.
Fine. You'll sing like a bird later anyway.
Well done!
I see. Nine out of eight is a rare feat.
No reason. Just curious.
Everything here is extraordinary.
What are you mumbling there?

Dark times are upon us... The town is dying... For it was written: Water shall become blood like that of a dead man. True. Blood spills faster than water. And the body shall be desecrated; and the children shall rise up against their parents.
Tell me, have you seen the Ripper?
I've seen more than one ripper… Do you look in the mirror often, professor?
I'm talking about Artemy Burakh. He looks somewhat wild and wears a leather robe.

I've heard about Artemy Burakh. Is he a ripper though? Nay, professor... He's a haruspex. He belongs to the respected Burakh family. It's not the same as cutting mongrels, it means something. Although if you really need a mongrel cut…
Do you know where he can be found?

He settled down at the Works, on the outskirts of the town. Either in the boiler-house or in the power-house… That's where he is, kind sir. But I would like to add, if I may, that he belongs not to a rough cellar, but rather to a halfpace.
What halfpace?

I knew his father, professor. He was a most worthy man. It is due to Isidor's good will that Foreman Oyun rather than the Haruspex is the current leader of the Kin and the taskmaster of the Abattoir. For Isidor had a relish for healing and learning rather than power...
Yes, I knew Isidor.
So he's in a remote factory building, huh…
I see. Dismissed.
Watch it! I'm not too slow on the draw, you know! Be off.
Tell me about the Backbone district. Where is it? Any points of interest there?

It's in the Knots, by the wall. That's where the Town Hall is. The common opinion goes that it's the most useless district of them all. A district of dimwits. My Pa, rest his soul in peace, used to say just that: a district of dimwits. Never allowed little me to be there so that I wouldn't pick their stupidity up...
Really? Your father seems like a most honourable person…
He was a sot, so help me, a thief, and a waste of skin! Cursed like a she-dog, drank away all our money, and ruined my pure-hearted Ma through his wretchedness!
The son is a success though!
That's disheartening...
Doesn't seem like your father's benevolent urges were of any use…
Do not despair.
Speak up—who is spreading the infection? Look me in the eye!

I swear on my soul's salvation—it wasn't me! Not my fault! You know it's a maneater, a shabnak, a creature of feminine gender—and do you see any, ahem, lady parts on my person? Eh! And so I plead not guilty!
So you're claiming innocence, my dear wretch?
Oh no, I'm far from innocent! Sinful, so sinful! I have commited many an infamy—but none so grievous as being a shabnak, a carrier! Who told you it was me?
No one did, you blockhead.

It is truly as they say: look for the woman! Nude, inviting, vicious—'tis always a woman. And many-faced, as has been written. For it is in the nature of a woman. They say the shabnak has also turned into a puny maiden! And lewd too, yessir…
Whys are you so nervous? You can only be taken for a lewd woman with serious reserve.

So what… You never know… You have approached me, and I am paralyzed with fear already. You know what they call you, professor? "The Harbinger of Death." Like an avenging angel on serpent wings, he hath spoken and rained destruction upon the sinful place! That's how it's been prophesized.
Try singing another song.
Stop squirming, you feathers-on-a-snout! I have approached you to barter for bangages.
I am not an inquisitor. You will report your courageous exploits to them when they arrive.
Is that delirium tremens speaking?
No one suspects you, idiot.
Have you seen any of the birdmask people nearby?

Executors! They took to hiding behind masks, fancy that… Never mind that they seem to appear on every corner. So a birdface sneaks up to you—and then what? How do you know who's hiding behind it? It may be a friend, it may be a foe. It may be my death! Go figure...
And who do they turn out to be most often?

Opinions vary on that one… To hell with them! I spit on their accursed lot. They bring corpses and bad news. I do not want to know who would be interested in labour this hard. A performance, dang it! I've always hated theatre…
Still, I hope that they are human. Why do they dress like that?

An overall and a mask are good protection, they say… 'Tis true. I've seen a lot of deadmen in my life—none of them were wearing an overall and a mask. But maybe the disease is indeed spread by vermin? What do you think, mate?
I am not your mate.
Uh huh. By vermin and sermons.
That is glaringly obvious.
You'd be better off helping them rather that putting yourself at risk uselessly.
How come this place never runs out of you sots… You've been ordered to stay in!
That's what I'm saying! Drunks are always lucky, as the folk wisdom goes. It's the same here, too—how can the bacteria survive inside you when you're pouring so much twyrine down your throat?
Why do you think it's a bacteria?

What else could it be? What else is causing them fevers? The dire beast called microbe. Shaggy in image, fangy in jaws, scary in manner. Smallish in size though, which is a relief. Has a knack for reproduction. Am I right, professor?
It is most likely a virus, and no spirit is deep enough to drown it.

You are of course an educated man. A man of academia, so to speak. But I would argue otherwise. Take my father-in-law. Drank like a fish—a fish that would then crawl under the table mindlessly—and no plague would get to him. Never! Not to mention flu. Five years ago when it happened for the first time he survived.
No way…

Oh, but there is a way! Having imbibed a good measure of twyrine in the morning, he dived into a house taken over by the Sand Plague—for reasons entirely humanitarian, I might add! And then he came back alive, unscathed by the pest, and he is still alive to this day... Yessir...
Twyrine seems to be a versatile beverage.
There goes the gospel truth! Twyrine is a unique beverage. Liquid emerald. It has all kinds of healing and enlightening properties.
Undoubtedly.
Your father-in-law must have been lucky.
It's a coincidence.
Go, sleep yourself sober. "Professor..."
I have no idea how you can drink this… venom.
'Tis a hebon that makes you live twice as long.
I doubt that.

One life you live is your own, another is the one twyre grants you. This is a herb greener than wormwood, it is, professor. Have a specimen for your microscope. It will be more accessible to you then. And my microscope is a spirit still…
I can see that. It's a shame it's not as precise as mine.
I have noticed mass mental instability among the local population. It is not impossible that it's caused by the abundance of poisonous plants.
Why not thrice?
You can't put spirits in your veins instead of blood, though.
I think I've heard shooting. Have you? What happened there?
Them military men do not take kindly to our brethren! It would be unwise to come close to the bridges now. They shoot straight. Why did they have to block the bridges? Huh? I'm asking you!
Why in the world are you asking me? Do you think they're doing it on my orders?
Well, uh… you're an authority. You're supposed to know things, hence me asking.
Do not provoke the soldiers and they won't hurt you.

Let them not provoke us and we won't hurt them. Here's this sod with his gun, protecting the state and civil order from me, wasting bullets… from his rifle, no less! I can stand up for myself, yessir! Their lives are no more valuable than ours.
His bullet will get to you sooner than your swearing gets to him.
True.
You idiot…
What is there to take kindly to, you useless sods?

Nothing, okay, fine. We're but a humble crowd. But why hurt them cultured people? They've sent a squad of flamethrower men—with flamethrowers, fuel, and everything. They're planning to assault the pub!
Why?
They want to capture Andrey, the architect. But we shall not give him out!
What for?
For being too tough. He gave the bastards the works yesterday! He's shown them that letting your fists loose can be a bad idea. No more abuse towards artists!
If only.
Serves you right.
You'll find a way to deal with it.
I don't know.
May I ask as to why you are so happy?
"Hail to the powerful and healthy storm," as they used to say. The times of change are truly upon us. The old will topple down for the new to be erected.
Your optimism is untimely. What's the point?

We're trying to escape the absurdity of it all, professor. There is a point to everything; everything happens for a reason. All those deaths couldn't have been for nothing. That's what I think. Through cleansing and suffering a new bliss will emerge.
Really? You couldn't have come up with that on your own.

Hmm... True. 'Twas a girl comforter, a puny lass that wiped away our tears. She comforted me yesterday. Without abhorring us down-and-outs. She said, "Everything happens for a reason; all those deaths couldn't have been…" Eh! She speaks the truth.
Forget it, you sot. The recent war had swept away way more lives than this plague. People have always died and will always die by the millions. "For nothing."
What a nice girl.
Yes, definitely.
Too good to be true.
What's the word on the street? Is no one preparing for the evacuation?

It is the truth they say about the world transforming! Yessir! It will transform, surrendering our mortal coils devoured by the soil to build a brave new world, all shimmering and gleaming! And we'll become the ground from which the joy will grow and bloom... and fume its odour sweet.
Hopefully you will live to see it. Don't be too fast to bury yourself.
No, we shall perish soon. We ragged freaks had it coming. There is no place for us in the new worlds. We're obsolete!
Yes, this is true.
A mentality like this definitely spells doom.
Nothing but burdocks will grow from you. This is scientifically proven.
Nothing I can help you with.
Well, let me have a look… Stand still. What is this bulging cartilage?
You really shouldn't walk outside at a time like this. It will come to no good…
Hey you! Don't you mess with us. We know a thing or two about life.
Let's barter, lad. I have a lot of curious things.
Why are you so bristled up?
It has begun! A crushing blow to the Soul-and-a-Halves is being prepared. There are almost seventy Dogheads. No one will escape their doom!
What does it mean?
It means the end of the Soul-and-a-Halves' domination in Earth. Notkin will have to sweat to break free from the dogs' jaws!
Are you describing a game of yours?
A game to some, destiny to others.
I hope you avoid manslaughter.
Do keep in mind that I have no part in the conflict.
Who is Notkin?
You will know when the time comes. If he's still alive by then, that is.
I hope you're talking about a game.
Who are the Soul-and-a-Halves and the Dogheads?
The Soul-and-a-Halves have a soul and a half, and the Dogheads have dog heads. As you can see, it's a clash of ideas; a matter of principle. It's an us-or-them situation. There will be no mercy.
You've got some fierce games.
Why the long face?
The war's been postponed. If it has come to this, we shall unite and hunt the turnskin.
Do you belive in turnskins?

You graduated from a university, and this is your question...? You think we're all total nitwits here? Looking for a werewolf? Werewolves only exist in fairytales. And a real turnskin would make you own skin crawl…
Sound intriguing. Tell me more!

Do you know the Baur Meges? The book of Steppe legends? It explains what a turnskin is. A turnskin can live by your side for years—and then all of a sudden—bam!—it turns! Don't be surprised then that your nearest and dearest are on their way to the cemetery.
But why?
Because that's the turnskin's nature. It was a man or a woman, then—bam!—there's a kagi standing before you. Death emanates from it. You geddit now, you big-city brainy?
More or less.
Mind your manners, young man.
No, I am not an expert on the Steppe lore.
I hope you know what you're doing.
It is good that at least the war is postponed.
If Khan and Notkin come to an agreement, that is. Notkin is proud, and Khan is fierce.
Hopefully they do.
What's the news in the town?
Someone's plundered our old powder caches! Who could it be?
You had powder?

Not powder. Powders. Powders-shmowders... We used to play Plague. Naturally the game demanded that we steal medicine. Then we arranged Drugstores and produced Recipes; competed at who invents the best one. All in all, a couple of recipes turned out to be fine… I mean, the kids that took those shmowders survived.
Good for them.

You don't geddit! They've survived the Sand Pest! You know what it does with your blood? It makes it boil in your veins like an egg in a pot. First it runs thick, then it turns into clots like cottage cheese. How do you like that? And shmowders did help!
Where can I find these… powders?
Hah! I'd never tell you even if I knew.
Could I study the recipe and replicate them?
Could you? Are you for real?
I am.
I could relay that to our guys… If they come across some, I'll tell them to keep the shmowders for you. But don't count on it too much; shmowders are unique and hard to come by.
I won't.
No, that was a joke. Ha bloody ha.
That was to be expected from you, lad. Now shoo!
That's bollocks.
What caches?

Caches! The Mild Dew's been looted! Cuckoo said someone's pillaged his cache too. But the worst thing is that Silly House has also been sacked clean. Who can tell now which shmowders are good and which are Catchfly's? If you eat the latter, you're toast—you can just as well wash them down with acid!
Sounds horrible...
Is everything all right with you, you little rapscallion?
A neighbour of ours has been killed by patrolmen! I still can't wrap my head around it... That means they can make away with me just as easily. And with you too…
What did they kill him for?

Well... They say he attacked someone too. He did have quite a temper, but they beat him to death with their mega fists! By the way, was there really an order to do that? For reals? How do we fight now, how do we defend our honour?
The order was issued to put a stop to the chaos.

Pfft... Right... Good luck with that! You keep in mind that we can stand up for ourselves just fine! If anyone hurts me, my Dina, or any of my friends, or Capella—they will be in big big trouble! My fists are in the right place too, ya know! Got it?
Why are you shouting at me? Do I look like a patrolman?
Just don't go running rampant too soon.
You people should stay indoors to protect yourself from the epidemiological hazard, not go around fighting!
Wha—?
Close your mouth, you'll eat a fly.
I said, stay in!
Why are you sticking like a leech to me?
Tell me, are you a doctor?
Well... Yes.
So you have a bandage? A tourniquet, any bandaging material?
What do you need it for?

Huh! "What for"! How is that even a question? What do you think is the most useful thing in a fight? What if you're bleeding or your joint's been dislocated? How do you fight a war without bandages? And they're nowhere to be found…
Come on, we've been there before... Stop this inane war of yours! Go home and stay in until aid arrives!

Until aid arrives? When would that be? And what are we supposed to eat? Huh? There's no bread in the town—and now there's no water too… "Stay in," he says… You must be eating healthy and nutritious food, ain't you? Got yourself some nice chow, don't you, sir Bachelor, sir?
You moron.
It will arrive soon. Have patience.
And why are they nowhere to be found?
Olgimsky, the leech, has collected all the medicine in the town and is now partly distributing it among those who are in need… And the tourniquets go to the patrolmen.
I see.
No. Bandages I have none.
No. I'm a scientist.
Where do you think you're going?
Fuck it! The town is a motherfucking mess! Grab your knives, everyone! I'm done! Seems like the old taboos are as good as gone. Well, ciao, motherfuckers! Every man for himself now.
What are you talking about?
What, are you blind? Going outside is like diving into flame now. You're lucky if you can hold for three minutes, from one door to another.
If you start stabbing people, there'll be no mercy for you. I mean you as a community.
Ha... Like there's ever been any. Why don't you shut up… bachelor.
Stay in! Everything is being delivered to you—both provisions and medicine. The sanitary train will arrive soon.
Yeah, when pigs fly!
It will come soon.
Don't you talk back at me.
Cut it with the strong language immediately! You little prick!
What's the news, lad?
It's definitely a good thing that the children are holed up in the Tower. Is it true that there have been no fatal outcomes there?
I don't know. I haven't been there.
I'm afraid it may collapse under the weight though. So many people have never gathered there at the same time...
And how many did?
Well... A hundred, a hundred and fifty maybe... But there's never been more than a thousand.
Is that so! That means I've got one more pain in the neck now—the construcrion sheltering a thousand children may collapse any minute. Damn it to bloody hell!

Oh, it's not like that… Don't you worry… It must have been designed to hold them, probably… And there actually was that time when a ton of people got in there—there was a festival. I was six then. We celebrated for three days and it went fine…
Who constructed it?
That I do not know. It was already there when I was born.
How old are you?
Eleven. Almost twelve.
I see.
All right... let us hope the Tower manages.
I wonder why I hasn't been informed about this.
Me too! I wonder why you haven't?
That attitude will get you into trouble.
So they say.
What do you have there?
I've saved up so many nuts... But who's going to play them now?
Will you finally tell me how you play nuts?

Oh! It's a whole separate life. Each nut has a name, an age and, most importantly, experience. But not just any experience! We believe that the more adventures a nut experiences—while staying alive, of course—the more precious it becomes.
Adventures?

Ha ha! Together with the owner, of course! A nut must drown in water, burn in fire, lie under a train, rob the Dogheads, get wet in a cellar, pay a visit to the Abattoir—and so on... But these games pale in comparison with what you can play in the Tower, of course...
Why?
Everything's different there. There's real magic. Visions... Continuous dreams. Even love. I've fallen in love there, can you imagine? It's an enchanted place.
My condolences.
Aren't you a bit too young for that?
You'll find someone.
There were seven of us in the gang. There are just three of us now. I wonder if it ever ends…
Do you miss your friends?
No... Not really. That's weird even. I know I'm supposed to be sad, but I just feel numb inside. Like frozen.
Yes, it happens. You will start to grieve after a while.
It'll end very soon.
Everything ends one day.
Do you like the Polyhedron?
If I ever get to the Tower, I'd love to play Reflections.
What is Reflections?

Well, there's a labyrinth. Nobody knows what its structure is like because it feels like it's a mile long. You keep walking and walking and walking and it never ends. And when you're out, it's not actually you, but rather your reflection—and you yourself go to the Otherplace.
How can a labyrinth of that size fit in there?

That's the trick! Perhaps you're not walking at all—perhaps you're going around in circles or standing pat—and the reflections make the space around you feel like it's shifting. Isn't that cool? That's the magic of reflection. Those who come out act very… mysteriously.
Mysteriously how?

Unlike themselves. It's like it's you, but not really "you" you… They're not very talkative. That's why they say it's a reflection—its only purpose is to be there so that your parents aren't worried and all that. And the real person goes to the Utopia country. A miraculous land.
Did many children go into the labyrinth?

They say many used to go in before, but then they realized what it does and got scared a bit. All in all, it's not so popular these days. But Smartypants did go in. So did Crowfoot, by the way… Most of them are with Notkin now.
A curious story.
I'd go in there too.
You make me jealous.
Meh. You're spewing nonsense.
You'll get there.
Well? What are you looking at?
Hey, Bachelor! Did you know that Burakh was looking for you?
What does he want from me?
I'm not sure. But he wants to spill rivers of blood. He was going to come to an agreement with you because he won't make it without your help... Hahaha!
Why would he spill rivers of blood?

That's how he can fulfill his purpose and become the Shepherd of Beasts. But that's just what they say. I don't know why. Perhaps he just feels like it? Are you planning to spill rivers of blood too? You're planning to raze one of the districts, aren't you?
It's a lesser-evil solution.
Just don't you dare touch the Polyhedron!
We'll see how it goes.
Do not worry, young man. Whatever happens, the Tower will not come to harm.
I'm an artificer, not a butcher.
No, he'll have to make do without me.
Let him keep looking.
Tell me about the Hindquarters.

Hey ho! The Hindquarters is a merry district! It's in Earth, above the factories, on the bank of the Gullet. That's where the ominous Willows are, a house of ill repute, and a pub called Factus Est. The Twins tend to spend their time at the latter—so staying there is dangerous for both your life and sanity!
What's The Willows?

A malicious wench lives there! Name's Anna Angel. A proud potato if I've ever seen one. She used to be a famous singer and now she's dealing in spells and hexes! We'd smash her windows with stones, if not for the respect we used to have for the previous owners…
Who lived there before?

A girl named Willow Mellow used to live there. And then she died! That's how it goes. No one would have thought about it twice, had she not died right after offering shelter to poor Anna Angel! Grace says that Willow was buried in a closed coffin... And that coffin was suspiciously light... Spooky, isn't it?
Are you kidding me?
Ha ha! Yeah, I so pranked you! Now excuse me, I'm in an awful hurry... We'll talk another time.
Hey!
The lack of proper education options is a grave social issue indeed...
You're a quick lad. Now off you go...
Tell me about the Polyhedron.

That's where the youngest Kain—Kaspar, styled Khan—has fortified! There are more than a thousand children up there now; almost every child in the town went to the Polyhedron—except for urchins, orphans, and bold daredevils like me!
Are you trying to tell me they live there?
Well... The older ones do. The younger kids just come by to play. But yesterday everyone who's older than three and younger than fifteen had a huge gathering there. They're hiding!
From the parents?
From fate, Bachelor... From fate. Yeah!
You cannot hide from fate.
Good for them.
Tell me about the Crude Sprawl.
Bah! The most rottenest place ever! The soil breathes there as though it could swallow you whole. A real bog! What could you possible need in that place?
How do I get there?
It's simple! When they tell you to go to hell, just choose any direction; when you've found the worst place in the world, this is it! Ha ha ha!
You are a very impolite young man. Try to answer me once again, but this time be serious.

Oh... There's something very alarming in your eyes… I apologize profusely! It's in Earth. The southernmost eastern district that borders the Abattoir. Its other end is adjoined to the Cemetery! Rawrrr!
Thanks.
Do be more polite from now on.
How about a smack on the head?
Nothing. I'm just curious.
Tell about the Tanners district.

A menacing place! It's the northwest cape of Earth, the backside of the town. That's where The Rod, the Saburovs' mansion, is. We don't play there. Alexander is not to be trifled with. You never know when his strict gaze turns towards you…
What's so bad about it?

Well, who knows… No, don't ever mess with the Saburovs. Then again, the wife—Katerina—is not only a witch, but also a Mistress. I was too young to see any of the old Mistresses. Katerina was the last one… Although I've never seen her either.
Stop—stop with the chattering! Slower, please! What are the Mistresses?

Rumour has it they're like goddesses. A Mistress is the Mother of All. They knew how to control time, focus power, create an Outburst, and tell the future. Among other things. Like I said, Mothers of All.
I see.
Shush, why you are shaking? I'm not making you go there.
Thanks.
Tell me about the Skinners district.

What is there to tell? It's just a district… in Earth. The nothernmost of the western districts, it's further to the north than the Termitary. Ah! Actually, a good friend of mine, Sticky, lives there! Sticky the Nuthatch! Do you know what a nuthatch is? It's a very sly snake!
And where does Sticky live?
Well... In a house on the bank of the river Gorkhon. It's actually tricky to find… When you're there, just ask someone, they'll show you.
I will.
Actually a nuthatch is a bird. All right, thanks for the help.
Like I would want to rub shoulders with the likes of you...

I'm sick, I'm in agony… My head seems to be filled with lead… my insides burn. Could you please donate a couple coins for me to cure myself and my family? I'll repay you… I'll spread the word of your untold magnanimity…
Take it. I hope you use it wisely.
How much is there?
A hundred is enough for you.
Five hundred.
One thousand.
Two thousand.
Three thousand.
Four thousand. Remember, it's intended for all of you!
What do you care? I can also give nothing.
Are you unwell?
I think I have a fever… My brain is on fire and my heart's also kinda… But it will pass… It will…
Do go straight home. Your condition demands you lie down.
What can you tell me about the local cemetery?
The Cemetery? Why do you ask?
The call of duty.

Then it may be of interest to you that the local burial culture is extremely primitive… The late caretaker of the Cemetery was a local too. He encouraged the backwards practices of illiterate herdsmen. The dead are still being buried carelessly!
Carelessly? What do you mean by that?

The bodies aren't always interred. The locals believe the Earth to be their foremother. Only a select few get buried into the ground; the rest have to do without. Some are buried deeper while others lie much closer to the surface.
What do they do to the bodies that are not interred?

The Kin doesn't show anyone what they do to their dead. I never belonged to the Kin anyway. The Termitary is perforated with holes—they drag the body inside, and in a day they pull out a leather parcel and pay their respects to the dead.
Don't the local authorities care at all?

The Kin governs itself. Big Vlad doesn't bother them as long as they keep generating profit. They're on their own… so what? They break no laws—so they're allowed to do whatever they want at home. They are a constitution unto themselves. They follow their ancestors' rites.
This is utterly barbaric.
Ew... disgusting!
Do all townspeople do that?

No, of course not. The civilized people bury their dead properly. But prejudice and superstition are very much alive—and the higher-ups encourage them! What is there to say if such people are in charge of the Cemetery? God knows what they do at night when no one's looking.
I've ended up in a real hellhole, it seems…
What was the caretaker of the cemetery like?
I've never talked to him... His daughter is in charge of the job now. She also adheres to the old traditions completely, following her father's teachings. She feeds the dead…
Feeds them? With what?
Bread and broth. She also pours fresh milk into the graves.
Ah, okay, obviously…
You look like you may very well relocate there soon.
Very funny... Yes, very much so... Is this an outsider's joke or a doctor's diagnosis?
A joke.
A diagnosis.
What do you need money for, old man?

One has to stockpile necessities! I think I'll spend the rest of the day shopping. The prices seem to be rising for some reason… That means people are worried. Or are those the profiteers' shenanigans? Huh? What do you think?
What does it have to do with profiteers?
Think for yourself. There are little to no eatables and other essential goods left in the town. Everyone's waiting for the regular train to arrive.
The town based on slaughterhouses has no eatables? Are you joking?
We cannot eat the meat of our bulls! We're not supposed to… They'd disapprove of us. They're very straightforward, you know. Like children.
When famine starts, you'll sing a different song.

I don't think there's going to be a famine… still, our reserves are gradually getting depleted. There are lines at every food store. A loaf of rye bread costs fifty! Seems like the ruler's death and the rumours of a maneater have disturbed everyone greatly.
Everything happens.
Yes, it's an ordinary panic.
Who is "like children"? Bulls? Is that your parenting policy, huh…?
What is the general food situation in the town?
