Oh, don't even ask… We've been waiting for a train for three weeks now. We're used to it coming like clockwork every month; the shops aren't used to stocking on perishables. And household reserves are at an end… All anyone can talk about these days is famine.
Really? I doubt there is a famine threat. Doesn't the town have a decent supply of edibles storaged somewhere?
I do not think about it at all.
What about your family? What are you sick with?
All diseases come from poverty and malnourishment... Oh, what will become of us?
Why are you asking me?
But they say there is an outbreak…
So there is. And?
Anyone can die... Any second anyone can get infected by anything… No one is safe… I'd rather it was shabnak-adyr the maneater raging!
Everything is relative.
Will everyone who gets infected die?
Everyone who asks moronic questions will, that's for sure.
No. Not everyone. Miracles happen.
Look! Leave me be! I don't even know what kind of disease it is yet!
Even if every second person dies, each of you has a chance to end up being the first.
You think that's my fault?
No, no, the thought never crossed my mind... But you must be able to think of something... To save us from the blight!
I have no plans to.
But isn't that the reason why you've been sent here?
I have not been sent here, old man! I came on my own volition. As a private person.
You can say so. Retrospectively… those bastards.
I'll try.
Easy, easy there... Nothing will. You will all die.
You should have a rest. You're exhausted. The air here is detrimental to your health.
Yes, that's just how this place is… Every breath threatens death… It's like walking through crossfire… or a simple fire. But what can you do? We have to…
You "have to"? Would you be so kind as to explain to me what emergency is forcing you outside?

We're looking for food... We're hungry! We need to check on our relatives... to see how they're doing! Secondly, staying in is even more terrifying. It feels safer outside. What if that thing engulfs the house like it did five years ago? It tended to just appear inside the room back then... by itself.
I said, stop scurrying! Away with the unnecessary fuss!
Nonsense. Things do not appear "by themselves".
That's why you are continuously being told to stay in! Wait for the Executors to come to you!
Really?
Not only do you increase the risk of getting infected, but you're also spreading the disease! I should have you all shot.

But for some reason it only makes pinpoint attacks… Some houses perish from the pest, while others remain unscathed. They seem to be in the clear; in my opinion, that means they're free to walk through.
No one cares for your opinion. Mine is the only one that matters in this regard.
It's your own fault if you get infected then. And the patrolmen will keep you carriers from entering other districts.
Really. Volunteers come to every house to bring medicine and take orders.
Lies... No one comes anywhere.
Wait a bit, they will.
You're spelling your own doom.
Fever? Anything else?
Oh, it's suffocating... Do you by any chance have any medicine?
You're suffocating? What about your bloodflow? Do your vessels hurt?

No. But my soul does... Why is Mother Earth so angry with us? Who's been tormenting her? What did we do wrong, professor? Did we gather too much twyre? No, the Kin's been doing it since ancient times… and it was fine.
What does earth have to do with it?

It's simple. The locals respect the Earth, even though we are no farmers, but rather herdsmen... They also say the sun evaporates these miasmas into the air, so the air is bad around here. So who knows where the pest comes from...?
It's not your job to think about it.
Yes, you're right. It's all the sun's fault.
Wasn't medicine distributed to you?
We have been given some, but they say this medicine doesn't work in small dosages—and big dosages lead to poisoning and even death.
Who says that?

People do... They say one has to swallow up twenty neomycinum pills to stop the infection. They're being tested today—various pills, that is—and volunteers are encouraged... They say if the testing is successful, they'll start handing the stuff out.
Perhaps... And who did you say was in charge of this?
They say the Olgimskys have snatched control of it. They'll be the ones to profit from our torment now.
Yes, that they will.
Mind your tongue.
Hang in there.
That's fine. You're all going to make it.
It's too crowded here. People burden the earth. It's time to cull the population… The Earth requires way less people than what we have. Otherwise there'll be calamity after calamity.
Oh really?
Yes! Earth is depressed under the burden of humankind. Its crust is way more delicate than it seems; it gives in under our weight. And then murderous spirits pop out from the underworld.
Are you sure murderous spirits live underground?

Well, that was me allegorizing... But the people of old claimed that the underworld is, well, underground. That's because they were afraid of what hides there. Worms. Heat. Caves. The dead... Even if the murderous spirits do not live there, it's still a bad place…
Well, that's probably true.
There are precious minerals and resources down below too.
This line of thinking would make sense for a child or an uneducated Steppe savage.
Eh... Within each of us there is a place where either a scared child or a wild barbarian hides. Whenever pressure gets too high, they start bawling... He he...
I don't know about you, but there's no one bawling inside of me.
That is because the pressure you're under is manageable…
That is not for you to judge.
Yes, the demographic crisis is poignantly evident in this desert. The population density here is one person per five square kilometers!

Yes, but they're gathered together, the people are all gathered in one place, and they're standing on the most sore spot of the earth, pressing upon a swollen ulcer... This town is quite unwell, wouldn't you agree? A nervous hernia, if you will... That's just how it feels. And that's the blister everyone is pushing and pushing and pushing...
Directional pressure, right?
You think the earth feels pain because of this?
Nonsense.
Why do you all keep whining and complaining! I'm just about to start howling along…
It's over. There's no point in struggling anymore.
This line of thinking will lead you to your death. Expressing it aloud will lead you to being arrested.

But there are no other feasible lines of thinking... It's obvious, isn't it? Only a blind person would claim this plague to be anything but the punishing hand of fate. It has no natural causes. The human mind is unable to comprehend its spreading process.
We'll see about that.

I don't think it's doable. Everything I see around me has an undertone of absurdity. This illness cannot be defeated—and therefore it cannot be explained. To explain is to defeat. You—you want to get to the bottom of this. Little do you know that this is impossible...
My intentions are none of your business.
Whatever you say, whatever you say…
Keep your advice to yourself.
And get to the bottom of this I will.
Do not measure the limits of the human mind with your yardstick.
No one is expecting that from you.
Do you also have your own ideas about the origins of the epidemic?

The Tower oppresses the Town. The Town smothers the Steppe. The Steppe gnaws at the Tower. That's the three different... heh... pieces. Too different to be put together, like three minds fighting over a single head. If I am not mistaken, this condition is considered to be... pathologic?
You're describing schizophrenia.

Right, exactly. Insanity, absurdity, hallucinations. The whole world is feeling feverish. And the war cannot come to an end, too; the frontline is about to crumble, and then the enemy armies will rush to our southern lands...
No way. Anything but this.
Perhaps you're right.
So you're a part-time prophet now too, old man?

No... My brain is boiling like soup in a pan... So I'm getting ideas. It's just that… you can't have it all at once… This greed would cost you life. And you, doctor, should leave… There's nothing to be done here anyway.
Leave? How in the world could I do that?
Soon, soon the long-awaited train will arrive. Everything will be here—the doctors, the medicine, the food.
Here's to hoping.
I'll leave when I deem appropriate.
Tell me, does any building in the town seem suspicious to you?
Why do you ask?
The carrier or the source of the infection could be there.

Oooh! I thought so—surely someone must be be picking the plague up by the handful somewhere. They throw it around then, and here you go—an outbreak. And then it dies out. Then the next day someone throws more bad stuff around… Sounds plausible… But who can it be? Perhaps the Executors with their masks and their cloaks?
I was asking about a place.

Perhaps it's the infected food from the Warehouses. Or maybe rats? What if something died beneath the ground? Rats gnaw on carrion, tear it to slices—and then they slip into the houses... And there you have it. You should talk to Saburov about that. He's supposed to be in charge of the cellars.
No, I doubt it's that simple.
Thank you.
Everything happens.
I continue getting to know the local sights.
We were lucky twice. This commander is even better than this inquisitor. What do you think?
Are you kindly joking? I've heard that this Alexander Block is rushing to get to the front.
So what?

So what! He's in a hurry! No wonder he's… you know. Feats of arms are waiting for him there—and here he has to deal with rats and purulent rags... It won't take him long, mark my words. Cordon off, bring the weapon in, aim, fire—and that's that.
By the way, where are his quarters?
In the Town Hall. Therefrom he will command, until the bombardment starts.
It won't.
I see.
I hope he is a decent human being.
We have to hope these terrifying weapons are being brought to the front, not here—and for your sake.
The soldiers aren't bullying you, are they?
I was almost shot.
By whom?
The gatehouse post soldiers. Do they have the right to shoot anyone suspicious?
Who cares about rights now... The one whose rifle shoots further has the right.
No. Only the infected.
Rightly so.
You unfortunates are simply out of luck.
I think this is a righteous plague.
Why?
It's a tool of history. We should listen to the voice of time.
Why is your time displeased with you then?
Civilization is about progress. Anything that has no practical use shall be eradicated. Rational thinking conquers all. If you stand in the way of the progress, it will crush you.
I don't have time for idle chatter.
Yes, many would agree with you.
Nonsense.
I am the last person you should bother with these ideas of yours! Be thankful I have spared your life!
So do I.
Go in peace.
Acually, my funds are also running low. Soon I will beg in the streets too.
We know all about you…
Aren't you a lively gal! Shall we barter, perhaps?
What are you so happy about, girl?
We've almost caught the Unseen Cat! Wanna come see her?
Where did you find such a cat?
It's the famous pale cat! Her eyes are like translucent emeralds, her fur's grey, and her body is completely transparent!
I would never go after such a fright.
The light passes right through her! It's very pretty. But most importantly, she's invisible in the dark. And rodents can't hear her—that's how light her step is. She belongs to the Pale Obtuse.
To the What Obtuse?
Ah, it's no use—I know you won't believe me anyways. Just come over and see the cat for yourself when it gets dark, it's by the 12th warehouse. The password is "Hell froze over".
I'll do my best not to forget this intricate phrase.
Not today.
Well, that changes things. Drastically.
So what, can you see its bowels too?
Tell me about the Tower.
What do you want to know?
How does it not fall?
It stands on a firm and very very very solid stem. But it keeps oscillating, too. It was scary at first, but we got used to it.
It contravenes the laws of physics.
Well done!
What's inside of it?
Us. We play there. Khan won't let you in, I take it?
I don't know who Khan is. Haven't had the pleasure yet.
It's just idle interest anyway.
Tell me about the Works.
What is there to tell? Umm… Well, that's where Dad works... and Grandpa used to, too.
Where are they?
What's produced there?
Well… sausages and canned meat, I suppose. Some kind of flour... I mean, I don't know. Meat food. We eat none of this, it's all for the train. Not that I would ever eat anything they make anyway.
Why is that?
Do you know what it smells like in there? Just try it! Eew... I hate that stink.
My stomach doesn't agree with foul odours either.
You're too sensitive, young lady.
I see.
No. I'm allergic to cats.
Definitely.
What's up?
The Soul-and-a-Halves got an opportunity to catch their breath. This is good, now everyone will have the time to prepare. Otherwise we'd have to mourn our boys… and the Halves would be orphaned.
The Soul-and-a-Halves?
It's just a catchy name. Notkin says it's because each of them has a familiar—a cat, a dog, a crow, or a grass-snake. Half-a-soul more than a normal person. Or a normal animal…
Is that a game?

It's a lifestyle that's larger than life! If you join the Soul-and-a-Halves, you have to adopt a pet. As you raise it, you change. Then, when it's grown, it gets the other way round, your Half begins to take care of you. And so you are always together, bound forever.
And what if the animal dies?
I don't know... No Half has ever died before. What kind of a Soul-and-a-Half are you if your familiar can die? They wouldn't take you in in the first place.
Naturally.
Animal lifespan isn't that long.
I see.
Hmm… I thought the locals believed that a normal person is supposed to have one soul. Isn't soul-splitting only reserved to your Steppe abominations by the local folklore?

Are you nuts? The shabnak don't have a soul at all! Although… Perhaps Notkin has finally done it. He used to make fun of the old legends, taunted the Steppe, played spirits. So perhaps the shabnak came to show him his place!
What do they do, those Soul-and-a-Halves of yours?
Stop saying nonsense.
What halves, what in the world are you talking about?
Tell me about the Termitary.
Dad won't let me go there. No one's parents let them. We're not even allowed to come close.
Why? Is it dangerous?

It's the people there. They aren't bad, but they can do you a lot of harm. They believe, for example, that it's okay to eat other people. Or, if a person is buried alive, it's seen as a gift for them, a great honor. And generally… the Termitary people can do something... abominable to you.
Can't anybody do anything about them?

Well, it's not like they actively hurt anyone. They just have their own way… they're all kin to one another. But who knows... It'd be dumb to get on their nerves. It's like going into a beast's cage. Who can tell what's on their mind?
Makes sense.
Children of your age are supposed to be supervised by adults if they go anywhere past their neighbourhood.
Still, how do I get in there?
Go to the east end of the Skinners, you'll see it.
Much obliged.
Tell me about the Abattoir.
Ooooh. It's creepy! Not only are you not supposed to go there, you shouldn't even mention it without need.
Why such extensive precautions?
Brother says it's inhabited by gods so old that beasts used to believe in them before humans even came to exist.
What? Bollocks.

No bollocks. It's all for real. When you come close to them, you do feel that someone impossibly, inconceivably large lives inside. People say the Abattoir so big because it covers the cavities of the unburied udurgh.
What udurgh?

An udurgh is, like, a really really huge living creature. Like an animal god, but made from soil. He produces sticky yellow tar instead of saliva, and it's with this tar that the sky is attached to the ground.
Lovely.
Unburied?

Yeah, he was only buried partially—the bottom's still above the ground. Some people say that the mouth is also sticking out, but others maintain it's his huge belly. And he breathes sometimes, so he hasn't kicked the bucket yet.
...What am I even doing here talking to you?
I'll take a look if I ever get the chance.
Then you really aren't supposed to go there.
And how do I get there?

Come on, you can't miss it. Missing this mostrosity would be an achievement in and of itself! Here's how you go—to the east, then turn once, turn the second time, then go south. It's right there, past the Crude Sprawl and the Skinners.
Thank you.
And the Crude Sprawl and the Skinners are…?

There they are, in Earth! Gee, you're completely clueless, aren't you? Let's see. Here you are, facing the river, right? The Guzzle's to the left, the Gullet's to the right. The area between them is called the Knots. The Stone Yard is to the right from the Guzzle. Earth is to the right of the Gullet. Got it now?
I got it, darling.
No... I didn't.
Ah, you're impossible…!
Well...
Don't worry, you'll get another chance to mourn the boys yet.
Easy there! Where are you running so fast?

Shopping! Everything's getting so pricy… The prices are rising by leaps and bounds! Literally by the hour, and I mean it! An hour ago butter cost a hundred, and now it's five hundred! I can't even imagine what it'll be like by the evening. What am I supposed to tell Mom?
Why is this happening?
People say it's because the train will not come, and because there's something stirring...
What train?

The train train! The one that transports food into the town. We have nothing stored at home, not even flour. You know how much I love stickjaw? And candy boxes, you know, the ones with green, yellow, and orange sweets all mixed up. But I've gobbled up the last one I had a week ago...
That is indeed a sobering tragedy.
So did you buy a lot?

Nothing at all... we don't have that kind of money. Do you know how much they ask for a loaf of bread in the Spleen? Three thousand! You could buy a horse for that! I thought for a bit that I was going bonkers…
So this is what sheer panic looks like…
What?
Never mind.
Are you afraid your mother's going to scold you?

Mom sent us all out shopping. Told us to look all over the Town and buy everything we can. Obviously, first and foremost it's sugar, salt, flour, bread, fish... Oh, oops! No fish, no, and no meat. What else? I forgot...!
I would also recommend buying vitamins and antibiotics. Do you have a drugstore around here?
There's one in the Atrium, two more by the Theatre... you'll find them. There is a drugstore or even two in any segment of the Town. And what are antibiotics?
Ask the druggist—and then go ahead and buy all sorts of them.
Why?
They'll come in handy later.
Thank you.
Do your best to remember then.
Hurry up then—while there still are any goods to buy at all.
You're so pale...
I'm dying for a gulp of milk... But they won't let us milk the cows. Do you by any chance have some?
Who doesn't let you milk cows?

Well, people say that cows have been oozing some ichor instead of milk lately. Auntie said she knows this for sure, and Mom nodded and added that Ayga, the cook, agrees—and she's a Steppewoman and all... she knows everything about cows. Ayga even went as far as to say that milk turned completely black.
She's right; doesn't sound like you should drink such milk. I'll check on your cows or assign this task to someone.
This story alone would be enough to make me never drink milk ever again.
I'm not a nursing mother, am I now?
Did you want to ask me something?
Yes. Have you tested our shmowders?
Shm-what?

I remember us playing shmowders. We used to invent various recipes, taking various amounts of various medicines and mixing them. It was like a competition—whose recipe would turn out to be the most efficient? And, well… some of them were.
How is it possible?

Now I realize that it was all accidental. But the thing is, everyone who participated in the game made more than one shmowder following their recipe. That means there have to be several more efficient shmowders in the town—we only need to figure out whose solution was the useful one.
Hmm… And how would I find this child prodigy if I ever went looking for them?

We don't know that either... Crowfoot's completely lost any skill, Beaker's brothers have died. And no one knows who else was talented with shmowders! There was this one guy… but I doubt he remembers anything at all. We were very little back then, you know. We were simply stealing the prettiest pills—no one really bothered to read labels.
What a shame!
You dummies...
Any chance I could get my hands on them?
Our boys shuffled through several old caches. Hopefully I haven't slipped my beau's mind… and he'll bring me one. Just in case.
And where does one find these old caches?
At the Dovecot or the Mild Dew… Why do you ask? It's not like there's anything left there—except maybe several "dead" shmowders. The ones that kill instantly.
Show me anyway. What's deadly to a five-year-old can become the salvation of an adult.
Fine, whatever.
Let us hope there won't be a case.
I have.
And? Have you figured out what they're made of?
Outdated drugs that are no longer produced.
I haven't.
What's with the disgusted expression?
Yuck! The river water stinks! I wonder why…
What do you mean, "stinks"? Stinks with what?

Who do you think I am, a professional stinker? I don't know! But the stench is awful, and tons of dead fish get washed ashore. Their bellies are all soft, white, and bloated… Yuck… I wonder if the water's been poisoned?
Could be, could be...
I didn't see anything of the kind.
Do elaborate. Are you saying it's abnormal?

Of course! We've got a very clean river here, the girls and I even drank directly from it. But recently water's become filled with fish scales—and the pollution is so thick, as if someone's mixed in this… substance there on purpose. You know, you just put your arm into the water, and when it's out, it looks like a mermaid tail, all scaled. And now it stinks too!
Well, what do you know...
It's just silt.
Do you by any chance know where I could get some water around here?
Almost all barrels have been emptied, but you may luck into leftover water in some of them. You can bottle it up and sell it! I wonder how much a single sip of water will cost in two days…
No less than a million, I guess.
A million? Nah, I don't think it'll go that far. But five thousand sounds plausible.
Just boil riverwater.
There is some running water by the Cathedral and the Theatre, but the flow dies out often. That's because water has to accumulate first.
Yes, that's also an option.
Yeah. It's like we're in a desert.
I'm just… perpetually thirsty. My mouth is sore as though I was always chewing dust.
Same here.
Have you been crying?
Our family is ruined...
What happened?

Do not eat meat! It was banned for a reason! I think meat is precisely where the disease is nesting. It must have all started with someone stuffing themselves full of infected meat. That's why everyone was blaming a maneater, too! It all makes sense now.
What made you think that?

Dad and other men attacked the guards yesterday and pried a meat storage open. The meat was then distributed among our neighbourhood. Then almost all of them fell sick… And I'm so afraid Mom and I will fall sick and die too…
How long ago did you eat the meat?
I don't really remember... Five hours or so, I think…
That's a shame. What about your father? Is he alive?
He was taken into custody.
Go home then.
I don't have a home now. It's infected!
Then go to the Cathedral.
I'm sorry.
It's gonna be all right.
Then it will be okay. If you were sick, you'd have noticed it already.
Fair's fair. That's what burglars get—especially at a time like this.
The disease is nesting everywhere.
I have something for you. Barter?
Bachelor, dear Bachelor! What is it that you have?
A lot of things. What would you offer for this…?
A burning desire to make you all very happy if you stop poking me at every given opportunity.
You are not alone.
Are you smelling of… fish?

No way! You're not supposed to eat fish! Or catch it, or touch it! Neither can you eat bread. Or go outside. You're not supposed to do anything at all, and that includes breathing. So how are we supposed to live?
Cleanse every object you get in contact with, use antiseptics. Boil everything that can be boiled.
Sure… Should we boil air or anneal it?
Just stay in and stop roaming the streets!
And also… I'm just starving for lemons and sugar!
I hear you.
Annealing works best.
Try silver water.
Tell me a story.

Are you for real? All right then. Here's the tale of the Gorkhon river and its tributaties, the Gullet and the Guzzle. Long time ago there lived an old man by the name of Bai Uraggha. He had the head of a bull, the body of a man, and the cow's hooves for hands.
What about his legs?

His legs stretched all across the earth, sinking into it like gigantic roots. He ate rocks, grass, and the trees that were to be found in his vicinity at first. But it didn't take him long to eat everything that his head could reach, and so the ground around him turned to desert.
Then what happened?
All in all, he was gluttonous and helpless. After eating everything he could reach, old Bai Uraggha felt thirsty. Guess what happened next?
I can't possibly imagine.
Think some more then. I'll tell you the ending if you tell me what happened after he felt thirsty.
Fine.
He must have died.
Correct!
What does it have to do with the river?
That's part two of the tale. I'll tell you later.
Looking forward to it.
Poor old man.
I don't have to tell you this, you know.
Sorry for interrupting you. Please, go on.
In all honesty, I don't really have the time for this either.
What is it, my fair lady?
Do you have any nuts?
Why are you looking for nuts?
First of all, you can play with them. And now you can eat them, too.
Didn't you eat nuts before?

Well… Would we eat you? Of course we wouldn't—and you're obviously nuts too. Eating nuts! It's like eating your kitten or your stamps collection. Every nut is a story! A chronicle of adventures. They even have names. But... recently we've begun to eat them. We have to choose each time which of them goes...
It does indeed sound very sad.
Where I come from, nuts are ground into flour by the hundreds—to be added into honey or a sauce.
That's not funny.
Stop teasing the soldiers. They don't have a sense of humour.
Have you seen general Block already?
I have.
What's he like? Does he really have long metal teeth?
He's just a person, same as you.
Great! That means he can be killed! Do you think I could ask for an audience with him and secretly bring a dagger with me? Will I make a good killer?
And how would you lull him into a false sense of security?

I'll try to seduce him. And if he remains passionless, I'll pretend to be a petitioner. I'll kneel before him, crawl to him as if I was trying to grab his hand—and then I'll pierce him with the dagger, right through the heart!
What an ingenious and elaborate plan.
You wouldn't reach his heart.
Don't even think about it.
He has regular teeth… alothough they are kind of long-ish.
I haven't.
What's the news?
The boys are mourning their dogs.
What happened?

Yesterday, the soldiers shot almost all the dogs of the Soul-and-a-Halves. The only survivors were Pong, Mittens, and Lobe. So several boys sharpened their bolts, took their crossbows, and went to the soldiers to get revenge. They haven't come back yet.
Why didn't you stop them?
We'd go with them if we could! But they didn't let us.
None of them will come back.
Good for you then.
Nice job. I would have done the same.
You can find better targets for mourning than dogs around here.
Was there something you wanted to tell me?

A girl named Clara was looking for you. She said she wanted to propose a path to salvation to you. By the way, do you know that she collects people's souls and demands they sign the contracts with blood?
No, I didn't know that. Why is she doing this?

Oh... It's all very complicated—and it makes me very uncomfortable. Everyone's afraid of a maneater for a reason, you know. I think she strikes a deal with them so that they would allow her to use their bodies posthumously somehow… to save everyone.
Is that so... and do people agree?
She has about a dozen signatures, I think. But she needs thirty or forty, something like that. She says that she'll be able to arrange a happy ending for everyone then.
Oh my... I'll do my best to intervene before she succeeds.
See? She's a nice, kind girl.
In all the time that I've been struggling with your lot, I haven't heard of a single act of cannibalism. So cut it, will you?
I'm not interested in Clara or her proposals.
Why are you so upset?
Mom said it's time we all went to the dumster. What do you think?
I agree.
But it's not like you'll be able to escape this fate either. You'll be taken to pieces and turned into stuffing and rags… heh.
"Heh" indeed.
Don't get in my way.
I think your mother is way too strict.
Nah, she's just rational. She has seen things. If she says dumpster, dumpster it is. I've always been dowdy, I'm pretty plain. And kind of a bonehead, too.
Well, dumpster it is then.
Don't say that. You are a charming little lady.
No, I don't think so.
I know all about you too.
Wow… that's startling! What's wrong with you?
Let's trade. Just look at this thing I've got…
Well, you know. I'm leaving the town soon. Do you know the train schedule?
Hey, but will you revive Grandpa? When the game starts again, I'll ask him to make me a hunter!
Who are you going to hunt?
If Grandpa shows you how to hunt right, you can even catch a star. But you can only keep it for a while. Only while the game is on.
And what are you playing?
It's autumn, so we're playing Underground Bonfire. Do you know the rules?
I used to play it when I was a kid.
You couldn't have played it when you were a kid! Grandpa only invented it a month ago!
All right, you got me.
Who knows...
No, I don't.
That's an inherent quality of stars.
I'm not so sure, little fellow.
Don't lose your heart! Miracles happen, right?
Of course they do.
Today has proven that there are no miracles.
So you're playing, huh?
Whoever finds another one first gets to eat them! These are the rules.
What are you talking about?
That's how the hide-and-seek works. You are the hunter, you are the hunted. Whoever finds the opponent first kills them.
Does that include me?
Of course it does! Beware.
Don't worry, kid. I'll finish the killer, whoever they are. I am the hunter.
I'll find the hunter, wherever they hide.
Thank you for the lesson.
You really shouldn't be running around like that…
Do you know me?
Yes. You are the Bachelor. You know about the Changeling and the Ripper, right? They're at your heels! And they use every opportunity you miss to their advantage.
What do you mean?
And they spoil your plans all the time! They talk behind your back and tell lies about you!
How?

Clara says you love the truth so much that you won't tolerate any lie at all and will raze to the ground anything that resembles it. Burakh says that you only care for your mind, not your heart, and that you are unkind.
I wonder how they know all this.
Because they are your doubles.
I doubt that.
They aren't telling lies. This is all true, kiddo.
And he's kind, huh.
Uh huh. And Clara is also very nice, she cares about everyone and keeps them safe. People say she's a saint.
What a hypocrite she is...
Then let us hope that I'm the most evil of us three.
Those bastards!
What's with the open mouth, kid? You're drawing flies.
Is it true that they can raise people from the dead in the Capital?
Who told you such nonsense?
My dad! He read about you in the papers.
I just wanted to make it so that people would live longer, really. And, preferably, on their own accord.
Sounds cool! So they wouldn't be able to die on someone else's accord then, right?
That would be too cool to be true.
People will forever keep dying on someone else's accord.
Rubbish.
Yes, it is.
What?
Wanna know what will happen to the Ripper?
And what will happen?
He will heal the god. And then the grief for the loss will break him. That's because a very pretty lady will fall in love with him shortly, and right now he's crafting the tool for her execution.
Wait, wait, wait. Why? What execution?
He has no choice! He wants to help everyone. He is actually not a Ripper, he's a Haruspex. He is a lot like you, honest and kind. Maybe he's your brother?
I'm not kind.
Please spare me a brother like this.
How do you know all this?
Because we gossip about you all the time.
Ah, I see...
That is not something I would ever want to know.
What's up, kiddo?
Do you like Clara? The Changeling?
I'm not sure.
She is the person who can definitely raise people from the dead! We personally saw Clara drive the disease out of a person. He regained consciousness and went back to his family.
How did she do it?

She put pressure on his eyes and temples—here and here—with her hands. It went on for a while. Then she held his head in her embrace and kissed his nails. Then dirt came spilling down from below his eyelids, and black worms crawled out of his sleeves. And then he started breathing a little, then a little more—and came back to life.
That is impossible.
From what I've heard of her, not in the slightest.
Why not?
I think she's a fraud.
She always sticks her nose into other people's affairs. And she'll get her just dessert if she keeps doing it!
Hey hey hey! Don't you say bad things about her! We won't be able to play without Clara.
Play?
Yeah, we play with her.
Then tell her not to get in my way!
I see...
I won't—if she behaves.
Do you have anything useful to trade?
The Bachelor is up for trading cool thingamajigs! Yay! Do you really wanna trade? For real?
I do.
Not this time, kid.
I am yet to determine that.
Why are you looking at me askance?
Mom says you're cold and calculating.
How does your mother know that?

Because everyone is talking about you, because you're a celebrity, and because everything we're hoping for depends on you. We're all so, so scared of you. And Dad says that you are a breath away from death and they're gonna force you to make the wrong choice.
Who is going to do that?
I don't know. I'm a little boy. I'm just repeating what I've heard from the grown-ups.
Hmm... You're really too sharp for a little boy.
Think for yourself and stop misquoting people.
You common folk are definitely biting more than you can chew here. Reserve your judgement for the matters you know a thing or two about.
Mom is completely right.
Who do you want to be when you grow up?
When I grow up and become an adult like you, I'm going to be a puppeteer. Like Mark Immortell. I'll do magic tricks, pull puppets by the strings and tell fortune from someone else's bones!
A daring dream. So you want to manipulate others?
It's either that or the other way round...
You couldn't have come up with this on your own.
Yeah, that's what Dad says.
Perhaps your dad said that in a bad mood.
Your father is very smart. Great parenting.
No, it's doesn't necessarily work like that. You can be simply yourself and remain free.
When I was very young, I wanted to be a military man. It was just about the time the war ended. My parents thought I'd become a celebrated counqueror.
Then I think you'd like to know that troops are arriving here soon! The troops of Alexander Block, the conqueror!
What did you say? How do you know this?
The Polyhedron showed us a prophecy! A train of iron will arrive, filled with armed soldiers. They're bringing giant cannons with them to raze the town to the ground and exterminate all life here!
…But why?
What do you mean? So that we don't spread the disease, of course!
Makes sense... But hopefully we won't have to deal with anything of the kind.
Don't worry, kiddo. We will exterminate the disease before they point their guns at us.
I know that already.
Did you want to ask me something?
Have you made friends with Mark Immortell?
No. I don't trust him. He's sleazy, like a weasel or a snake. He likes to be economical with the truth—and that is something that I abhor.
Oh yes! You love the truth and want to know it, right?
I guess so…
No need to guess, it's obvious. And Mark—he knows the truth and is afraid to distort it. That's why he uses masks, puppets, and riddles.
Perhaps.
Once again you are demonstrating the level of intelligence that I find rather disconcerting.
Sorry! Won't happen again.
Yes, please be so kind as to avoid doing this in the future.
Bear in mind that there's only one smart person here: me.
He's a curious fellow.
What's that noise?
The maneater escaped through a locked door again!
Yeah, right.
She did! And they said it's safe inside! How can it be safe if she creeps through the cracks?
Stop saying nonsense.
Listen to the adults. They'll explain it to you.
Let us hope she is gone for good then.
Are you all right?
I'm scared by the Masks. I know it for sure that there are no people beneath them!
Who is beneath them then?
Sometimes I think it's the sharp claws and white nails of someone's gigantic fingers...
Wow! Your imagination is staggering.
You think so? That's a rather ingenious remark. Especially considering the role they play in your dying society...
Sometimes I think so as well.
I really hope I'll have a chance to depart this place as soon as humanly possible... I'm sick of it.
Maria said she likes you so very much that she'd be willing to renounce the throne for you.
…And follow me into exile?
I don't know. I'll remember to ask her if the topic ever comes up again. And it probably will, since you are all she really talks about. Are they going to exile you?
Don't even think about it. It was just a quip.

Keep her safe, will you? She's a bit odd, but really nice. I'd be glad if she ruled over us. Then our life would be beautiful, engaging, and—most importantly—adventureous! She can transport us all into a wonderland.
Of couse I will. She'll be safe.
I can't say I care for her all that much.
But she does care for you…! What a shame. Oh well, your call...
My call indeed.
Most likely. It doesn't seem that I'm likely to return triumphant from here.
Ahem. Well, one certainly couldn't tell that by her attitude.
Hey kid, where is the Hindquarters?
It's on the Gullet's bank. It's where The Willows and the pub are located, and the Works are by the Hindquarters' side.
What is the Gullet?
The river that cuts the town transversely. The one closer to the Abattoir.
I see.
Thank you.
Could you point me the way to the Crude Sprawl?
Ooh... it's on the outskirts of the town, by the cemetery and the Abattoir. If you keep going past it—kinda diagonally, you know?—you'll get to the Rotten Field.
And... what's the Rotten Field?
It's where they bury the bulls' bones. The place is covered with fur instead of grass, and it's all bones bones bones underground. Bones and horns. Yeah.
I see.
Thanks.
Tell me about the Theatre.

Oh, it's our piece de resistance! The place for the most significant things to happen! The shows they do... puppet plays about a shade, an orphan that came out victorious, a little thief girl, and a scientist who made the world end! Lots of stuff!
So it's a puppet show, huh.
Not only that! They also have the Masks perform every evening, but I'm not allowed to those shows.
Why?
I'm too little a boy.
I see.
And where is it?
On Spin-a-Yarn Square, duh!
And where is that?
It's in the Marrow district. That's in the middle of the Knots, closer to the Guzzle.
What is the Guzzle?
It's when you're very very hungry and eat or drink something very very quickly. Look, here.
Yeah, I know what guzzling is.
It's a transversal river. The one closer to the Polyhedron.
Now I see.
Thank you for clearing this up for me. I was at a loss before this enlightening lesson.
All right, see you later then.
Tell me about the Tower.
You don't need that.
Why not?
Because we won't let you in anyway. There's a secret room inside.
And what's in there?
Like I said, a secret.
Well, suit youself.
Who is "us"?
The little ones.
Do you play there?
Oh yes! We very much do! We also live there. And go on journeys sometimes.
Hmm, I see.
Okay then, no pressure.
What's that Cathedral in the central square?
It's not the central square at all, it's Bridge Square. And the central square is the Spin-a-Yarn one.
Why is it called Bridge Square?

Because at first no one knew there was going to be the Tower, so the plan was to create a square that would be completely situated on a very large bridge, like that wide! They would make a fun-fair there.
Well, I guess the Tower is quite more compelling.
Of course it is. I mean, there could have been magicians at the fun-fair... But the Tower is way more exciting than any magic tricks.
Why is that?
Well… Because.
You have masterfully evaded the question.
And still—what about the Cathedral?
I don't know... Never been there. My sister attends it sometimes. And always comes back with a handful of love letters!
That's olain hypocrisy!
How old is she?
I think… twenty? I think.
Then it makes sense.
A pity the plan fell through!

No it's not! The Polyhedron is obviously better! What would they sell at the fun-fair? The things that the train delivers? You can get them in any store already. It's boring... no toys, no stickjaws, no fireworks...
They'd think of something.
Yeah, I love fireworks too.
Great question, kiddo!
I've heard so much about you, ooooh!
What's in your pockets, pumpkin?
Presents. Uncle Bachelor, do you want to trade presents?
Why not? Sure.
You can't just trade presents away.
Let's barter, pumpkin! I can see that you have a lot of interesting things…
Why so gloomy, pumpkin?
I want Grandpa to get better! It's sad without him...
Is your grandpa sick?
My grandpa is dead. Grandpa Simon is sick. No one plays with me now... The grown-ups never let us into their games. Neither do the boys.
He really loved you little ones, didn't he?
"Loved"? Why do you put it like that? He still loves us. And he always will. Even the naughty ones.
Sure, of course… Just a slip of the tongue.
Grandpa Simon is also dead, pumpkin.
Grandpa will get better. Now go play.
Don't be sad, pumpkin.
What's up?
Are you really playing hide-and-seek with a maneater?
Yes. And when I catch him, I'll eat him!
Be careful though! Everyone is very frightened. He's a good runner and he has strong teeth. A good eater too. A gobbler even.
Sure, I'll be careful.
Don't be frightened.
Who in the world is filling your little heads with all this…? There goes my hope that at least the kids would be exempt from baloney-spewing…
What maneater?
The one that ate Grandpa Simon.
Don't be silly.
Why else would everyone say that there's not a single piece left of him?
No one says that to me.
Go play in the sandbox.
Don't worry. Grandpa Simon is fine. Hopefully I'll soon get a chance to confirm that first-hand…
You shouldn't be running around unsupervised!
What's the news?
This Clara, the make-believe saint-girl, is actually a dirty liar!
Oh really? Did she lie to you?
Not to me, no. But now I know very well that she's not who she pretends to be!
Who is she then?
When she lays her little hands on someone, people die. Everybody said she had a healing touch. But it's the other way round…! Better avoid her embrace. Her hands are far from tender…
Did you actually witness anyone die?

My brother told me. He did. She walked right behind an armed mugger as he squatted trying to ambush someone. Brother was keeping an eye on him. Clara put her palms on his eyes. He gave a jolt and then went quiet and fell down stone cold very soon. And Clara just laughed and walked away.
Quite a story…
Attagirl! You'd be better off avoiding the likes of her though.
It's not like I'm interested in her tenderness.
What, has she been beatified already?
Beauty-what? As in made pretty?
I'm saying you people were quick to proclaim her a saint.
She's no saint! She is actually the baddest killer there is! There goes the promise to "save us all"…
Why do you call her a killer?
And who said that Clara would save everyone?

They said two harbingers were to arrive, one of them celestial and fair, bound to save everyone, her hands warm. The other is her dark doppelganger, a shabnak-adyr—a clay maneater made of the bones of the wrong dead people. She'll crawl from beneath the ground, and plague will devour this land. There you go.
And what do you personally make of this? (...I wonder who fills their little heads with this drivel?)

At first it was believed to be about the Mistresses, Maria and Capella. But I'm so fond of Maria! She shines from the inside and she's all magical! I'll never in a million years believe that she's shabnak-adyr the maneater. So it has to be a spirit thing. And that means Clara is one of them…
Is she? Which one? The good or the bad?
Sounds unconvincing. The Mistress interpretation is actually more plausible.
Whoa... And which dead people are wrong?
The ones that were only half-buried. They were naughty in life, and the Earth couldn't digest them. So their bones make evil spirits. You'd better ask Grace, she explains it very well.
And what does Clara have to do with all this?
I see. I'll ask Grace for clarification.
Nevermind. Just thinking out loud.
Hi there, pumpkin.
I've heard a lot about you too.
You look cheerful, that's a good sight.
Do not condemn us for our lasciviousness. That's just how the local customs and morals are…
Do give me a shoulder massage, girl. I'm tired. My muscles ache.
Let me kiss you, will you? It will invigorate me.
I have something for you.
If this is a token on your affection, then I shall offer you the last thing I have in exchange.
Deal. Let's barter.
I've heard the word "maneater" repeated more than once today. What was it all about?
Soft flesh, warm blood... So sweet! I can constantly feel it with my whole body. There is a maneater in any of us girls. Wouldn't you agree, darling?
I agree, but I also find anthropophagism terrifying.

Well, you don't really think she dragged Simon to the kitchen and is boiling him there on a slow fire, do you? Of course not. It's all very metaphoric. If he's overwhelmed by her, if he's into her, if she had her way with him… then she's a maneater.
Who, Simon? I thought he was two hundred years old at least.
Flesh is eloquent! It says a lot about its owner. Simon's body was made from very tough flesh and very hot blood. A body to be jealous of… like yours. It would be a shame is shabnak tracked you down.
Why don't we talk about something lovely instead? Like you, for example.
You know there's only one thing on my mind…
I can see that.
You've had a bit too much.
Enough, please.
Metaphoric?
Are you being so predatory on purpose? These little games of yours can end badly, you know.
Tell me about your customs.

The body is sacred. The naked body is the most accurate image of the world. People used to tend to their bodies as if each of them were a shrine. Cripples and freaks used to be banished from the community not so long ago—just before the Saburovs came to power. Such was the bidding of the Kin. They were devoured by the Steppe. Earth corrected its mistakes.
Why do you strip your sacred body naked then?

Because I know the Dance and have the right to do so. But in the Termitary they wrap themselves in so many clothes and cloths that it becomes impossible to make out human features beneath all that. They cover their bodies to set up some protection againts evil spirits. And it's not like they worry about themselves...
Who are they worried about then, my sweet dervish?

They know that the body doesn't belong to them. Who would be hurt if a bull were to bite a finger off them? The whole bottomless cosmos would. Everything is akin to everything and everything is interconnected with everything. You know about that, don't you?
It contradicts natural sciences, but… generally it can be accepted that your theory has the right to exist.
Oh, you killjoy... So many words! Why don't you just smile instead?
There, is that better?
Of course I do, my pretty. You stop being smart over there and just dance, okay?
Is your dance special in some way?
Yes. It is a tribute to our world's beauty.
Oh, that I'm perfectly willing to accept.
What happened to them next?

That's the scary part! The locals believed that if the Steppe doesn't accept a freak back into her womb, they'll creep out again as an evil spirit—a nastail, a mara, or a shabnak-adyr. That's how it goes. And that's why no one really cared for freaks around here.
Some cruel utopia was being built here.
Not even close, as they say... But butchers can feel it very acutely. They have to. It's the law of survival. A guarantee that the world wouldn't turn against them one day... Like it does now.
So, the whole issue is that somebody had had their little finger cut off… And here I am, running around and trying to find the reason behind all this.
Don't make fun of me. It's only a legend, but there is an ancient truth to it.
Anything is possible.
Come on, these are just silly fairytales…
Do you like me?
They say you're the smart hero.
That is correct. I'm an intellectual. That means I'm very smart.
How are you smart? Smart people are four-eyed nerds… bulgy heads on stunted legs. Cunning, cautious, weak, old even… no, you are not a smart man. You are a warrior.
So intelligence is a sign of weakness to you?
That's just common knowledge. Women of the Steppe do not love smart men. We love violent men, furious men, we love destroyers. Were you not one of those, would I have fallen in love with you?
You are correct. I am a destroyer.
How so?
I destroy lies with my mind.
Oh... So that's why there are always sparks of hatred in your eyes. And that's why your smile is so spiteful.
That's because I'm destroying the disease now. And I will succeed—no matter the cost.
But not for you, sweet angel.
I destroy death.
I destroy superstition.
You can be both.

Really? I thought you can only have one. Your eyes are throwing needles, and your teeth are clenched fast. You've got the face of a man who can sweep down anything that stands in his way. The face of a destroyer.
Correct. This is the true purpose of smart people.
You know so much about me! I wonder how?

It's a den... Everyone loosens their tongues here. Some due to alcohol, some due to swevery, and some due to delight. You can't remember who says what, but everyone is talking about you. They say you don't look like a smart man.
Why?
Tell me my fortune, sweet girl.
How am I supposed to tell your fortune? You don't have a heart.
Wrong. I do.
But it's cold, isn't it?
What makes you say that?
You are absolutely heartless. Seems like pity is alien to you. Even your obsession can't really be called a feeling.
My weapon is cold reason. It has no need of emotions.
You are correct. Pity is not the feeling I foster.
Is it so obvious?
You are very beautiful.
Do you really never tell lies?
I hate lies.
Why? Lies are often inescapable. And they make your heart feel warm and nice, too...
It is through lies that the weak and the dishonest set their dark plans into motion.
What makes you think they have to be dark?
Because they replace the true state of affairs with a false one to profit from someone else's suffering.
It's in their nature.
I don't have a heart, remember?
Nothing is more villanous than deceit.
Why? I didn't say "deceit". Telling a lie doesn't equal deceit.
All my life those who pretended that black was white prohibited me from winning. Every deceit hides someone's dark intentions.
Why don't you tell me who the carrier is?
Look, there are so many of them around… A thousand and a half, no less! Every third of us is boiling alive. Every single one is ready to drag his fellow man with him. So which one do you need?
No, you don't understand. I need the person that spreads the infection but doesn't get sick in the process.
Like the Typhoid Maid?
Yes. Precisely.
How horrible... Perhaps she doesn't even know herself how dangerous she is. Can you imagine? She must feel nothing…
Wait a moment! Why are you saying it's a "she" rather than a "he"?

I don't know... It just slipped out. Maybe it's because we were talking about the Maid. And everyone's looking for a female maneater, you know. It must be the same wretch… All in all, it just slipped out.
All right...
I feel that you know more than you're letting show.
What Typhoid Maid?

People say all kinds of things around here, you know… So they say that in a faraway land beyond the sea, in the West, there was a horrible pestilence a hundred years ago. Only in their case it was typhoid. And then it turned out it was all because of a maid. She worked for modest households, went from one kitchen to another to make soup. She was sick with typhoid, but in such a fashion that she didn't die.
Yes, exactly. Perhaps someone like her is walking this place too.
Yes, you are right… and each one fits the bill.
What's the word in the den?
Turns out the Inquisitor is late Mistress Nina' sister. A younger one. I wonder if they are alike…
This cannot be!

Can you imagine? I stood their gaping too. Some of those who were loyal to Nina came to pay their respects to the sister of the late Mistress. They came to pay respects—but ended up paying a terrible price for that! We were too rash to assume that such an inquisitor wouldn't execute people.
But why? For being loyal to Nina?

They hate one another. Or rather the inquisitor hates the Mistress. I think Nina probably disregarded her at all. Not a single person who knew Nina—take Andrey, for example—remembered her ever talking of having a sister…
How do you know that?
Ah, I don't know... Rumour has it. Andrey has a face like thunder, see? Although I can't say he was surprised by the news. Perhaps he did know beforehand?
Perhaps.
Curious…
What does that entail?
Everyone who loved Nina is probably going to face bad times… We were too rash to assume such an inquisitor wouldn't execute people.
Why?
Don't worry, it can't be worse than what you have right now.
You dancers are so serene—as always. Are you really not afraid at all?
The darkest hour is always just before dawn. It feels so great to clean out all the dirt and start life anew!
Yes, good thinking…
I'm so afraid of the debauched soldiers though. They're definitely going to frequent the pub.
Start a rumour that it's not a pub, but rather a plague house.
They won't be stopped by that.
Well, their commander is keeping them in check for now.
They won't be staying here for long.
That's how it always is.
I wish...
How do you think it's all going to end?
Simon will live eternal as long as the Polyhedron stands; that means all the prophecies have already come true.
Could you please remind me what prophecies you're talking about?
That Simon is meant to live forever. They said he had died—but he hadn't! The Kains will transfer his soul to the Polyhedron, and it will flicker there eternally, shining its light upon us.
And how are they going to do that?
I don't know... Why are you asking me about it? I have no skill to talk about it. That's what Yulia—or better yet, Maria—is for.
Then I'm off to their places.
Forget it.
Do you believe in the immortality of the soul?
How can I not? The soul is immortal, but it gradually departs the world of the living and goes away into space, faraway and cold. If you let it go, it will be lost in the void forever.
And what about transmigration of souls?
Nonsense.
Get drunk and think about nothing.
What's with this… odd smile?
I want you to be happy. Touch me tenderly... Take my hand above the wrist or my waist. Lower...
What's gotten into you?
We shall all disappear soon—only you will remain. I want you to be happy.
Why would you all disappear?
We cannot live. I feel that when those up above us will be deciding our fate, it will turn out that we are not to live in this world. We will have to be no more. Am I right?
You quite probably are.
We'll see.
Thank you.
Nothing can be further from my mind.
I don't have the time to anyway.

If you see a mugger, barber, looter, firestarter—any violent person, really—you go ahead and whistle or call for the guards. Just enunciate the word, will you? G-U-A-R-D-S. Otherwise we may confuse it for the shrieks of the infected. They're wailing constantly, y'see; out loud, and collectively, too.
Are there a lot of infected people here? I'd rather avoid them…
So you're patrolling the streets? Be so kind and protect those who can't stand up for themselves.
Enunciate, hmph… Are you aware that whistling is actually a skill—and not everyone has it?
The infected areas are strictly off-limits. Keep out.
I want to barter.
See this thing? I've taken it off a thug. Keeping an eye on them is your job, by the way. I will barter one for one.
I've been granted emergency powers. You must have been informed by the governor. I'm Bachelor Dankovsky.

Yessir, we were, sir. I apologize; better safe than sorry. Come through. But keep in mind, sir, they're all crazed, mad, and insane in there. Possessed. If they attack you, go ahead and run anywhere, but do not kill them! We'll have to intervene and beat you within an inch of your life. For they are innocent and in pain.
So they are going to attack me, but not you? How in the world does that work?

Well, you is doc. We patrolpeople have nothing to offer them but a good old blow on the head, and we won't let them out. They tried to escape, there's no denying that. They did. We taught them a lesson though. And we're protected, too, thanks to you.
Protected?

Yessir… They've distributed them pills among us, told us 'twas on your orders. Told us they're very much a good remedy to invigorate the body, but bad for the heart. Also they make it so that your blood doesn't curdle no more, but rather fills them veins, making them bursty and thus shabby... Am I saying it right?
You seem to be describing cardiovascular diseases—in which case you are correct, yes.
You should stop trying to be smart, mate. Just stand guard.
I had nothing to do with it.
But infected people are a danger to society.

Yessir! Which is why they have been blocked off on the governor's orders. What business would you have with them? We keep your life peaceful and free of them—and theirs is free of your exasperation as well. You're welcome to come and take the risk if you so desire, but please keep your emotions to yourself.
I'll try to.
Just do your job, will you?
…What are you saying, Kindred One? Don't you see who stands before you? I know the lines. I am Isidor's son…

Oh, it's you… Yeah, I see you right and clear. Well… I for one have always respected your father. As for you, I've never believed it was you that… well, your father… oh, forget it. Rest in peace and all that. Come through. Just you watch it—are you really as quick on the draw as they say?
No way. All lies. I'm calm and gentle.
Okay, okay, go… Your goal is the potion, isn't? The golden twyrine tear? Can it really be made?
Everything happens. What about you? Do you drink infusions or brews?

I do… Our guys used to take them from Stakh, Isidor's apprentice. Way better than them pellets. We distribute those among the population—they love pellets, especially the ladies. But a brew's a solid thing. That's why we're standing here all engulfed in the pest—and we couldn't care less... Come on now, go. I've no time for idle chatter.
Thank you, Kindred One.
Keep drinking them then. And drink mine, too, they work.
It can. All in due time. I'll make it if you stop bothering me.
I am what I am.

Hush… Watch it! No killing the infected! Go ahead and exterminate them marauders, killers, and thugs—I'll be more than grateful. But don't you lay a finger on them infected! I'll attack you straight away then, and it matters not that it was your old man that had cut my sore out from me. For 'tis my duty. You gotta know how it works.
I do. Don't worry.
Deal. But don't complain if I fight back.
Be silent, human. Here is my home. Don't you dare stand in my way.
You idiot! I know!
Don't you know who I am? The disease will not take me. I have no fear.
Calm down. I'm a surgeon. You got my drift?
Anything I can do for you?
I'd be much obliged if you helped me learn how to get around your town.

There's more than one town here. The first one is called the Bull Project. The second one—the offspring of the Project—is the Districts, I mean the residential part itself. Not so long ago the town also dropped anchor across the river, but I wouldn't go so far as to call that part a district too. It's just... the Polyhedron.
Tell me about the Bull Project.

It's the industrial base of the town. The Station, the Warehouses, the Works, and the Abattoir all belong to it. I wouldn't recommend going there... It's not an appropriate place for a person from the Capital. It's filthy there, and the stench... I'd say it's not an appropriate place for anyone at all.
Didn't think about going there anyway. Say, how come such a tiny town is divided into districts?
I've hated beef for as long as I can remember.
"The Districts"? A peculiar way to call the… well, the town itself.

Well, it just sort of came to be that way... The Gullet and the Guzzle—the Gorkhon's tributaries—divide the town into three parts; each of them consists of many separate courtyards, so maybe that's the reason.
And what are those parts?

The lower part, adjacent to the Abattoir, is called Earth. The one between the Gullet and the Guzzle we call the Knots. And the triangular promontory between the Guzzle and the Gorkhon is the Stone Yard.
That's… intricate. What about the districts' names?

The Stone Yard consists of two districts: the Bridge Square and the Atrium—plus the Mistresses' Tombs, of course. Earth has four residential districts: the Skinners, the Tanners, the Hindquarters, and Crude Sprawl. In the middle...
Is something wrong?

I'm just not sure you need any of this... The Knots have seven districts: the Spleen, the Marrow, the Chine, the Backbone, the Mouth, the Flank, and the Gut. I don't suppose I need to go into further details; surely the Kains will show you around. They are expecting you after all.
Much obliged.
…Starting this conversation was a mistake.
That'll do for now.
I see. Well, here's to hoping none of it comes up today.
And what's inside of that... Polyhedron?

Nothing really... Children like to play there, I guess. And they say it's perfectly empty, bare as the palm of your hand. What could there be inside such a monstrosity? I find it unbelievable that it's still standing at all. I'd never let my children enter the damn thing. Ever.
I see. What about the Bull Project?
So you've never actually been there yourself?
The kids don't like it when we grown-ups try to visit them in the Polyhedron… Not like there's anything special in there. Why would anyone even want to climb that thing?
All right. By the way, why do you call your town "the Districts"?
Thank you.
Tell me about the Town Hall.

The Town Hall is the most useless place in the whole town, I'm telling you. The only thing it's good at is taking up space. It's the most prominent building in the Backbone. Sinister... and still useless.
Why useless?

Because we are ruled by the—well—Rulers. There are no officials around here, and no need for them, too. You want to know what's up there, in the Town Hall? The post office and the jail, nothing more. It's fine; they'll finally repurpose the building someday. Turn it into a school maybe? Whatever the facility, it would still be of better use.
I see. How do I get to the Backbone?
How come you still haven't got a map? You're lost for good without one! The Backbone is in the Knots. That's the middle part of the Districts, between the Gullet and the Guzzle.
Much obliged.
A school instead of a jail? Great idea.
What is the Termitary?
Two massive buildings in the eastern part of Earth. The Termitary marks the Districts' border. Beyond that there is only the Abattoir and then the Steppe itself. People do not belong there.
Why?
Well... They just don't. It's not a people place.
But someone has to work there, right?
Some… folk do. The Steppe people, the butchers. That's way outside of your area of expertise, believe me.
That was intriguing, my good man.
I have a feeling you're not much of a talker.
I see.
The Warehouses is a district as well, right?

It is. But there's not much to tell about it… It consists of two parts. The first part is where everything that the town exports is stored: meat, sausage, ham, bone meal, and so on. The other one stores various hardware, and also the manufactured goods that the regular train delivers.
And how do I get there?

That's in the Knots—its southeasternmost part, to be precise. To the east of the Station. The meat warehouses are the ones closer to the Station, the hardware ones are closer to the town. There's a railroad track running between them.
Thank you.
Tell me about Nina.

When Nina died, everyone was terrified. No one could wrap their mind around it; it was truly and utterly unthinkable—and yet it happened. Dying is not really a common habit around here, you see. And so when Nina passed away, everyone started saying that a shabnak came for her soul, or maybe a turnskin... a creature from beyond.
I see. But what can you tell me about Nina herself? Her name doesn't really ring that many bells to me.

Nina Kaina! Nina the sorceress... The most gorgeous woman I've ever seen. So wild and fierce and intimidating! Just one brief look at her walking down the street—with or without her escort—could make you weak in the knees. You could almost picture her upon a throne. She could cut you with a knife looking you in the eye—and no one would say a thing. Only a shabnak could take that one.
So what, did anyone find the turnskin?
Not really.
So now you want to give it another try?
Very funny…
I'm not in the mood for laughing. At all.
Now that's a twist.
What is a "shabnak"?

A make-believe monster from the Steppe... A bloodsucker of some sort... just, you know, a revenant from beyond. Or maybe a possessing demon... I don't really believe in such things. On the other hand, sometimes the things you see... Live here long enough and you'll get used to all kinds of weirdness. The Steppe is wiser than we are.
Uh huh. Definitely wiser.
Where is the Station?
Didn't you get here by train?
I got here by chance. How do I find the Station?

The Station is not a part of the Districts... It's a part of the Bull Project. It is located in the southernmost part of the town. Attached to it, so to speak. And still, how did you get here? If our regular train was here...
What is a regular train?

A goods train which delivers edibles and other things... As you can see, we have nothing around here. The train usually comes on the 25th of every month... but now it's already two weeks past due! The last one was here in July.
I see.
I got here on a switch engine.
I asked you first.
Tell me about the Abattoir.
Just your regular abattoir.
Clear as daylight.
Death is never a habit—not even someone else's. You can't really get used to it.
What is the history of this place?
The town was built step by step.
Please do tell more. Yesterday I had a geography lesson, today let's have a background review.
The town grew bigger as the owners of the Bull Project grew richer. Eventually the Town of Beasts surrendered and became the Town of Men.
Go on...

The Town of Beasts nurtured the Town of Men—and demanded nothing in return. That's how the Districts came to be. The inhabitants of the Town of Men didn't really concern themselves with bulls. All they did was build, trade, and craft... Even the smell is somehow not omnipresent.
Fascinating.
The town is thriving. Life couldn't be better.
Sounds like a real utopia. It's mind-boggling to think that this is all possible in a small community built upon a gigantic factory.
That's because our rulers prefer investing into the local environment.
And why is that?

I think they kind of feel like the rulers of the world—and it makes sense, after a fashion. Our self-sufficient town is a world; it became a model of the Universe. See? It's lost in the Steppe void, brought up by the ancient traditions of our savage people.
Whoa! That's some big words.
Good day to you.
Good point, by the way. Judging by the size of your... Abattoir, the production must also be massive; the whole place is supposed to be reeking of bulls!

Miraculously, it doesn't. The Abattoir doesn't let the scent of death out. All the stench in Earth comes from the factories. And even that is negligible, really... Well, that's just one of the peculiar quirks of the place.
I see.
What exactly do you mean by the "Town of Beasts"?
Just, you know... It's absolutely barbaric. Bulls set the pace there, not people. And the people that work with the beasts aren't really so far ahead of them, evolutionarily speaking.
I see. So what happened next?
Have a good day.
Three different worlds coexist within the town. Surprisingly, they are all in accord, but it's really startling that they are—and unclear how that's possible.
I've noticed that too.
On the other hand, people of the three worlds don't really mix with each other. Though coexisting, traditionally the parts remain separate.
But what was the foundation stone, so to speak? The Abattoir?

Historically, the oldest craft around here was tanning; eventually a group of factories sprouted on the river bank. About eighty years ago that settlement burned away, and then the Abattoir was constructed.
It was only constructed eighty years ago? Unbelievable! I was sure that was some sort of a megalith...

Later on people wanted to refashion it into a factory. There had been some unusual stone formations and caves; they were... repurposed. Yeah, that was quite an eccentric solution. But a clever one, too: no need for complex constructions—just use what nature itself provided you with.
Repurposed… but not refashioned into a factory? Why?
The Kin resisted.
How in the world is the Kin so mysteriously influential—and yet I've never had the pleasure of meeting it?
Wow. It seems that the love for absurd structures is a far more ancient trend in this country than I could ever imagine.
What about the Abattoir?

The access to the Abattoir was restricted, so the Works emerged as a separate complex. All because the Foreman of the Abattoir made a deal with Olgimsky, promising to double the product in exchange for nonintervention into the Abattoir's internal matters.
What a curious deal. Care to elaborate on that?

I don't know any details, really. But rumour has it they've made an agreement. Olgimsky managed to install the current Foreman to the position of the head of the Kin—and the Foreman serves him in exchange, making sure that the whole Kin works for the Bull Project.
So the profits go to Olgimsky, huh?
That's right.
Hmm...
Farewell.
I'd like to talk some more about the feudal lords. Tell me a little about the three families, please.
What do you think of the Kains?
I have a soft spot for resolute, outstanding, and bold people. Their kind is rare nowadays.

You're right... the Kains are conquerors by nature. They fear nothing. They're up in arms and ready to overthrow any rules, any dogmas, any taboos. You have that in common with them, don't you? Well... every coin has a flip side.
And what is that?

The Kains are insane. Possessed, like lead performers on the stage. They're cruel; without a moment's hesitation they would sacrifice anything in the world to achieve their brilliant goals. To their credit, their sacrificial list always starts with themselves. lt has always been that way.
How do you know which way it's always been?

Their family goes a long way. It is at least ten centuries old. Might well be that their roots are lost in the depths of time immemorial. People used to be more attuned to magic back then, and a human life used to cost less. Do be careful around them, Bachelor…
I appreciate your advice.
Don't tell me what to do! I will manage my predilections without your help.
It's not a random passer-by's place to be opinionated about people like us!
Nothing good, I suppose. Their notion of communication is rather annoying.
It is. And their policies are peculiar as well. Don't get me wrong, I'm not trying to sell the idea to you... I only know that they are very fond of you. It's not easy to win their favour like that.
Really? And how did I win it?

Thanks to Maria, I guess. She has that supernatural intuition of hers, her mother's heritage. She can feel the resolve within you, she can read your intentions; that makes her believe that you're going to help us all. And we—well, we believe along…
I appreciate that.
Believe in yourselves. No one will babysit you.
Did they send you to me or something?
Of course not... They would never do anything like that.
Then mind your own business, my good man.
Who in particular?
I mean the family as a whole... Their agenda.
And what is the Kains' agenda?
They make our childhood dreams come true.
An eccentric course.
What do you care?
I don't care much about them. In fact, I don't care much about any of you. The disease is the only creature that has my interest around here.
Keep your chin up, citizen.
All of us will have to make a sacrifice in the end. Our town is like an aerostat: we were bold enough to take off the ground—and that means someone will inevitably have to fall down…
Maybe there'll be no need for sacrifices. I'm on the verge of victory already!

Maybe, may well be... But many of us would like to see the highlight of our achievement to live on... as a monument to our feat, if nothing else. If something has to be destroyed, let it be something recoverable.
Why are you telling me this?

Because I care! And I'm not the only one. Let the utopians live, Bachelor! Life and death are in your hands now! Save the utopians' lives, even if they are not to your liking. For it is through their deeds that we achieve immortality.
I intend to do just that.
Who do you call utopians?
And what is your idea of "the highlight of your achievement"?

Everything that the utopians have created. The tangible memorial, the evidence of the human ability to make dreams come true; the proof that you only need to overcome your fear, misery, and inertia to do that.
Who do you call utopians?

I'd consider at least a third of the town's population utopians. Painters and labourers, men of property and beggars, young and old. The utopians are those who believe in the power of the human spirit and the infinite scope of creativity. Take care of such people, Bachelor. Let them live.
I'll do everything that's in my power.
Huh, and let the others die, I suppose?
Not you, I hope?
Farewell.
No, thank you.
Good morals and luck are a great help in managing a small community without resorting to violence. Personal standing can work wonders.
What do you mean?
I like our town. We're all one big family. But sometimes I get the feeling that we're all controlled by an unseen power, our actions but fiction.
It's quite possible.
You are lucky.
No. It's pie in the sky.
Sorry, I can't help feasting my eyes on your outfit… who was the mad tailor?
Anything I can help you with?
Have you been given the vaccine?
Tell me, what is a vaccine?
A protective agent.
But how does it work?
It's a weakened specimen of the disease that our body can fight off. After you've suffered through the process, the body becomes resistant to it.
So vaccination provides permanent protection?
It usually does.
Then why does the vaccine circulating around the town only grant temporary protection? The "black ampulas" and "blue ampulas", I mean? People are willing to sell their souls for them, and still…
Because it's not a vaccine. It is an experimental sample. The body fights it for a while, but then it stops.
Will you ever be able to make a real one?
Maybe.

You see, my father used to deliver mail. It's a huge risk. His health is badly damaged by the abundance of various chemicals. He's coughing blood and has a constant headache… He's been bed-ridden for two days in a row. I'm so worried about him!
So he's a postman?
A courier, more like… he delivers messages and small parcels. People are staying in, so they use courier services whenever they can.
People like your father help to maintain order. They make our job easier.
What's his profit though?

It pays rather well—the rulers are seeing to it. I also know that some people—like my father, for example—have chosen this line of work out of sense of obligation. It was only later that the Kains offered a reward for it—and he didn't refuse, of course...
People like him deserve to have a real vaccine. I'll start working on it today.
Yes, that's commendable.
I'm doing everything I can.
You should thank me for having this one!
Where did you get these samples anyway?
They're being sold on the black market. I don't know where they came from, but rumour has it that they're made by you personally… We are so, so grateful!
It wasn't just me.
You are wrong. Doctor Rubin made them.
It depends on the disease.
I have no time to give you educational talks.
Why do you ask?
No, thank you.
My heart is crying for my poor children... How are my dearest doing? Is everything all right? Oh, women's share is hard…
Would you kindly mend my clothes, my dear?
You've got a curious town here… I never expected to see something like this in such a remote place.
Everyone's tired of the endless construction work. We want some quiet.
Is there a lot of construction going on?

Not a lot, but I cannot shrug away the feeling that the world is changing all too quickly. The rulers invite architects from the Capital, and they turn everything upside down... It's fun for the children, but a torment to us.
I'm sorry to hear that.
You have a very tidy little town. I haven't seen something like this for a long time.
Doesn't it have a positive side?
Of course it does... Estate is never lacking, and the constant construction projects provide workplaces. Still, we want some quiet.
I understand.
And endless battle! We only dream of peace…
Why are women being attacked?
I seem to remember that when Victoria died everybody rushed to look for an undead "coaler".
Why would they immediately rush looking for an undead… something?

Victoria was a Mistress... Somehow it seemed that an ordinary creature couldn't hurt her. Her death was unexpected, she was very young. And so well-loved by the people… So the rumours started immediately that a bayun maneater has taken her soul.
So what, did they try to seize every fifth man too?

No... No one was seized. But there was an anxiety. There was no doubt that an evil was walking among us. You can always feel it, it changes the… density of the world. Your instincts just tell you that it's true. This is all old Steppe wisdom… and you can't avoid it, you really can't. The Steppe is wiser than we are.
Superstitions like this have thrown sand in the wheels of countless scientific discoveries…
Nothing to be done about it.
What the hell...
Who is Victoria?
It was arrested, I hope?
Do you have enough food?
Oh, we're absolutely miserable… the last of it has run out completely. We're starving, no less! How can it be? Why? People can go for forty days without food…
Starvation weakens the body. That's why.

But the prices, just look at the prices! It's unheard of! A piece of stale bread costs a thousand. Where am I supposed to get that much money? How do they live with their conscience and demand that much of me when my children are starving!
Are you really that low on provision?

Oh, what a fool I was! And I'm not the only one... So much has been burnt and buried... We were afraid that the meat, the oat, the fish, potatoes—that it could all be infected... The day before yesterday and the day before that, we did... We didn't know that the train wouldn't come, and we just threw it all away! We expected new safe food to come.
The train might come soon.
No it won't... Who in their right mind would send a train here? There's a quarantine. Thanks to you!
You make it sound like it was I that had ordered to block the town off.
