I feel there's still a lot we need to talk about... You are blasphemously doing what can only be performed by one invested with a special right to power.
This is what the people of the Steppe believe. And I'm telling you that Simon... is more than a man. I'll go on working on him for a long time yet. And Victor and Georgiy aren't going to stop me!
Aren't you a little too sure of that? Do you have a lot of places left to hide? I wonder how they haven't found you yet…

You are wicked, Burakh... And scary. You know, you and the Bachelor really are... inhuman. What with all this spite emanating from you... And I feel that there's an enormous and evil creature controlling you both with its hands!

I've just been thinking about the feeling you give me—and there you go! No better way to describe it. Some call you a saint—but to me, you look like the exact opposite. It's said that all tempters assume the guise of holiness!
Well... I've come to tell you that you must leave. There's a manhunt underway for the Ripper. It's led by the Bachelor.
Stay where you are, demon! I don't know if I'll be able to kill you today—but you will lose a lot of blood. You are mortal too, I know it... however hard to kill you may prove!
Wasn't it you who stole Simon's body? You certainly didn't do it in order to bury him. You're holding a freshly sharpened scalpel!

...I never touched Simon—in fact, I never even met him. But if you tell the Bachelor that I've stolen his body and that I'm here, I'll be in a lot of trouble. A patrol will be dispatched here at once, and my mission will end in failure.
Stop... You have no idea...

Every time you show up at The Crucible, be prepared to suffer! These walls will burn the very thing within you that allows you to do your wicked work. Call it magic, if you will, or call it supreme justice.
…And how are you going to drive me out, old man? Will you draw a circle around yourself, or cover the walls with arcane signs? Aren't you afraid that will summon a demon scarier still?
I just wanted to...

All the suffering you will have gone through here will seem like gentle caresses compared to the torture you will endure if Maria touches you—not even with her gaze, but with thought alone, a mere recollection of you! Be warned, heiress of the earth! Now begone!
Ouch! It burns! What is this? What is this?
Ouch! You'll regret this, impudent old man! Your sorcery won't save any of you from retribution!
I am a harbinger.
It won't help.

You don't have to worry about that. Rest assured you will do something for me. In fact, you are doing something for me already, even if inadvertently. Believe it or not, but the pleasure brought by your visit feels startlingly physical for the kind of purely intellectual stimulus it actually is.
...Is this something that you expected?
Shame on you, Yulia! You're making me blush...

"Expected!" An apt observation indeed! Bear with me, please; I am still young, and whatever acumen I've had the time to acquire is clearly not enough to suppress the excitement one feels when everything happens just the way it was expected to happen. Oh, the joy I feel when everything falls well in line with what I have predicted—by which I don't mean the brute probabilism your mother would resort to, but a watertight, well-grounded calculation of likelihood! You check your notes... you make minuscule adjustments... and then—bang! You see your assumptions gain flesh at your own doorstep.
I'm happy that you've been expecting me. However silly it might be to be happy about it.
I suppose you worked out on paper what I should look like too, didn't you?

Frankly, I imagined you as a completely different person. Tall as a lamp post; white; ragged... with your ribs bare, and a firm, shapely bosom. Long hair, off-white and disheveled of course... and a pair of huge, puffy peepers.
That's the image of a saint. It's what they would look like a thousand years ago…
Nice. Was I by any chance carrying a long, rapaciously curved scythe?

Right. Enough silliness. Let us get to the meat of the matter. You know... I am dying to know what your request may be. I'd even venture an educated guess that you wanted to ask me something about Eva Yan? But what could it be? Anyone could have told you the basic facts; who she is, where she lives, what she prefers to wear... Are you interested in something else then; something concerning her soul? Is this the case?
But how would you... Who told you? Did you speak with Katerina? Is this some kind of a joke?
Alas, no, Yulia. I wanted nothing of the sort. You can roll cigarettes from your scribbled calculations. I don't fit into your constructs!

Oh no, I didn't speak with Katerina; I never do. Morphine addicts and other kinds of substance abusers are not the company I normally prefer. They make too bleak an impression. I have ceased my relationship with the Stamatin twins for that very reason. Now these two are of potential interest to you. Did you meet them yet?
How did you know I was going to ask you about Eva?
Tell me more about the Cathedral! Why is it so empty?

Why... it is empty because it was built before the religion was allowed to reach maturity. Even an atheist like me knows what a cathedral is for. They are not—as Peter Stamatin would have it—"a set of walls covered by a roof". Rather than that, they're vessels of the numinous; miracle incubators, if you will. The issue, in our particular case, is that we have the Tower on the other side of the river to serve this very purpose...
Is Eva in love with the Bachelor? He is a demon.
Your atheism is groundless... I think you'll soon change your views.
Why are you looking at me like that?

I am going to keep looking at you, or rather to keep watching you. I get the feeling that every move you make may be reliably predicted. This is not an opportunity I would ever miss, for it feeds remarkably well into one of my theories... perhaps, the most pessimistic of them all. Well, off you go... harbinger.
I understand now. Goodbye.
I'm brave! I'm not afraid of you!
That is ill-advised. The moment I decide that I want to fight you, you will drop dead. I merely don't want to begin before the time is ripe.
You can begin right now. If you dare.
You're mistaking me for someone else... As I have come, so I will go... And right now I only want peace…

Destroying you, a Mistress of the Earth in the making, would take too much of my power... After you collapse with a ruptured heart, I will be lethargic for over a year. And right now I need that power like never before.
No... No! Don't look at me like that!
Why? To charm the Bachelor?
...Lethargic? Did you say lethargic?

You ought to know that in a matter of a few days my power will grow to its fullness, and I will reclaim all of the scintillae of magic now scattered across the Memory of my dear mother. Run away from here. As soon as I become a Mistress, this plague will be over—no matter who sent it upon us. There will be no place for you here.
It's for these words that you will pay... And not you alone! Now I see how right my dear mother Katerina is...
I will stay here.
I'm telling you, I'm good, not evil! Why can't any of you see that?
I need to talk to Mark, but in private! Without you.

See, Mark? Shall we give her a chance perhaps? It'll be a lot of fun. So what was it you were hoping to tell Mark? Could it be the same thing you told my uncle Georgiy the other day? Actually, I'm beginning to get angry... I should be angry now but this is just too amusing...
There will be nothing amusing about that, Maria Kaina. Oh, how I hate you! Goodbye!
So I've been saved by my sheer lack of artifice?

Of course, Clara. Surely you didn't think those tricks would work on us. Or is there really something you're missing? Could I be the naïve one, and you the saint? Let's see... No... not even remotely. You do feel I can break you with a mere effort of my will, don't you?
Nothing... I've walked into the wrong door!
I'm just testing you. So far in our encounters, you've been the bigger loser!
You cannot possibly have important news for me. You cannot possibly know something I do not.
Capella has had a bad dream about a tragedy striking at the Cathedral. Very soon, perhaps as we speak. Have you had the same dream?
It also concerns the demon you worship so much—I mean the Bachelor. After all, it was he who occupied and defiled the town's Cathedral!

How exactly did he defile it? Perhaps by sheltering sufferers in it? Why, it's only because of him that the Cathedral has at least partly begun to serve its divine purpose! Its routine has changed—but only to bring it back to the intended roots; how can a Changeling like you not feel it? What fool has called you a saint?
Pull yourself together. Capella has had a dream in which tragedy struck at the Cathedral. Everyone inside was dead! It's worth checking!
You'll remember my words tomorrow! I had a dream once…
You could not possibly have had any dreams. Don't lie to me. If you actually had that nonexistent sister, she could be the one having prophetic dreams. Not you.
You don't even have to... you probably know everything anyway, don't you?
All right... Capella has had a dream in which the infection found its way into the Cathedral and killed everyone inside!
Alive, you say? It would've been a good idea to listen when the bells were ringing…
Yikes! No! I'm afraid! Suppose I walk in and there are dead people in there. And I'll get blamed afterwards…
Don't be afraid. The Cathedral is well-guarded. Here, take some money and give it to the guards. They'll open the doors and you will check together... You will have witnesses...
That could work... Either way, I won't go past the door.
Give me your hands, let me touch you... And you, and you, and you too... There, there, no need to be afraid... Nothing more will happen...
Look into my eyes. What have you got here? Can I touch?
Must be some dirt in my eye, I'm sorry... Or maybe a piece of clay... I need to rub my eyes... Where are you?
You don't see me, watchful guard. And my voice is your own fancy. It's coming from within...
Who knows?

There'd be none to see in any case... They say it strikes at once. One faints before one can take three steps. Only someone special—someone like Burakh, Simon, or a Bound person—can withstand the sickness for a long time...
Are you at ease now?
I have…
Did she abuse you? Or was she kind? You didn't mention my name, did you?
She almost killed me! Every time I'm at the Crucible, the Kains use some kind of destructive magnetism against me!
I'm so sorry... Can I do anything to reward you for what you've had to suffer through?
I'd prefer never to see her again…
No. I should even say it was an enlightening visit. And I'm most content with how it turned out.
Drop a word for me... At least to your friends, the children.
I can guess. Are you and I really Mistresses, though? Can you really say something like that to me? Why joke like that?

I had a dreadful dream last night. I saw a sinister creature come in the dark of night—a thing of the Steppe, a shabnak-adyr. She sneaked into the Cathedral and killed everyone, everyone who was hiding in there! All around, I saw the dead—the dead—the dead!
How can I help you?

I do not know if I should trust that dream... Maybe it was no vision—I'm not used to having those yet, and cannot tell a dream from a Dream... And the children wouldn't stop talking about the shabnak-adyr to me. They've been told all those scary things...
No, Capella dear. I don't know that yet.
Well… it makes sense. Can't an infected person get inside?

The probability is very small. But the Bachelor is the one who estimates the time since infection, for his own bigoted reasons. He has some diabolical term for it, "the latent stage"... Something he needs to put in his reports to the capital…
Should we really be afraid of your dream then?
I'd rather ask Katerina.

Forgive me, Clara dear, I know she is your mother now—but Katerina is wrong too often. You can ask her if you wish, but I know that her visions are often distorted. The theme is right but the details are twisted. And the demon is in the details this time.
I feel sick every time I'm at the Crucible... Maria is going to kill me.

If the dream is prophetic, it will destroy her Bachelor. An envoy from the capital is arriving the day after tomorrow, and everything will depend on them. Maria will never go as far as to put her Bachelor's success at risk. And I'll reward you!
But why don't you want to write her a letter?
Why are you calling the two of you Mistresses anyway? I don't know about Maria, but you—how are you a Mistress?

I'm still only a girl. But that will change... Try it regardless! The Kains don't think that bad of you. They always try to be intimidating, they like to dramatize everything, they enjoy striking up a pose! My dear... I'll reward you just for asking the question! If only you ask it on your own behalf! Please!
But what about me?
Simon is not dead.
I just wanted to take a glimpse at your workspace... That's really impressive.
What would you need the keys to the Catheral for?
Maria told me you had them…

What, you and Maria talk to each other? Unbelievable. Maria denounced you as a Changeling and said that if you came to her again, she'd have you thrown into the Gorkhon to see if you'd sink or swim. Does this mean you've swum?
No!
I'd like to see if everything's all right in there. I have a suspicion that something bad might happen inside.
Everything's all right. The Cathedral is well guarded. No new infections have been reported in the last twenty-four hours. Anything else?
I'll only have a quick look…
You monster! You're keeping them there in such conditions? It's like a death camp!
Quit fooling around! Let me into the Cathedral.
So you sank? That makes you a non-witch; but then you must be a revenant, and I don't know which is worse. Shame that the bullets in my revolver are leaden and not silver. But perhaps they'll do too…
Bachelor, give me the key... Why don't any of you believe me? Why am I the only one you're ever suspicious of?
I'm leaving! I don't need anything! Just don't shoot me…
It's firm, mother.

Do you remember everything I have told you about those Bound of yours who are infected with a utopian heresy—and about some of them... or perhaps many of them being instrumental in bringing the wrath of heaven upon our town?
It must be so, mother.

There is a mansion in the Stone Yard called The Stillwater. Living there is a girl named Eva Yan. Both good and bad things are said about her; she is said to be affectionate and depraved, a kind soul while also voluptuous... but I am not talking about that. Lust is not the kind of sin to incur such a punishment.
Why are you talking about her then?

Eva has been led astray by utopian ideas. What has particularly captured my attention is that Eva, the gentle Eva Yan, is spending an extraordinary amount of time at—the town's Cathedral. There is no knowing as to what is drawing her there... but her way of life is incongruous with such a piety. It is mysterious...
I'll try to solve it, mother.

Eve is gentle and weak... Begin with her. She is unlikely to be rude with you. Try to use your powers on her first... for from then on, you will commune with some dangerous and... difficult collocutors. They may overwhelm you with their rage... rendering you unable to sway them.
Go to sleep, mother dear. Sleep and lay all your worries aside…
I know, mother.
Remember what I told you about Yulia. She is intelligent... very intelligent. Be careful with her too... I don't know her very well but she seems like a worthy woman. And very fond of Eva…
I'm afraid of the disease. It's here already, standing by our windows…
I haven't met that kind of people yet…
I can't even imagine how I ought to talk to a girl like that. They scare me—these depraved ones…
Well... I was hoping to have some rest here too.
Fine. I'm leaving.
All right, I'll come by later.
Quinine can help... if you don't have anything better.
I'm just going to rest here a little…
Yes, I'm just popping back for a moment... Is there a mirror anywhere I could look into?
Stop worrying about that! Can you really think of nothing else now?
I have brought the relics to her. Here they are.
You cannot go in now. If you do have them, better bring them back to Nina. She remains the Scarlet Mistress for now.
I am. I've forbidden it.
Can you even imagine what's going on there?
It appears that she's ignored that prohibition.
Maria doesn't listen to me anymore. There's not that much left of me anyway… Perhaps something will change when her mother comes back.
What's her buisness in town?
The streets are dangerous as hell. And you are so indifferent?
And they said Lilich had restored order in the streets with an iron fist… Is it true that they've erected a gallows near the railway?
I haven't seen it. They did light fires though.
Thank you, I'll intercept her there. And, as a punishment for her wayward behaviour, I'll arrange for her a meeting with a certain family member.
I am, Grace... And I'm fond of you too.
Grace, oh Grace, I know of you this: you sing merry songs to the dead when the nights are cold and murmur lullabies for them on warm nights…
...Don't. I'm going to tell you everything anyway. Why are you doing this? Do you think we're strangers?
Very... very much so.
Why?

Because there's no escaping it now... And it's been coming to us from the Steppe... Getting closer... Step by step... The dead felt her coming... She pierced the earth with her sharp-boned stilts... Which reached them underground... No one will be spared...
Do you know why it happened?
All right, I'm sorry... So you believe that I'm the harbinger of good?
…Will you brave the depths? Will you answer my questions candidly and without prejudice?
Yes... I will.
Are you afraid, Grace?
What's going to happen to us, Grace?
There will soon be a plague.
Why is this happening to us?
Who are you, Grace?
I'm Grace… My father was the caretaker of this cemetery... He poured milk and twyrine over the graves... My mother swept the gravestones with her hair... They taught me to listen to the dead.
What will become of us, Grace?
I doubt that, Grace. The faith of humility is a faith for the doomed. Whoever is resigned to death deserves to die. Don't think this reckoning is inevitable.
...Perhaps with good deeds, love, and a serene mind this scythe of death can be escaped?
I'll stop by later.
Do you pull people's souls out with these hooks? Why else would you need so many different ones?
Yes, Grace. They're special hooks.
You can see them? Whoa. You're weird…
She's affectionate, kind, and defenseless.
Have you managed to convince her?
Her face is fair, yet her thoughts are poisoned and dark.
No, I didn't. She's in love... and I don't think her kind of impudence is what could bring the wrath upon the entire town.

...But it would have been so easy. What is the matter with you, my daughter? Had you at least told me that she threw you out, that you weren't been able to convince her, that a frantic Bachelor stormed into the house and scared you off, flimsy thing that you are... I would not have been angry. But you say that you gave up on her of your own volition!
Why, I don't hear any tinkling... You speak strangely…
Eva, oh Eva, I know of you this: you love the Bachelor more than your own life. Will you agree to touch me? To brave the depths? To answer my questions candidly and without prejudice?
Get away from me, wretch! Cover your ears with your hands and run! I am your death!
What? What's wrong with you? Go away, please go, don't touch me...
What have I done... I just couldn't help saying it…
I'm not sure you're right, mother... Could it be you're mistaken?

I know whereof I speak, sweet daughter... The voice that talks to me in my dreams is incapable of lying... For many years, this has been how my visions come to me... Let other Mistresses say that isn't genuine... I know... My visions have at times proved truer than theirs...
Who do you want me to convert today?
How am I to speak to him? I don't know any of his secrets.

It won't be the way it was yesterday... more like the day before yesterday, perhaps... perhaps he is with us already... perhaps he is himself preparing the utopians... albeit in his own way... and you, find out... what he is up to...
Why did you choose Mark of all people? I don't think my words could sway someone like that.
Did you say he's a theatre director? Could he by any chance have connections with the Caravan?

He's been living here for a long time... I don't remember... don't know... but he's never taken an interest in children... wouldn't even notice them... even banned them from attending his performances... No, it's not that…
So he's not that wicked? But then what do you need him for?
I'll do what you've told me to. I'll tell him what you said; it won't be difficult.
And so? Pray tell, don't keep me waiting…
Do you trust my insight? Do you know that I can read people's souls?
Would I entrust you with such things if I didn't? Would I let you rewrite and redraw people's destinies if I didn't trust you, my angel?
He's not one to side with either the Utopians or the Humble. He stands apart.
Maria thinks he's under her charms and in the ranks of the utopians. He's playing along. But that's not how it really is!
I think Mark just wanted to scare you. He's against us, mother... We don't need him... he's wicked. Let him subvert the utopians instead!
I'm frightened... You sound as if I'd have to kill them!
Yes... yes, mother!

We must continue! There are not many Bound left... Our town will not be spared for the sake of ten righteous men—nay, it will be destroyed on account of a single rebel... As of now, we are losing the battle... and for all I know, my husband may be exterminating the truly faithful in his fury...
That's very likely! Everyone who he turns my attention to, seem to acknowledge fully that they deserve to be punished!
I need to think about it some more... For now, let us continue to act…
...How?
Who are you going to send me to, mother?

The blade of your words will now be pointed at the very heart... of the utopians' false doctrine. Only the Kains themselves are more dangerous than them... I am talking about the brothers Stamatin—the rebellious architects who have challenged... too many things. You will begin with Peter. Convert him.
What happened at the Cathedral?

A disease carrier got into the Cathedral last night. Everyone inside perished. Yes, yes, making it past your impregnable quarantine. Human or spirit, it's very clear now that this is an individual who can walk, and is probably quite malicious. Many people are revelling in this particular certainty.
What does Olgimsky have to do with this?
Quite so. The bacterium has been caught and encased in glass. I didn't do it on my own, though. I had help.

This is a witch hunt in the making. As if dimwitted blackguards murdering women in the streets wasn't enough—it seems that our governor is now inclined to extend his greedy reach towards the town's notable people. Several young women stand accused after the Cathedral business.

More importantly, they say that you are now able to track down the shapeshifting disease carrier, сomparing their blood to that sample you obtained yesterday. If they are one of the townsfolk, it can't be that hard to recognize them.
Also true.
All these rumours are not groundless…
Why are you telling me this?
Is there anything I can do?

Check on them—now that you have the capability. Hurry, before your discovery breeds baseless speculations. One would want to save innocent lives. Or else… nothing can be certain in a situation like this.
And you? Can you do anything?
I don't know the rules of chess…
How do I hook him?
...Do you believe that too?
Think about Peter... Throwing that weight off our enemies' side of the scale will give us more breathing room. Perhaps the plague will stop…
How can I gain his trust?
Hmm... It all hinges on Maria again... Maria and Nina... yes, that is too strong a citadel... only a miracle could help you.
Is Peter in love with Maria?
…What?
And then I'll drink with you. So what do you think? Will you answer?
How did you manage to do that, Peter?

Wait! …Why are you asking me? I can see you taking me by the hand, leading me here... a circle of light from a bright lamp.. Stop! I sought oblivion in the green fairy's embrace... I desired you, so that you could give me a chance to forget... and you're reminding me again? You're lying! Who are you?
What's wrong with you? Haven't you seen me before?
You're all but dead, Peter! Do you understand what this daydream of yours means?

I don't know... I'll do what Andrey says... Bring my brother to me... Where are you, brother? You're the only one I trust... I'm surrounded by ghosts, by translucent greenness... maras and chimeras... the double-faced Changeling... only he is real, my support, my bulwark...
I'm going to have to take your twyrine away. You're at death's door already.
Do you realize why it happened?
I'm Clara. The harbinger. I've come for you!
Why am I double-faced?

Look, there are two of you... oh, chimeras, chimeras, monsters... One's hanging from the lamp hook on the ceiling, lighting up the place; your green lips smiling, whispering something... The other one—there she is, laughing at me, crouching in the far corner... dissolving into pond weed...
Wait! I'll bring you back to life…
Had you been alive, Peter, you'd have converted. But you're dead already.
...Really? Why? I think I'm quite alive...
Look, my sister and I are twins too. But one of us is here, on this inner side of Existence, and the other's on its outer side. We are one, but I'll never take her by the hand. Convert, Peter.
Why? Death... I'm terrified of death. Of true death... this here is just a game for now. It's not real yet, is it?
There's nothing terrifying about death... Not for you at this point, anyway... The void of oblivion is what's terrible... Convert.

You speak too simply and too fast... But you scare me nonetheless... No, I'd prefer a painful death... The vivid death of a martyr burned at the stake... I couldn't bear oblivion... I won't accept it.
Convert. Here, I'm turning around and leaving. I'm the angel of your death. Make your choice while you still have time. You've summoned me, and here I am—here to comfort you.
I've come for you. But you won't heed me... Farewell.
Wait... I'm going…
Go. My sister, the paraclete, will be waiting for you there... outside.
Is this life though? You seek death yourself!
Yes, it isn't. But that's just for now. Reconsider, Peter. Come back.
Come back to me.
What? What do you mean, in danger? Now you've truly grabbed my attention! What's happened to him? Let's go, you'll tell me all about it along the way…
Your brother holds heretic views…
Andrey, oh Andrey, I know of you this: you're in love with Maria...
Nonsense! I'm not in love with Maria. I do admire her—that goes without saying—but I only love one person in the world, and that's my brother. So cut the crud and tell me what's threatening him!
Andrey, I fear that this pestilence has been sent down upon him—personally.
Forget it, Andrey! Let's pretend we never had this conversation, all right?
A miracle, you say? …No, I wouldn't throw that man out. Goodbye, Andrey. Forgive me for being so faint-hearted.
But…

So you're saying we have incurred wrath from above with our impudence? Liar! Double, triple liar! I don't know what God you believe in, but I don't think you're even old enough to have a concept of one! And you are either a lying impostor—or an abominable Changeling, a temptress, a thing from hell, a shabnak-adyr, a maneater, made of dead bones and dirty clay!
Don't yell at me, don't call me... that! I'm leaving... I'm leaving!
Oh but yes, precisely!

And here's what I'll tell you: only a godless apostate and devil-worshipper, which is what you Saburovs are, could dare deny the greatness of God's design! It is nothing like that tower built out of an ambition to topple heaven. It's a different world, you idiot! This tower was not built for the sake of faith or of faithlessness. It's something else entirely!
What's the tower got to do with it?
I will not betray my brother's creation, and I will not let you tarnish his name! Get lost! Go to hell. Go back to the earth you came from!
No, I don't dare do anything of the sort... Who am I to talk like that... Goodbye, Andrey!
There is only one world. You've been living without faith before—so I'm here to give you a jolt!
All right. I'll think about it... Perhaps I even won't go back to him at all.

It’s written all over your face. But let’s get right down to business, seeing as you have very little time; the walls of this house are pernicious to you, little imp. What is it, then, that’s causing your displeasure with me or, say, with the most charming Mistress of... this hospitable house?
Mark Immortell, I accuse you of heresy and blasphemy. You were the one that brought down the plague upon the town!

Now those are some strong words! You're much too impressionable, my child. Katerina's only dabbling in prophetic rhetoric because it's her last resort, now that she's foreseen the beginning of the end... An ugly trick to pull, and cheap too... take a professional's word for it.
What, are you a priest?
What? What did you call me?

That was affectionate. I could take my words back though. Admittedly you don't quite fit the definition yet... but you're almost there... although there's still some hope left. Perhaps a miracle will happen and you'll turn away from that path.
You've challenged heaven. You're the reason for all that's happening now…

Why all the twisted notions? Why are you so hateful? It's only play-acting, all of it! Like any game, play-acting is a mere shadow of Existence, a tiny fragment of it, a semblance—not a hollow semblance, mind you, quite the contrary, filled to the brim! Play-acting is fuller than reality... since it's smaller.
You're always play-acting! Always a mummer! That's why you have this manner of explaining things.
Yours is a world without faith…
There's room for God inside the tiniest fragment…
And who told you He's not present in here, Changeling?
All I've seen here so far is the dead hollowness of puppetry!
That explains a lot, doesn't it?
It does to you, puppet master!
Another toy semblance…
It will lie to me too... How am I supposed to convince myself?
And who are you?
I've been posted here on the Bachelor's orders! I am an Executor, and I oversee the hospital. You are not allowed to go inside. Do you hear those horrendous screams? It's the agony of the incurable.
Where is the owner of the Theatre? Is he dead?
Oh no... Tell me I don't have to go there again! Why is he so careless about choosing his friends?
I see your mendacity with my own eyes now.
That's not true!

I'm leaving—gotta lay low for a while. See you underground. And I'll always be glad to see you—you of all people should know I'm not at all as mendacious as my jealous detractors are making me look! You'll always be my welcome guest…
It would seem that you're right... And what is your nature, prophet?

All this time, none other but you have been the disease personified—the tool for the world to restore the balance with. All this time, there have been no sister. All this time, Clara has been chasing herself around, confounded by Katerina's visions becoming true.
I don't believe you... Prove that you're telling the truth!

Oh, just rejoice, will you? Your actions have attracted the attention of the almighty Powers That Be. Do you know what they want from you? They'll send you a note today. Forget your silly little tricks; now your only chance to prove you are not the plague is to perform a genuine miracle.
You're lying. I've already performed many miracles.
Do you really trust me so much?

And killed just as many people with your miraculous hands. No one knows what you are. No, you need a miracle on a grand scale. Something all-encompassing. Something to shape the world. Make it happen—and boom!—we'll believe you. And I'm not talking about those gnarly... angulous... freaks. Their pseudo-lives are of absolutely no importance.
It's all just a game for you! How dare you!
In the end, you'll be surprised to find out that everything that you've heard, every single thing, was the honest truth—even the seemingly contradictory things.
So the Powers That Be will tell me what to do?
Think twice before doing as they tell you, though. Those guys are a bunch of little liars.
It's all just a game for you! How dare you!
It's all just a game for you! How dare you!
Yulia! People love me... I've done them so much good... I've even been called a saint...

You? A saint? What kind of an imbecile would call you that? Is there even a God that you believe in? You are a changeling, and your sainthood is the lamest kind of mimetic apery. You remind me of Anna Angel at times. She is utterly ludicrous, I grant you, a grimacing imp, if you will. You are a bit more serious than that.
What are you saying? What are you even talking about?
I'm sure you have. I feel sorry for you, Aglaya Lilich…
No. Fate can't be chosen, and this isn't about fate. It's you I'm worried about.
Well... You know everything about us already. Now that you've got this far, you're much more powerful than us…
Who was Clara, the grave-born? The one who raised her hands first?
And yet I still have to choose a reply from the options I'm offered.
The real game is what's happening between you and us. That was an official warning I had to make. I warned the previous charcaters too, but they went straight for questions... Such boring people.
I don't think I'll be able to ask a more interesting question…
I know, he's a demon... I can sense his otherworldly nature! Is there really no escaping him?
My sister... Aren't you her? Aren't you the sister I spoke into existence?

No... But I'll console you.. Your sister is here... she has talked to me a lot.. her and I are alike too, we are one... because she is you... don't be quick to condemn her... she too is dismayed, not knowing who she is... one of you will make her choice, and the other will follow.
It's all so complicated! I can't understand your allegories! But tell me, I'm the miracle-worker, aren't I—and not her?
Who is my sister then? Am I not the Mistress of the Earth?
No, no... Somehow I feel it's not what's going to happen to me! I don't want to get my own back on the Powers! I can sense how weak they are... I'm sorry for them.
Shut up and listen to me. Did they want miracles from you?
Yes... Three days ago I received a letter…
I don't think so!
I don't know who I am either... It seems I'm a soul that's been put on trial before you... shortly before its impending death.
I didn't give myself that prerogative! Or are you already putting me on trial as a thief, to be hanged alongside robbers and looters?
Alone? I'm not sure of that…
I'll visit them to look into their eyes again. But I'll come back with my own verdict, same as back then! And you'll defer to it! That is what you've decided yourself…
And I don't like cowards, liars, and traitors!
It will fit you nicely, I know that for sure! But what do you need it for?
I want to kill certain people who really deserve to die. But, being cowards, they're waiting for me. That's why I'd like to sneak up on them unnoticed.
No! I need nothing from you, demon.
What do you think this Inquisitor really wants? What's her objective here?
...You've pierced me right to the heart! Is that really so?
I've already spoken to him! It's you I want to listen to now…
Save it then. Everything's in your hands now.
That's why I'm asking you…
I've been inside. What is it? Who are you harbouring there?

Much as I'd like to tell you that it's inhabited by my fantasies and my dreams, it would be untrue. Children live there: petty, pathetic, malicious, craving to imitate the grown-ups... But the place improves them, it makes them better, and that's why I don't object... Perhaps one day it will harbour someone's dream...
What's so bad about the children's dreams?

Take a look outside. That's what's bad about them... Every child is capable of crossing over to the other side of reality, but few are able to bring back something beautiful, good, and... magical. No, the Tower is not for children... It's for lovers, dreamers, and poets.
I believe you, Peter…
Now I understand completely!
You're mistaking me for someone else... just as you did back then.

Because he wants to leave it in a void, in icy solitude... like a unique butterfly preserved in formalin, pinned to the Steppe like to a piece of cardboard! No, I don't want that to happen! Who needs a victory like that…
Don't despair, Andrey... You're making a mistake by not trusting me.
I will be able to change the Bachelor's mind.
Be quiet! You mistook me for a cat.
I don't have time for this. I'm leaving right now. Be off, I'm telling you! There is no time.
So rude…
Wrong choice. And your loss…
What are you talking about? It's ridiculous. I am here on my own business...You are not the center of the universe…
Serves them right. Good people suffer no woe at my hand. Such is life…
I need you to stay here for at least an hour. Two would be even better. And it would be best for you to stay put until you're paid a visit…
Why?
He is, Haruspex... But they can't strike you—so why would you need them if not to kill them?
He's just as horrible a bloodsucker as you are—how could you both not surround yourselves with killers?
And why would you warn me? You know full well there aren't many reasons for me to trust you…
I'm warning you so that you have more. It's high time you realized not only evil walks this earth!
Aglaya asked me to, Burakh... She's worried about you.
I see…
I'll tell Aglaya where you are. She is looking for you... She'll send someone after you.
For I am the harbinger. Aren't you the one hunting my sister? So wait for her here. She will come to you…
Well then. That's reason enough for me to stay here.
It's not about profit, Burakh, I have my own reasons… Give me as much as your soul tells you to.
Deal. Now tell me where the serpent is.
Everything that you have on your person, Haruspex. It must be a lot.
Those are tears, yes. I've been crying a lot lately. See what I have to do to placate the unbearable hatred you all harbour…
You need the evil sister. And it's not me.
You are looking for the miracle-maker. It's not me. So do you want me to show you where she is?
…Tell me where she is.
With a scalpel, as usual. But he's accompanied by his Kin slaves. They obey him now. Aspity provided him with an entourage!
I've killed his companions. He is alone, you'll deal with him without a sweat.
Tell me where he is. I'm going after him this instant!
Be careful, don't make a blunder. I'm rooting for you to win. Most importantly, don't you forget who pointed the direction to you.
How much money do you have on you? Do you think I went looking for you and risked my life for free?
You'll be satisfied, Changeling. Nothing to worry about.
There's an ambush waiting for you by the exit—twenty or even thirty muggers. And you're alone, your henchmen are gone… I'll make them leave in two or three hours.
The one you're waiting for the most will come to you here… You know who I'm talking about, don’t you? I am her harbinger.
I'll stay put for some time. Don't you fret.
You mean death?
You are a sharp man, Bachelor. I won't tell you more.
Me? You've never told me anything of the sort before. Have I really deserved it?
Which ones?
Those with nothing more to lose, I suppose. Such as myself.
What about other people? Can we call on them too? Or must it only be the Bound?
Yes…
I've staked everything on this military operation. My mission, my soul, my own destiny and our country's. I need a voice from above—because I don't know who to listen to anymore.
I didn't come here to answer riddles.
And what does that have to do with me?
It's nothing to be thrilled about... Odd that they didn't just die.
I don't understand a thing... I was told that Rubin had made some sort of a discovery concerning me.
Someone beat me to it! And you knew...
...Who told you?

…Filin, oh Filin, I know of you this: you knew ahead of time about the disaster that was to strike the town. Will you agree to touch me? To brave the depths? To answer my questions candidly and without prejudice?
…Sure, kiddo, ask away... Where did you get my name, anyway? Did Saburov whisper it to you, the scum?
You're... not asleep?
Hey, is that magical? Show me... Why, what's the matter?

...Gee, would you look at that! Hey villanous lot, you heard the lil' tot? You're not the Mistress of Earth by any chance, are you? Or an inquisitor on an official mission? Eh? Who d'you think you are, you wee lil' Saburov foundling? Lessee what colour your skin is on the inside... Get her!
I know what colour yours is. Black, Grief... It's black.
Wha—? Hold on there folks, don't touch her just yet. What did you say? Black? And why is that?
That's what I'm asking you; why is that?

The Saburov scum is tryin' to frame me. Knife attacks 'n other kinds of nastiness. Now, can you imagine me cuttin' someone with a knife? Eh? Of course you can't! I'm not guilty of any of that and neither are my lads. Now Saburov, he's not angry on account of the people—just on account of his people... I want to give him the actual cutthroat so that he leaves me alone. I'll clear my own reputation in the process too, so it's a win-win!
I'll put in a word for you.
Look at your own fellows standing there—you could run through three people with one of those knives they've got... Are they just a deterrent?
Yep, they sure are, 'n I can prove it... 'Tis not they who carve people up, all right? Especially not Saburov's people...
Go ahead. Prove it...
There's nothing else I need…
Clara's here... Hi, Clara! So—you're not a Changeling anymore?
Some trifle! I have a whole nine of them, and I loathe most.
Right. I forgot.
Check me. Am I really the disease?
No, not you... Oddly enough, I must say.
Then let me go.

That is exactly what's about to be ascertained. And you're the only one who can ascertain it. That's the essence of the sacrament. By establishing the present you will establish the past. With that which is yet to be done, you will establish that which has seemed to have been done beforehand. It has only worked the opposite way before.
Who are you?

I do exist, sister, but in a transient way. For now, you are still the Disease, and I'm the persecuted saint. The problem is, there's no me yet; I'm a figment of your imagination... A consequence of a lie you told! And yet how wonderful that lie itself turned out to be... Theft had made a miracle possible...
No... I don't understand. But it was your choice. Neither the Haruspex nor the Bachelor got one like that…
Farewell, sister.
Did you hear what I said? I've taken up your burden. There will be a miracle. And you will have to go.
It couldn't have been any other way, my dear sister. Farewell. I'll take the disease with me as I leave. A lot of evil will be gone from this world along with me.
So now you're the holy miracle-worker?
So it would seem, sister. Now that you've acknowledged yourself as an instrument of the Inevitability.
...And now you're leaving this world forever?
I was never in it, dear sister. Don't forget, there's just been you all along.
I know. I'm talking to myself now.
My choice to be a miracle-worker was a part of their vicious plan too! The miracle had been preordained by them beforehand. They have defiled the nature of the miraculous.

So you think they've been laughing at us? You think they were sitting there rubbing their hands in anticipation, expecting us to perform a miracle while they knew that the inevitable necessity, which they themselves had created, would not win? You haven't understood a thing... and the truth of my words is confirmed by my still being here...
Which is how you've overcome your hollowness!
I don't understand…

You rejected the stolen fate and became yourself. Well, I have nothing left to do but pick up what you've thrown away. It's my burden now. There's very little time left—but perhaps it will be enough for me... And you have no idea what's happening to me right now.
...And now you're leaving this world forever?
I understand! I'm the one who'll leave soon, and you'll stay behind!
So it shall be. Forgive me.
But is this doubt that I'm seeing in your eyes?
Is the burden you've taken not too heavy for you?
No. Don't ask again. You'll see for yourself soon enough.
Why are you asking?

The plague was just a tool. Forget about the evil, and I'll carry it away. But have you understood correctly what the means will be to achieving the genuine miracle that is to take place here? It wasn't the banishing of the disease; that was a mere rehearsal... Do you realize what's being expected of you? Have you chosen rightly, Clara?
You're the evil spirit now. Temptation, doubt, and equivocacy are your nature. Farewell. I don't wish to listen to you.
Oh no! You're making me doubt myself again…
Yes. I'm ready now.
The Inquisitor insists that miracles and me are mutually exclusive.

I don't know... I haven't even thought about it. Aglaya doesn't tell the whole truth. From her point of view, there are no such things as miracles; that's just the way she was made. But we—we, not Simon!—are living proof of the contrary. You have a chance to preserve things as they are! You can do what others can't. They're impeded by enmities and hatred.
Who's enemies with whom, sister?

The Inquisitor and the Commander. The Haruspex and the Bachelor. And then more conflict across these lines. All of them are bent on destroying what they detest. If you want to perform a miracle, remove the threat to each of the town's organs.
Now you're tempting me! Do you want me to kill?
Is it true that I'm an instrument of the Law?

There really is an envoy of the Law in this town, and it's one of the new arrivals. Is it perhaps the Bachelor or the Haruspex? It's evident that both of them are destroyers. Each of them has already accepted the inevitable. But could it be you? It would make things that much worse...
How do we find out, then?
We can't. We can only make it happen. How can I know something that hasn't been done yet? I'm not omnipotent.
Or aren't you?
The Inquisitor is convinced of that!
Are you the plague? Speak!
What must I do?
...I'm all enmities and hatred myself!
But to preserve things as they are is the capricious wish of the criminal Powers That Be!

You are free to choose your own fate. Now is your time to decide who you've been all along. It's only from the Law's perspective that you're the disease. But you don't recognize the Law. You're a thief. You'll escape the Law by stealing for yourself the path of a miracle-worker. You'll defeat it by performing a genuine miracle...
If only…
I still feel like I'm being deceived...
Enough! Who am I? Speak!
And you? What's going to happen to you?
I'll accept the destiny you'll have rejected. And then I'll vanish at once, because I don't belong on this Earth. Go, sister. Make your choice. Do not tarry.
I'll come back to you yet…

She was indeed conceived as the disease, an instrument of the Law... but she was born a thief. At the very moment of her birth, she got a chance to become someone completely different. The girl came into this world, having stolen for herself the fate of a miracle-worker.
Does this mean I'm not a toy? Why are the Powers That Be acting so strangely towards me?

Why not? The Changeling, not knowing who she was herself, had fallen into our mirror trap. It was a surprise even to the children who were playing with her. So it was a conundrum... why, there's no point in hiding that we hadn't expected it either. So maybe, just maybe...
How? Hadn't you made provisions for every circumstance beforehand?
When she first performed a lesser miracle, we were ourselves astounded... We had never thought it could work. It shouldn't have.
Unbelievable…
Why did you put me in a position like this? What was that split-personality gimmick all about?

In fact, it was much gimmickier than a mere split personality. It was the gimmick of choosing one's own fate. A logical and temporal conundrum. A Moebius strip of events. A backup plan. And it seems to have worked. Clara is the game's main protagonist. And so is the Sand Dirt... so is the Utopia.
What was the point of this whole affair? What was the pestilence for?

You see, we're conducting an experiment of sorts... We find the inevitability worrying and oppressive. We wanted to see for ourselves just how flawed the idea is of constructing a sarcophagus for a miracle... Or perhaps not a sarcophagus, but a space in which a miracle would always be possible.
Why "Changeling"?
Because that's what she is. It's her nature. And she'll stay true to it until the end... Well, almost until the end, seeing as she's the only one with the miracle option. Don't miss it.
And what about the Haruspex and the Bachelor? What are they for then?
They haven't performed any miracles, but both had a chance to accomplish a heroic feat of a different sort... And prove or disprove a number of slippery points in the process.
The Haruspex?
A heretical aspiration! Who do you think you are?
This is why the Changeling was conceived as either holy or possessed. Who if not she was to solve this... essentially religious issue!
The way you're interpreting it, it falls short of counting as religious!
Amen to that... Still, we reserve our right to experiment.
So why did you design the Changeling like that?
Holy or possessed? Is that the same as "thief and miracle-worker"?

Not quite. A thief is a miracle-worker's equal, whereas holiness is not nearly on the same level as... possession, if that's what we're going to call it; ultimately, it's a question of your freedom or lack thereof.
So why did you design the Changeling like that?
I hate your experiments... I find them stupid and naïve.
Diverging branches. He was the only one who could attain true freedom. He wasn't facing the kind of dilemma that the ever-deceived Bachelor found so dismal.
What? Even here, you're not letting me go back to the previous selection? I'd be interested to hear about the other hero too…
Well, sorry... You haven't made your choice yet, have you? The miracle is yet to happen. This was just a reminder.
The Bachelor?

A tempted destroyer. He could have accomplished a feat of moral heroism. The strongest, the most straightforward, he was too strongly tempted by vengeance and destruction for his not going through with it to be anything less than... miracle, or something close to one.
What? Even here, you're not letting me go back to the previous selection? I'd be interested to hear about the other hero too…
Enough. I'm leaving.
I think I'll find a way to even up on you too. To rub your nose and walk you into your own trap. Because it's clear to me now what your goals are.
I think I'll find a way to even up on you too. To rub your nose and walk you into your own trap. Because it's clear to me now what your goals are.
That would be the outcome we hoped for the most!
Oh no, don't lie.
You still don't understand what I'm thinking of now…
And the sister... Did she really exist?
Of course not. The same being sang in two different voices. You had made her up yourself—don't you remember when? It was a falsehood…
Well, the answer has been hinted at…
Enough! I've seen her; I've talked to her.
Is this you talking to us now... or not? Who's speaking?
Me. The Changeling.
Me. The player.
Then it shouldn't surprise you that at certain moments you were seeing Clara in front of you. Right?
Hang on! Here's the important part. Who's she? The twin? The one that doesn't exist?
Oh, we beg you pardon then. This means we're dealing with a really, really difficult medical case here... There's nothing we can do.
Hang on! Here's the important part. Who's she? The twin? The one that doesn't exist?
Seeing as the plague girl invented her in order to save her life and dodge an accusation—she is in fact the saint and miracle-worker.
Then how can we be talking about anything resembling a choice?
I see. In fact nothing should've worked for you at all.
Can a miracle be performed under such conditions?
I've got an idea of my own on the subject…
Indeed? As it happens, I've discovered the meaning of my freedom.
Of course you have. Liar.

So listen how my plot's unfolded... As you probably know I've been deceived three times by people I sincerely trusted. First the Powers That Be, then the Inquisitor—and now, finally, I've found out what the point of the whole affair is. I'm a plaything! And so, undoubtedly, are you.
I know already... So what now? I suppose you'll suggest that I leave it to you to decide?
Of course! How did you know?
What, for your sake? You're a plaything!

Really? Then could you please make it so that I could show up at the Council and present the Commander with arguments in favour of the following arrangement: the corrupt town disappears from the face of the earth, and the Polyhedron stays. It's aseptic and... damn it, it's simply worthy of preserving!
What does that require?

I wrote to you about them the other day. But in case you lost that letter, I'll tell you how to spot them. They all want one thing, and that's to preserve the marvellous Tower. Nothing else matters to them.
No. That will not be.
I'll try to do something. How do I know who your Bound are?
All right. I'll come. If you tell Block yourself that you're on my side, the Inquisitor will be disarmed.
It appears that you've been helpful... Without you, Rubin wouldn't have discovered what my calling was.

Really? Then I could present the Commander with arguments in favour of a proposal that will preserve the town at the cost of destroying the Tower. This is a wise arrangement, and—as my heart tells me—a lasting one. I'm thinking about the future of my community.
What will you need for it?
I will. Have you got your panacea?

I'm out of panacea. I'll have to use the last flask and the last batch of ingredients at the Council, as an argument in favour of my proposal. You don't need it anyway, do you? Isn't it true that you can heal with your hands?
No. I don't need you at the Cathedral, Burakh. Goodbye.

You are an instrument of the Law. At least keep that in mind now that you've chanced to be able to make the choice here. Don't try to be something greater than you are. That's the best you could do in your position.
You're wrong, Aglaya Lilich. I could do a lot in my position.
But you still want me to topple the Tower in the process, don't you? While I don't think there are any good reasons to do that, other than it being what you insist on…
...And so you want to destroy the whole town? And that's after all your talk of love, kindness and mercy...
I agree that an act like that wouldn't befit a saint. But you deny my sainthood, don't you? So your reproach is unfair.
I am the Sand Fever, an embodiment of the Law. I have begun the culling of this town, and I will complete it. Such is my decision.
You want to settle scores with me? Is that it?
I haven't observed any logic in your words and actions, Aglaya Lilich. If I was an instrument of the Law, why did you banish me?
I have touched you. Tremble. You are condemned.

Because you had yielded to a temptation. You had embarked on a perverse course of action: to preserve this outrageous synthesis, which is nothing but a death machine—and to add more deaths to the tally for the sake of its preservation! Your words had also led astray the Bachelor and the Haruspex, to whom I had taken such pains to explain the real state of affairs.
Really? I didn't know that…

You'll never understand this... because you are a sacrificial victim passionately seeking to avoid her lot. So don't judge your superiors, even though you've been invested with the power to judge and to punish them!
I haven't settled on my sacrificial victim yet. Keep that in mind. All right?
What are you talking about?
My principal goal is not to destroy the Polyhedron but to heal the town.
What are you getting at?
Hence I would recommend you to turn your attention to Dankovsky, who intends to destroy the town. Touch him…
You are a destroyer and a killer, Burakh. But for me, you would've drowned your town in blood. Was that what you wanted to save it for?
But I'm not the plague and not a murderer. What's a touch from me going to do to him?
You're a destroyer. You have a cold heart. You can't fully fathom even the true beauty of that Tower of mirrors, whose nature still eludes you…
I've made up my own mind already, Bachelor.

Yes. I admit I have an ulterior motive here. I'd be glad if I didn't have to wreck the town; I might even believe the Ripper... wild though the idea may be. But the only thing he wants is to remove Aglaya from his prophecy…
What are you talking about? What prophecy?

The Kin demands that he kill her. She is his sacrifice. Without it, they won't acknowledge him as a Foreman and Warden... He wants to deceive both them and fate—and to frame the matter differently. He wants to kill the Polyhedron!
But the only thing you want is to preserve the Polyhedron and destroy Aglaya.

Yes, I love the Polyhedron. It is alive, no less alive than the Earth, and is worthy of love. It, too, is inhabited by a collective body; it, too, is infused with a divine essence; it, too, is the dwelling-place of a soul, if you like!
Don't fret, Bachelor. I know what you're driven by.
What, is it alive? Why do you put it like that?
This whole town is like a pair of conjoined twins. Everything is alive here. I understand this very well! You can't even imagine how well…
No, I'm not ready to go outside yet... There will be no turning back. I must make up my mind.

This person is sick. No, don't blame yourself—that's not your fault. One of your rival counterparts must have overlooked them... or left them on purpose. Nevertheless, no entry. It's under quarantine. I keep a sorrowful watch.
Can't they be helped?
Even being one of the Bound, they're just an ordinary person. They can be cured, just like any other. You're the healer here, it's your area of expertise.
All right, I'll try to think of something.
I only need to speak to them. Through the door maybe.

They are unconscious. The development of the disease is uneven, sure, and this person can resist it longer than a commoner would, but there'll be no talking. Unless you offer them a good antibiotic. That could bring them back to life for a while.
Yes... That is an option, even though it's temporary.
All the better. Stand your guard.
Then get to it. You shall begin with Grace, the late cemetery caretaker's daughter. She is especially dear to me.
I'm going to Grace this very minute.
With Grace? Doesn't she sympathize with you... with us?

I want to be certain of that. Make friends with her. And if you need to find out more about her, Lara Ravel is the person who will tell you all about Lasca. She is as much of an angel of kindness as the poor daughter of the caretaker... and her father has recently died too.
I'll find a key to her.
According to one of my faithfuls, a wounded man has slipped away. He should be somewhere near the town cemetery by now.
The wounded factory worker was carried off by the Ripper.

The wounded man has escaped yet again. With what little time he had, he should be hiding somewhere nearby. Could he be in the house by the river? Burakh said that there were blood stains all over the embankment.
I'm going to drop by often.
Please do not think I'm finding it unpleasant. And even if I did…
Let's dispense with the courtesies. Victoria, do you love your brother?
What did we talk about?
You asked if I could hide you away in a safe place. Somewhere you won't be found by your persecutors... So I told you.
Ah... So what's the place?
In the Atrium, of course... Are you making fun of me? Is this a joke?
I'm not. It's no laughing matter at all…
I want to talk to you. Your elder brother... what kind of a person is he? People say you don't love him.
I do love him very much! And he loves me. We have a great affection for each other.
Why do they say then that you two don't talk to each other? And haven't seen each other for a year?
Yes. I think he'll be glad to see me…
Beggar? Now what is that supposed to mean?
Oh why do you take everything personally? It's actually kind of self-enamored on your part. And by the way, we call them as we please. Who are you to tell us otherwise!
Tsk... So how does it all work?
Smarty Pants, huh? It got off lightly, it seems…
Bark and more bark; where's the bite, Aspity?
No. I haven't met any big fellows.
Repent.
Who did you want to kill?

A guild fellow of mine... his ardour was disproportionate to his talent... You see, he nearly convinced the rulers to grant him that side of the river for his project... Yes, he deserved to die. But I didn't kill him...
So who did?
What was his name?
What's the difference? We had him buried under a fictitious name—a tribute to a celebrated architect of old, so there's some consolation for him, at least…
Who are "we"?

I must have a reason to keep that secret, don't you think, old boy? Why would I torture myself over it otherwise? They say he fell down from a great height and broke his neck. That's how he died. I've also heard a rumour that he got lethally intoxicated with bad twyrine…
You do realize that your secrets are easily seen through, don't you, Peter?
Well, not by Saburov…
Doesn't Saburov have real murderers to keep himself busy with? Why in the world would he waste his time trying to get even with you!
Against the current background, this dubious murder seems really too unimpressive to warrant such a diabolical revenge.
A demon can't do a good deed? Not once? Ha ha, you are so naïve! What if it wanted to trick you?
A Steppe spirit can do no good under any circumstances.
But who told you that the what you're getting me to do is good?
That is, for once, something I'm confident about.
For sure?
Gravedigger
I know where the Great Pit is. Always wanted to know what a Great Spit would sound like inside.
By the way, I've found the Bachelor.
How brave you are! Did he say anything? Is Loafer all right?
Apparently he found the boy and took the powder from him. He was acting rather strangely when I met him.
Instead of looking for the boy, he got carried away trying to hunt down the Haruspex.
...Could it be he was testing that horrible mixture on himself?
I really hope he was!
I don't know. Well, I have to go. Goodbye, Capella.
Troublemaker

They say the Kains have their own little shop… and they offer stuff at bargain prices. But it's not like anyone can waltz in there and buy whatever they like—the offer is reserved for the poor and the people that the Kains consider especially trustworthy... I wonder where this shop is?
I wonder whom the Kains trust…

Well I never! You're a theatre person on top of everything? For a being of such purity, your interests are amazingly broad! And here I thought a holy person would shrug at the allure of vain worldly pastimes…
Are you doing that on purpose? Are you a pathological buffoon?
Mark Immortell, I accuse you of heresy and blasphemy. You were the one that brought down the plague upon the town!

I didn't expect this... I was absolutely sure you were in trouble, yet here you are, safe and sound. Have you any idea what I had to do for the money that I've asked you to collect?
L. Ravel
Lara's Note
I'd rather go to the Inquisitor.
The Bachelor is looking for the shabnak plague carrier among suspicious young women. Perhaps he's here?
The Bachelor is looking for the shabnak plague carrier among suspicious young women. Perhaps he's here?
The Bachelor is looking for the shabnak plague carrier among suspicious young women. Perhaps he's here?
Will the Bachelor be coming home tonight? If he can't find me, he'll probably spend the whole night scouring the town… And if he does find me?
Who else could have the secret keys to the brother if not the girl? Maybe she'll give me one—then I won't need a hook…
Yes. But this discovery does not eliminate the overall danger. The country will have no peace until the source of this disease is found.
Yes... All I want is to survive for four more days. The rest doesn't matter.
No, not at all.
If you help me, there will be no need for gallows.
Could I perhaps beg a small favour of the omnipotent Bachelor? Please help me out of this place! I've already heard the shabnak whispering in my ear…
That's quite right, my good man. Obey—and you will live.
If we ourselves are to suffer deception—our hands are no longer tied…
Yes, I often remain unnoticed…
Why?
Say your name.
Oh, I get called all sorts of things... I go by at least six different names right now.
I'm Clara. But I don't think the name particularly suits me.
I can't tell. I have to be cautious…
That's just my fate. Never what it ought to be…
Thank you, Maria.
I lied. I need them for myself. I wanted to use the Inquisitor's name to get to the precious statistics.
Okay…! Take them. Why wouldn't I let you have them?
Why indeed. Hand the papers over!

No, no, no... This will not do. You have received the invitation of the Powers That Be, haven't you? Why haven't you visited the Focus of the Specular Tower? It's a rather curious place. Go, have a look… And then come back here. Otherwise the impression will be lost on you.
What makes you think I haven't been there?

To the Focus? Of course you haven't. Had you gone there, you'd look very different now… Trust me, I've seen a lot of you lot… It's okay, the town is clear, you'll manage to go there and come back in half an hour. We can wait.
Well, as you wish.
Yes, the town looks clean—but I know what hides beneath this false purity!
Oops, forgot about that.

No, no, no... This will not do. You have received the invitation of the Powers That Be, haven't you? Why didn't you pay a visit to the Focus of the Specular Tower? It's a rather curious place. Go, have a look… And then come back here. Otherwise the impression will be lost on you.
What makes you think I haven't been there?

To the Focus? Of course you haven't. Had you gone there, you'd look very different now… Trust me, I've seen a lot of you lot… It's okay, the town is clear, you'll manage to go there and come back in half an hour. We can wait.
Well, as you wish.
Oops, forgot about that.
Exactly, the town is clean! I wish the stubborn Commander would see that…
Why haven't you visited the Focus of the Specular Tower? It's a rather curious place. Go, have a look… And then come back here. Otherwise the impression will be lost on you.
I've already been there. I know who's hiding there all right.

Yes, yes... But do visit the place all the same. They too know that you know that they know… etcetera. Reflections! They realize you're not like those two unfortunates. Perhaps they'll also be smart enough to offer you a more engaging story than they offered them.
They are figments of other people's imagination, just like the cobbles under my feet. What could they come up with that you wouldn't know?
It seems like a hideout for creatures utterly devoid of meaning and purpose. But fine, I will. Pity about the waste of time, though.
Hypocrite! Why not just say it—that it's predetermined; that I have to visit the Focus and will only be allowed here after that. Oh, you silly miracle-worker wannabes…
Where shall you go now, oynon? Who will you look in the face?
I was going to ask you the same.
I don't know... I did everything I could.
I'm looking forward to midnight!
You are a midnight creature, aren't you?
I, on the other hand, don't think I'm going to watch all this.
*** I lost my temper! Burakh will not want to talk to me anymore.
I know. I know it wasn't your well.
Simon Kain and I are... connected. Perhaps even similar. Through me, he'll return into this world.

Interesting. So you say you are the means to his rebirth? How is that to be understood? Surely not literally? Otherwise... forgive me for not believing you. From what I know, Simon will return as early as tomorrow.
No. All I meant was that my actions are somehow bringing back what has disappeared from the world after his death.
Do you still insist that you're able to perform miracles?
But how?
That is none of your concern.
You want to bring him back with magic! But that's sacrilegious...
Yes. And that's precisely the explanation.
No, no... I don't insist on that.
Such matters are beyond your comprehension, Changeling.
And so you are the miracle-worker here? Is that what you believe?
You are a necromancer and a warlock, Georgiy. I've always felt that you Kains are my most formidable opponents.
And thank God for that!
As far as I could understand him, Simon's blood had been shed because of me... Is that what you think too?
…Here you are. I've got everything I ever wanted now...
You are very beautiful... so lifelike. But you're incorporeal, aren't you?
I knew I'll find you here.

Oh, but look around! Can you see who is sitting down below now? The ruthless Inquisitor—hand in hand with the bloodstained Haruspex! The beak-headed demons are wandering the shrine and the faceless are serving her… I'm so scared!
You have commited an inexcusable, irreparable folly...

Don't torture yourself... Do not assume I've done it for you. Not at all. I just wanted to inhabit this place. To bring the Cathedral to life a bit… so that there were at least something miraculous here.
I see...
Suicide is not the way to fill the Cathedral with grace.
…Tell me, Eva, does Maria have anything to do with your death?

Maria, Maria, Maria once again! Why, why do you have to keep talking about her? What does she have to do with this… You are with me now… And it will only last for such a little while! So why ask me about Maria? As if there was nothing else to talk about…
Why did you do it then? Was it really because of…
Easy now... These are ordinary Executors.
Can you hear a whisper beneath the dome? They're speaking to me, but I cannot make out their tongue… I was a slow learner… But I can feel the tone. They're threatening… and condemning me…
I hear nothing.

What am I supposed to do... I have condemned myself to being imprisoned within these walls. How long am I to endure this torment! But perhaps everything can change? Perhaps the evil that's dissolved here comes from the Inquisitor and not from me?

You also think so? Oh, I'm so scared! I fear that I've released something malevolent with my actions… Yes, this place is no longer empty… And something mystical has indeed appeared—I feel it all the time. But it frightens me so very much! What does it mean... how do you think?
But now I can fly! A miracle happened! All I had to do was strain my legs a bit… and fly. It's just that I had to abandon my body not to go down… otherwise I would have fallen…
So you have breathed life into this Cathedral. Do not grieve, Eva. You have not died in vain.

You are the only one who could have said this… I knew you'd be the only one to believe in my miracle… Because you're special. You wouldn't judge me too harshly. You're not… not really picky, and you are free from religious dogmas. Do you acknowledge my miracle?
... Yes. I do. But why are you shivering? Is there something depressing you?
Don't be afraid of anything.
...I am not an expert on religious matters— and tonight is the first time ever that I regret it!
I need the truth.
...No. It wasn't Maria. But enough for now. Go. I don't want to see you anymore.
I'd like to stay with you a little more.
That would be well within your power. You're a spirit, so you can disappear easily.
This is unnecessary. Although... I am eternally bound to these walls now—until this Cathedral falls. I shall never see other worlds.
Until the Cathedral falls...
I'll make you free soon, Eva.
But that's exactly what happened—you have fallen down… you idiot!
No, Eva. You have committed suicide. Now this Cathedral is desecrated and cursed.
Does the Inquisitor bring evil? Is it true that she has deceived us pretending that evil is good?

I think so. I'm observing her when no one else is looking, you know. Yes… she's vicious and arrogant. One should never behave themselves like she does. Even I have never allowed myself to do anything of the kind. She despises you and hates everyone else.
Such is the fate of anyone who commits suicide.
So I thought...
Will you come here again?
...Yes. I will.
No, Eva. We are seeing each other for the last time now.
You are most likely correct.
Soon I will free you. Farewell, Eva.
Yes, lady Katerina.
That's right. You're a good girl, caretaker's daughter.
But you can't heal with blood! …Or can you?
That's not quite fair... But evil is alien to me. I've always helped people. And always considered it a blessing.
I know. I've seen it too recently.
Why are you speaking as if you were reciting a psalm?

Because there are no other words to speak properly of such things. And as for you, obedience will suit you much better than waywardness at this time. You are in too questionable a position—and it is beyond my power to change that on my own.
I fear nothing. My conscience is clear.
Of course I will care of them. After all, who's more in need of care than those rejected by everyone? They'll get their own chance to serve a good cause too... won't they?

Women who weave time into threads of power. They let power go through them and then let the threads back out. Even as men are building a town from wood and stone, the Mistresses weave its soul from intangible substances. The joys and the sorrows, the epiphanies and the lethargies, the feelings, the inspirations, that is the yarn that the Mistresses spin.
How did they appear?
I think I understand. Feels familiar…
Are they different, these Mistresses? How?
And the third one? Who was the third Mistress?
So? You got it? No tail behind you?
I got it, I got it... Come on, take it, time is of the essense.
Stop sweating it, will you? No one was following me. Just look outside the window.
I've brought you some mincemeat for barter… Take a look.
I'm very scared now…
Who knows... Everything points to it.
And she is indeed your twin? Are you impossible to tell apart?
Yes! That's truly how it is.
…What more evidence do they need? And how much of it?

We shall see. Tonight Katerina and I are going to talk about you. Tomorrow we shall state our will to you. And if everything turns out well, tomorrow you may already be helping me restore justice and mete out retribution. What destiny Katerina foresees for you I cannot tell. In the meantime, rest. Take the small bedroom upstairs.
Not miracles, I hope? I can't be commissioned to perform one! It's a power bestowed to me from above!
Good night to you. An unquiet one though it may be.
And you, do you know this man?
I met him today. He made a good impression on me. A determined, clever, and honest man.
That's not what he seemed to me. I'm sure he's a servant of evil. He has long sharp teeth and slit-like red eyes!
Really? He could have been just tired. He has complained to me about quickly becoming exhausted in our climate.
Ah, you're joking! And I'm not joking at all. He's an evil demon! Throw me out if you like, but don't trust him!
But he seemed to immediately despise me.
Don't worry. His opinion of you, whatever it may be, will not influence mine.
…Really?
Why will it always be falling? I'm a good person...

But people are convinced to the contrary. You will exist in several guises here. The guise that will live in the collective mind—and, one may speculate, the collective memory—is a most terrifying one. Every day, people will witness signs of your otherworldly nature. They will be frightened.
No! I will be remembered for my mercy! And always spoken of in praise! You'll see!
Doesn't matter... It won't help them any.
I know all that! There's no need to teach me the basics.
Just dropping in... Don't spill the beans yourself!
I know. I know all that already. Goodbye, good soul.
I'm stalking for prey. If you don't need this goon, he'll do for me.
Where are those robbers?
Over there, next to the cars... Be careful, don't come close! They're wicked good knife-throwers.
So they stabbed this guttersnipe with a knife?
Why?

Looks very suspicious. Unsteady eyes, like he's done something nasty. The kind you can tell is a scoundrel at once. Murmurs something that cannot be understood—threatens to kill somebody. See, he hasn't got the kind of head that honest folk have, either... But he seems more afraid of the Warehouse people than of me. Still, he wouldn't say a word to me.
Is this dog-headed midget also in Alexander's service?
So that's who he is... The Ripper!
No. He's the Haruspex.
Dear me... That's even worse. So where does he live?
Thank you, Grace! I'll stay away from the Works.
So what did you do to become hunted like that?
Who would know me, Executor? I barely recognize myself anymore…
Off you go, then. Come back when you get a costume. Then we'll quite rightfully pass you for one of us.
Wait for me.
*** It was a failure. I shouldn't have lost my temper....
Anna, I'm back. The Olgimskys are waiting. Give me the medicine. It won't help you anyway.
...How can you know they won't help?
Pray, Anna. You're looking for salvation in the wrong place.
So you're afraid, then... That's a clever girl.
Everyone is equally deserving of a severe punishment.

*** ...How do they call upon the menkhu, the faithful of a Warden kin? Known by their hands, for they are butchers; known by their eyes, for they are surgeons; known by their deeds, for they follow the lines. Freezing within the burial hole, silent at the threshold of non-existence, the Kin do not greet the worthy Warden. If only you arrived earlier.
It was a rash decision. Now I will never know what I could have learned today.
Hang on... What was it you said? "Soul-and-a-Half"?
Yep.
How can someone have a soul and a half?

Some people even have two, but they're freaks. You see, a soul-and-a-half is a monster. A demon, sort of like a hobgoblin or a dust-wraith. That's why he's a monster—because he has more than one soul. That's the idea.
I see... So—they attacked you? Hurt you?
So your friends are monsters?

No, they're a different kind of Soul-and-a-Halves. It's what they named themselves to make the Dogheads afraid of them. Not that anyone is afraid of them, of course. Our might will crush them all! Actually, the reason for the name is that they've each got a Half. A little pet familiar. That's who they get the extra soulage from. And boy do they adore the little beasts!
...My heart is beating so fast now... Why would that be? Or have I felt this before?
And what did you do to make them throw you out?
And there I was wondering how a pathetic creature like you could vex everyone so much. Turns out you're really asking for it...
You're a real scoundrel, aren't you...
Why so?

Why? Because first I get chased away into the Steppe by my Soul-and-a-Half mates—and then I run into a Ripper there to boot. Boy was I begging him to let me go—but the bastard knew what I'd been picked on for, then pulled out his knife, and here I am, carved up like so much fillet. It hurts. Help me, will you?
Poor thing... Come on, come to me, let me touch you with my hands. You'll feel better.
Look at my footprints carefully. You may notice something unusual.
How do you know?
I know a lot. Are you forgetting who you're talking to?
That's what I've heard from the people who were robbing the dead at the station. Be careful, if they find out you gave him shelter, they'll come for you too...
No one would dare to touch me... least of all a robber. There's no one villainous enough here to pull a knife to me... That's what my father used to tell me—and that's how it's always been.
