Everything's going to change soon, Grace. Keep your lodge locked at night. Expect no mercy from anyone, dead or living...
Why do they honour you so much?
For feeding them—long after no one else would. For singing songs to their ancestors and comforting those slain at their hands.
What would be the point of living under a sky like that? No, my door will never be locked.
So where's your wounded man?
So where's your wounded man?
…Death?

No. Leaning over the wounded worker was the scary man who'd inflicted all those wounds on him in the first place. I asked him not to kill the workman, but to heal him with living blood instead. And he, the scary one, said nothing for a long time—there was just the sound of his wheezy breath—but then he took the workman and dragged him off somewhere. To his den, he said...
A robber?
You have to have the blood of a man who is still alive and walks the earth. Infusing this blood into a wounded man's veins, if done right, will be beneficial.
And that man knew?
I need him.
What do you mean, vanished?

I brought the wounded man here. Examined him. He was beyond hope. Then I went to get... my tools. When I came back he was gone. That was ten minutes ago. The trail of blood led back to the town. I saw blood on the embankment too, but that doesn't tell us a lot. So I've lost him. Where could he go?
And what were you intending to do to him, you cruel man? He was still alive, wasn't he?
I'll look for him on the embankment. He may have found shelter at one of the houses.
You fear me, Ripper. And rightly so. You must already feel that I'll be the undoing of your gory plans.
What a gloomy and damp place! No human being could live here...
I have no time for this.
No. Do tell.

She believes that we want to bring Simon back to life in a manner that western legends attribute to necromancers. She thinks we are trying to exchange his life for many other lives that are freely given away... It seems that Aglaya Lilich is well-prepared to blame us for every life lost this past week. Why wouldn't she, if she thinks that we benefit from every single death?
Surely that is not the case?
A memory? I'm not sure I follow.

Dealing with the dead calls for scientific precision, doctor. In reality there is neither magic, nor necromancy. The dead cannot be raised from their graves. Their souls may not be transfused into inanimate objects. No one truly expects the spirits of their ancestors to reappear in their newborns…
What a relief…
Would you like to know more about what I mean by "dealing with the dead"?
Of course.

There is life after death. That much is certain. A man most certainly has a soul. And that soul certainly belongs to a better world—more so than to the one it leaves behind. Trying to prolong the time the soul has to stay here is not doing it any favours.
Yes. Undoubtedly.
No. Why are you telling me all this?
I know. She even talked of this before.
My compliments, good Doc. Shell out the cash 'n we'll show you the stash, eh? He heh... Oh hey, your artillery mortar's arrived, Doc, the one you're gettin' for free. Go get it…
I don't think it's yours, is it? Or are you just that fast…?
Felix, qui potuti rerum cogoscere causas.
No, certainly not.
He might even survive this, what with him being Simon's brother.
Qui ingorabat, ingorabitur…
Heads up, Kaspar!
Grace? No, it's not Grace who's gone mad...
Wrong. There's an Executor standing at your door.
An Executor is standing at your door, Anna.
Isn't there an Executor at your door?
Impostor? Changeling? What?
Are you going to deny it?
I am too! I've come here to set everything right. Should it matter to you what I call myself?
No use arguing…
How dare you!
Have a tip, kind sir. Now off you go…
Like the Tower?
...Why have you constructed the Polyhedron, Andrey?
You've ruined the town, Andrey.
"Scraps"…? Oh, you mean the bacteria! Yes, it makes sense. Sorry, I just thought you meant… something else.
Don't go, Rubin. If you care for my opinion at all, stay! I'll definitely need your help down the line.
I knew it… I knew you were going to do this!
I'm sure Georgiy's decision will be fair and just.
Ahem... I was hoping it was the other way round…
This is ridiculous.
At ten o'clock?
I see. So what are you going to do?
You're not doing yourself any favours by being abrasive.
I apologize for the unfortunate choice of words.
So you want to stop them?
Don't you worry, I'll do just that.
Well, I suppose I salute you too.
Oh really?
I don't fancy myself anything. I'm not pretending to be someone I'm not. I am what I am.
Seriously? You're threatening an emissary of the Powers That Be? Or have you forgotten whose envoy you're standing before?
Compared to Him who has sent me, Him who is guiding me—those you serve are mere puppets, mere toys in His hands!
I'm sorry... I didn't mean to say that.
I don't know…
Of course I do! Or do you suppose harmony is the same as beauty, you dim pathetic creature?
I'm not talking about beauty... I'm talking about the miracle of salvation!
Why am I pathetic?
I'll tell you why you're a thief later. I just need to see you in action first, so that I could finally convince myself.
Did the Bachelor inform on me? Did he say that I'm the personification of the disease? But that's not true!
In due time, inquisitor, I'll be the one judging you. Then you'll see what my kind of justice is like.
Right. Like there was any doubt about that... The outcome was predetermined—is that what you're saying?
No, it's not about the outcome being predetermined. It certainly wasn't. What's true, however, is that the particular course of action you were going to take was completely irrelevant to me.
Why?
...Actually, I'm the reason all of this exists.
I know already.
Don't they care about the people?
So you're representing the Law? Then I'd like to ask you a question which has been weighing on my mind for days.
I don't need rewards... I won't cleanse anything from now on—just to make you sorry for not believing me!
Go ahead and ask. As you can see, I'm being very nice to you for now. Not merely satisfying your curiosity, but going as far as to try and preempt it.
Why am I being hounded as a thief? What does it mean?
You're in good mood. Is it on account of your previous visitor?
Impudent girl! Are you trying to play games with me?
No... I wanted to ask a question. Why am I being hounded? Why are they calling me a thief?
Playing games with you would be boring. My little dolls are more fun.

It means that this is your nature. It means that this is your preordainment. As to what exactly it is that you've stolen... that's just the question I'm trying to find the answer to. What kind of a theft can possibly upturn the very foundations of existence? It's no wonder that the Law is after you. You are a great criminal indeed.
...Is that why my Bound are, by and large, all criminals?
Your Bound are no mere criminals; they're wicked to a rare degree. That is because they've broken the Law. They are to blame for all the evil that has flooded the world.
But is anyone who breaks it necessarily a monster and a fiend? I'm talking about myself here!
Isn't it too cruel to blame a handful of people for all the evil in existence?
We're inherently evil, Clara. Evil is what defines human nature. An attempt at self-discovery is a provocation. Don't make the mistake that your doomed counterparts are making now. Stand down.
The Bachelor and the Haruspex? How are they my counterparts?
That will not be. I haven't fulfilled my calling yet. And I won't leave until I've fulfilled it—even if it's evil.

Yes, they're hopeless. The issue is moot in their case. They never had an alternative—having never reached that degree of complexity. While you've had the misfortune to reach it, and that is your curse. Stand down before it's too late. What they can be forgiven for, you can't be.
No! I won't leave. I'm staying.
So this is a trap? All right. I'll think it over…

You still have time. I'm going to use you in my experiments. You see, I know who we all really are—while some, including your counterparts, don't know yet... I'm going to watch you tread the same path. And if I'm guessing correctly, and you really have those abilities... this place won't forgive you for it. And neither will I.
Well, be my guest…
They're not my counterparts. They are homunculi, demons, notwithstanding their human shape. Don't equate me with them! I'm not afraid.
And what role would that be?
And what if I don't reveal myself? If I just deliberately won't?
You will. Any single action of yours will tell me more about you than you think. And that includes refraining from an action.
You sound as if I were some animal you were studying!
Well, at least that's something... Or are you implying that I only have myself to blame?
Don't try to be clever, my dear. It's getting boring. Really, we ought to be done with this quicker…
So what's going to happen today?
…Another wicked criminal?

Judging by what I've managed to find out, he's elbow-deep—nay, shoulder-deep in blood. An amazing specimen of irredeemable sin. He has no concept of mercy, and no conscience. Come to think of it, I'm not sure he has a soul at all.
What if I do find a soul in him?
What do you need him for?
You can try. I think it would be an exercise in futility.
It will be another small miracle then…
Guilty, of course... Everyone's guilty.
Wrong! I'm capable all right! Don't try to convince me that I'm like that... foreman of yours!
Quiet now... Don't yell. Surprising in a holy person like you, this fervent insistence on your predilection for lying... Falsehood are evil. A stench rising from the abyss of death.
What a hypocrite you are! Goodbye. I don't want to be here any longer.
The choice is yours... As usual.
Aren't you afraid that I could deceive you?
Don't put yourself on that list. I'm watching you too... and your true nature will not escape me.
All sorts of things. He does have a soul, by the way…
"Acknowledged Foreman Oyun as being in possession of an immortal soul." Note taken. Very good, my dear. Anything to add to that?
We also talked about Burakh, the Haruspex—that demon who certainly has no soul!
I'm not telling you anything. I find you abhorrent!
He said he was going to kill him. One can hardly wait... right?
Now that's a dramatic change of expression if I've ever seen one!
What do you mean, which part? I hate him!
I will reward you if you do exactly as you've been told. Don't for a moment think I won't find a way to check. So no trying to deceive me!
You're kicking me and asking for my help at once! I'd rather you made up your mind…
You're much easier to deceive than you think, Aglaya Lilich.
"A little"! I don't need anything from you!
And how did you do it?
With a miracle. You won't understand.
I've banished... a certain someone from there.
A carrier?
…Maybe.
It was my sister. I never expected to run into her... It's insane…

Then how can I verify the truth of your words? It's easy to claim credit for a work that does itself. I once knew a man who'd convinced an entire village that the sun would have stopped rising in the east but for his heroic effort. Incidentally, he too was considered a saint...
You have no alternative. Isn't it your duty to cleanse the entire town of the infection? If the Powers That Be find out you had a chance to reduce it and didn't take it...
You understood everything long ago... I can see it in your eyes. So why are you afraid of admitting I'm right?
How indeed? What are you driving at, impudent girl?
I was just expressing my sympathy for you…
I'm glad the demon is dead.

People tend to demonize what they can't understand... You see a twisted image of yourself in your counterparts... more powerful, while also badly damaged... You don't understand how the two qualities combine. But you're wrong. How is he a demon, silly? He is just like you.
I don't think so. He's not a miracle-worker. I mean, was not.
Actually you're right... But that changes nothing.
Of course you just thought you saw them. What could possibly happen to me?
What, what is it? I don't see my soles…

Here's the plan for today. You will go to the Kains and find out why this perverted Polyhedron is so precious to them. Same pretext: say I'm accusing them of starting the epidemic. The "it's a work of art" evasion is no longer an acceptable answer.
And why would it be unacceptable? How is it not a work of art? If I had a tower like that it would be precious to me too!

The Bachelor is already working on this theory. What I need is mysticism. He doesn't understand it; you will. Even if you won't, you'll still be able to passably communicate it to me. Any more questions?
How many questions can I ask now?
No. No questions. I just need to be myself, right? Well, I'm going…
Who am I?

I haven't understood it yet, my dear... Perhaps you will bring me the answer today, on the soles of your shoes... Have you ever seen them? They're most curious. Every time you walk away, I look at your feet... a very interesting view!
Don't make fun of me... Is this the final test?
You are afraid of me, Aglaya, aren't you... That's why you haven't killed me yet. Afraid that if you do, something will be irretrievably broken, right?
I'm just not cut out for having a fate at all.
No. It's not like that. I even like the Polyhedron. I now like whatever you hate!
Well, so what have I found out? I doubt you know what I know now. Or else we'd be seeing less arrogance out of you... you plaything.

Why, no offence taken. A typical example of rushing to conclusions. You're behind the times. Truths like the one you just presented me with are no longer fashionable. That's more in the Bachelor and Haruspex's line... By the way, don't give them hints if you meet them. Let them work it out on their own.
All right. So what have you found out?
Well, sum it up. And I've already found a path to victory... All these simulacra, these reflections of reflections shall confuse me no longer. I am firm in my faith! And I am free.
Oh indeed?
So tell me... where did I come from? Speak, dummy. Try to talk me to death.
I don't need your truths. Goodbye, Aglaya Lilich. I've alredy realized how to perform a miracle that will convince you... forever.
Why?
People aren't inclined to be on good terms with their own history—yet in this particular town, the impossible happened: the people prevailed over the power structures.
How did it happen?
You couldn't tell by looking at them... I can see you've only been interrogating aristocrats—for the common folk, you're completely unconcerned!

I didn't say their lives were easy or prosperous. I said they were happy. The common folk will tell you the same. The well-off are never satisfied. The local rulers had understood or sensed it. They were truly extraordinary people, and they took a creative approach to the problem of universal happiness.
How?

It was a joke, obviously. Do you seriously think I would interpret mythical figures literally? That said, there's definitely something... obscure about you. I can't get rid of a gnawing feeling that as I stand here looking into your eyes, you're simultaneously staring at the back of my head.
That's because I'm an... unusual kind of girl. This must be a bad time for me to turn up, right?
Is that so? That explains a lot... So you have supernatural abilities?
Not exactly... I'm no sorceress. I comfort people. That's why they trust me.
An epidemic? No. I know nothing about it…

Then listen. Due to the threat of an epidemic, our town's ruling families have divided certain burdensome duties among themselves. Bachelor Dankovsky has asked our family to take charge of setting up special facilities... as well as commandeering medical supplies.
Oh yes, all that medicine will be of no use to her.

I don't want to force her to surrender it. After all... with the kind of relationship that we have, I can't afford to be rude or intimidating. And you seem capable of being really persuasive. So persuade Anna to donate her stockpile... voluntarily! She doesn't need that much anyway; It's more like compulsive hoarding at this point.

A creature more terrifying than anything you'd see in a nightmare. It's not alive, but pretends to be so. It has no will of its own, but acts with a lot of resolve. The Earth brings it forth from time to time, fashioning it out of the bones of the dead. It had magical abilities and often assumes a human shape.
Do I look even remotely like it? You hurt me… a lot!
What is its purpose?

The Earth fashions it when angered by men. In the old myths, the Earth would grow angry from hunger. And it would get hungry when the dead weren't buried in it. The people of the Steppe honour only the most righteous with that... So... you can guess the rest. The creature would appear in times of lawlessness. To kill, of course. Which is why they call it—call her—a Maneater.
You're saying that... a creature made of bones and clay can have warm lips, soft skin, and silky hair?
Oh, that's just my sister... I see her eyes too when I look at you. She can also do many things that ordinary people can't. She's my twin, after all.
By the way, since you're such a master of good deeds, would you like to do something really beneficial?
Why not? Tell me.
Those were your own words. Why ask me?
That's the reason I'm here.
What is that supposed to mean? Explain yourself. Are you saying that you're the cause of the disease?
No. Quite the contrary! I strive to be a source of good and good only.
Oh how your eyes light up! Let me guess... Yes, you thought you were the guiltiest party right up to this moment. And now you're hoping to find a more convenient culprit!

You're a good psychologist... But if you thought you could intimidate me, you thought wrong. Both my conscience and the things that weigh down on it aren't nearly as big as they might seem at first glance. You shouldn't have fallen out with me so soon…
I will come again. And then we'll have a frank conversation. It will ease your mind, I promise…
Wait, wait... Let's not quarrel... Be nice, and I'll help you. All right?
No. I don't think it's going to be a good deed at all. You shouldn't try to deceive me. I can see it all in your eyes.
A very wise decision.

You think? Well, perhaps... So the thing is, the town's short on medicine. We're scraping together what little we can. But there's a certain someone who's been stockpiling various drugs for five years by now... A young singer named Anna Angel.
That won't help. A completely pointless idea.

Strange girl... You act as if you're well-informed about what's going to happen to us. I hope you realize how suspicious this looks. Or do you flaunt your knowledge so openly because Saburov is in charge of punitive actions?
No, no, it's not what it looks like! I just... blurted it out before I knew any better! Must have been a premonition. I told you I'm a little... distracted. Some would say batty.
You fool! It's exactly because the Saburovs are destined to… take charge of punitive actions, that I found shelter under their roof. Farewell.
A singer? Young singers tend to be blithe. What's up with her? Odd, very odd…

There could be some foul play involved... But I don't think she knew or prepared anything beforehand... It's just that she lives in the Hindquarters, in Earth... A few years ago, there was a really bad outbreak right nearby. She's been buying up medicine since then.
How do you know that?
And so?

Well, she's been spending every last coin at the pharmacy for the past five years. She visits every pharmacy in the town on Wednesdays, buying heaps of whatever new medicine hits the market. Hard to ignore, you know.
And you're going to take her stockpile away?
What's so strange about it?
You know what just occurred to me? That she's already taken care of my father.

Isn't it the other way around? Nevermind, just kidding... So he advised you to ask me? Crafty, that... I've underestimated him. So essentially, he wants to do me a favour by getting this monster out of our way?
She's a monster?
Yes, that's right... Curious now, aren't you? No, Anna's not someone to suspect of starting the outbreak. Did she give up her stash?
Like she had a choice! Of course she did.
How did you manage that?
I explained to her that none of it would help anyway.

If it's true, Anna deserves to be left alone for providing valuable information. But that Anna is a crafty and dangerous beast... The offspring of a cat and a serpent—that's what her totemic ancestor was. But you won't find any proof. He's not going to succeed.
He loved Nina?
He did.
So he pierced the town's heart with a sting for her sake?
Can't you see the chimney? There it is!
I can't. I'm not too impressive in the height department, as you can see.
Thank you.
Ugh... That's horrible! Do you think he's dangerous?
What? No... he's dead already. Although they say the dead are even more dangerous than the living! Especially if they decide to forever haunt those who'd slighted them before they died…
No, I mean the Bachelor! I dread him for some reason... an inexplicable fear, like a premonition. He's not a turnskin, is he?
So... the living are much more dangerous than the dead after all. But these ones seem kind…
Are you talking about the Bachelor? I find him menacing too…

He doesn't look cruel... You think he's the actual monster from the Steppe, whose coming was announced today? The terrible doll made of human bones? No, I don't think so. The shabnak always seeks to assume the shape of a woman.
Yes, it's those exact bones that I feel in him! He's somehow... not real. Like an animated strawman.
Don't you argue with him, though! He represents the Law now! And the Law is not on our side.
What? The Law?
I didn't know it myself…
By the way, he's still looking for that wounded man... He'll get here sooner or later.
Trying to mess with my head, are you, dear...? Want to lead me straight into the rogues' den? There's no way I'd go there.
Don't be silly. Children aren't evil; it's not in their nature. No, Anna, evil comes from elsewhere...
So what if he did? Why is it making you so anxious? Surely you won't be mistaken for some homeless boy, what with this mansion of yours. Hmm?

Yes, of course... But perhaps he didn't kill that boy after all... Then... then things aren't so terrible. Clara, do me a favour please! I really need to know if that crime has actually been committed. I mean, to know whether he really is... that cruel. Please!

There's nothing worse than a crime against a child! Especially in this town... Only a stranger could be capable of such a savage crime. Any local would know how the Kains would react to something like that—especially the younger ones!
Anna dear, it wasn't you who killed him... What are you so afraid of? No matter how brutal this murderer is, he's a threat to everyone equally. Trust me...
Yes, this is terrible... monstrous.
Don't worry. It wasn't he who killed the homeless boy. It's not this neighbour of yours that you ought to be afraid of… Anna Angel.
So it's the Kains' reaction you're worried about, huh? And here I almost thought you were upset about the boy...
Well... The Haruspex let the homeless boy go.
Oh. Thank goodness. But perhaps he didn't do it out of kindness of heart? Did he?
Good heavens... So it's true.
Looks like you're not particularly interested in who killed him. So it's not the Haruspex that you were afraid of…
It was I who severed his life's thread, Anna Angel. Remember it. Goodbye.
Quite likely not... It must have been a calculated move. He was afraid that another murder would make his existence in this town impossible.
Who knows... Maybe it was kindness. Time will tell who's evil and who's good... And we won't have to wait long now. Be patient.
It was so wonderful... Why is this even happening?
You're lying; I can't hear a thing. It's empty and silent, as it always is.
It may be empty now... but the Bachelor will see to it that it will soon be just as I've described, I promise you that. I for one can hear the screaming already. Don't know about you…
I've always said that this Bachelor is a bringer of death!
So can I! I always know more than you do.
May be, may well be…
Call for Mark. I need to talk to him.
*** It didn't work out. I was silly to let it out...
Are you telling the truth?
I always tell the truth.
Check for yourself if you don't believe me.
How come?

I can't tell you yet, but I will later. So many things are mixed up here, one doesn't know who to fear more... So you're with the Saburovs now, right? Good... you'll be safe with them, and the children won't hurt you. Here, I've got a present for you.
No. I prefer to keep clear of beasts…
Have you been crying? Don't hold back if you want to cry... It's nothing to be ashamed of.

*** As ever, my tongue runs ahead of my reasoning! So many times have I promised myself to keep mum; to let the others talk... It wouldn't work anymore, even though it seems there may be a silver lining to this cloud.
If I have a what?
Look. I can work miracles with my own hands.

You're dropping in quite often now... This is a dangerous place for a girl who doesn't cover her knees. Also, too many temptations here for a saint. And finally, this is as goddamn unfitting a place as any for Lady Plague to be in! Way overcrowded, ha ha... How can I help you?
I've brought you some herbs... Take a look and see if they're any good. And give me one of those bottles over there…
I've come to like the smell. I enjoy breathing your air.
Do you intend to hide in here? Pour wine over your dead, play leap-frog with corpses? This debauchery will not be without consequence! Pray…

You've acquired a taste, then? I should never have shown you that path... messes too much with a head as young as yours. It's a part of you forever now. Anyway, no need to regret it. What have you got?
Don't grin like that. It's not for me.
I don't regret it. Your herb has no effect on me.

No! I don't have any medicine. When I was young, I used to play at the house of a wicked witch—now that's who had a real stash, for every disease... She lived for a hundred years. Her place had that pharmacy smell everywhere! Do you take me for someone like that crone? Nonsense!
Don't lie to me, Anna. I even know where you keep it. Why are you trying to deceive me?

Oh, what a pain... This is surely a plot against me... They want to kill me, destroy my life, send me to an early grave. An early grave, yes... Listen! I don't want some disease to eat me alive, to ruin my skin... Leave me that if nothing else, or just shoot me with a gun!
It's not their fault, Anna. It was an order.
All right, I'll tell the Olgimskys then that you have nothing. Right?
Give them at least some of it. Leave the best-looking ones for yourself. I think that's a good idea. Isn't it?
Did you say they require blood?
Your Ripper, that's who.

"Our" Ripper? Ah... you mean Young Burakh? Sadly, that's a misconception. I used to think so too. I wanted to get as many twyrine infusions out of him as possible... they're priceless! His father had been a respected man who knew his trade... This one, though, doesn't know a thing.
Are you sure?

Quite. When I brought him to Isidor's workshop, he didn't even know how to use a distiller and just stood there gaping at it. He doesn't know what twyre is. How can someone like that be a knower of root knots and grass fibers? Even the Stamatins by now have more knowledge of herbs than him. Amateurs... the plague take them!
Yes, you've convinced me! But there's no need to say it like that. Especially now. It's too... dangerous.
Right. What about Anna, then?
Don't underestimate intuition. He may be following a gut feeling…
I was just lucky.
Is that true?
Yes.
How do you know?
So you still haven't realized who I am? Are you not surprised that she gave me all of it so easily?
I don't know... But it does feel that way. Why have you suddenly turned so pale?
But you knew it as early as yesterday... didn't you? Was that why you sent me to that uncanny place with the old necromancer and his niece?
This is not a request. It is an ordainment. What made you reconsider?
I've concluded that no evil can come from decisions that I make. So I will make decisions.
Good. We shall begin with a mysterious creature named Aspity. I will show you where she lives.
There's no need. I know it all anyway…
Seems like fate wants it this way.
Why her? Who is she?

The question is not who, but what. Children say she is an evil spirit. Simon didn't like her. That bitch has been called a walking plague even before this. I'm sure that a woman, a maneater, and a spawn of the Steppe—which is exactly what a shabnak is—is a fitting description for her.
If so, she's in for it.
Asps, spite, and spit.
What is your verdict, then? Is she guilty?
Nothing. She has no soul.
I couldn't decide... But I did feel our souls had something in common!

...I saw this coming. Just thinking about the consequences of your alliance sends shivers down my spine... So what now? I suppose your friend will tell you everything herself, especially considering your talents. Or am I getting the wrong idea about the nuances of your cordial relationship?
You hate her, don't you?
My new father has more important things on his plate than doing you favours!

Aha! So they've adopted you? That's symbolic... Well, if not me, how about doing a favour to my father? After all, your—ehm—father is not the governor yet... and hopefully will never be. So Saburov could do with my father owing him a favour.

She scares me, plain and simple. My father, on the other hand, truly hates her. The fact that she's still alive has made me reconsider how I feel about my father... It turns out he's much kinder than I thought.
What makes you say that?
So what did Aspity do to displease your father so much?
*** I lost my temper there for a moment... Where am I supposed to find a bull now? At least, it feels like I did the right thing. Dealing with this Changeling may be bad for one's health...
So she's out to destroy your family, but is wiping out the Kin instead?

If we knew for sure that she's the one stirring up the Worms, butchers, and workmen, we'd make short work of her. Saburov would not object, nor would Judge Kain take a break from his indifference. But you see, I'm a sensible man... and deep down, I'm convinced she's just an ordinary dirty lowlife.
Have you met her?

Once. Her face left quite an impression and so did her speech. That sing-song drawl, that guttural accent of the Steppe... Fascinating. On the whole, she looked rather uncanny. But I thought back then it was just something she was doing for effect. My sister also thinks she's just a vagabond girl obsessing over demonic dreams.
Was it a long time ago?
What do you mean?

Exactly that! Yes, yes... there's a reason things have been going the way they have! And that horrible thing at the Termitary... Yes, she's aimed a battering ram at him that will strike him down any time now. And now she's shifted her attention to me. That's what's happening! Should I warn him...? I don't like this... but he's angry at me...
I'll tell him what you said when I get the opportunity.
I'm often told just that: wrong door. People simply won't believe that I've come to them—at long last…
What? Are you trying to be funny?
Not in the slightest.
Are you feeling well?
What? What the... Who sent you? Was it Yaklakh?
Aspity has set up a trap.
Yaklakh? Who's that?
Hey... Anyone in the hallway? Take this thing away...
My family is at the peak of its power now... and you think you can warn me about some danger? Especially when it's from that half-witted beggar?
It's what your son wanted me to say…
Fat Vlad... Do you think your belly will shield you from death? No-one needs your money, you blind fool!
You're in danger. Aspity has set a trap for you!
There's no one in the hallway. It's dead quiet. And you—you'll regret this!
Crush her? Go ahead and try.
I don't trust you. Why bother to talk? Hm?
We'd be better off together than each on our own.
Quite the contrary. We'd be much better off on our own than together.
Would you perhaps like me to do something for you? What could I do to warm you up to me?
As you wish... But now I'm offended.
Ah... so it's money you want, you little informer... I can appreciate that, I really can... So, take this for—heh—saving my life. I'll have a better look at her, then.
That's better... You'll appreciate me yet.
Aspity, oh Aspity, I know of you this…
Clara darling, have you gone mental? Must be the local air. Happens to outsiders a lot. I'm no "Aspity"!
Saba Usp'tae…
Sahba-ötün…

Look, that's enough. You're being obnoxious. Are you trying to bewitch me? Would you like to see me try that too—the way I do it with creatures like your little self? Careful, Clara, my child; you may go missing…
Don't be cross. I just want to talk…
No. I don't. And don't look at me like that...
Are you sure you want to make an enemy of me? I'd think twice if I were you…

Why, I've made friends with you already... only you don't know it yet. The one I've made friends with, my very own sister, isn't the person to disown our kinship. If you could only get on good terms with her—so could you and I... Oh, just kidding. So what about you, are you not afraid of the shabnak?
I am. Shall I perhaps fetch you some spring water?
Shall I perhaps fetch you some spring water?
I'm not. Would you like me to do anything for you? How can I make you warm up to me?
And why are you worried?
That's none of your concern.
I know it myself.
Are you sleepy? Why are you lowering your eyes?
And you're not going to interrupt me?
No, I'm not. Speak.
Sahba-ötün, oh Sahba-ötün, I know of you this: you've fallen in love with this Burakh! Will you agree to touch me? To brave the depths? To answer my questions candidly and without prejudice?
Saba, oh Saba, I know of you this: your greatest desire is to kill Vlad Olgimsky. Will you agree to touch me? To brave the depths? To answer my questions candidly and without prejudice?
There we go, I knew it was a spell... You're an idiot, Clara. Your sister is smarter. Get lost.
But…
Beware of the sister, Aspity dear... She'll come back here as soon as I leave.
Out.
All right, I'm leaving.
Did you... did you cause the epidemic?
...The shabnak-adyr exists? Is it you?
I see. You may wake up.
That's what you all say... Let's just make our acquaintance for now.

Who you are is no secret. It was you that sat on Simon's chest last night. It was you that Isidor had warned him about. Tell me, why were you so cruel to him? Why did you not let him pass away with the same noble and majestic countenance that he had worn among the living?
Is this a joke? I'm not death! Don't worry…
I am quite unafraid of you. In fact, I even entertain a degree of pity for you. Do you realize how dangerous the walls of our house are to you?
Yes. I feel fear and I can't explain it.
Are you that sure of yourself?

Maria is near. Her mere proximity will turn you to ashes once she ascends to the fullness of her powers. And that will be soon. You are probably feeling the pain already... akin to a deadly radiation turning your bones into porous lime... Am I right?
Why are you so calm, Kain? Could it be you've planned something cunning against me, you heretic utopians?
Is she a witch? I can't think of any other reason for her to hate me... The power that guides the palms of my hands is a benign power. There's no doubt of that.
Yes... I can feel her proximity destroying me... but I don't believe she'll win.

Saddened though I am on Simon's account, I am nonetheless not so foolish as to be angry with you. Only a fool would curse and threaten the wind that has torn the sail off his mast. Besides, unlike Georgiy, I profoundly doubt the imminence of your victory.
I feel sorry for him too... And I feel sorry for all of you. That's easy to understand... But why should you pity me?
Yes... wind is sent from heaven. All that matters is not to sail against it.
I don't know anything about myself either…
Because I don't want you to doubt in my good intentions.
Because I want him to be buried in the earth.

If you know where Simon's body is being hidden, it ought to look quite suspicious to us. You must have been pursuing your own goals, I suppose; ritual ones. We are not merely talking about a body of a dearly departed. Do you understand that?
Are you from the Steppe? I mean, a pagan?
No! Quite the contrary...
Yes. I want the earth to have her due.
Of course I do! I know what a semblance is.
I understand. And so—where is the body?
Do you understand the risk I was taking coming here? You were right, you know... about the rays.

Your words sound wise and quite fair. You evidently know what you are talking about. The destruction of Simon's body would inevitably lead to the destruction of our entire town. But now that the body has been found—we will try and use all of our influence to save the town... one way or another.
So what do you think I would've done had I been who your crown-bearing daughter thinks I am?
Whatever has happened or will happen to Simon is going to impact the universe. That's what you believe.
So you know already?

Like I said, we know everything already. But it is good that you have come. My brother is very angry and prejudiced against you. And as for me, I will now think twice before believing any of the things you are accused of. She who you are being mistaken for would indeed never have given us the body.
This is making me dizzy... So... you engineered all of this from the very beginning?
...Was this a test?
No. It's not like this. Take some money. This is all I can do to reward you for now. Aside from trusting you, of course.
I know, but I can't tell you…
You are already the talk of the town. Wicked people are afraid of you. And not just the wicked people. You inspire fear... in many, my dear daughter.
Yes. Rather a lot... All those places to visit. I had to go everywhere. And observe everything.
Yes... I understand... Will you tell me about it?
I don't think I should... I really don't. You don't need to hear about any of that... my dear father and protector!
…Are you willing to continue helping me in the future?
I can see this is not what you want to ask me about... Has something happened?
Are you finding it difficult to talk to me, father? Have I done something to make you angry?
...Are some people really afraid of me? Who are they?

That doesn't matter. It is for the better. You can see what's going on yourself. Monsters are hatching one after another, each uglier than the one before... You poke your finger anywhere and you squash some abominable spider every time. Is the epidemic spawning them, or did they spawn the epidemic? I don't understand anything anymore.
...Follow your heart's calling, father.
Yes. You're right. A lot of people are getting causes and consequences mixed up now. That's because everything has become a closed loop. They are right.
What wicked person have you found for me this time?
Father... Do you really want me to do something that your own patrolmen can't do? I'm no Judith…

I understand that. You must be thinking that I have got myself a personal enemy—an enemy who is challenging the order that it is my present duty to enforce and maintain. I understand. You must be thinking that I want to destroy the thief and mark him with the brand of Jonah. Rest assured that it is not so.
Why?
Why would they do that? With the… corpses, I mean?
They probably wanted to hide the bodies. Which can only indicate that the thieves had a hand in those people's deaths.
...Do you think they deliberately infected people?
Why look for it? We know where Grief's quarters are...
Who could know things about him? You know... things. He won't open up unless I catch his soul with a hook.
I don't know. Olgimsky surely knows something, but he will say nothing. Think. Do your own research.
I'll try... I think I know who that could be…
I don't think I can do it. I don't know anyone around here...
No... I'll be the one who restores order here.
What? What did you find out?
Grief is not the mastermind. He really did prohibit murdering. The killers are being incited by a different man, known as Barley the Barber...
What about me... don't you care at all?
If it's true we need to inform the Bachelor immediately. He seems about to try to snatch Wolf's glory from under his nose.
I'm glad you are unhurt, Clara. But I also know that you'll never come to any harm, however things might turn out... Such is your preordainment.
That's true. Still, I'm terribly scared.
...And what's your preordainment, father? What's Grief's? Why do you even need me for if you know things that are hidden from me?
Enough... We'll discuss that later. Now to the business at hand. I need to send a messenger to Wolf at once.
See this sack? I stole it from Barley's lair... Take it. It's very heavy. And wet…
...Look.
It's Wolf's head... The sergeant in charge of the operation. The one who first found out about the killers' secret meeting…
Well? Fine parcel, eh?
Barley killed him. He's the real leader of the barber gang.
(...fancy that, this one isn't afraid of me either... not that it counts for much since he's just too dumb to be afraid.)
I will stay here even after I leave. Will you solve my riddle?
That was just me being concerned about you... Take your time and think a little, then I'll ask you again.
But why don't you ask Grief yourself? You know where he lives. Bring him in and question him... why do you need me?

The wily lowlife is denying everything... He feigned fear and pretended to have had nothing to do with it. He acted his part so well that he even raised the alarm himself! And yet I'm sure it's Grief who is inciting the killers, as well as buying up their victims' stolen belongings. Ask him if it's true. I am sure it is.
Don't you have a way to loosen his tongue?

That is not all. I suspect that Grief enjoys the Olgimskys' protection... in exchange for giving them kickbacks from his illicit trade in twyrine. Should Vlad take offence, I would prefer to face him fully armed. Ask Grief if it's true. I would like to know everything about him... before he's dealt with.
I'll ask.
I don't understand.

I've set up a trap for Grief. Sergeant Wolf found out that the killers' ringleader had called up a meeting at a certain secret location. All that remains is to discover that location, and we'll catch Grief red-handed. The ringleader is none other than him. It cannot be anyone else.
Actually, I haven't asked him yet... Because, you see, it was he who sent me to you, to intercede on his behalf!
I don't know about your judgement, father—but mine has to be fair and impartial!
So am I to tell Grief you're not going to go after him today?
...Have you talked to it already? What did it tell you? Did you remember to ask it about... yourself?
I don't believe a single word it said! But it said that I'm the plague... Which I don't believe. Don't disown me, please!
How could I have asked him about my own holiness? It's a sin... I mustn't. But you do believe me, don't you?
I don't even know where to begin…
He deserves to die.
I knew that. Who do we send to him, then? An entire squad has been massacred by the barbers...
Spare yourself the trouble... father. It's all been arranged already.
Begin with the Olgimskys. That is the most important sin for me, and the least for him, for it is not his fault. So did Olgimsky protect his illicit trade? Did he benefit from it?
He didn't just benefit; he presided over it. Grief was his stooge.
Now then, we shall skip the issue of the barber gang, since it's clear now who their true mastermind was... thanks to your courage, my brave girl.
I won't be able to tell for certain until I've asked Vlad himself…
Don't skip it just yet. Barley was as much of a puppet in Grief's hands as Grief himself was for Olgimsky. Everyone has their toys.
...Yes, let's skip it.
And I was beginning to regret my bias! It seems I shouldn't have... Well, that settles it.
Aren't you interested to know what my verdict is? Whether Grief is the cause of the disaster that's struck us?
Well... Is he the cause of the disaster that has struck the town? What's your verdict?
So what would you say about him?
Covered in blood from head to toe! He may look like one of us—but I'm convinced that he's not human. He was spawned by the abyss. An evil spirit's will is behind his actions!
Leave him alone. I'll put an end to his misdeeds in due time.

Because I've decided that today shall see the end of any and all killers who use scalpels, razors, knives, barber scissors, or any other manner of blades. The epidemic mowing down human lives is bad enough on its own. The streets will be safe—in daytime as well as at nighttime!
The Haruspex is not one to get caught easily...
I know where his lair is.
Indeed? Where is it?
In a factory building by the railway.
There's no one there. Wolf and his squad swept all suspicious areas along the railway tracks. Including the Works.
That's odd…
I don't know. So this Haruspex is going to walk into an ambush as he gets home…
Is Rubin really there?

No. No one knows where Rubin is. The Kains dispatched about a hundred men; they've been searching for him since yesterday, turning half the town inside out, but he's still nowhere to be found. I, however, am going to search the other half... and I have the feeling I will succeed. Then the Kains will understand who they're dealing with.
And is it true? About Rubin?
And this Haruspex, is he—
I just wanted to say that there's an ambush laid for you. Don't go home today…
So that's how it is... Then I suppose you don't at all care about who's waiting for you back at home!
Really? Who laid it?
I doubt it's a pleasant visitor. Whoever it is, someone knowing where I live is no good news. Or is it Young Olgimsky?
Alexander Saburov, my adoptive father, detests you. For no good reason, I'd say.
Thank you... what was your name again?
No. Not Young Olgimsky. It's Rubin.
What? Rubin? You talked to him?
Yes, him. Young Olgimsky.
Then he can go to hell. Chap's got nothing but money on his mind.
...While you've got nothing but blood on yours, eh? You're really thick, Haruspex. Or are you too busy to stop and take a more thorough look at me?
...What? Why on earth would I do that for?
Because I am you. Except I'm always a step ahead of you. In everything.
You see... I like you.
Go away, Changeling. Got enough on my plate without you.
How rude! Don't go home tonight. You'll remember my words later.
That was a joke. Rubin is who's waiting for you back home. He'll have yet more to add to your plate.
How should I put it... Well, I did.
No. I found out by chance.
Is he... plotting revenge?
Alexander Saburov, my adoptive father, detests you. I share the sentiment, but I don't want to be part of anything underhanded.

I'm a trifle tired, I am... Eh well, my life's barely begun—and it's almost lights out time already... Questions! Who's got time for that! Oh no, I ain't angry at all... just tired. 'Tis all because of 'em questions. You agree to answer one, and a bit of your life's blood escapes with the answer. With the anger. Anger is our life's blood, lil' pimple...
I feel sorry for you... You must be in pain.

Whoa, whoa! Who are you to feel sorry for me, you lil' tot? Eh? I won't tolerate anyone's pity, I've got my own pity to spare. Ain't you a kind lil' lass, a loving lil' one... Makin' me go all soft on you… eh? Where did the anger go? No anger in sight, none at all... heh heh.
There's a reason for that, Grief. We are alike, you and I. Our paths have crossed for a reason.
And do you know there's going to be a manhunt for you?

Bah... old news. Dontcha teach a cook in his own kitchen, all right? They'll end up grabbin' the wrong man. The Bachelor—more like the Bitchelor!—wouldn't put in a word for me, so perhaps you will help out, what with you being the Saburovs' new little sweetie? Tell him I had nothin' to do with it, will you?
He won't believe me. He's too angry with you. He doesn't answer to anyone, so there's a lot of rancour in him...
Better tell me why there are thugs posted around your warehouse, standing there twiddling their knives.

How else do we defend ourselves against Barley the Cunt? Son of a bitch's lured all my men away from me, promisin' carnage. Those animals didn't go over to his side for the plunder; just out of sheer blood-fuckin'-lust! And who do I have left? There, go ahead, feast your eyes: my loyal faithful; that's the lot. Eh, one gets what one gets! As they say, beggars can't be choosers...
Why are you hiding your eyes? Don't you know I have the gift of seeing through any lie?

Cut the braggin', thief darlin'! A gift like that spells early death, y'know. Must be the reason Saburov took you in, you poor lil' soul... So you can see through any lie, eh? How about seein' the fact that I haven't taken a single life, none at all?
Am I supposed to just make up that "truth" or what?
They do call me a thief, and I am one—but I'm not that kind of thief! I don't steal truth.
I was going to anyway...
Sure, go on. Whaddya wanna know? Just do me a favour and skip the mumbo jumbo part.
…Filin, oh Filin, I know of you this: you are the real ringleader of the killers! Will you agree to touch me? To brave the depths? To answer my questions candidly and without prejudice?
…Yeah. I'm the real boss... I was lucky Barley came along at the right time... let me cover my tracks 'n shift the blame 'n get off scot-free... The Bachelor never got my number...
What did you need it all for?
…For 'tis my soul's desire. This... killin' urge. It's just that… my hand was itchin'... for some jolly funtime...
That's not for you to judge! After all that I've found out...

A blow with a big blunt stick in a dark alley, that's nice and clean, it is, especially when it's not from behind... with a knife, there's even a bit of gallantry in it... especially when it's not your own knife... What do we look like on the inside? Eh? Whadyathink? No one wants to drag that out in the open... that would be scary, heh heh... that would be givin' away the secret...
What secret?
Look, here I am, standing in front of you, flesh and blood. See a stamped paper? Thought not.
Now tell me about the Olgimskys. Have they been protecting your shady business?
Fat Vlad's the real man, 'tis he who's runnin' the market... The young one's clueless... It was he that ordered the black twyrine too... his own doin'...
And the final question, Grief. Where exactly did you dump the bodies into the river?

...That wasn't us... I know, I know the whole chant with them stiffs... but that was the Worms from the Termitary, 'n I got the blame... I know nothin'... 'tis not my scope of murder, not my style, I swear to God... poisonin' all the water, that's just... gruesome...
All right. Tell me, was Olgimsky acting in collusion with you?
I don't believe in magic, Grief. I can't be affected by it. Something's wrong here...

It depends. Which one? There's more than one Olgimsky, you know! Heh heh... One might have, and the other one might not have. That's why you can't bring them down. One hand takes and the other gives... The right hand floggeth whom the left hand caresseth... Heh heh heh... There's your answer.
Grief, were you aware of the coming epidemic?
I don't get it…

Well, we did figure it out... Eventually. You see, black twyrine had been used as medicine during the first outbreak—and this time around the trade got really hectic 'n all... But those who'd ordered it must have known, probably as far back as summer... Heh heh...
And... who had ordered it?
You know the answer. Who were you just askin' about?
The elder or the younger?
I don't know…

Like you ever would, lil' pimple. That's it. 'Nough questions. Gonna grab some rest now. I'm really tired... You go away, nothin' for you to see here anymore... What, you liked my answers, didncha? Oh you tot… Heh heh...
Ugh! You'll regret this, Grief!
I'll ask you more questions later... and the way I'll ask them, you won't be able to dodge the answers anymore…
That's it, question time's over. Two Olgimskys for the price of one was already stretchin' it. Heh heh heh...
Wait a minute! There's something I don't understand…
You're a cruel monster, a ghoul! Any Ripper is a lamb compared to you!
...I am you... so go easy on the righteous fuss, will you? You and I are very similar... our paths have crossed for a reason...
Were you selling your black twyrine yourself?
...So that's why Saburov didn't want to arrest you at once.
...He's lyin'. 'Tis not Olgimsky he's afraid of, it isn't... Think bigger...
That's right, you're one of Simon's Bound! But... why?
I think I've sensed it...
Being my friend is dangerous, Notkin. Take your time and get a closer look at me.
What had the people you threw into the river died of?
Don't you dare mention God, you scum!
What?

Simon liked me... Or am I not one of your Bound anymore? Forgotten, have you? Ain't you a forgetful lil' tot… Like being dead can stop Simon from prohibiting things... from tellin' you what to do and what not to...
What? Who said that?
That's what I'm asking.

Hell knows... Violence has always been their thing. But cutting people up with knives and razors... that's neither his style nor his level of courage. I don't think he'd allow that. He may be a vicious bastard, but he has his limits. No stabbing and slicing, period. Everyone feels this way.
But somebody is stabbing and slicing…
Saburov.
You know, we too can beat a bloke silly. But knives are taboo. Whoever uses one is less than human; a cancerous growth! Grief is not like that.
All right, you've convinced me. But do you think he might have caused the epidemic?
Little-known, you say? How do you know it then?

We know everything—we're close by and have a nose for these things! That's what he hates us for, that bloody Filin! So this black twyrine, it's kind of sinister. Why are they so hush-hush about it? It's not like twyrine trade hasn't been around for a while. The whole town knows. And now there's this...
Is Filin his last name?
Grigory Filin, that's what he's called. It was shortened to Grief eventually, and "Bad Grief" is his own invention. To sound bigger than he is, I guess.
I see…
Black twyrine! Do you think the disease has been spreading through it?
I don't know, father... How could I know? I'm no scientist…
Come closer, my daughter. Tell me—advise me—what measures must be taken to stop the epidemic? Where do we send our brave patrolmen and the Executor suicide squads?
That's not for me to decide, father! My advice would be of little use here.
There is nothing wrong with your saying this. I am thinking aloud, and I would like to know whether the harbinger agrees with me. For there is someone else speaking through your lips—is there not?
Yes. There is.

That is my job to do. Do not worry about that. To be the ruler during a plague is a cursed part to play and a grievous burden: a man doomed to nothing but error. Yes, all of those measures are just a way to comfort ourselves. My only hope is you. I hope you have not allowed despair to take over you yet. Do I need to restate my request?
It's not contagious.. One falls ill when one's time comes, and it notices him... It is then that the disease aims its jagged spear at a man.
All of these measures mean nothing. Send some of them to the Cathedral, and some to the cemetery, shovels in hand. That would be my advice.

Five years ago, the Sand Plague broke out in the poor districts where, due to our negligence, the social and sanitary conditions had become truly appalling. If, like the plague, it is spread by blood-sucking fleas and their host animals, perhaps a culling of bulls and other domestic animals would be the best solution?
Why cull bulls? Bulls don't get fleas; they aren't a threat.

I will tell you what I'm going to do. Don't say a word to anyone about the plague! I refuse to allow a panic, and so I will ban all expressions of mourning. Let them celebrate instead. To the Bachelor, I have recommended that he reassure sick people, saying they have been afflicted with a "general condition"
As you wish.
Rats—that's who you ought to exterminate without mercy! There should be a reward for every rat killed.

Let no one talk about the Sand Plague for as long as possible. Now if anyone attempts to escape and is heard saying that the disease is incurable and a pair of boots is the best medicine, that person must be taken into custody. Is that something you would endorse?
You're looking for the cause in the wrong place.
There's already talk of the Sand Plague at every street corner. Aren't these measures coming a little late?
Yes. I would. But do you really think this will be enough?
I had the same impression.
Was it her? The shabnak-adyr?

Ah, I don't know... it just looked somehow... off. Just like the kind of creature that the Earth would make. The Earth doesn't know what we really look like... It can't create a woman that no one would tell apart from a real living one... can it? I, too, used to think it was a girl with a pair of sharp bones for legs...
What made you think it was miserable?
Its face... And just everything about it. It wants to speak to you. It pleads for protection from some danger.

Ah, if only this were the real shabnak-adyr! That would put an end to the meaningless lie about me having a sister! I could finally become myself again and live peacefully! So you're saying it's not dangerous?
Why are you shivering, Grace dear? You're not one to be afraid of the dead. Why would you be frightened by some bones?
All of my dead were once alive. They may be dead, but they're human... And this, the thing that came to me—it's impossible. It's a real…
A real what?
Could it be a trap? Perhaps this demon seeks to punish me for the things I've done for my new family.
Have you talked to it?

No, I haven't. I was terribly frightened... And I don't think it spoke either... but when I listened closer I realized that the strange humming in my ears was a voice muttering from somewhere... as if from under the ground, in fact. I couldn't make out the words, but somehow I understood...
Understood what?
...So my father has failed... Why is everything my father does always so pointless?
No. I don't. Who am I?
Of course I know. I am Clara, a thief, and possibly God's chosen one. There's no other explanation for the miracles I've performed.
…Are you the shabnak-adyr?
No... Who says "shabnak-adyr"? You're saying it wrong... you have to say "shabnak-adyg"—there's less evil this way.
You haven't answered my question.
I was made from your leftovers... I was made for you... I am you... I exist so you could see things clearer…
Are you making fun of me?
Tell me... is it true that I'm the plague-spreader?
The cemetery caretaker's daughter said you were in danger. Why?
Because you are in danger…
What's the danger?
All right. I'll do everything…
Lies—lies are the true infection devouring everything around! I understand that now...
...Do you understand now why everything hinges on you? Remember what I've told you...
No. I still don't understand…
I do.
Farewell... funny man…
No matter what I've undertaken lately, my senses keep failing me! It's as if I were replaced by a double... why?
…What? You're asking me?
No... Of course not. I was just thinking aloud.
What, you've been convicted?
Quit it. I'm telling you, I want to be alone. And you're the last person I'd like to see.
All right. I'll leave in a moment.
*** Curse the Bachelor! Every time I see him I break out in a cold sweat!
*** Beyond doubt, they are trying to seduce me. Who knows what would happen if I were to give way to this temptation.

"...Bring this Сhangeling to me without delay. Her case must be investigated immediately and she must be court-martialled. If she attempts to escape or use some psychophysical trick—do not hesitate to shoot her."
"...also... be sure to make all the necessary arrangements to affect death by hanging..."
A. Lilich, Inq.
The Inquisitor's Order

"...You must watch the Сhangeling as carefully as you did yesterday. Let her blame herself if she fails to appear at my request. You know what you should do if she tries to play the same "imaginary twin sister" card."
An Instruction Issued by the Inquisitor

Can you feel where this is going? It's not like I insist—if you really find it all that repulsive, you're free not to come. I can appreciate your choice, because I can relate. Still, the offer is standing. It's up to you… no matter how painful it is for me to accept. I find solace in the fact that I can end the previous sentence with "for now."
A. Lilich, inq
The Inquisitor's Note

This Aglaya Lilich has installed some kind of a tyranny in the town. She failed to carry out the task she was entrusted with. She gave shelter to both of the demons. She has appropriated the fruit of someone else's labour and travestied someone else's accomplishments. As if this is not enough, she acts as if she were a conqueror standing atop the ruins of the enemy town! This has to be stopped.
You should approach her directly and demand an answer—just like she demanded an answer from you. Try it, Clara, don't be afraid... Who knows what may come of this?
Your Benefactors
The Powers That Be, Regarding Aglaya Lilich
And where is he? The Haruspex? I wish I could talk to him…
He's here at the Termitary. I'm looking for him myself... because of a different matter, though. Could it be the folks here who supplied him with that blood? What do you think?
Anything is possible... Ask him.
But what does Rubin have to do with it?

Have you seen the Bachelor? We expected him to come here but we probably missed each other... He's the one that talked to Rubin; I haven't seen him for five days... I wasn't sure he was even alive. Georgiy wanted to off him.
Georgiy has pardoned him.
I'll look for the Bachelor.
For what?

We assumed responsibility for the town at an inopportune time... We'll see. Perhaps the Inquisitor will handle it better... Meanwhile, think about ways to reach a compromise with him... Maybe you'll be able to explain to him that our intentions have been entirely good.
I'll try.
I don't think I'll manage to do that.
So this man... is he alive and well?
They thanked you. Called you a benefactor.
Alive today, gone tomorrow... You'll run out of those flasks before you know it.
You're the evil spirit! You may look human, but I know what you really are—a demon! A possessed demon! You're being controlled by something different, from the other side! Goodbye.
*** This is not the right way to talk to them! I was confused! Mistakes were made...
What makes you think I do?
You're similar. You both live for the sake of the dead... Or am I wrong?
You're both kind souls, almost blessed fools... just like me, I suppose. I sense people who are like that.
You're probably right... But if you're so sharp and observant, why don't you talk to Grace herself?

Why would you put it like that? A "kind soul" is not the same as a kind person... You're crafty after all! You seem to say perfectly good things—but they're actually quite backhanded. You've probably got something like that in store for Grace too... don't you?
I'd feel rather awkward…
I barely know Grace; we haven't spoken a lot. Do you want to make friends with her?
Sorry! I'm sorry! My words often come out crippled. I'm bad at expressing how I feel.
Of course I do!
Katerina is a friend of hers... She needs to know.
Lara, you're not listening to me at all.
*** It didn't work out... I am too short-tempered for my own good! Why, oh why did I have to say this?
*** There you have it. Whatever happens, human lives must not be sacrificed for the common well-being!
*** I am unable to speak to the old man properly. He plays his words so deftly that I can't escape the feeling I am being led into a trap.

Yes, I too think that this is terribly sad... Have I told you I used to be afraid of it? I thought it was the Albino who had brought the Sand Plague to us. The shabnak-adyr... It's certainly made of clay, sticks, and ground bone. There's no doubt about that.
But now it's clear that there's nothing to be afraid of... is there?
So why do you trust it?
There's no wickedness in it. Or anything else. It's hollow, like that skull on a fence. Is it true that it came for you?
It is. Which is why I must talk to it. How could we arrange that? The Bachelor didn't shoot it dead, did he?
I don't know. I have no desire to meet it! One doppelganger is quite enough!
How do you know its route?
I know everything that has to do with the unliving—and it's not of the living. When the unliving are offended, they always leave by that path... Into the Steppe. Forever.
Poor Albino! Well, perhaps I'll still manage to meet it...
Don't act surprised!
Impossible! I warned them not to kill anyone but Earthkin, the butchers and the Worms enslaved by the wicked Haruspex!
They did mean to, Maria... but I beat them to the punch.
Yes, Maria, I'm afraid... How is a feeble child like me to take on a demon? For I know he is a demon. Obsession equals possession.

That cannot be... Fear is not your kind of emotion; or else what good of a Mistress are you? In any case, I will repay you; there will be rewards. Unless perhaps you would prefer doing me the occasional small favour to strengthen our soon-to-be... bond.
Maria, oh Maria... Nothing will bond me to you, nothing ever.
No... I just wanted to tell you that—I'm going. I'm going to go and do your bidding, you see? Which makes you the one who ought to be afraid.
A petty rat who thinks itself a puppetmaster... I'll yet see a theatre purer than you're even capable of imagining!
*** Mistake! A bad mistake! For this kind of a creature, a name would mean much more than simple definition... Saying her name would have granted me the power to control her.
I'm not yet sure I'll want to accept that title.
Don't say that... father! And forgive me like I've forgiven you.

A Mistress is not a title. Once you have crossed a certain line, you become the person everything hinges upon. How you will use this gift is a different matter. But you are no longer in a position to refuse it. So what disposition are you going to make of our town?
Do you have any parting advice to give me?
I don't want to use that gift. I'm just leaving.
You are truly a saint... Or could my reason be so clouded with grief that I fail to hear the sarcasm in your voice? No, I wouldn't want to think so. Do you really want to hear a few behests from me?
Yes. I'll do what you weren't able to do, father. After all, the adverse fortunes that marred your brief tenure as a ruler were quite extraordinary…
...I was joking, of course. You'd probably be no better as an advisor than you were as a ruler.

Then I will be concise. First: find someone among the Kains or the Olgimskys on whom you could rely as on yourself. Let them preside over the Bull Project, let them send reports to the Сapital! Metropolitan bureaucrats are the greatest menace. They doze off when the freight trains arrive on schedule—but wake up the moment something goes wrong.
Why is that a threat for us?
Ha ha! So everything's been all right until now? I'm sure the bureaucrats still don't know a thing…

They will not let us build our life the way it was intended. The brittle magic of our community will be trampled underfoot. Our erstwhile blissful existence will be irrevocably gone. Everything will be completely different. New people will arrive, and the deadening power of the state will lay down its own Law here! Do not let that happen... as we didn't let it happen before.
Will I be able to do it?

You'll do fine! You'll devote yourself to other things; you'll be spinning your yarn... While your chosen regent must be cunning. He must learn to mislead them... to mask our distinctiveness... he must not let them redevelop the North-East Line any further east than the Gorkhon estuary... He must be cautious!
I understand, father. You're tired. You need some rest now.
I know what to do. Those who favour hard logic and direct action are bound to be misguided. But I can work miracles. And my hands are untied.
Poor thing, your eyes are all swollen... Have you been crying?
Look at me, Anna. You're afraid, aren't you?
Look at me, Clara! Why did I chance to cross your path? What do you think? Could it be so that I could sing an ode to fear and give you a vivid example of what that leads to?
Are bureaucrats that easy to mislead?

Of course, damn it! We've always been misleading them! Our great advantage is that they don't take us seriously. As far as they're concerned, we are a factory and a railway junction. Beyond that, they know nothing—see, even the Inquisitor hasn't learned everything.
Just like that? Really?
That one's a hopeless fool.

Of course! Should an inspector arrive, take them to the Town Hall at once. Say that the Abattoir is out of operation, and quarantine the Termitary—whatever is going on inside it. If they want to take a stroll around the town, take them to the Chine. And the Polyhedron? Tell him it's a temporary obelisk. A fairground attraction!
I don't know how to talk to bureaucrats…
That's not misleading at all. It's precisely that.
Why are you talking like that all of a sudden? What's the matter with you? Or is someone hiding behind that curtain over there?
Would you say that's why you've ended up among the wicked?

Of course it is. You've understood everything already... What does the Caravan have to do with it? A children's bogeyman, one of those silly stories they tell each other after dark... Maybe it never existed. Maybe I never was with the Caravan... Take a look at me; how could I possibly have been a singer?
So you're a liar too…

I am an embodiment of fear. I live in a world that's made of fear entirely. I may not have become a singer, but I've become the voice of Fear. And fear has an unpleasant voice... shrill, whiny, capricious, utterly unmusical…
So, if you're like that, why did our paths cross?

Probably to prevent you from becoming like me. A voice—an entrancing voice, sweet as a dream and beckoning, is what you and I have in common. Do you understand? That's where we intersect! Not the Caravan, not at all! Forget the Caravan!
I have already…
You, on the other hand, won't stop thinking about it! You're hiding something, Anna! You're still hiding something. What is this Caravan? How did it get here?
Ask the Powers That Be. You've paid them a visit already, haven't you? They'll tell you... what the plague is for and what the Caravan is for. It's their games!
Fair enough, fair enough... Which means it's not all that important in the end.
So... is it going to hurt a lot? When is my turn?
Would you like to be the first or the last?
I don't know. But I think not. A brief moment of pain, and then you'll attain the eternal life, dissolving in a multitude of hearts.

…Last. Or not—I suppose it's better to get it over with at once! No, wait... I'll tell you later, all right? Better still, just sneak in unnoticed sometime. Will you? Maybe it's better if we do it that way?
Maybe. I'll come after you forget about this.
Goodbye, Anna.
I don't want you to bow to me.
Not out of fear, I hope?

Out of love, lil' tot... Pure love, all white 'n crunchy like freshly starched linen 'n all... C'mon, think about it: who do I got to go fearin'? No one. For, as you've most correctly guessed, I ain't feared Barley too. 'N the fear, you'd ask? Just for show. Although I do fear myself, I suppose...
That's true. We have no one to fear except ourselves.
...Have you really changed so much? Then for this alone, these twelve days have been worth living.

Back then, y'see, you figured out the sheer scale of my nastiness, just how much of a villain I was, didntcha? And then you just froze in place—'n my heart sank 'n I thought, so much for ever being forgiven. That's a lil' tot that's gonna condemn me. But you didn't—you forgave me; and I was never the same again. I'd be happy to give my life for you now! I swear to God 'n my own accord!
Happy? Honestly?
Good. Your atonement will be your salvation. Wait for me to come for you.

You won't find a more faithful servant from now on, no ma'am! For I have repented. All my cutthroats would die for you too! What is your command, Mistress? My life for you! Me—becomin' like Simon—could I even have imagined...? But even the old man could never become someone like you.
Please! Stop talking like that!

Eh... Who are we when you come to think about it? What are we? A bunch of walking corpses, we are, condemned to death the moment we're born; a bunch of dolls in the hands of the powers that be. Eh? And you two, you're the real humans. But he, Simon, was a proud human, y'see? 'Twas for our sake that he'd made himself into what he was... And you, holy dove; you have surpassed him—for our sake as well.
Have I really? We don't know that yet.
Don't say things like that! It's the kind of talk that leads one astray.
Repent, repent... You've all still got time to see if your new sentiment is sincere.
You're making fun of me, right? That's not good. You shouldn't…
Do you have any... parting words for me? You're an observer of people—so what do your calculations indicate?

Wait. Give yourself a moment's pause. Are you sure you want to know what my research has yielded? You see.. whether or not you take my calculations seriously, the moment you learn the results you will have no choice but to act them out. This is merely my way of seeing the matter, though.... So, what do you say? Would you like to set off this trip-wire of mine?
I do. It won't do me any harm. In my humble opinion.
...Actually, you know what? No. I don't want to. You're right.

You remain an indefinite value. As such, you have walked the road that lies behind you. Your refusal to be categorised was your strongest weapon. However, this advantage will be stripped from you as soon as you permutate into a constant. And, frankly, I wouldn't be surprised if that happens before the day is over. What kind of a value you will become? That's the only actual choice you have.
I'm not Constance. I'm Clara.

This is of no importance. Don't try to translate your perplexity into a language that is legible to us. Cease this wordplay of yours. Didn't you see everyone disappear? You won't see anything but raw vectors now, lines along which your effort may be applied... Well, really...
Why did our paths cross, Yulia? Why are you one of the criminals and the wicked?

I don't qualify as wicked, but you can call me criminal... in a way. Just don't conflate the two. You see, I am of the opinion that it was your duty to end us. Didn't I just tell you, there are no people anymore? Symbols is all that we have left. We all represent opportunities that you have missed... the nine ways to get swallowed by the deathly quagmire.
I don't like you! I find you even worse than Grief!
What?
You should be grateful to me for having replaced you. Otherwise it would have been you—and not me—to rot in this desolate place I am consigned to. You would have been left hanging by your strings...
I'd have been glad to trade places with you. But I wasn't given the choice!
You wanted to rule over people's fates too... I understand.

Oh, but you were! Let me remind you how intrinsically evil people are. The very nature of you—is evil. You were given exactly as much choice as was necessary for you to affirm your malevolent selfhood. It is not too late yet. Let go of yourself and you will fall even lower than I have fallen... lower than any of us, the nine sinners, from which you will pick the righteous seven.
Enough. There's no evil in this world... and no need to be afraid anymore.
No. I'm pure and devoid of evil. I will make my own choice.
I see what you're getting at!
What's on your mind, Lara?
Rue not what is to come, for it is a blessing.
Oh... Nothing really... Tell me, how much life-giving blood will you be able to make from me? How many doses will it be?
No less than a hundred and fifty, I believe. And according to Rubin, anything up to five hundred.
I don't know, Lara. Time will tell. Isn't it the same to you?
Of course, of course... Even one would be quite enough. It's something to rejoice in.
Yes, to rejoice in.
Oh... that's a lot. Even in a lifetime of relentless activity, I could never have saved or... or created that many people.
Lara, Lara... Why you too? How did you of all people end up among the wicked?
You mean given birth to? I thought it wasn't something you wanted.
Self-sacrifice is something one must go about competently. I was incompetent.
That's just nonsense!
Simon failed too. That's why you're making the decisions and not him... Or are you him now?
Are you raving?
No one is more similar than you and Simon. Even we, the Bound, are mere playthings, while you are Humans. With a capital H. Such as I could never have given birth to even if I had got married.
Did you want to?

Sort of... Not really, but I'd often think about it at night. No point in hiding my sins anymore. But that was all a pipe dream. Go ahead, do what you must. Poor thing, I'm so sorry for you. I wouldn't want to carry your burden. Terrifying to bear, yet it would be wrong to refuse it.
Please, that's no sin at all! You deserve solace.
Yes. I'd gladly have taken your place. But I can't refuse to play my terrifying part anymore.
Even if you knelt before me, you'd still be towering over me.
And you, Foreman Oyun... Why have you crossed my path? It's no coincidence, I know.

I am a monster, Mistress. A chimera. You were right when you called such humanlike, double-natured beings demons. It is good that you'll destroy me with your magic hands. The evil I stand for will go down with me. It's unnatural to be double-natured.
…Your grandfather was a bull, wasn't he?

True. You can see yourself that my bloodline must be terminated. Evil channels through me, as it does through your counterparts. Someone dark had been stirring behind their backs before you came along and took charge. Now that dark soul is no longer with them, and you ought to drive them out. Don't let them loose.
Have no fear, I won't.
We'll see... Something's wrong here, I can feel it.
That was a quick and easy surrender... for someone so strong!

I've always known I would bow down to no man. Yes, everything points to this being her at whose hands I shall be dealt my doom. Small. Frail. Young... This is what a true Mistress of the Earth looks like.
That's good. It's good that meeting me has curbed your pride.
I haven't accepted the title yet.
For as long as you're alive, you'll remain the Mistress. It's I who bow to you.
Don't talk like that, mother—as if I were a stranger to you.

Heed my final advice, dear daughter... Be smart. Don't repeat my mistakes! You will not be alone here. Maria is ascending to the fullness of her powers—right now, at the same time as you—whilst Capella, the tardy one, will take a few more years to awaken. Do you understand what this means?
No, not quite... What?
Maria will not awaken. And Capella... I don't think she will either.

A period of your antagonism with Maria is beginning. Along what lines will it be? Which of you will be the good one, and which one wicked? Will it be up to the Kains once again to determine the meaning of good and evil? How are you to take the good path if Maria doesn't choose the evil one...?
Why divide everything into good and evil right away? Could that have been your mistake? Our mistake…

That was what I thought—when I chose my own dark path... I thought the conflict was not between good and evil, that neither good nor evil existed... That wasn't true! For it is in the nature of humans to translate even a dichotomy of red and green into the language of good battling evil. We are doomed to make choices...
But did you really choose evil?
