No, mother... That's not what the ongoing battle is about. Trust me, good and evil do not and will not exist today... Even if the town is laid waste to!

I now think I did... Nina could control it at the time... and I couldn't. Nor was Nina wearing the black tiara... But don't put your trust in what is more alluring, more attractive! That is usually where evil lies!
And yet I'd still like to ask about my sister... Did she exist—or didn't she? Back then... a week ago?
I'll follow your advice, mother.
What kind of an answer would you like me to give?
A truthful one.
I'd like to know which one of us you loved more... you know?
You, daughter... You.
Goodbye, mother.
I know... A Mistress cannot lie.
She didn't, daughter. We had you and you only. You showed up many times, and were different each time...
Goodbye, mother.
I know... A Mistress cannot lie.
Well... sister. It's time to say our farewells.
You're the only one I don't feel sorry for. You're a thing. "A thing that comes in the dark..."
So it is... Can't say I'm not glad.
Why? Everybody's glad to see me.
What could possibly make me glad to see you? You're my more successful rival. You have become what I couldn't... I'm jealous of you.
There's nothing to be jealous about, silly! I've gone from a saint to a priestess of blood—a miraculous meat-grinder!

Oh yes! I wanted it to be me—me striding across the town in triumph; me going from house to house, carrying death on my black wings; me choosing who deserves retribution... An enviable role, that. But look at what I've become instead—a slave to the Kin, a household familiar, a keeper of relics.
Tell me, would you like to trade places with me?
That's not true! I'm not like that! I chose a different fate for myself...
Come on! What's done is done. It's not like one could choose one's fate retroactively, or change that part of it which has already been fulfilled...
One could. I can. That's what these things called miracles are about.
You'll never understand that. That's why you are a mere thing, Aspity.
Isn't it something to be proud of?
I was saving the seat of power for a worthy successor—but I couldn't save that successor's subjects. You've killed them!
I've saved who I could. And I will save even more!
Tell me, what's it going to be like—when, you know, the time comes?
Why talk like that? You've helped me. Who would I be without you?
Do you want the exact details?
I'm going to have to settle down here, aren't I?
Block is inviting you to come along. He'd like to take you away with his army, right?
That's not the issue…
Let's get straight to the point. How many years will one person last us?

But you can be in both places at once, can't you? Such is your nature. You'll stay here with us forever, and at the same time, you'll go to war... alongside Block and his army. Your nature could easily allow there to be two of you.
Don't bring that up again! I'm not the plague!
You're talking about spiritual grace, right? Whereas I'm talking about myself.

Well then... This is how I see it. We will be vigilant at all times. As soon as there's a new outbreak somewhere, we will board up that house at once—or that district, if need be; thankfully it can be done, given the peculiar town planning here... My master did that five years ago. You will immediately pick someone from among your Bound and—
What if they refuse to become a donor?
I wasn't referring to that.
What, then? What's your take on all this?
They won't. Once they've given consent, they'll stay true to their word. Or else our being Bound would amount to nothing.
So you think all I have to do is just lay my hands on them once, and it will be done?
How long will one person last us?
I don't know... Possibly forever. It's said that the town's survival hinges on the seven righteous ones. You said yourself that seven would be enough.
So you think all I have to do is just lay my hands on them once, and it will be done?
I don't think once will be enough. And you'll have to do it in public, to avoid rumours and speculations. At any rate, I'll make the extracts and see what happens. We'll try this and that.
Ugh! That sounds a bit too... mechanical, for lack of a better word…
All right, Stakh. I've understood your plan. You're going to have to be the last in that chain.
Your role in this is a mechanical one. Ask the masked Executors. They're already excitedly sharing details with each other.
What's that supposed to mean? My "role"? What role?
I'd like to avoid that. Miracles and mechanics don't mix very well, do they?
I don't know. That's up to you.
Yes, it's up to me... And that points my thoughts in a certain direction…
...So we've gone full circle?
So that was the easiest option?

Yes, it was perhaps... the simplest solution. And the most emotional one, behind its veneer of calculation. Three deceptions, one after another... gradual disillusionment, bitterness, a desire to retaliate against the oppressors... predictable obstinacry and a contrarian decision.
Does he at least have a chance to defeat you?
Depends on what he's understood, doesn't it? Surely you two have had a conversation aready. How profoundly has he been enlightened, this sophisticated gentleman?
'He seems to have found a way into the Focus and realized he was a toy.
I don't know.
Then ask. He's at his usual place.
All right. I'll ask. And then I'll make you sorry for abusing the rules.

Ah... I see. He should better bring somebody else to the Cathedral then. As I've already said: his trajectory is so designed as to make it difficult for him to abandon his arrangement. Except by a lapse of judgement—but we're not concerned with that.
Indeed? And why the hell are you planning beforehand which decision will be free and which won't be? There's no escaping from this loop! So long as you're here, this will last forever.

That's why we initially planned pure destruction for our dearest Changeling. Which would obviously include our own destruction... You know all this philosophical stuff, don't you? The truth as liberation... ephemeral things... the wheel of rebirth…
Nonsense. I don't believe in that.
That's fairly well-advised…
That's nice to hear.
So what am I supposed to do?
We surmise that this paradox can be resolved... but that's just a hypothesis. Hint: in your case only, out of the three. Why?
I'll soon find the answer to this question.
Go to hell…
So it was a kind of loop?

Yes. The purest version of one, it seems. Two diverging pairs of decisions. Both pre-determined, but the dilemma is a harsh one indeed. That made the freedom all the more salient. And then, you see, there were also feelings involved... Love.
Does he at least have a chance to defeat you?
Depends on what he's understood, doesn't it? Surely you two have had a conversation aready. How profoundly has he been enlightened, this great intuiter of things?
He doesn't seem to have understood anything at all. Perhaps he doesn't even care. He thinks himself a hero.
Ah... I see. Then it would be better if he waived the choice altogether. That would at least be unexpected. Seems daft, doesn't it? But it's not that simple... The Haruspex is a man of action, and—
Indeed? And why the hell are you planning beforehand which decision will be free and which won't be? There's no escaping from this loop! So long as you're here, this will last forever.

That's why we initially planned pure destruction for our dearest Changeling. Which would obviously include our own destruction... You know all this philosophical stuff, don't you? The truth as liberation... ephemeral things... the wheel of rebirth…
Nonsense. I don't believe in that.
That's nice to hear.
So what am I supposed to do?
We surmise that this paradox can be resolved... but that's just a hypothesis. Hint: in your case only, out of the three. Why?
I'll soon find the answer to this question.
Go to hell…
That's fairly well-advised…
I don't know.
Then ask. He's at his usual place.
All right. I'll ask. And then I'll make you sorry for abusing the rules.
Of a surrogate kind, right?
Love can't be surrogate. It's either there or it isn't.
Don't try to be smart here. I'm the expert in love, not you…
Well, no one's taking that gift away from our dearest Clara...
I'd still like a hint. If this is the situation with my invariant, then how am I different?
Now then, what have you understood, sweetie?
It's all been clear to me for quite a while. I know there's no one here except me and you, and that you left this place a long time ago. That which is talking to me is your pitiful residue.
Whoa. Since then have we been on such familiar terms?
We were talking to the Changeling. Ignore that. We're assuming you couldn't possibly have asked such a question.
Why, what if I did?
Ah... Point taken.
Come now… What makes you say that? We have after all kept ourselves a function and not a constant…
Don't try to be smart. I don't understand such words.
Still the Changeling? That deeply immersed in the character...?
I was joking.
I'm waiting for more.
Speak to my colleague. He's your invariant. Yours, not the Changeling's.
I want to know what kind of a miracle I can perform myself! You swear it's genuine, right?
...Shall we tell you? Brace yourself! We're going to actually tell you!
Yes, tell me.
Stop! Don't. Anything but that.
Go ahead and tell me you didn't plan anything at all for me. Scumbags…

Well... initially, we were going to rest content with just the destruction, but then we quickly slapped together a different ending... which had this sacrificial miracle in it. On the whole, though, we didn't really plan anything, to be honest. There just wasn't enough time to think it through.
...You guessed?
I guessed.
No. What did you have in store for me? What's my ending?
Fantastic. Now be quiet, I know where I'm going next.
So is the plague an evil or a blessing?
Oh, that's up to you to decide.
Or was I that blessed divine messenger precisely when I was spreading the plague with my hands? Was I doing His will?
Whose will? That's the principal question. I'm still losing the thread and don't know who I'm talking to.
Can a miracle be performed under such conditions?
And why are you still here? Have you been left behind or something?
Why are you here? Go away... I'm scared! You're scary.
Scared? Why are you scared, little girl? What did you say your name was?
I've come to play with you a little before I go…
Oh... Thrush.
Is it derived from "thrust", as in into the ground, or "crush", as in in the process?
Hey! Don't say that… it's scary!They took the coffin this morning and drove away with it! It's not coming back! Ever! No one is going to thrust anything anywhere!
Thrush... See, that's a very fitting name. Did you make it up for the game?
Uh-huh... So that I don't catch the disease.
So you're afraid of a play-disease? How could you possibly catch it?
Anything can happen... One doesn't trifle with such things, you know. Sometimes it's all fun and games till it happens for real. That's what I keep telling Measly but he wouldn't listen...
Ah, so we're being sensitive now... If you're afraid of a coffin, why play a game like this? Well, whatever; I don't suppose there's a point in talking to you…
I want to go home! Let me go, I want to go home!
How old are you, child?
I don't know... Not old. And you may be a great big dummy but we're still the same height!
It's because I'm hunkering. That's why we're the same height. See?
Want to know who's the great big dummy here? Look in the mirror.
So you're back from a funeral... By the way, you can tell me who it is you've lost.
You don't have to wait long, little toy. Hang in there, I'll release you soon.
Well, he's picked himself quite a witching name too.
Just in case!
How old are you, child?
Well, you know... just to see if you say anything interesting. But now I see you're just playing around in here.
No, little boy... I'm not Clara.

A high flying bird you've become.
The Executors are watching you, barely able to hide a smile... and I don't like their smirks one bit. Soon enough you are going to see that they were not smiling because they were happy for you.
Beware, if you may, we were both trapped. Each one of us has suffered a tailor-made deception. They say you are not like me, and this is not something I would argue with. Moreover, I've just found out something utterly ridiculous about myself. Hopefully, your fate will not be a reiteration of my own.
Be very careful, anyway. Self-assurance is your worst enemy. I've learned of at least one way to achieve victory. Perhaps it may work well enough for you.
Come see me if you will. Give me the benefit of doubt, so to speak.
D. D. D.
The Bachelor says Goodbye
What do you want?
Well, enough idle blather. Since you've already turned up and made a farce out of this Council, decide quickly, and let's be done with it. We're not going to hear anything worthwhile here.
What, are you jealous? You do realize you're not the centre of the universe, I hope?
Yes... I don't like ceremony and circumlocution either.
That was gruff... Well, it is the twelfth day... Don't you want to tell me something?
No.
This is embarrassing. Why aren't you directing the conversation anymore? Dominating it?
What would be the point? You're not part of my plans.
Just wanted to have a final talk with you... Before the Council begins. To extend a hand, if you like.
Please explain. You've found room for everyone in your plans, but not me?

Something like that. Both the Bachelor and the Haruspex are of this world, and you aren't. You're a foreign body, a demon pretending to be human. They're people of the same flesh and blood as myself; you're a thing that comes in the dark. They aren't demons. You are.
So you've placed your bets on these two? Perhaps both at once?
...Those aren't words to be thrown around lightly. How will you prove it?
So what now Inquisitor? Are you going to burn me at the stake? Will you even be able to?
I won't... I'm no longer able to do anything at this point.
Which part is unclear to you?
I'd like to hear your advice. Who knows, maybe I'll follow it.
Any final behests, maybe? How am I to act? How do I win? Maybe I'll heed you, who knows…
I've already told you. Step aside. Get out of this world. That's the best solution for you.
Why do you detest me so much?

You've joined forces with the Commander. I can predict the consequences of your alliance. You being a fanatic and visionary—moreover, in the guise of a prophetess possessed by the Holy Spirit—he'll certainly acquiesce to you and will end up completely under your control.
Are you saying this on purpose to make me strengthen that alliance just to spite you?
The Commander is the lowliest of you all. Not just a puppet but a double puppet. Or a triple one. That's why I can relate to him so well.
No. And I'd generally advise you against calculations like these. I'll always be a step ahead of you there.
Could be, could be... All right, goodbye. See you at the Council.
Sorry to say we probably aren't going to reconcile our differences.
What sort of an impudent hint was that?
It wasn't. I didn't quite mean to say it.
He who has ears, let him hear.
That something is more of a someone, I suppose?
No it isn't. I meant exactly what I said.
Ah, the arrogance. And here I hoped you'd have the inner strength to love them as thyself.
I feel nothing but loathing towards myself too.
Yes, certainly. Thank you.
Not nine but seven, to be exact. Nine were invited, seven were chosen. Nine sinners, seven transformed.
Not much of a relief, that. Everyone else gets decent confidants, and I…
Sinners? Them? What are you talking about!
No, no. I do love them... I feel sorry for them.
Still, rules are rules. You won't get around this law no matter how hard you try. Not that you need this kind of petty self-assertion in the first place.
All right. I'll be back soon.
Why not? If I can defeat the Law, it means the Law has no power over me—right?

Let's not get mired in theorizing. That would be inane. I could tell you that some forces cannot be defeated without yielding to them first... but let's skip the poetry. You're not going to sway me. The town shall not be spared but for the sake of seven righteous people.
That's hypocrisy, plain and simple.
Why, isn't it seven already?
No. Not yet. You can take a nap across the street for now. The Crucible is no longer a threat to you. Perhaps you'll even dream of something unusual...
I don't think so. Admit it, you'd be glad if I overslept and missed the Council, wouldn't you?
I don't feel like it for some reason.
What does it matter? Do whatever you please; it's not like it will change anything. Go ahead and oversleep. Or die in your sleep as a parting gesture. It's all up to you now.
Are you trying to flatter me?
*** Let her remain inside! Hopefully, she won't be going anywhere now... I wonder what those who remain faithful to her cause would say...
I want to get inside right now. But you're not going to let me in, right?
You buffoon... It's not like I have other options! I'll have to—sooner or later.
They can, they very much can... In your case, if I'm not mistaken, everyone can make it through. This is one of the brighter aspects of your great mission. A pleasant bonus, if you will.
What about Eva though? And the Olgimskys...?
Do you think this is funny?
Yes, Eva, the Olgimskys, the Foreman of the Abattoir, all of them. But be quick. There's a reason you've come here, isn't there? You wanted to talk?
Yes, I was going to ask a few questions. All right, I'll try to save everyone. It seems I'm destined for this… being the saviour of assorted nobodies.
In fact I just wanted to say how deeply disappointed I am... if not to say disgusted. I suppose you'll eventually pass it on to those on the inside.
Eventual passing-on is always a certainty.
That came out sinister. I could do without being reminded.
Thank you.
Then wait a little more.
We can wait, but time won't. It's the only thing that's truly out of our control. That was a hint, by the way.
Thank you. I'll ponder over it on my way.
Granddad... Our dear Granddad has died!
I'm sorry.
Your grandfather hasn't died. He's merely moved on to the afterlife. Don't cry.
I was imagining something more horrible.
Of course it isn't. Don't cry.
What kind of a question is that?
Uh-oh... You're not going to... hurt us, are you? I just asked because I was curious…
There, there. Why would I hurt sad little things like you…
Not anymore. I've changed. Now I'm a real miracle-worker.
Then we've got to go home too. Was this a good game? What do you think?
Passable…
Horrible! Your game is simply atrocious.
Actually, it wasn't your game, kid.

If you like, you can ask us questions and we'll answer. The ones who were here before you here loved asking us questions! And we didn't mind. We'll give great answers, explaining everything and all. Look, this here, with the holed pebbles, is the Abattoir. And that over there—can you imagine?—is the Polyhedron!
You know what—how about you told me instead who your favourites are?
That's cute. Do you even realize that you're in there, on the inside?

Favourites? Mine is this, you know, this—Foreman! The great big one! That's who I like the most. The Haruspex is all right too... I always want to know which of them wins the fight in the end. And Thrush loves Lara, that doll over there...
Why?
No, I was asking about us, the protagonists.
Do you want me to tell you honestly or dishonestly?
Honestly.
Well... we don't particularly like you. You're weird. The Bachelor, that one's all right. Except it's a shame he's got that suitcase completely attached to him. I wonder if I should tear it off.
Don't. He won't be able to do his work then.
Pity you don't like me... Eh well, I can't make you.
Dishonestly.
Then—you, of course!
You're funny, Measly. Now, off you go home.
I don't get it either. She just does.
Are you even capable of love?
Go home, kids. There's nothing for you to do here anymore. The game is over.
Yes, we are. And you?
Of course.
No. I'm not.
I don't know.
So you're leaving the decision to me?
Yes. I am. Why would I have brought you here otherwise?
But what's the point? Do tell me. And be careful! A lot will depend on your answer.
The point is that in this case, the winner will be—
…Love, right?
...No. Mere humanity. Any kind of it—even malicious, and yet still a living one. We win and you lose here, you see?
You're wrong. Go, there's your Eva, crying by the railing. You'll be the only one who sees her.
A good answer. Thank you.
You know, I really couldn't care less. As far as I'm concerned, you understand less about sacrificial victims than the Bachelor does about mirror towers.
You've disappointed me, Haruspex. I didn't expect such pettiness from you.
All right. Let's not argue in here. Will you let me decide?
I will. I like your decision.
You know, I've seen all of this already! So what's the difference? Nothing's changed!

If you really think so, step aside. Let me make the decision. If you don't understand anything, then mine and the Bachelor's decisions are inherently better than yours. And mine is, of course, better than the Bachelor's.
Why so?
There's more feeling in it.
No. Not more. Just as much, or as little.
It's because your confidants are children. I wish mine were like that...
Yes. And so, hopefully, will I.
Farewell, my general. This is truly the end. Our time is up.
Don't worry, my general. I know how much you value clarity.
What if I said no?
I've made up my own mind. If your answer is no, I'll find a way to reconcile myself with that. Perhaps after a while I'll realize what I don't realize now.
Now you've surprised me too. Imagine that! I was almost thinking—
No. I know all that already.
So be it then.
And you're aware of how it's going to be implemented?
I don't need to be. Because I trust you.
So shall it be then.
Make your own choice, Commander. You are free.
You're intending to go back to the frontline, aren't you?
I've trusted you... and I'm not going back on that trust.
Nothing.
Would you like to talk to the Haruspex?
No. I don't. I'll do as you say, and I need no one else's advice. Do you definitely believe that this is what must be done?
What are you talking about?
Will you leave this place with me?
Of course! Where am I to be now if not on the battlefield.
No, my general. I will have to remain here forever. Otherwise, how am I to transform my Bound?
Exactly. I'm glad you feel the same way as I do. You will help me take power in the country. My army will be at your disposal. Make us a tool in His spear-hand.

I'm not asking you to think it over—such decisions are better left to the heart. Instead of nursing a single town for the remainder of your days, you could turn the entire country to the true faith. Our entire star-crossed, long-suffering land.
No, no... I'm not up to a task like this! How could I ever be?

Who is up to it if not you? Who will do away with the unjust rulers? Who will stop the war? Who will put an end to the suffering of the poor? The moment is right. It is at times like these, ridden with strife and turmoil, with no end to adversity in sight, that true power breaks free. My regiments can turn the tide. And I will not allow a lawless tyranny!
O, how mistaken you are!
True... You must be right...
Your virtue will vouch for this!
Don't tempt me, my general. This path is not for me.
How can you not understand... You're living a dream. All of this is a mere haze. You came out of thin air and you'll pass into nothingness.
Yes... You have a firm hand.
Is that what you think?
I feel I must do what must be done here. If it is necessary that we are rejoined, we will be when the time is ripe.
To me, you look like a body with its soul taken out. A thing that looks and acts human—but isn't!
And in the meantime, I've realized what my mission is…
Yes, do tell me, please, it's very interesting. How did you wriggle out of that trap?
I didn't. I'm a hero. Better to be a trapped hero than a free cripple, isn't it?
The town will suffer…
The town is an instrument. It was made for humans, not the other way round.
But you're not human!
You're forgetting about freedom. All that's happening here is happening for your freedom's sake. Do you understand?
I must admit I'm a bit confused—but it was for the better. It allowed me to escape the iron grip of my preordainment. I'm content with being able to choose with my heart.
The creators of this dilemma had limited your choice to two options…
I'm content with as much regardless. If you give me a chance to choose, you can be sure I'll choose the most humane solution. The most human one.
Oh really? The Bachelor at least figured out he was a puppet.

I'm not a toy, Changeling. I am Artemy Burakh, a Haruspex who knows the lines, a Warden who has fulfilled his mission and reconciled his father's spirit with the Earth, and has made the correct choice. That's who I am. Do you understand?
Are you at least aware that you're a mere toy?
And I'm not a puppet. Must be because I never figured it out... What else do you plan on surprising me with?
Do you really not care?
So you're a believer in salvation through ignorance?

No. I don't. But you do seem to have got it mixed up. You think, don't you, that what happened here was all on your account? Yes, you're confused... But then allow me to take charge. Tell the Commander. He listens to you with rapt attention. He wouldn't even bother listening to me.
You can be persuasive... Perhaps you are right after all…
No, Haruspex. That's not going to happen.
Who, you? But you are nothing!
What makes you think so? I'm as human as they come, and no amount of your insults will change that.
Wait... I think I'm beginning to understand you... And now... yes, now I see that you're closer to victory than me…
You're a demon!
Why?
Because your nature is different. You're a golem without a soul—or more exactly, with a borrowed soul!

That's where you're wrong. If nothing else, I'm definitely not lacking in the immortal soul department. Rather, it's my soul that some people wouldn't stop trying to borrow, as they seek to control me. Try telling them to their faces about their demonic nature...
You're wise! So you do know how to win? Aglaya was right…
That last part sounded oddly covetous.
Could be... I'm not the one without sin here. That would be you.
That's no laughing matter. You wouldn't understand anyway...
I'm more than a plaything, Bachelor.
Of course not... For the town's sake.
There are no bachelors and no towns here, blind man! There's just you and I. And you are my past. Meaning that, technically, there's just me and I.
Then the I that's me is the better one.
No way, Bachelor.
As if anything could be apparent to you! You're a bodily frame devoid of soul and will; you're not capable of understanding a thing at this point.
Self-denial is the meaning here, silly. Deny yourself and you win. Yes, that's how it is! That's the essence of my discovery.
How banal! Even bordering on trite, don't you think?
Don't rush to conclusions. I'm on the verge of making my final discovery. In a nutshell, I feel I've been imbued with more meaning than is apparent to me.
There are no bachelors and no towns here, blind man! There's just you and I. And you are my future that I don't even want to happen. It's dull.
Too convoluted, Bachelor. You're that learned fool from vulgar comedies. Try repeating all of that in Latin; you might bring down the house. Goodbye.
It was for you. You think that because your nature is evil. It's only fitting that you should reject it.
You don't say!
I've always sensed it in you. At first I thought you were a demon, because you weren't like them, with a power of a different kind growling inside you—now I see why it seemed that way!
Isn't that also the essence of your supposed miracle? Assuming, of course, that Rubin described it to me accurately.
I can make any miracle happen, Bachelor. That is my essence.
No, Bachelor. It's not that. Goodbye.
You're possessed with pride.
Not at all. Actually I realize that you're closer to victory than me. See, I've had the humility to admit the greatness of your feat. After all, unlike me, you had no predisposition for it…
Not at all. I'm merely aware of my responsibility and have no intention of disowning my power. There's a greater pride in humility—haven't you ever heard that adage? Goodbye. You're getting nothing.
Ira furor brevis est.
Ignorantia non est argumentum.
Duo bus certantibus tertius gaudet.
Felix, qui potuti rerum cogoscere causas...
I understand now! It was she; she stole your soul from me! She's already visited you, didn't she? Didn't she?

Heads are going to fall like no tomorrow. I know how Inquisitors work. Karminsky is a real ghoul... and a shrewd one; there's no hiding anything from him. No. I'll try to forestall him. Perhaps... yes, perhaps it will even be a winning gambit!
Wait... What are you doing? Don't!
You want to try and hide from the all-seeing eye?
There's one place I can actually hide from him. I'll go to the Termitary. They're awaiting we there. The Mother Superior is stamping her little foot impatiently!
She'll... she'll have you killed!
I understand now... She's beaten me to it again. Always a step ahead of me!
I've been looking for my sister.
Not now.
You don't have to say anything.
Sore, oh how sore I am… My throat and my eyes are burning with sand, the ground underneath me is crumbling. ...I'd give anything for a drop of water.
What on earth could you offer in exchange? Don't come near me.
Why don't you get some yourself? You can find a bottle in any bin, and there's a water-barrel's just around the corner.

My ears are abuzz, I'm so short of breath. It's twyre that's sucking me dry. ...And who knows if the water in that barrel is fine to drink anyway? Terrible things are happening all around. Have you heard about last night?
No. What happened?
No, and I have no desire to. Be on your way, I don't want to talk to you.
They say last night Simon Kain died. Nobody knows how it happened, but the main suspect is Artemy Burakh. And he killed his father too.
The two of them—first the Haruspex, then the Bachelor—will drown the town in blood.
I don't believe it. The Warden is not a person to break the joint of time, he won't foul his hands with the blood of his kin. He has no reason to kill Simon, too.
So you're not allowed into shops? Or are you pressed for money?
Have you seen the prices? I cannot even buy an empty bottle, my dear. If this goes on, it won't matter how much we've stockpiled.
You are not the type to stockpile anything in advance anyway. Can you at all remember where you were yesterday and what you saw there?
You can drink from a spring.
You can get water from a spring and purchase a bottle in a shop.
Sorry, I have no water.

Oh, I wouldn't make it to a shop. Rumour has it they're full of sweet nothing anyway. Should've hoarded all I need in advance… Eh… had I known where I would fall I wouldn't have come to that place at all.
Which in your case means you don’t belong anywhere.
The town will have more stockpiles and hoards than people soon.
Hey, hey there... get your little hands away from me! You're clapping dish at the wrong man's door, I know your type!
The salvation of this town is in my hands. Be on your way, you poor soul. Perhaps you will be saved after all.
You think I'd waste my time on a petty nobody like you?
Can't you find a bottle in the street? As for water, you can get it over there, from a barrel.
Tumultuous and a-rumble is the town; and people wrap themselves to hide the face in dirty, ghastly rags. ...And you, girl, have you tried twyrine? They say it offers good disease protection.
Everyone will get infected sooner of later. Twyrine won't help you with this.
Every bullet finds its billet. How about we barter?
I've always said that shit tends to happen in the fall. A sordid time—and dirty, too. All muddy.
As for me, I like fall. The air is so transparent and everything's chiming and singing and glass-like.
Is summer better? It's not about the season.
What is there to complain about then?

There's not a single bite to eat. Folks are dying. Who could have thought it would turn out like this for Simon, eh? Eh heh heh… Everyone's reduced to a pulp, but here we go again. Shutting people in—is that their idea of how things are done? They're working men, you know, they're not cattle!
Is the Termitary still closed? What's it like in there?
It's painful to even think about.
Keep your problems to yourself, will you?
In all honesty, they don't look like men, even working class men. You at least are capable of human speech.

Hmm… Here I am, talking to you, and I'm starting to get shivers. What if you're the mara everyone's looking for? Look at you with your hands folded and all—what if you turn your head a bit and your face is all twigs? You don't care about people. You're full of spite. I, for one, am going to keep an eye on you so that you wouldn't follow me anywhere.

There's a community there, everybody knows that. So sometimes 'tis hard to make sense of them. Hopefully they won't start eating one another… 'cause there's not a crumb there otherwise. How long will they last? Their only hope's the Superior's daughter. They value her words, like, for real. Perhaps 'tis their salvation.
Say they unlock the Termitary. What if it's infected? That means hundreds of sick men crazed with pain will pour into the streets. A horrible thought!
Shut up!
Yes, everything's bad. And it keeps breaking. Will you fix it?
Why are you always groaning? Be on your way.
Fall is a very fitting season for everything that's happening here.
Keep clear of the marsh, it's putrid—just like the last time. I've told an outsider doc about a mate of mine already; a shabnak got him by the leg—and it snapped in half that instant.
I don't care about your friends. I'm in a hurry.
This time it will be more than just legs.
Thank you very much. I'll do my best to avoid it.
Yeah, sure. Fix this. And yeah, everything's sordid.
What else has happened, grampa?
It's bad enough without you groaning.

Tell me, dear, how is it that all the factory workers are supposed to get it all for free, but we didn’t get a thing? Are we not good enough? Are we second-rate people? 'Tis my firm belief that if everyone is supposed to get it, then everyone should!
What are you supposed to get? From where? Most importantly, what does it have to do with me? I'm not giving away anything.
What are you talking about?
I can't understand a thing you're saying.
Protective clothes, boots, and so on. Boots are essential. They say the disease comes from the ground, it's the shabnak rising. And it's true.
Sorry, I know nothing about it. But I don't think this kind of protection will help.
You are a bore.
Where is everybody? Both Dogheads and Soul-and-a-Halves were here just a sec ago. Did you scare them off? Hey, don't you come closer!
And hello to you too. So you are a tough guy, aren't you? Well, how's it going?
What are you talking about? There was no one around.
If everyone's run away, how about we barter?

Yesterday a shmowder cache was plundered, heard about that? And the formula's irretrievable! The only thing we can do is search for the ones that are still left. Geddit? Or maybe you were by the Mild Dew yesterday too?
I'd rather take a look at what you have. Perhaps it was you there yesterday, not me? Let's check!
Beware! You won't be able to get away from me next time.
What are you implying?
Someone wanted shmowders real bad. That means soon everybody will. That's what I think. Why would anyone need shmowders otherwise?
I don't understand you at all.
Aren't you a bit too young to become a prophet? Why are you so sure anyone would want your "shmowders"?
Shmowders can cure you for real! We've tested them ourselves, actually. And they worked! Yeah!
Where can one get hold of them now?
I don't need medicine or drugs to cure.

Lika the traitor's played a dirty trick on us all. He's likely to have one though. But the thieves and the Dogheads and the Soul-and-a-Halves—everyone's after him. They'll tear him to pieces—and good riddance, too!
I see that you are a bloodthirsty man.
Who knows—perhaps none of the three parties catches him.
I'll tear you to pieces if I get my hands on you! Just you wait!
So what about you? You're a brave guy, right? Or a mad one? Fill me in on the news.
It's no point going to the shops now. Yeah. We'd rather search the warehouses for food. Gotta do the job tonight. And don't you even think about telling on us, you hear me? Or else!
You shouldn't walk around the town at night. Anything can happen, you know.
The prices will fall when there's nobody around to eat.
Like I would waste my time on you. Get lost!
Do you have anything new? Shall we trade?
What's the news?
I have bartered a hook and three nuts today. The kiddos will be green with envy. Gave out three rifle rounds for them. Oh, if only I had a rifle! I'd so…
Not bad.
And what would you do?

They'd be afraid to even come close to me! I can do without a rifle too! But bare fists are not enough when it's one against four... And father says there are... mafrauders now burgling abandoned houses—but they can break into ours too. And so I'd go—bang! In your face! They'd never try it again!
Aren't you a hero. But my advice would be to avoid marauders. Even patrolmen can't always deal with them.
Run home, will you? What if "mafrauders" come and you're not there?
What's the news on the street? Seen anything worthwhile?

Rumour has it, everyone who fights or just hangs around at night is a bandit. And what are we supposed to do, huh? If anyone lays a finger on me or one of my lot, they'll pay for it—and to hell with the new rules!
Don't be so angry. Strength is not about fists.
When rage and fear fill the town, you will only find salvation within yourself. Let those who are dear to you into your soul.
But what about medicine? We've searched every nook and cranny for shmowders. I wanted to get one for Dina. Just in case…
Dinka will be fine. I know for sure. Everything will be fine, actually. You... You'd better take care of yourself...
Medicine is of no use. It just burns your entrails rather than save you.
How are you? What's up?
Clara, something's looking for you... or someone... Anyway, Sticky's been tracking it, but he failed. And he's very good at this. A creepy creature.
Do not worry about me. And thank you.
What does it look like?
I know. But who knows who is looking for whom and who finds whom first.
Like nothing I've ever seen! 'Cause I haven't seen it. 'Cause it was Sticky tracking it, not me, I'm telling you.
Why are you calling it creepy then? You haven't seen it!
It's for the better that you haven't seen it. You don't need to.
Well, you have come close to me already, so let's barter.
I suggest you follow their example.
What's news? Still up to no good?

You said you can heal with your hands. Is it for real? If one of my mates falls sick, will you help? Everyone's scared of you now, they say coming close to you is bad and dangerous and... Were you in the Cathedral yesterday?
What are you talking about? Don't parrot nonsense. You have come close to me, haven't you? So what?
So don't you come close! How's you blood, is it running cold already?
I was in the Cathedral. But that's not why they got infected. Do you believe me?
I believe it wasn't you. Capella says so too—and she knows stuff. Too bad the Cathedral was hosting the hospital. My ma was there, and now they say they won't let her out, and I'm not allowed in.
I'm very sorry. I wish I could help.
Any more news? Have you seen the creature that's been looking for me lately?
I don't have time to deal with your problems.

Sticky says it's made of clay and bones. He followed it, but it disappeared into the Steppe. Ask Grace. Also someone's buying all the vitamins from us—and it takes like a kilo of them to be of any use.
Into the Steppe, you say... All right. I'll check it out. Thank you!
I think I have an idea of who it might be.
How's it going? What's the news?

Do you think the Bachelor would give me a vaccine if I asked him, eh? He must have some. He used to test drugs in the Mouth and had some business with Rubin later. But we couldn't get a closer look back then.
Even if his vaccine saves you, it'll take your soul away.
They failed miserably. They have no idea what they're up against!
You'd better ask Rubin. He could help.
Yeah right, like I can ask him… He's a wanted man, thanks to the Kains—they're like mad dogs on the loose, they have all their men search for him. It's not like I'm a better searching party!
You are so in the loop it's uncanny.
Their vaccines are of no use anyway. You'll live longer without them.
Barter? That would help me a lot.
Got junk you don't need? Let's barter.
Well, you are the only fearless and smart person around. You'll just have to live with that.
I didn't see anyone.

If I bring nothing home today, my family will either starve or die from the disease. Could you help me in any way? Please spare some coins so that I could get medicine at least, please! I'll spread the word of your kindness.
Soon neither you nor your family will need medicine.
Take it then. I hope it helps.
I have nothing to give. I'm sorry.
How much is it?
A hundred. That's enough to get medicine.
Five hundred.
One thousand.
Two thousand.
Three thousand.
Four thousand. Take care, do not lose it.
You're not supposed to count gift money.
What's wrong with you?

My arms and legs won't work properly, I've got fiery circles before my eyes. I feel hot, as though something was burning me from inside. I met a big-city doctor recently, he told me to lie down. But who's going to feed my family then?
The Earth will eat all of you if you keep listening to him.
He is right, you should go home. I can't do anything for you now, and the streets will indeed do you no good.
It's all the same—you will all die. A day sooner or a day later, what does it matter?
I doubt you'll make it. Trouble has already come to live in your house.
I'll share what I can. But it will hardly help you, you look too bad. Well, at least you'll have a chance to save your family.
Aren't you a bit too picky?
Are you sick or something?
I have a fever, but it'll pass... The prices have risen tenfold. The water barrel by the Skinners got a leak… and the soil beneath it turned red. Nothing good will come of it.
How would you know what comes of what? Be off—who knows how much time you still have to stumble in my way.
Go home. Who knows how everything will turn out? We have to have faith while there still is at least a shred of hope left.
How are you feeling now?

I know I'm about to die. My bloodflow is slowing down, making the veins groan; my chest is on fire… We will all follow in the Ruler's footsteps. But even as we die, we won't be able to leave this place. We shall become the Sand Plague's body, its dead cells...
You're right. You are all too keen; and so your end is nigh.
Go home. Who knows how everything will turn out? We need to be patient—just a little longer.
My children, oh my poor little darlings… You make my heart bleed… What will become of you? Ah girl, you'll know what caring for your children is like when you grow up.
Please don't eat your heart out. What is to come, will come.
Could you mend my clothes please? See, it's all torn.
Stop moaning and get busy! I need some sewing up done.
Caring for them is nothing compared to being scared for them.
Your moaning will help neither them nor you.
There will come a day when both you and they will be no more.
I've got a loose stitch. Will you mend it please?
All things must pass. They just do. The only thing that matters is if they pass you by.
Why are you in so much pain?
What about you personally? How's it going?
Is it hard on you?
We are all mere orphans without Simon. We have neither a true Mistress, nor a Ruler in the town. After all, Katerina is not Victoria.
There are other forces that can save the town.
Ill words yield ill circumstances. You'll call trouble upon your head.
There's no point talking about it.
Simon's gone for good now. The body's gone. Or maybe he has simply gone somewhere on his own—people say all kinds of things… Perhaps the Immortal Man is still alive. He would have restored order.
"Order", pah. It's always about order with you.
I think even Simon would have been powerless to. And the most horrible is yet to come.

Couldn't be worse! Have you seen the prices? We've been told to burn everything, bury it, and wait for the fresh goods. They used the pest as a scarecrow, and now they're lining their pockets. What can we do? People are starving. Some of us can't trudge through a single day without food.

Everyone's staying in, too afraid to go outside. There are only couriers and patrolmen in the streets. And I hear someone crying constantly next door… It's all that big-city doctor, he brought it all on us. Why did he have to come? There's a quarantine now. And there won't be a train.
It's not just starvation. Twyre is in bloom and so the earth is spending its lifeforces elsewhere—instead of sharing with you.
I'm sorry. So, so sorry! If only I could save you all…
There's no point complaining. Just accept the upcoming suffering. No one is to blame for it.
You ain't seen nothing yet. Your current blights will pale in comparison with what is to come.
It's the souls of the people that the Earth wouldn't accept. You poor soul—if you hear them, you will have no peace at all soon.

Isn't he the one who is maintaining the order you care about so much? Weren't you talking about it before? He will do it with an iron fist. And he'll destroy anything that doesn't fit his idea of order.
You think the local quacks are better? The Bachelor will crush everything that doesn't fit his idea of order, true, but the Haruspex will cut anything that is not his kin.
Do you have a needle and a thread? Please mend my clothes, I'll pay you.
Hi there! Do you know how to play Reflections? You don't seem like an ordinary girl. I wonder what you'd look like coming out on the other side!
Trade? I'm sure I have something you might like.
Wanna barter? See what I've got.
Do you have anything of interest? Shall we barter? Do take a look, perhaps you'll find a use for this thingie of mine?
There is not a path in the world that would be unavailable to me. I shall penetrate the Polyhedron as well… in due time.
Hi! I remember you—I was just this high back then, and you were probably even smaller. Is something bothering you?
Just consider the thing standing before you a Reflection of mine. And I myself am already far, far away.
Do you? Sorry, I can't remember at all... Say, how does a House of the Living work? I think Lara wants to found one... If I don't end up there, does that mean I'm dead?
Go home! It's not safe outside.
No, it's vice versa; if you do end up there, you'll only get out feet first.
Why would you want to go to the House of the Living?
I don't. If anything happens, we will all hide in the Polyhedron. Khan says it's the safest place in the world. No adults allowed though.
Sounds like a good idea.
So how many of you are in there now?
A lot. Yesterday the father of one of our guys was killed by the Station, and now the lad won't say a word. Khan says he's better off in the Tower; it lets you see those who are already gone.
Kaspar thinks he knows something that others don't?
That poor fellow. Are you sure it wouldn't be better for him to go home? He has some family left, I hope?

Khan wouldn't just offer random advice—he means it. Plus the lad's family has enough mouths to feed as it is. Ah, I have to go get the groceries! Ugh, what am I supposed to tell Mom? The prices are rising by the hour!
People just got scared, is all. The freight train won't come, but, on the other hand, the population is diminishing, so it crosses out.
Trust me, if this town is to die at all—it is not to starve… not physically anyway.
Did you catch the Unseen cat?

Are you making fun of me? It's fine, no hard feelings. You do very well know that there is no Unseen cat. That said though, your eyes sure do remind me of it. Are you a Soul-and-a-Half? But you don't have a pet…
No, I only have one soul. I'm here to help.
It is beyond your abilities to comprehend me. We may very well meet again.
I invited the Bachelor to have a look at the Unseen cat, but I know he won't come. He doesn't seem to understand us at all. Is it true that he's very smart?
Intelligence is relative. Often the voice of reason tangles the ways of fate, whereas the heart always leads you down the right path.
That big-city doctor will do a lot of damage! He can't see past his nose without a microscope. You'd be better off not talking to him at all.
Are you looking for something?

Everyone's looking for shmowders. The lads found some in the Silly House, in the Crude Sprawl. But they're all "dead"—and now no one seems to remember the correct recipes… All of our stashes are empty—weird, isn't it?
Weird indeed. Why would anyone want those things? They do more harm than good anyway.
How is it possible that no one knows how to mix a proper shmowder anymore?

Crowfoot used to make good shmowders... but he's gotten rusty. I mean, we used to mix anything we could find. I never tried the results, but some of us did—and they kicked the bucket. My beau promised to get me one if I ever need it.
Do you really want to take this risk? It can be poisonous…
It's not medicine that cures, trust me.
Will you play with us?
I'm in a terrible hurry, dear. Next time perhaps.
Of course. What are you playing today?
How about we barter instead?
Not now, darling. But soon I will.
Honey, I want you to know... We won't be able to play for quite some time.
Have you forgotten? It's autumn! And autumn is Underground Bonfire time. Ha ha… And Uncle Bachelor tried to tell a lie. He said he used to play it too.

He never lies, sunshine. Maybe it was a joke. That is exactly what's so horrifying about him: he doesn't recognize anything but the truth. And everything that sounds even remotely false, he exterminates. But hey, why am I saying this? You're too young to understand.
Aren't you afraid to play such a game?
We'll play every game in the world very soon, you and I.
Don't talk to him. And don't listen to anything he says about me. You hear me? It's all lies.
So he won't be able to get into the Tower, right? What if he thinks that it's also a lie? I mean, he won't be able to see everything no matter how hard he tries, he's very much a grown-up already.
Hey, I underestimated you! No worries. I won't let anyone change anything around here. We'll play in the Polyhedron yet, I promise.
No, I'm brave! I fear nothing!
Yes, my love, you are the bravest. Now go and play. I have a lot on my plate right now.
What's that on your little palms? Have you been playing in the mud? Found anything interesting? Something that may be of use to me, perhaps?
Soon is a long time from now...
Who knows? Turn that frown upside down, sunshine.
Promise me you won't be wandering around here for a couple of days, okay? Or better yet, go to the Tower. If you don't listen to me, something bad might happen.
That's it, I don't have time for this. Off you go, buddy.
You can't play because of that monster chasing you, right? Is it true that it's a maneater who is looking to eat you?
Have you seen it as well?
Repeat after me: there are no maneaters! It's just spooky tales.
What did I just say? Off you go!
No, Sticky told me. What if it eats you? Will you then be stuck inside of it? Then we won't play for sure...
I'll eat him! And I'll have a bite of you too if you keep getting in my way!
Sticky! Well, if I find this boy…! And you—don't listen to idle nonsense... Do you really think there is a thing in the world that can eat me?
Don't come near me, sunshine. I'm not feeling too good. Go home.
No.
Come on, trade with your friend Clara... Look what I've got!
What's that in your eyes? Here, look at me...
You said you'd play with me yet. And they say you'll be caught tomorrow. Did you tell me a lie then?
What are talking about? If I hear that again, I'll grab you, cook you and give your legs to the odonghs!
I've never lied to you, have I? And that means everything's going to be fine. Stop whining.
Sorry, sweetie, next time.
Yeah, well... You don't really look like you want to play today.

They said the Inquisitor would arrive and everything would be in the right order again. But instead came this lady. A bad lady! Dad went out yesterday and never came back. Mom is crying, she says we are all going to die soon. What's it like, Clara? And when will Dad come back?
I'm sorry, darling, you won't see him for some time now.
You won't ever see him again. He's dead. And your mother is right, you will all be there one day.
I'll do my best to fix something at least, sweetie. The bad lady will pay for this. Now go back to your mom. I'll take care of you.
I know you. You're Clara. They also call you the Changeling.
Well, since we already know each other, how about we trade?
Time will tell, pumpkin.
Aren't they waiting for you at home?
I used to be allowed to play until late. We would all go to visit Grandpa. And now he's gone. They said it's for real. Gone completely! And there's nothing left, not even a smallest piece of him.
I have no idea why Simon was wasting his time on you. Didn't he have anything better to do?
It's all right. Soon you'll be old enough to play in the Tower. You'll have your own games then.
Tell me about the "Taglur".
Hi there! Are you all right?
It's a game about a circle! You join hands, and then again and again and again. Until the end.
End? What end?
Never thought it was a children's game.
Until the circle closes. That's the end of the game.
Why did you ask then? Or do you mean the other game? I can't talk about that.
All right, bye, pumpkin. Good luck with your circle.
All right, so long, pumpkin. Good luck with your circle.
Bad child! You're useless…
Don't bother me with your silliness.
General Ashes is coming tomorrow to grind us all to dust. That's what Daddy says.
As long as I'm here, everything will stay as it has always been, sunshine. Don't bother your pretty head with it.
Nonsense. Tell me something good for a change.
Well, it's good that we have the Bachelor. He's so scary he'll probably scare the general away!
Only to abuse you himself. Don't even think about trusting that mendacious demon.
You're right, pumpkin. Even the scariest man can serve a good cause...
Are you judging me? Or do you sympathize?
Neither. Why would you need my sympathy? Or do you have something to be judged for?
I simply don't have anything to say to you.
Aren't you cold? The weather is deceptive in fall.
If nothing makes you warm, then that means there's no warmth inside you.
It's all the same to me, be it sympathy or judgement. I can't even feel the cold.
I feel nothing. I'm empty inside, so what does it matter if it's hot or cold outside?
If nothing makes you warm, then that means there's no warmth inside you.
Whatever.
I know the dance. When I dance, I exist. I offer my juices to the earth, luring twyre out of it. But after that, when twyre blooms, I don't get drunk with the odour.
You do make me feel empty.
So it's you who we owe the twyre blooming to? I don't know if you are to be thanked.
Find your own way. Perhaps you'll find yourself before it all ends.
Whatever.
Can I be of assistance?
What could there be inside such a monstrosity? I find it unbelievable that it's still standing at all. I'd never let my children enter the damn thing. Ever.
You mean the Polyhedron? Why wouldn't you take the children's word for that? Are you so sure you're smarter than they are?
I don't think they're going to ask for your permission. You can't prohibit dreams.
That's where children's dreams live. Perhaps yours is among them as well. Did you dream when you were a child?
No wonder they call you deranged. What's next? Are you going to suggest we all fall on our knees and worship it or something?
This is pointless. I'm not going to waste time bashing my head against a brick wall.
You're right about one thing—soon you will all be doing what I suggest you do.
No, thank you.
Good morals and luck are a great help in managing a small community without resorting to violence. Personal standing can work wonders.
Excuse me. I'm in a hurry.
You should be listening more carefully. I like our town. We're all one big family. But sometimes I get the feeling that we're all controlled by an unseen power, our actions but fiction.
I don't think I can relate to that.
You're not far from the truth.
I'm surprised by how calm you are. Borderline smug.
The vaccine is a protective agent. It's a weakened specimen of the disease that our body can fight off. After you've suffered through the process, the body becomes resistant to it.
And what if it falls? The Tower with its fragile stem, all those unnatural structures? I'd rather the working districts were fenced off.
But why do people hoard vaccine ampulas then? Something's not right here.
We've only got experimental vaccine now. The body fights it for a while, but then it stops.
I've heard about it before, I think. So you believe in this panacea?

You see, my father used to deliver mail. It's a huge risk. His health is badly damaged by the abundance of various chemicals. He's coughing blood and has a constant headache… He's been bed-ridden for two days in a row. I'm so worried about him!
Hm. I see. So it provides permanent protection?
Yeah, sure, I really hope it helps you.
So a working vaccine is coming soon?
You're amazingly knowledgeable! Get lost, doll. You have no idea what you're talking about.
Salvation is not about vaccines.
Thanks. You're an invaluable source of information.
If you ever see the Bachelor, please kindly tell him it's rubbish. His facts and figures will save no one.
Forgive me, I did not know. I am truly sorry to hear that, but I still doubt the Bachelor's vaccine will help. It lacks a crucial component.
I am sorry...
Many more will pass away before the solution is found.
I think it is highly unlikely. But you're entitled to your opinion, of course.
Don't you like the Polyhedron?
No, of course I do! It's wonderful. But the more children gather there, the more anxious I feel. It's so shaky... And my girl is spending all her time there.
Do not worry, it is more stable than most buildings in this town.
Rubbish! Relocate to a different place then.
*** Maria will not get this necklace.

*** I don't like her behaviour in the slightest. It's as if she is hiding something. Is she disillusioned? Did someone scare her? What is on my dear mother's mind? I am going to have to talk to her later.
*** There. Not a sign of Andrey. Not a trace of the body either. I wonder what I should do now?
Runt
Lika
